I had the Chef's special for the night which was a meaty steak that was cooked to perfection with a side of crab.

We shared a bottle of the Cotex de Bourg, Roc de Cambes 2010 which was out of this world.

Service was outstanding and I highly recommend this place for a romantic date night!
author: Veronica A.

description:
I will say the food was a 4.5 but the service was a 1 so that is why my review is 3 stars.  I was meeting my friends there and I was a bit early.  The hostess' were very nice and asked if I wanted to be seated or just wait at the front.  I actually asked for the bathroom and one of the hostesses actually walked me over to it.  A nice touch.  I then waited at the front until my friends arrived.  When they arrived, we had to wait just a few minutes to be seated. We had a nice table by the kitchen so we could see what was going on over there.  The salami slicing machine was near us and it was interesting to watch.

Our waiter was just plain awful.  He would disappear for long periods of time.  It took him forever to take our food order after we ordered drinks.  We brought me a second glass of wine when I said no when he asked if I wanted another one.  It took forever to get our check.  It was as if he were not important enough for this waiter.  Sucked!!!

The bread guy brought around some bread, two different kinds.  Both were yummy.  The bread guy came around a 2nd time later and asked if we wanted more.  He was better than our actual waiter.  Two of us started with the red romaine salad.  The salad was a bit deconstructed when the mascarpone cheese smeared along the inside of the bowl and the lettuce leads laid out in a fan shape.  My friend though the portion was a bit small.  I liked it though and it seemed plenty big to me.  I loved the fresh nectarines in it.  My friend's mom had the Dungeness Crab & Melons appetizer.  She really liked it - good crab pieces in it.  We also did the chilled shrimp.  It was 5 big prawns with a very spicy cocktail sauce, almost two spicy.  

For entrees, my friend and I each had the sablefish.  It was very nicely cooked, very flaky.  I loved the lettuces and parmesan crisp that came with it.  My friend's mom had the cod. She really liked it.  It was also nicely cooked and flaky.

For desserts, my friend wanted the dessert off of the tasting menu she they let her order.  It was some sort of nectarine dish.  I had three flavors of sorbet.  All very tasty and dairy free!  my friend's mom had the pavlova which she really enjoyed.  

So overall the food was very good but also very expensive and the service was very bad.  This is a great location but I don't think I will be back.
author: Karen C.

description: We went to this place with about 8 colleagues and the service was terrible. The menu was very limited to fish, beef and duck.  The waiter act like he didn't want to be there or assist us. When asked if a steak could be prepared to our liking we were told no because it would destroy the integrity of the dish....really??? Apparently medium well for duck and steak means still very red and bloody. When we asked to   cook them longer the waiter rolled his eyes took it back and only blackened the outside of the meat.  Oh did I mention a couple of us had stomach  issues later after the meal?? There is something to be said about terrible service with a side e of upset stomach. This was  a horrible experience for us and I'm very disappointed  that the staff was allowed to treat us so poorly and a manager didn't bother to come over and make right.
author: Adrienne J.

description:
I went here for a large event, so I understand that doesn't reflect the restaurant as a whole. This is why I didn't give it a 1. 

However, I had the beef rib and my co-worker got ahi tuna. Mine was tough and his was so over cooked it was flakey. 

I'd never go there again and personally pay for this food.
author: Michael P.

description:
Superb service and good food. Some people may think the decor is a bit tacky, but I think it's more in the classic side (Esp with the color scheme, dome, and the jellyfish lamps).
The seafood is quite fresh. I am not usually crazy about oysters but they are very tasty especially paired with the sharpness of lime juice and their delicious cocktail sauce. 
The Ceviche was also delicious, made with real crab meat and squids. They have good cheese selections. Try the raw sheep milk cheese!
Putting the food aside, the service is what makes this place stand out. They are not imposing or overbearing, very well executed.
Do check them out, at least for the happy hour since they have really good happy hour deal. 

I didn't go to the restroom so I can't comment about that. The venue seems clean in general under the evening dimmed light.
author: Jenny T.

description: Wonderful happy hour, so great in fact, we skipped our regular reservation. $7 for 6 oysters? YES. The mignonette was delicious and the shuck was clean. Everything tasted good and fresh. We also ordered ceviche which had a little kick. The burgers were small but delicious. I had a manhattan and it kicked my butt! Older decor, kindof reminded me of the Cheesecake Factory, but overall yes a definite stop. We'll be back.
author: Guisela L.

description: I came here on a business trip and really enjoyed my meal of steak and shrimp. The beef was grass fed and fool of flavor. For years I would stay at the Pan Pacific and walk by this place.  They have chandeliers the look like jelly fish and carvings of mermaids. It had a very nice atmosphere and the service was great.  This will be a place I stop at for dinner whenever in SF.
author: Doug G.

description:
Farallon was the venue for a late Valentine's Day dinner. With a 9 p.m. reservation, we missed the dinner crowd. However, even with a reservation, we were asked to wait as our table wasn't yet ready. A hostess walked us to our seats, and we met our server for the evening. Our server greeted us warmly, welcoming us to the establishment. He explained the menu and the special Valentine's Day tasting menu. He stated we could swap out items on the menu in favor of creating our own tasting menu, but when we asked to substitute a similar-priced appetizer for another, as the entire table must order the tasting menu and we wanted to increase variety, the chef denied us this option, stating the low stock of main course ingredients as the reason. This didn't make sense to us, but my dining partner and I went with the flow. 

The dungeness crab and beets (on the regular menu, as well) was well-designed and executed, with succulent crab and crunchy beets to highlight this dish. 

The sablefish had the skin in-tact, blackened and crispened such that it complemented the white, flaky fish well. 

The clam chowder, however, lacked what makes clam chowder clam chowder: clam. and bacon. and oyster crackers. I had to ask for this to be delivered, as it was skipped, and when finally presented after the main course, it was explained the dish had to be hastily made, as they had run out of the original batch. My dining partner was looking forward to this dish, and was left sorely disappointed. I wish they had offered another soup in its stead. 

The beef rib was tender and juicy, and made for the heaviest of tasting menu components. We didn't leave the restaurant hungry, but we did leave disappointed. The greatest disappointment was the dessert, with the delivery of a sour sorbet in an overtly-sweet sugar-based meringue casing. Props for presentation, but zero credit for quality. Given that Farallon is known for their service, I felt intimidated to even point this out. When I did, one of the servers told our server and he came back with the same plate of half-eaten sour sorbet and explained nicely that he was also providing me a new scoop of sweet sorbet. This is where I cannot recommend Farallon. This is not how a fine dining restaurant should have handled this. This is where the server or the host should have offered a replacement. Especially when taking my plate, one server noted, almost in solidarity with me, "TOO MUCH SUGAR, I KNOW." 

Overall, I would recommend following Yelper Jessie L's instructions and come here solely for the oysters and sliders during HH. I cannot bring myself to recommend this restaurant for a full meal, having had a sub-par dining experience on a special occasion.
author: Jen B.

description:
Unfortunately, our dinner was pretty disappointing.  Our server was lovely and trying really hard, but it just didn't seem like the back of the house (or bar) could figure it out. 

There were two times during our dinner where we didn't have drinks we ordered (I didn't get to drink my final glass of wine because it arrived AFTER we were totally done with our dinner and my husband had finished his wine).

We got the picked crab to start - which was fine.  

We then got two scallop appetizers (they only come with one scallop so our server recommended we get two).  
I LOVE scallops.  This was the strangest scallop dish I have ever tasted.  My scallop was cooked just fine but my husband's was rubbery (and not seared on top) but the strange thing was that there was a super sweet corn/popcorn/blueberry mush around it that did nothing to compliment the scallop (only overwhelmed it).  It did look pretty though.

We ordered the filet to share and this was fantastic, but we sat for at least 30 minutes waiting for it (and we ordered all of our food at once). 

The restaurant didn't seem that full though?  All the servers seemed like they were trying really hard to accommodate for the slowness in the kitchen and bar but for a dinner as pricy as this was ($300 for two), I expected much much more.
author: r t.

description:
Me and wife decided to take the Bart down to SF To basically get dinner and to be more specific sea food. 

Of course once we got out of the mall mayhem and made it to the street I used Yelp to guide me. 

I just want to repeatedly write: best lobster ever but I'll be a little more detailed than that......

To start the bread was fantastic. It came out with butter that had Hawaiian sea salt on it. Mixing the 2 was some of the best bread+butter combo I've had in a while. 

The desert was also awesome. I landed on the blueberry cake and I'm glad I did. It was the perfect way to end the meal.

Now to dinner. I got the surf and surf. Crab plus lobster. The crab was great but the lobster was phenomenal. 

Get the lobster. Best I've ever had. Seriously best I've ever had. 

For great seafood don't complain about the price!
author: Joe B.

description:
Food was over the top. Service presented by David even better. Filet was excellent 

What a very hip place to dine.
author: Lucy M.

description: So we were visiting San Francisco with another couple and we have been there many times but always try to find a new spot when we are there.  We searched Yelp and found this place and it did not disappoint.  The vibe was very cool when we walked in with huge glass jellyfish hanging from the ceiling.  It was clean and the service was great.  My wife had the scallops and I had the filet.  Both were absolutely delicious and cooked to perfection.  I had to control myself not to lick the plate!   We will definitely be back!
author: Tim O.

description:
Pretty darn near perfect service, food, and atmosphere.

Farallon says that it's celebrating its 20th anniversary, and it's been almost that long since we've been there. My husband does not love seafood, and the couple dinners we had there when it opened just weren't special enough for me to overcome his lack of enthusiasm.  But, after this month's trip, Farallon is back on our fancy restaurant list.

The seafood choices and preparation were outstanding. He actually liked and told others about the halibut tartare, and I was in bliss with fresh shrimp cocktail starter and a main course of seafood & baratta accompanied by an order of crab chowder. That was plenty of food, and the birthday dessert ice cream sandwich didn't weigh me down too much.  

Each dish had an uncommon and appealing taste. Preparation and presentation were top notch, too.

We especially appreciated the customized service we received. Many of the other diners were obviously tourists and had Things to Do. We didn't. Chase, our server, adjusted the pace of the courses and food delivery to the retarded slowness we requested. We were allowed to linger without being molested by helpful table clearers or intrusive questions if we wanted more of this or that.

The space is interesting without being weird. The acoustics mute most stray sounds and the tables are just far enough so you feel some privacy. 

This 20-year old has improved with age. I'd especially recommend it for fish-loving visitors looking for a high end meal.
author: Galen W.

description:
This'll be short and sweet. I'm a vegetarian, but I love fine wine, and great servers and sommeliers. 

You can read a fraction of the other reviews and easily confirm the quality of the servers and service. 

The wine list is a Northern California dream! Last night the Pinot wine flights were stellar, and at $70 for both, it was much less inexpensive than a bottle of fine wine, plus it was much more fun and satisfying. 

One of the wines tasted a little off, and I asked of the sommelier if he could confirm (if it was corked or not). Poof, back came a new glass from a freshly opened bottle.   Our new fave California Pinot!

Beautiful tables, decor, service, and with no trouble they made me a unique vegetarian entree. Their Brussels sprouts are from God! Charred on the outside, oiled and grilled on the inside. 

$200 for both of us; entrees, wine flight and dessert. Well worth it!
author: David S.

description:
I don't see how this restaurant is going to survive any longer.  Perhaps this place was in its prime 10-15 years ago, but I've now dined here on multiple occasions and it's simply disappointing.  The ambiance is great, service is good, but the food is below average.  On top of that, it's extremely expensive.  I am not sure how this place will survive in San Francisco with so many good restaurants here by serving expensive, mediocre food.  

I had the amberjack, and it basically was raw and disgusting.  I also had the dorade, which was burnt to a black piece of charcoal on the outside and over-salted on the inside.  The amberjack was $36 and the dorade was $45.  Total rip-off on top of not being tasty. One of my dining companions had the filet for $49. It was okay, but certainly not better than an average piece of steak. For $49, it should be a really good to excellent piece of steak.  

I have dined here a year ago, and I felt the same way.  The food is mediocre.  It's unfortunate because San Francisco does not have a great fine dining seafood place, and Farallon could potentially be that place.  However, I find Waterbar much better. In fact, the seafood I have had at Sutro's Cliff house (yes, Sutro's Cliff House by the ocean) is better than the seafood I have had a Farallon.  Farallon has so much potential, but it really falls short of being the "star" seafood place in San Francisco. Instead, it is simply mediocre or below, and I will not dine here again.
author: Gunnar F.

description:
This is an expensive place, let's just get that on the table up front. It's easy to spend $175 for 2 people after tip. 

The food is well prepared and the menu changes regularly so what you might read about in a review below is likely no longer available.

The waiter we had was awesome. He asked if we had any particular time constraints up front and after he found out that one of us had a tickets to the basketball game, he made sure to be right on top of getting us our appetizer an entree ASAP. We sat down at 5:30 and we were probably out on the street by 6:15. Not rushed, but definitely expedited. Gotta give him credit for making things happen quickly.

He described each item on the menu in excruciating detail which was nice. 

The portions are somewhat small so you'll at least need an appetizer plus an entree or a 'small' plus an entree in order to leave feeling satisfied. The two of them together will run $50 so add on a drink and you're quickly at $75 per person before tip.

The atmosphere is basically a 'date' atmosphere. Upholstered chairs and low lighting.
author: D E.

description:
Knocked off a star since we didn't get to sit in the main maritime-themed dining room.  It was kinda the whole reason I wanted to eat here.  sigh.  Instead we were seated in a section close to it.  It's like going to a concert and paying the same ticket price as everyone else, but getting stuck in the nose-bleed section of the theater - so you're not quite getting the same experience, BUT still paying the same price as everyone else. 

I remember first hearing about Farallon as a child while reading the classic Farallon cookbook (yeah, even back then I was a food-obsessed kid). 

Like a lot of classic restaurants, Farallon feels a little dated.  The seafood-theme verges on being a little cheesy with the jellyfish chandelieres and seashell columns; however, the service is top notch.  The prices are definitely modern day prices.  We left here with a $300 bill for two people.  Definitely keep an eye on the entree prices. 

For appetizers:
gnocchi and oysters with spicy nduja sausage - found the spiciness of the sausage to be a little too strong in contrast to the delicate oysters

Caucus Abalone -  served on garlic bread which I think was supposed to be eaten like a crostini.  Not sure that was the best way to serve the abalone. 

For entrees - Sablefish from the Farallons- AMAZING!  This is definitely THE dish to get here. I don't really branch out when it comes to fish, but the sablefish was buttery and not fishy at all.  Great flavor. 

Quail & Sonoma Foie Gras - should have stuck to seafood.  This dish was just ok.  Didn't really feel the qual and foie gras meshed too well together.  Also one of the more expensive dishes. 

Sides:
Spaghetti Squash Carbonara - probably one of my favorite dishes.  It comes with a fried egg on top that you mix with the spaghetti squash and bacon.  So good! 

Bottarga French Fries - great as an appetizer. Loved the bottarga aioli. 

Brussel sprouts - decent veggie side. nothing special. 

Try at least once and make sure you specify you want the main dining room and will wait for it!
author: Hieu H.

description: Awesome grand platter for my bday. Corked a nice bottle of grgich. Ordered the crab and prawn cocktail also. Nice dining room an old school mosaic all over the ceiling. Grand platter was nice the lobster claw was crack. Ask for some drawn butter on the side. Oysters were fresh and delicious with the champagne vinaigrette. Cracked crab for days. Had the mint chocolate profiteroles for dessert. Great service and ambiance.
author: Matt C.

description:
My husband and I planned a weekend getaway in San Francisco and really wanted to go out to a really nice place with excellent food.  We researched for a few weeks.  Originally we had reservation's at Gary Danko (should have kept them), but due to being short on time (went to a concert after) we cancelled and made reservation's at Farallon.  We were staying at the Kensington Hotel, which literally has a private door from the hotel to the restaurant.  I did a lot of research on Farallon before as I wanted to make sure we were going to have a great "culinary experience."  

We arrived about 15 minutes early and sat at the bar.  The bar is fairly small, especially when they open up the bar area an hour prior to the dinning area.  You would think there would be more seating available.  The bartender's were very nice.  We ordered an oyster platter, caviar and champagne.  Oyster's were good, small but good.  We got caviar as well.  My husband has had it before but I have not.  It was good but but over powered by the potato chips they served it with.  I also thought it would have been nice if the bartender/waiter could have provided us with some knowledge about the caviar we ordered, especially them knowing it was my first time. 

The champagne was delicious!! So I looked it up online as I wanted to go out and by some in the near future.  Well.... I was disappointed when I saw the price!  What I paid for each glass (two) is how much a whole bottle would be.  This unfortunately made me skeptical for the rest of the meal as it happened again.  

Our reservation was at 5:30 at about 5:50 the hostess finally came up to us and seated us.  I we were then a bit disappointed as I saw other people drinks carried to their table for them and ours wasn't.  Call it snobby but we are paying the same as everyone else and would like the same experience as them.  Especially since I was having to carry my belongings and now my drink.  

For dinner we had a delicious mixed green salad with figs and goat cheese.  Delicious... probably best part of our dinner.  The bread, which I was warned about, was not good at all.  It was not fresh and it was actually cold.  As we were looking over the wine menu, a gentlemen walked over and began talking about their wine selection.  I told him we wanted to get a bottle of white wine preferably from Spain.  He was able to talk us into another bottle from Italy.  The way he described the wine seemed to pair well with out plates (plus it was within our price range of how much I wanted to spend on a bottle of wine).  NEXT PART REALLY DISAPPOINTED ME.  He came up shortly after we decided on a bottle and stated he was going to bring us a different wine and to not worry it was within our price range.  This was a first.  We didn't know what to say.  We were confused.  We weren't sure; if he ran out of that wine, assumed we wouldn't know any better or if he truly wanted us to get a good bottle of wine.  

Well... I again researched the wine after he brought it to our table.  I paid $55 for a bottle, when I could have purchased it for $22 at Target.  As for the wine it smelled very fruity but the flavors did not match up.  I felt as if he took advantage and didn't want to spoil a good bottle on us.    

For our dinner plates.  I ordered scallops with risotto and my husband the sea bass.  I ALWAYS finish especially if it's a small portion like this was, but this plate I did not.  The scallops were under seasoned and the risotto tasted like canned corn and rice.  My husband's was over powered by what seemed to be canned beans that the sea bass sat on.  

For dessert we ordered the peaches and cream.  Nothing spectacular what so ever.  The vanilla chiffon tasted like they made it the day prior.  As we were paying our bill they brought out small pieces of chocolate with sea salt on top.  That was probably the the best tasting thing out of our entire experience there.  We were so disappointed that I actually had to write a review on this place.
author: M E.

description: The osters in here is the best oster in the world.cant say by words. You guys have to get it.
author: Nhi N.

description: Great seafood w good service provided. Nice ambience. We ordered crab and squid as starter, duck chest, scallop and one fish(forgot the name) as main dish, and 1 small dish of fresh Oysters. all are extremely fresh, not salty, impressively delicious:)
author: Lorna L.

description: Definitely a bit overpriced, first time ever had smoked mussels, that were terrific. But overall the meal was average.
author: Mike B.

description: This place is incredibly beautiful! This was one of my favorite dining experiences ever. Delicious sea food. Great options. Would love to go again!
author: Evie E.

description:
This restaurant is beautiful! The front room has Goliath jelly fish hanging from the sealing, while the back has chandeliers fashioned into sea urchins. 
The servers are very knowledgable and attentive. They can speak to each item on the menu, what wines it pairs well with and even what you can finish off with for dessert.
My colleagues and I had an assortment of oysters to start our meal. All the varieties were delicious and recommended by our waiter. We followed up with the tuna tar tar which was to die for and then each had our own dish which ranged from their incredible steaks to succulent salmon. 
We couldn't leave without having a little something sweet to end our night so we shared the assorted gelato plate and a perfectly textured, not overly sweet flan. 
Definitely a place worth a date night.
author: Sarah E.

description: This was my second time at Farallon & my first time was a few years ago, celebrating an occasion. I was afraid I'd be disappointed returning. If anything, the experience was even more stellar. We were a party of two, seated in the back in a romantic booth. Our server nailed it! She was friendly, knowledgeable & professional (wish I could recall her name). I had the scallops, started with a house special G & T (very pretty, light on the gin). My husband had the swordfish & said it was probably the best he'd ever had. We shared the chocolate dessert with chai. Everything about this restaurant is special; the decor, the aromas, the service & mostly the delicious & skillfully prepared food. I'm delighted to recommend Farallon to my foodie friends when in SF.
author: Heather ..

description:
As a surprise for my boyfriend's birthday, I brought him here. We Barted into the City, and once I lead him to the entrance of the restaurant, and announced, "Here we are!" he exclaimed, "Woah! Hey, there's jellyfishes!!!"

Flashback to the prior evening, when another restaurant I had booked had to cancel my reservation due to the weather, forcing them to close the restaurant for safety and repairs on a short notice. Oh well, Farallon was another dressy restaurant I had been eyeing. I made a reservation through OpenTable, and also gave them a call to ask questions. I believe the gentleman I spoke to was named Alex. He was very nice! I told him it was my boyfriend's birthday, and I wanted to know what the seating was like in the restaurant. He asked me if we preferred to sit across from each other (table option) or next to each other (a booth option). I instantly chose the booth option. As for locations within the restaurant, there's an upstairs and a downstairs. I chose him to pick a booth in an area that would be the most romantic. I also asked if "Happy Birthday" would be written on his dessert, and he said yes, that it would be written upon the dessert of his choice.

The next day, it was Monday. As we Barted into San Francisco, we were running late for our 6:30 reservation. I called the restaurant, and asked them if it was possible to push our reservation to 7:00. It was no problem.

Once we got into the restaurant and claimed my reservation, the ladies at the front asked if we needed to check in any coats or belongings. That was nice of them to ask, but I said no, and instead asked where the bathroom was. It's right on the first floor, by the stairs, and before entering the dining area. It was a very clean, though kind of small bathroom with a few stalls, but it's well-lit. And emphasis on cleanliness; ladies, I'm sure we all know the feeling of going to a restaurant and going to the bathroom to switch out of our street shoes into our heels. 

The entrance and the restaurant decor, by the way, is wonderful. Once you step in, you instantly notice the jellyfish chandeliers hanging above. They're beautiful and unique. We were lead to our booth in the main dining hall, which is dimly lit, and has tentacle chandeliers (my boyfriend thinks they're coral, I think they're tentacles). As a pleasant surprise, a happy birthday card in an envelope was sitting atop our table, waiting for us.

We were instantly served water upon request. For drinks, my boyfriend ordered the Rose of Cinsault, and I ordered the Sake (I was intrigued by the name Bride of the Fox). His Rose was very refreshing and not overly bubbly, like some Roses that I've tried. My Sake was sweet, but not too sweet.

After ordering, we were each given a small plate of bread. There were two types of bread: one was a piece of a croissant, the other seemed to be walnut bread. The butter was sprinkled with Hawaiian salt. My boyfriend and I dislike butter on its own, but with the Hawaiian salt, the flavor was wonderful. I didn't know it was Hawaiian salt until I read another review.

For appetizers, we ordered oysters. We ordered two of each: Drake's Bay, Kumamoto, and Kusshi. I'm not an oyster connoisseur, so I can't comment on the subtle flavors and textures, but we both enjoyed them very much.

For entrees, he ordered Local Sablefish, and I ordered Reichardt Farm Duck Breast. We also shared our entrees. The sablefish was delicious, and the crunchy, crispy skin was the best part. The mashed potatoes (yukon gold potato puree) were creamy, the smoked mussels were delicious, and the lollipop kale was the best kale I've ever eaten. I think the sauce from the potatoes was what made the kale so delightful.

The duck breast was divine. I'm used to Peking duck, and the slices of duck were very tender and delightful. I guess the sauce was Cinderella pumpkin? 

For dessert, he chose Vanilla Bean Cheesecake, and I chose the Pumpkin Spice Sundae. His dessert came with "Happy Birthday" written in chocolate, and a lit candle. We also shared our desserts, and enjoyed it all very much.

When the bill came, it came out to $165.01. Not bad! Especially since other reviews said to expect to spend over $200 for a party of two. Food is definitely pricey, but that's to be expected for a high-end dressy restaurant.

I'm impressed with how we were treated as well. My boyfriend and I were the youngest ones in the restaurant, but the waitstaff treated us with respect as they would with any other older diners. I've experienced service elsewhere that treated younger individuals more rudely, so I was impressed with the professionalism here. They refilled our water glasses, they checked in on us without being invasive, they brought out our food and drinks in a timely fashion, and were kind to take photos of us on our phones upon request.

We both want to come back, especially for the oyster happy hour!
author: Jo W.

description: The interior and decor of this place is anything but magnificent. Ideal for a romantic date or dinner. Dinner menu is small and not exorbitantly expensive. Taste is great. But like most expensive restaurants, portions are small so be prepared to spend some money if you come here.
author: Anuran C.

description:
Weird,standoffish, crappy service. My dirty Ketel one martini was literally just roomtemp vodka with an olive in it. My mom's cosmo was so sweet she almost couldn't drink it. We would have complained and asked for new drinks, but our server disappeared until after our food arrived.
We had the pork and the sablefish, both had really nice flavors but were so salty it was hard to eat. Plus, what could have been beautiful crispy skin on the sablefish was rubbery and soggy.

Beautiful restaurant with expensive, bad food. Inattentive service. Worst martini ever made.

What a shame
author: Devon D.

description: I hate leaving reviews like this.  The menu was very short and expensive, which I wouldn't have minded if the food was exceptional.  Alas, it was not. Our bartender was sweet, but she couldn't make up for the fact that the caviar blini's we like fat, wheat puffy pancakes.  The caviar was little to none and the three fat blinis sat in a bowl of butter. Total waste of my per diem.  There are too many great restaurants in San Francisco to spend an evening in a subpar spot.
author: Lisa B.

description:
It seems like nearly everyone I spoke to at the conference I attended this week ate here. My experience was slightly different as I was part of a group in a private room and limited menu but I really enjoyed the meal. I ordered the fish, which was tasty. I also sampled the steak but didn't think it was anything special. Service was very attentive- they filled our wine glasses like water, literally, if I had a quarter glass of wine left they would top it off. 
My meal was good and I enjoyed my experience here.
author: Christine H.

description: Great place especially for happy hour! $7 for half dozen oysters, I'm not a big fan of oysters but my boyfriend loved them!
author: Olivia R.

description: I rarely give a restaurant 5 stars. The food, the service, the ambience, the building decor, EVERYTHING was absolutely wonderful. I had the sea bass with smoke mussels and garbanzo beans and arugula. What a wonderful combination.  Excellent choice of wines and liquor.  Wow!
author: Edwin S.

description: talk about a surprise!  I made a reservation for a large group of people and it was a wonderful experience!  Our waiter Steve was right on point with the suggestions, he's manner was excellent, and he's service made us feel like kings!  The decor of the restaurant was unique and fun but with elegance.  At the end of the night, I got another surprise.  Ended up Farallon is one of the Michelin recommended restaurant in SF and I can see why.  Thumbs up all the way to all the staff members at Farallon!
author: Anthony L.

description:
An Amazing Meal.
Since I was by my onesie, I sat at the bar and had a great time-good conversation with the bartenders, and fellow diners.
The freakin' mixed green salad was spectacular. Every bite was scrumptious. A salad that made me stop and savor. Wow.

Then I had the Grilled Swordfish. OMG. Literally a party in my mouth. Prepared perfectly, the sauce was divine, the cellophane noodles were a slick compliment. Add a bottle of Cloudy Bay Sauvignon Blanc and I was in heaven.
author: G G.

description:
My all time favorite restaurant is Farallon. I highly recommend. We have been coming to Farallon restaurant since it opened in 1997. Yes that's right .... a really long time but never disappoint us. My husband and I don't have dinner at Farallon 
as often as previous years but now we try to make it at least once a year for my birthday weekend. This place is great not just the food but the decor is breath taking. They have a pretty awesome extensive wine list. We had our dinner paired with wine. Dinner was amazing last night! No complaints here. 
The staff is wonderful and as always we were greeted immediately. Thanks to all the staff and a special thanks to the awesome Executive Chef Ryan Simas for always taking care of us and making my birthday celebration another awesome experience.  Farallon restaurant is great for any special occasion or simply just enjoying an excellent meal.
author: Glenda C.

description:
Although I did pick this restaurant to dine with my colleagues I was expecting something cheesy and generic.. I picked this restaurant out of convenience as it was close to my hotel..BUT...to my surprise this is restaurant is actually pretty good!

I think we were the only asians in the restaurant and probably the youngest too, not that it's a bad thing or good thing but just a general observation. Noticed that the average crowd were in their 50s and it seems most of them were celebrating something special that evening as most of them were couples.

It looks like a very themed restaurant as it should be since they specialize in Seafood and it's actually not cheesy at all, to a certain extent I think it's pretty cool.

Now back to food..the food was good and exceeded my expectations for sure. It's not like they invented any super unique dish or flavor but they did everything properly and the results were great food and great flavor. I'll let the pictures do the talking.

Oh right, oysters are a must order and I suggest trying different ones. I ordered the platter with lobster and all but I think the next time I visit I'll just use the money and order 2-3dozens of oysters.
author: Jive O.

description:
True confessions: I came here for the decor. I'm a marine biologist, and just needed to see this magical place I had heard of. I wasn't disappointed. Kelp, jellies, feather duster worms, urchins, sea stars, molluscs! It was stunning and beautiful. 

Being a marine biologist, I am also.....nowhere near rich enough to actually eat here. However, they have happy hour every day from 4:30-6! We got a dozen oysters for $14. I mean, you can't beat that! I would definitely give five stars for the decor, ambiance, and happy hour. The cocktail was not great though, and for a place of this expense and caliber I would expect a really good cocktail. I suggest sticking to the wine.
author: Kari E.

description: Great hh menu. Really enjoyed their seafood selection. Convenient location too! Right next to Union Square :)
author: Vicky T.

description:
I found the manager to be lacking in social graces and the host at the front desk incredibly rude. When I asked for a table I was told I would need to wait an hour and twenty minutes as they were all filled up for the night. I was directed to eat at the loud bar. I sat down and booked a reservation online using OpenTable. I found a reservation open 15 mins later. The host didn't believe me and was very rude about the entire thing. I alerted the manager who could careless and likely rewards the man for his rude behavior. It was as if they wanted to create an exclusive feel to the place. 
The food was nothing special either. I ordered the Dungeness crab (which was over priced and not worth it at all)  which was burned and overcooked. It tasted awful. My wife had a great meal and really enjoyed her food. I was happy about that. 
Dessert was weird at best. It looked great but tasted odd. It was some sort of marshmallow pop-rock walnut thing that the server recommended. It was not worth it...
I would not waste my hard earned money here again.
author: Josh L.

description:
Farallon may possibly have the worst valet service I've experienced. One valet guy and many hangry customers with their double-parked along Post St, just one block away from the busy Union Square, calls for a disaster. Already running late for a holiday dinner in December of last year, we saved ourselves the trouble and parked in the public parking lot below Union Square. But aside from that issue which initially ruined the night, my dining experience at Farallon was quite pleasant.

The holiday party was held in the Beluga Room, which was spacious enough for a party of ~70 people plus a DJ station. The undersea themed room was fitting for Farallon, with walls painted with all imaginable sea creatures and their famous jellyfish lamps immediately outside the room.

Private functions held in Farallon's private dining rooms have a set menu. We had two options to choose from for first course, entree, and dessert. As Farallon's specialty is seafood, I stuck with the fish options. 

Hawaiian kona kampachi with radish, arugula, and almonds (first course) -- The fish was delicious, light and fresh with a peppered crust, but the arugula was overpoweringly bitter and I wasn't too fond of radish flavor either. 

Cast iron roasted sea bass with potato purée, pancetta, and pomegranate reduction (entree) -- The sea bass was very moist and well-seasoned, and the skin delicious and crunchy. The potato puree was very smooth and creamy, and the pomegranate reduction added a bit of sweet and tart notes to the dish. I was very pleased with this dish and highly recommend it.

Marzipan galette with pear sorbet, almond brittle, and pomegranate (dessert) -- This was very light and enjoyable. The pear flavor was distinct and refreshing in the sorbet. The galette was flaky and the pear butter marzipan filling was good, yet not too overpowering with almond.

Overall, the dinner service was good and well-timed in between the courses, and the open bar staff and waiters were friendly. The food was delicious, but overpriced. But you dine at Farallon for the undersea decor anyway. Just take into account the traffic time if driving here, especially on the weekend.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Superb! finally came back for 2nd round of yumminess seafood. First time was way back in 2011. Great service, still in awe with the jellyfish on the ceiling. Scrumptious seafood bar...it's amazing watching the chefs pile up clams, mussels, oysters, crab and giant lobsters onto huge plates. Mouth watering just thinking about it!! Sat in the big room, small table. Ordered bottle of Stony Hill Gewurztraminer and a second...goes great with seafood. Hamachi crudo, fresh oysters(miyagi and drakes), clams(not as big and tasty as ones from anchor and hope, but still decent), foie gras, bone marrow, scallops as my entree. Buuuurp! Super good! Great way to celebrate an anniversary =D
author: Vee V.

description: Food is good: seafood is fresh and cheese cake is not too sweet. Service is good: quick seating and serving of food. The only reason I am giving 4 stars instead of 5 is because the setting is a bit dated.
author: Ginger Y.

description: Farrallon is one of those places that one returns to ever year or so.  The place is always busy so be sure to make reservations.  The food is your usual affair for a trendy, touristy SF restaurant, nothing great but nothing horrible either.  Prices are right up there with most touristy SF restaurants but I guess it's ok if you know what you're getting into.
author: Alex N.

description: My husband and I love it here food is very tasty service is fast and courteous , glad we gave it a try we will be coming more often now
author: Abigail B.

description: Basic go to for their happy hour.  Not the best wine selection but the oysters and ceviche make up for it.  Surly bartender so try not to sit at the bar unless you are happy and just don't care.
author: S K.

description:
I was so looking forward to trying Farallon after reading all of the reviews. I enjoyed it, but it  fell short of my expectations. The food was good, but not spectacular (aside from my osyers.) My mom and I both ordered the grouper and both agreed it wasn't anything to brag about. However, my husband pretty much creamed his jeans over the chioppino, so that's good! I felt like I had to gnaw on my hard, crusty bread like a neanderthal. 

The atmosphere has a classy, cozy feel. The service was excellent at the beginning of the meal, but we were neglected more and more as time went on. The "health care mandate" in SF is absolute nonsense and I believe their prices were a little high for what we got.
author: Jenna H.

description:
I had the best burger ever! Happy hour is 7.00$
Unbeatable.... twice, the best
Third time, not a charm
Missed happy hour, 15$ with French fries. Hard to beat, BUT, they changed everything except the meat. My mouth was burning from the oversalted and peppered fries, the bun was a very salt embedded looser. On top of all that, they were out of Pinot Gris. !!!!
VERY disappointing . My bill came to what it would cost for TWO at happy hour
(SP!) farallon on post
author: marcia p.

description:
Finally, the BF made a decision for dinner that didn't suck!

Arrived a few minutes early and was seated promptly at 8:15 (our reservation time). The only issue I had was that we had to wait an unusually long time for our server to arrive to take our orders and to bring us our food. We watched the table next to us (who arrived at the same time) get halfway through their meal when our mains arrived. 

The interior is beautiful with nautical themed mosaic designs that were tastefully weathered-looking, and the booths and chairs had a lovely rounded look to match the porthole decor on the walls. Lovely jellyfish chandeliers by the front. 

Every time I go to a nice seafood restaurant with the BF, he ends up ordering the dish I want and since I want to sample the variety of entrees the restaurant orders, I usually go with my second choice. BF chose the sablefish, and I went with the albacore tuna. Hollandaise was a bit of an odd pairing with the tuna since it was super heavy and rich. The sablefish on the other hand - perfection. 

Desserts were all at $11 and were neatly and artistically plated. The Nutella bar got a bit too chocolatey in the end when we ran out of ice cream to eat it with, but if you're into that kinda thing, definitely go for that. 

Might come back solo for the sablefish.
author: Ann Y.

description: The interior decor is like an outdated seafood restaurant in Disney. I expected animatronic mermaids and grouper to jump out any minute and start singing a Sponge Bob Square Pants tune. The food is that frozen puff pastry kind of good like we were in a tourist restaurant in Florida where key lime pie and Skully's catch of the day were the hot dishes, and uncultured locals run around wearing flip flops and chomping on chewing tobacco. Just wondering if the kitchen staff are dressed up like fish or pirates. Maybe the chef wears a clown fish costume and the pastry chef looks like a angler fish, the dishwasher might dress up like a one eyed pirate with a plastic parrot on his shoulder.
author: Gamera B.

description: Every aspect of this restaurant is SUPERB, except the wait staff. If you want to feel shamed, and be waited on by staff who feels entitled, then have at it. Are they union? It's really too bad that they can't get in servers who deserve to work there.
author: Natalie M.

description: Wonderful ambiance, great service and good food.   I will be back.   One of my all time favorite restaurants.
author: Kathy P.

description: Beautiful place! It's like an underwater fairytale come true! The food, service and atmosphere are beyond compare!
author: Gaby M.

description:
Pros: Restaurant was beautiful and the host was very nice.

Cons: Food is overpriced and not good. We had a horrible waiter that made us feel rushed throughout our dinner even though the restaurant was empty. We asked questions about the menu, such as how a crab was cooked and served and he's just reread to us the title of the dish with a smug attitude. Like duh, we can read that but we were wondering if the shell will be on it still or not. He was the asian one with blonde or gold hair. He ruined my experience there and I will NEVER come back.
author: Diana S.

description: I would give a 5 if my seafood wasn't slightly over cooked . I know nick picking but if that's your game it should be spot on always. Love bar, oysters, service and staff
author: John C.

description:
I made reservations (which is crucial if you're ever wanting a table) for a date here; knowing, that the WiFi sucked. It was a very romantic spot for the two of us with absolutely no phone interruptions which has its perks. 

THE FOOD- 
was amazing, they really pulled-their-own so-to-speak.  The presentation of every dish that came out looked spectacular, and photo ready. 

The neighborhood is a little sketchy (I wouldn't recommend wearing an Alaïa), but the decor of the inside was magnificent! It hasn't changed since the last time I came.  I truly love this restaurant, it's one of the best Seafood "fancy" restaurants in San francisco that won't max out your card.
author: Marina S.

description:
OK so this place has a bunch of stars for being fancy bla bla bla. I went here recently and looked forward to the seafood selection. Quite honestly I expected the semi-cheesy decor, as I had looked at pics beforehand. 

We missed reservations and they took about 30 min to act like it was super busy, but it wasn't (lol). The food was pretty good but nothing extrodinairy, especially for the $$$ tag. Service was nice but the guy didn't seem too interested in his job, hahaha. 

I think the highlight was the nutella dessert, which may or not have been from a box (jk but nothing too fancy). I wouldn't go back now that I've tried it, just good but plenty other amaze-ball places in the city.
author: Mahsa T.

description:
Had business dinner with three of my colleagues. Order the "super deluxe platter" and ordered fish and steak dishes. As with most upscale restaurants, service is first rate. The taste of food is delicious, with just enough flavor to accentuate the Mahi mahi. The tuna was also delicious. 

Atmosphere is has good mix of old fashioned charm with touch of contemporary lightening. 

The only issue is of value, our 4 entres and large platter came to $400 before tip.
author: Lee H.

description:
Incredible experience from start to finish!

First of all, our server Mark was on top of everything the whole time and Luke the sommelier was awesome!

We enjoyed 3 different French wines during our meal. Bubbles from Taittinger, a Clos De La Rue (Exquisite Chenin Blanc) and a late harvest Muscat.

We couldn't believe how many different oyster selections they had and the differences in flavor for each region they came from.

My wife's petrale sole and my branzino were cooked to perfection.  They were both lovely paired with the Chenin Blanc.  We can't wait to come back for this experience again. 

Make reservations in advance. We were seated immediately and were provided with a really nice table in the back.
author: Ryan K.

description: We have been here several times now and have to say that each time has been good! Been as a couple and also with friends. Each time we found that the food was good with a nice variety to choose from. Also, Service was excellent! ,good fresh food nicely presented.
author: May C.

description: One doesn't just 'eat' at Farallon; it is a dining experience from the moment you walk in and are greeted and seated promptly. Though on a solo vacation, I had made a reservation for one and was seated in a lovely comfortable area where I could enjoy watching the activities throughout the dining room, and the open kitchen. Service was prompt and attentive without being 'hovering'. My cocktail order was taken almost immediately and I was presented with the evening's 'gift' from the chef, 2 small portions of truffled aioli garnished with crushed hazelnuts and pomegranite. Fresh warm bread and butter also arrived instantaneously. I chose the bone marrow with sea urchin and truffled steak tartare as my appetizer, beautifully presented and impeccably clean in flavor. For entree I chose the buttermik-poached Petrale sole, beautifully garnished with vegetables. Service was at the pace I chose, a luxury solo diners don't often discover. And while I was much too full for dessert, they were happy to package their chocolate mousse for me to take back to my hotel. In planning this vacation for several months, this was the meal I was really waiting for. And it surpassed all of my expectations. I did not have wine after two cocktails so my bill for one was actually modest considering the unique ambiance and superb food and service. It's a splurge, but one I will repeat when I'm next in San Francisco.
author: Dean P.

description: We went here for a business dinner and I'll admit, I was a little nervous. The menu was quite fancy for me and what I'm used to. Everything we ordered was delicious though. We got scallops, prawns, and crab to start. We also ordered salads and the majority of the table ordered the tuna steak. We also indulged with dessert. Everything was very well prepared and full of flavor, and the staff was attentive and very professional. It is quite pricey, but the food combinations were of a higher caliber so it didnt seem like you were "overpaying" for a simple meal.
author: Shannon B.

description:
I haven't dined at Farallon for dinner, but I have been there for their Happy Hour and they have a pretty decent selection of bar bites.  When you enter the restaurant, it's hard to not be amazed at their Disney-like 'Under The Sea' decor (http://bit.ly/1EwKjkn).  For me, it just makes me hungry for some seafood, and if that's their goal, they've succeeded for the most part.

The Happy Hour offerings like most places are offered only at the Bar and Lounge area at the front of the restaurant.  Here's what I had:

$6 Sliders w/ Fries for Happy Hour -- http://bit.ly/1LG7fmG

$6 Half-dozen Oysters for Happy Hour  (2 orders) -- http://bit.ly/1J4sDmA

Both are really good deals if you're looking for a cheap dinner.  The best deal is the Sliders w/ Fries.  They're not the best sliders I've ever had, but they're pretty good regardless and the fact that they come with Fries is always a plus.  The Oysters were pretty much decent for $1 oysters.  Still a good deal though, and why wouldn't you want to have oysters with the underwater decor??  It's brilliant!

So if you're in the Union Square area and are looking for some cheap eats, I suggest giving Farallon a try during their Happy Hour.  I hope to go back there to try their dinner some day.  It looks like really solid restaurant!
author: Rodney H.

description:
The food was quite good!  We had the large "fruits de mar", seafood platter, which is a bit pricey (4x original price), but delicious.  I had the crab soup and dried scallops with a couple glasses of wine r commended by their sommelier. Also really good. 

They lose a star because our server was god awful - he was easily the worse server in the room. Was stoic and impossible to communicate with (we spent over a thousand for 4 people and he couldn't care less about us)
author: Jimmy T.

description: Excellent food. Loved everything we had. Somewhat limited menu and a bit pricey but worth it yo.
author: Laura G.

description: My friends and I came here for a birthday celebration over the weekend and expected what you usually would for a seafood restaurant in SF Union Square. Don't get me wrong, our server was amazing. She was really helpful and made it a great experience. The food was okay, it could've honestly been better. But what made our great night a bad one, was when one of the servers at the end of the night came up to our party and said "I just wanted to ask you...was the service bad, because the tip was very small?" Woooow...I mean....WOOOOOW, did he seriously just come up to my best friend and ask that? First of all, we split the bill 3 ways, so he probably got it mixed up and didn't see the rest of the tip. Second of all, we tipped over what was necessary. So for him to say that was totally uncalled for, even if customers weren't to tip well. I used to be a server at a restaurant myself and that isn't something you ask customers. That was totally RUDE! How dare he?! He was an Asian guy with blonde streaks in his hair. Just so everyone knows how rude he was. Okay, so my bff and I tried to let it go and not make a big deal out of it, but it really bothered us even the following day so I decided to call the manager to let him know how rude the employee was, and get this, he didn't seem to care much either. He was very careless in his tone and said he'd buy a drink for me because he would like to welcome us back. A drink?? Thanks but no thanks Brian. Supposedly, they're sending a gift card to my bff since it was her bday celebration, and if they do that would be great. This post will be updated if/when that does happen. Until then, we're not coming back to this place. BUT again, kudos to our female server who was great!
author: JujUb Z.

description: Great food, great service. The decor here is very beautiful and fits the atmosphere perfectly. They have so many great seafood dishes to try and it will leave you wanting more. It isn't the cheapest but the cost will be worth your enjoyment.
author: Marco R.

description:
I hadn't been to Farallon for many a moon until a visit a couple of weeks ago...what the heck was I thinking? I'd go again in a heartbeat, it was really great. The room is beautiful, you really feel like you're somewhere special. Service on point, and the scallops in the Scallop Tom Kha were ABSOLUTELY the freshest and most delicious I've ever had. 

The oysters were divine too. I think Farallon gets overlooked by locals who are always chasing after the newest resto but do re-visit!
author: Gwynnie P.

description: An amazing date night with my husband. The dining rooms are stunning and I would recommend that you ask to be seated in one of the dramatic and luxurious booths. Service was warm and attentive, portions were appropriate and beautifully cooked and plated with the freshest seafood. One of the best experiences I've had dining out in San Francisco. Highly highly highly recommended
author: julia k.

description: Me and my friends went there for happy hour. Food was ok but the service..oy vey. The bar wasn't crowded at all but the bartender wouldn't even tend to us. Isn't that the main part of his job? BarTENDer. To tend the bar...
author: Namie S.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday. The design is beautiful. It is a nice place with cloth napkins and tablecloths and put together human beings in fancy clothes. It is a great place to celebrate. The staff was very kind and patient. They spent quite a bit of time talking to is and explaining the wine and the dishes. We start with champagne and oysters which were delicious but expensive for what they were considering the high quality of food in sf. Then we had the fish tartar which was fantastic and highly recommend. The fish was very high quality and really flavorful cuts. For entree I had the lingcod which was So flavorful and rich. The wait staff worked hard to get us to our show by 8pm. It was a great dinner, more than average for sure. I think the food was probably worth it but with so many great places in sf I would probably hold off on coming here unless you really have a whole night to devote/special occasion and you just got paid before checking out this place.
author: Anne S.

description:
Was looking forward to this dinner, since i had very fond memories of my last visit (loved the ambience and the food).
This time it was "ok" but clearly not on par with the level of this restaurant. Service was inattentive, seating was poor (we were under a staircase and next to a service station) and the food unremarkable (ex: fresh squid ink linguini was undercooked, hard to do with fresh pasta). Only great dish was the chocolate dessert.
Won't be coming back, so many better options at this price range.
author: Umberto M.

description: Having eaten here before but never enjoyed the raw bar experience or the small cubby beverage bar in the corner it was pleasing to find just as much attention to detail. Very accommodating and professional. Nice to see the little details are taken care of.
author: Gregory F.

description:
I'm so sad from our recent visit. This used to be a glamorous restaurant, but it is more of a faded version of what once was. Our food was just okay. For the price we expected the best quality seafood that is expertly prepared. Our seared tuna & grilled octopus dish was oddly prepared. The tuna looked like it was flash fried and the octopus looked like it was just boiled. The waiter was nice but didn't seem to understand our concerns, but did asked the kitchen to remake the dish. The tuna crudo was not thinly cut but rather cut into irregular chunks. The scallops dish was seared well. The sablefish dish was good, but was a small portion.

The decor is faded and the seating upholstery was pretty threadbare. It's time for a refresh. 

The highlight was the curated wine list.
author: Linda C.

description:
This place never disappoints as a safe fall back.  Last minute spot for a valentine dinner.   Drinks are consistently good and the food is prepared well.   Portions are small.. so we always order two entrees per person.

An interesting fact:  the acoustics in the main room with the concave ceilings- depending on how and where you are seated, you can actually hear the conversation of the people sitting all the way across the room as if they were sitting next to you. We've experienced this twice now.

The kitchen is open and faces the seating area for patrons to watch the cooks perform their magic.  Low rating this time because we watched one of the cooks wipe his nose every two minutes as he prepared food all night.   I think he forgot he was on display.
author: Danny D.

description: I  was expecting really varied seafood.  There was no fresh scampi, petrale sole, or any type of more typical seafood dishes/pasta.  Should have looked at the menu.  Cocktails are good, fresh bread, but menu felt eclectic and seemed to try too hard to be different.  When my sis asked about the types (tastes) of fish, our waiter pointed to a painting on the wall!  Appetizers sounded great but were small and just ok (sardine gnocchi). To be fair my pork chop was cooked nicely and had great flavor. I think this place is all about the jellyfish decor.  So all in all a bit disappointing if you like straight-up non pretentious yet delicious food!
author: Lisa J.

description: Just another pretentious seafood restaurant with average service and mediocre entrees.  Also the back room of the restaurant is very loud.
author: Pat W.

description:
Just by looking the pictures, this place looks amazing and it was pretty nice once I actually went in.  Service was great and friendly staffs.  Now let's talk about food here.

It's a pricy place, they serve 280 dollars per oz caviar and 4 to 5 dollars per oyster from different region.  I didn't go for caviar even I really wanted to try what's the different 200 dollars per oz and 280 dollars per oz.  LOL just kidding, don't have that kind of money.  So I ordered 6 oysters from 3 different regions: WA, BC, and SC.  It tasted ok, not sure what's strange about it.  I used to eat doze of oysters in New Orleans, so I am more familiar with the mild taste of Gulf Coast oysters.  In some oysters, the taste were way too strong, even lot of lemon and sauce couldn't cover it.

Baby Beets & Dungeness crab salad next, the dressing was interesting and taste was good but not great.  Main course was Sablefish.  I liked the taste of the fish and it's hot but the broth on the dish was a little bit cold.  The serving potion might be a little bit small for a big guy like me.  It's about 4 or 5 oz, I guess it's standard for a fancy restaurant.  Too bad the broth was so tasty but lukewarm was not that great.  Also it's priced at $38.  

Best part of the dinner was desert.  I ordered Bergamot Angel Food cake.  Loved the earl grey ice cream with the cake.  I would say that's the star of this meal.
author: Eric L.

description:
Decor is not from dry land, reminds of an under sea adventure

Food
Speaking of adventure, the seafood selections are an adventure with rewards in the form of new delicious flavors

Bakery
Bread for the table was also tasty with salted butter.

Can't wait to return again.
author: Mark O.

description: We loved The Farallon. Service was great in both the bar & restaurant part. Alec helped us in the bar during happy hour. His suggestions where great. In the restaurant side we had Kirsten. She was great. Fast & sweet. Her suggestions where great too. By far the best steak I have ever had! We will be back for sure. Will be sure to tell everyone to check it out! We loved it so much that this is the first time I'm doing a review.
author: Lori S.

description:
SF Restaurant Week 2015 stop #11

Go for the jellyfish bar, stay for the paint-by-number-esque pano #AdamS painting of the sealife with cinnamon rolls. Also the food.

(-_-) Mixed Oysters / Clams $3.75 ea (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=z5sBKCaYd7iOTWFZA_gM0Q)
(^_^) Seared Foie Gras $27 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=p0Mf_aV_DKaNc2GLBnk4wA)
(-_^) 1/2 oz US Paddlefish Caviar $35 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=-PNBIOtjm919vZl0NIJ8og)
(-_-) Salty Bacon-Rabbit $32 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=z8q13PBqNPJ1rIg6cmMaGg)
(^_^) Iced Tea $4 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=a4YHrOxbPY2uNgkz-ojSTQ)

Oyster Service: oystmg I wish places would take a cue from Farallon and give a (tyvek!) chart card indicating the oysters on the tray. Other restos do narrate what's what then leave me to remember, but please. #aintnobodygottimefordat And the oyster fork? Best. oyster fork. ever.

Food Service: unsure why my menu was taken away, but they totally gave me another one later and let me order like 15 minutes till closing. I subsequently got then ate the dish past closing time; no one seemed hurried to shoo me out. So gracious. I did my part to speed-eat it though. #thatswhatshesaid

Full Disclosure: Had I had a different server, I might be saying something more like 3 1/2 stars.
author: Dan B.

description: Came here several times with business colleagues. Always enjoyed the atmosphere and food selection and quality. It was one of my favorite stops while in SF. So much so, that I insisted that my wife come here with me for her birthday celebration dinner. By the time that we got to the restaurant , she wasn't feeling well. As we waited for our table, I asked if they had something like bread or crackers that might help her. No big deal. Answer? Absolutely not! I was shocked at how utterly rude and indignant those of the staff that I spoke to. Had we fallen prey to arrogant, money hungry, careless wait staff as well? Yes we did. Shortly after our food arrived, I paid for the bill plus tip, and left. I don't think we will be back. Nor will I be taking any more colleagues to this poor excuse for service restaurant.
author: Jack N.

description:
Definitely go for Happy Hour.  We had two orders of oysters (tomales bay 6 for $7) an order of happy hour ceviche & killer fries.  2 champagnes & 2 LIITs for $100.  Where can you go in San Fran or anywhere for that matter for that price.  The oysters were killer.  The fries were crispy & creamy at the same time and the ceviche tasted like we were in Puerto Vallarta.  
For dinner my husband had the Bone Dry Scallops which were outstanding.  I had the gnocchi & oysters which was amazing.  I would definitely recommend Farallon.
author: Dotty S.

description:
My daughters brought me to this restaurant to celebrate my birthday.
I love the decor.  Wish I could say I loved the food.  I ordered the most expensive entree, $89.00 to be exact.  It was undercooked.  I sent it back and when I cut into the center of the steak, it was pure gristle.  I did not order anything else, as we had to be somewhere.  Our waitress was lovely.  I won't be returning.
author: d t.

description:
Upscale and great service. Amazing wine selection! The Sommelier presented the wines and was very personable. I had the Pave cooked medium rare, I inhaled it.  Dined at the restaurant with colleagues (eight in total) and everyone truly enjoyed their food / dining experience. The oysters were awesome as well! 

I had been to this restaurant before with friends and enjoyed it both times.  I highly recommend the restaurant for special occasions and business dinners. I will definitely go back next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Kera G.

description: I was up sold on my oyster appetizer to include caviar. Didn't realize the caviar taste was $170. Total dinner cost with tip for two people $400 :( food was good but cost is going to hurt the credit card balance!
author: Tracy C.

description:
Swanky, sleek and playful is how I would describe the Farallon.. The interiors are whimsical and subdued at the same time. Definitely a fun, fine dining experience. Glass jellyfish hang from the ceiling and a seat upstairs allowed us a view of the raw bar while we discussed important matters.. like appetizers vs. main courses. I went with all apps because I wanted to get the most bang for the buck and I wanted to have room for dessert... However, when I go back I will splurge on the Fruit de Mer - Royal! 

The apps did not disappoint.. each dish was beautifully presented and every ingredient was super fresh. The dishes were as fanciful as the interiors and you can tell just how much work the cooks put into each dish. Our server was very busy but managed to keep us all happy and we enjoyed our dinner, drinks and dessert and lingered on until closing time..
author: Sara F.

description:
Farallon's happy hour used to be $6 before 7p in the Jellyfish lounge. I guess they've changed it and it's now $6 before 6p. I still think it's a great deal. I just have to head there right after work!

March 2013
*Margarita ($6) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco#wPZJq0rpXjqpEKs0jtj7yw
*Oysters ($6) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco#-mX2GLuxl73uWF3nxPZEIw
*Charcuterie ($6) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco#1prCfCFIgJeJFRJJhYu0tA
*Sliders ($6) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco#BlHtsXzQI5H5hyIKWkghcA
*Spinach dip ($6) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco#Ol7EgxdLXZ0px44J1Hvq6A

The oysters are a must at $1 each! I could polish off two orders myself! I don't know what possessed me to get a margarita, but I did. The drink didn't taste that stiff at first, but I felt the effects later. Was buzzing the rest of the evening after another round or two.

I'd definitely come back for their HH. I've had dinner in their dining room years ago with the fam and that was fun too. The vibe is different. More formal. I tend to like the more laid back vibe in the lounge. Great HH to start off my night!
author: Elena N.

description: The ambiance is noteworthy; jelly fish chandeliers and sea urchin lights!  A very nice and classy touch to this seafood dining legend. The food is always spectacular as is the presentation. The sea urchin was especially good as was their various appetizers of shrimp, Dungeness crab, mussels, oysters, etc.  A nice wine list.  All paired with a friendly and attentive wait staff.  Always a fine dining experience.
author: Stewart H.

description: Excellent service , amazing food, so good for dating. Scallops, sablefish, oysters were really good. Recommend.
author: Anastasiia M.

description: Went there for a Birthday celebration, The food was Excellent, Amazing presentation and taste.  The problem was when I sat down in the bar to get a drink to wait for my guests , I ordered a virgin mojito and when he came back the waiter said, " Sir you look respectable, but are you alone or will you have other people coming".   When I said we have a reservation at 7:15, he seemed surprised and said oh well never-mind and quickly left.   I asked several times for the head host to ask the waiter to tell him what he met by that because I was still kind of upset, he never did.  At the end of the night I asked for the manager and told him the story and he assured me that I was mistaken and that he never used the word respectable, and that the waiter was just  trying to "make lighthearted conversation with me'.  I let it go but the next day I was still upset by now with the manager just dismissing my concerns. After a heated conversation with him by both sides, my bad, he agreed to check it out and get back with me the next day. Nicely enough he did, and he said, " I talked to the waiter and he now remembers that he did use the term RESPECTABLE in reference to my having a virgin Mojuito."  So just to  put it out there so I can let go of it,   THAT JUST IS NOT TRUE.  VERY POOR  ABILITY TO RESOLVE CUSTOMER SERVICE ISSUES ESPECIALLY IN A 5 STAR RESTAURANT.
author: Craig K.

description:
I've had better. 

It's really hard to mess up fresh seafood especially if you're simply serving it cold, accompanied by an array of accoutrements. With that being said, the lobster was good. The sauces served with the lobster were just ok. Avocado mousse was more like a pudding than a whipped avocado. And the drawn butter was cold. It's my understanding that lobster is to be served with warm drawn butter. 

The Louisiana Prawn appetizer was nothing special. A total of 4, one inch long prawns served abed ordinary cocktail sauce. For a "high class" restaurant such as Farallon I was expecting huge prawns and scrumptious sauce. The "prawns" we ate could have easily been categorized as shrimp. And the sauce seemed semi-store bought, semi-homemade. Disappointing. 

I had the cod entree with mussels, bacon and fresh cracked crab. Sounds good, right? Not. My cod was cold. The plate, fish and sauce were all cold. I didn't want to send it back since my friend received her entree and I didn't want her to wait for me. Looking back on the experience I should have sent it back. It had the potential to be terrific. I wish the server had noticed the plate was cold and therein, the food as well. 

We had a reservation for dinner at 5pm. We arrived a few minutes early and waited 15 minutes before being seated. We weren't given a booth even though the restaurant was empty. Our server seemed like a nice enough guy but was a bit pushy about purchasing an expensive bottle of champagne. And the first question he asked me was if I was a tourist or resident of San Francisco. It made me feel like he was trying to assess how much tip he was going to receive before we even got some water. Farallon is known for spectacular service but from start to finish it all kinda fell short. 

Nothing stellar. Though I enjoyed the ambience, decor and experience I don't think I'll be back anytime soon.
author: Rosalyn W.

description: My husband and I enjoyed our anniversary dinner at Farallon. Our server Nancy was knowledgeable, friendly, and very attentive. The food (as always) was incredible. We started with a flight of oysters from the raw bar and the grilled octopus (LOVED). Our main course were the scallops and the choucroute royale. If you're not in the mood for seafood, you absolutely must try the choucroute. We finished our meal with a decadent chocolate mousse. Can't wait to go back!
author: J H.

description: This was one of the nicest meals I've ever had. From the attention we received from the FOH, delicately timed moments between courses, to the little "crumber" the food runner used to clean my fathers mess, it was just flawless. I called ahead and painfully asked for a vegetarian meal and what the kitchen made for me was so thoughtful and filling, I just wanted to make sure that the chefs and cooks knew how much I appreciated it. It was my fathers birthday and the lobster he ordered with beets and burrata, heightened by the micro mint, moved him to silence. He said he had never thought about a dish's composition so deeply. The desserts were playful, seasonal, and wonderfully plated. I loved watching the sous or executive chef quietly expediting and handling the evening. Beautiful restaurant, talented chefs, flawless execution.
author: Dani W.

description:
We had an amazing experience here. The food was divine and the wine selection superb. I loved the ambience and decor. 

For appetizers we had oysters from Maine that were amazingly sweet and meaty. The foie gras torchon was spectacularly delicious, coupled with elder flowers and a subtly sweet finish. The beef tartare and caviar was to die for!!!!

Definitely I'd return.
author: Adrian K.

description: Very good experience. The platter for appetizer was really good, loved the crab. The Halibut was ok but the Trout was outstanding. Side lobster dont worth it. Recommend Local Chardonnay.  Is a bit expensive but worth the money. Jellyfish chandelier in the entry was unexpected,  but dont let them drive you away.
author: Francis A.

description: Great atmosphere and excellent, but slow service. Nine in our group so that influenced service. The Sea bass was good but the vegetables were way too salty. The presentation for all meals was interesting. Lots of different dishes. My halibut was good but not memorable. Some of the other entries were well received and raved about...crab, beef, other fish dishes.  Overall a nice dinner $880.
author: Willliam O.

description: First time in SF & decided to go here. It was a real decent place with some cool interior decor. I ordered the lamb as I'm not a huge seafood fan & my gf & friends ordered some great dishes. Service was good & it wasn't super packed on Sunday night.
author: Matt K.

description: This place was cool if you're looking for a change of pace in atmosphere. The under the sea feeling and decor was really cool and different than anything we've experienced but the food was more fine dining in that it was smaller portions for a decent price tag but everything seemed worth the price and a cool experience.
author: Amber C.

description: Really lack lust. The service was really good but that is it. Between my table we ordered 8 different items off the menu to share with the table. The steak was cold, the carpaccio was mediocre, the crab was good but not great. It was a meal I could have easily prepared for myself with a quick trip to the fish market. Completely unimpressed for the price and quality. Will not come back, and will steer all friends clear of this dud of a seafood restaurant.
author: Blake G.

description: great daily happy hour 'til 6pm in the jellyfish lounge (the front bar)...$7 for 6 oysters...fresh and cleanly shucked on a bed of ice...taking a few dozen and finding excellent....shucked so well and sweet....few glasses of $7 wine and plenty of bar snacks to make it an early dinner...tasty giants hot dog, fish & chips, charcuterie, cheeses and more....professional staffing in an upscale environment at happy hour pricing...
author: Hen A.

description: Gluten free options and the waitress was very helpful with what could be modified on the menu. Best piece of fish, seared to perfection with an incredible flavor. Great service and food.
author: Regina R.

description:
2.5 stars. I took my boyfriend here for his birthday dinner. First, as far as the food..... it was good. Not great, just good. The gnocchi with poached oysters appetizer was my favorite part of the meal. The abalone chowder appetizer was also tasty. My BF liked his sablefish main course. I had the ribeye, which was unremarkable, and served with fries, which drives me nuts, especially at fine dining establishments. I find it lazy, cheap, and uncreative. I know, first world problems. But really, nothing blew me away at all. 
As a side note - and this is not really the restaurant's fault, but it was very annoying and distracting nonetheless - there was a family at a table next to us that made a HUGE production out of their teenaged son supposedly consuming some ingredient in his meal that he was "allergic" to. This family commanded a great deal of the staff's time and attention over this matter, while the kid continued playing on his iPhone obliviously the whole time. I think it's safe to say he'll live to see another day. To this family, and you know who you are: Please get over yourselves. Anyways, back to the dinner review. I'm sorry to say that the service at Farallon needs a good deal of improvement. At the price point to dine here, service should be a symphony, and it was far from it, which was disappointing. The service was not warm nor very attentive. For example, our server repeatedly brought us the check prematurely, when we intended to order more. We were not checked in on during the meal, and the server did not thank us or say goodbye/good night prior to us leaving. He just disappeared. I will say that there were two staff members that were very nice - the gentleman serving bread and water, and the young man downstairs in the jellyfish lounge who took our drink & oyster orders while we waited for our dinner table. I'm glad I got to check Farallon off my dining bucket list, but I would definitely not go out of my way to return.
author: Andrea M.

description:
So my partner in crime, Miss Bad Idea Bear, is thinking of moving out of state.

She's one of maybe 3 female friends that I have, and honestly she's the funniest woman I know.

To try and convince her that SF is the bomb we went here to since she's always wanted to try this place.

The decor looks like a sea captain took acid and designed this place.
