Enough bread put on our table to feed an army Battalion.  

Nice place for Riesling geeks who like fish to accompany their wine.
author: Anthony S.

description: Absolutely surprisingly wonderful.  Had a large group in the winehold room and everyone thoroughly enjoyed their meal and the service.  Truly a wonderful experience.  Thank you to the staff for a great experience.
author: Jay G.

description: Spectacular establishment!! Beautifully decorated, great service, delicious drinks!!!  Small but BIG on class and elegance! Creative cooking by creative chefs!!
author: Mrs S.

description:
Best Bronzini ever had.... And I have had a lot. 
Great service too!  After 8 nights in SF .... Wishing I had found this place earlier.   I will be back. Fantastic experience!    And Jamie provided awesome service. Thanks.
author: Pam G.

description:
I came here a few years ago and it was amazing! The tuna sashimi was so tender it felt like we were eating air. The service was also top notch. We went to Pinot Days at the Metreon and walked to Farallon afterwards with a group of 8 people on our reservation. 

The service was solid again but something seemed to be different this time. The dishes seemed a lot smaller overall and the food, although good and made well, didn't live up to the super high price. I know this is in a tourist area so maybe that is it but it seemed like a VERY expensive meal for what we got. If I'm paying 50 dollars for a steak, I would like a slice with a certain proportion. 

I always try and not ding a restaurant simply because a waiter was slow or if a dish was not as hot as I would like it. I understand it's tough to be 100% all the time BUT, I will speak up if a policy set by the owners affects my experience. 

One other thing that bugged us is that we had 5 bottles of wine for the large group and when we sat down we were told we could only bring in two of our own bottles. Even if we paid corkage on them, they would only allow us two bottles thereby forcing us to buy their marked up wine. 

Not a great experience and i likely won't be back as there are so many options these days.
author: Donovan M.

description:
This was a great place for seafood although the prices were a little high but they had a great happy hour. This place is located in Union Square. We dined here before going to see a play.
Most of the drinks and plates were $7 for Happy Hour. Happy hour was a little crowded though and it was hard to get a table. Luckily we had reservations for dinner and were seated at the bar to enjoy discounted HH. We enjoyed some champagne , seafood bisque, and raw oysters on the happy hour menu. The service at the bar was much quicker than trying to wait for a server during happy hour to get to you. The bisque was well prepared and smooth in texture with a nice rich flavor profile. The oysters were a little small but delicious. I tried a few different types including the Drakes(on HH $1 AN OYSTER), Blue point $3.75 each, and Kusshi $3.75/each. 
We arrived a little early to our reservation so they seated us at 5:30pm. Our waiter David was very friendly and offered up suggestions for what to order. We tried the 1/2 chilled Maine lobster which comes with Lemon Aioli, Avocado Mousse and Salsa. All three of the sauces paired nicely with the lobster but the Avocado Mousse was by far my favorite.It was creamy and smooth with a little spice. The lobster comes de-shelled from the tail and the claws are cracked so not much work for delicious meat which I appreciated. The cost was $24. 
For our main entrees we tried the Ono with fennel and Shallots and the Arctic char on top of smoked bacon, cauliflower puree and brussel sprouts. The Arctic Char was perfectly seasoned and perfectly cooked. I did ask for it to be more medium than medium rare though. All fish is cooked medium rare here unless otherwise specified. We also tried the lemon hair pasta which was a special. It was nothing special but the flavor profiles were nice. 
For dessert I had the Eclair- presentation was beautiful with the choc curls . The dessert was nothing special although it was good and had the right components to make a well thought out dessert. 
For two people with drinks we spent about $196 for 2 glasses of champagne, seafood bisque,oysters, lobster app, 2 fish entrees, side of pasta dessert and a bottle of sparkling water. 
The presentation on all of our dishes was on par with the prices and quality of seafood we received. The plating was beautiful and well though out. I will for sure be returning the next time Im in Union Square.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: As always the food and service was great, but honestly I expected nothing less. This definitely a place to bring someone if you're trying to impress. The only thing I would suggest is having live music for a few hours maybe from 5 to 8. (Two or three piece band playing jazz)
author: Madison G.

description: I had the pleasure of visiting this restaurant in November 2016.  Love  the semi-classy ambiance,  attentive staff,  great food, and wine.   This place had a very comfortable feel and environment.   Awesome for couples and family.   Oysters,  little neck clams,  halibut, and chicken dish was delicious!   I would love  to revisit if I am in San Francisco.
author: Suzie Y.

description:
I usually do not give 1-star reviews but I honestly cannot give this place any more than 1 star.

I came here for a company dinner (big party) and was very excited to try out such a high-end restaurant. They seated us in this separate room not even in the main restaurant room but in a room (still part of the restaurant but in a hotel next door - probably because our party size was too big), but i wish we were in the same restaurant area as everyone else. 

They started us off with appetizers and I was not impressed. The gnocchi was tasteless. The only appetizer I likes were these mushroom rolls.

The waiter was very rude and impatient. The second I sat down he was rushing me and my colleagues to order our courses, when k didn't even get a chance to look at the menu! I felt so pressured and stressed! 

The small salad that came before the meal was ok - nothing special. I've had better salads at trader joes!

For the main course, I got the halibut. The fish was good but the sauce they had ALL over it (like drenched) was this horseradish sauce and I really do not like horseradish. I wish I knew that would be in there! It didn't say it on the menu. 

Finally, the dessert came out. The waiter told  us the 2 options we had and we all chose. One of them (this tart) was delicious but the Nutella cake was way too rich for all of us. I think we all took 1 bit and the rest was left.

I will not be back to this place. I'm not sure why so many love it so much. I didn't feel like they catered to us at all like mentioned in some of the other reviews.. I was really let down.
author: Nahall K.

description:
The service here is impeccable. Very well paced. I never felt rushed or ignored. Service is critical for me in how I evaluate a restaurant. If I could, I would give it more than five stars.

Food was excellent too. Bread served to the table with butter and sea salt. I know this restaurant is well known for its seafood but I had the pork cheeks and could not have asked for a better meal. I did have a clam and oyster appetizer which was very good.

I had read in another review that the wine list  needed work. I thought the list was fine. It is not all California wines but I enjoy wines from many regions.

The atmosphere here is very relaxing. This restaurant is meant for a special occasion or just having the need for an excellent meal.

I really don't have a critique of this place. I highly recommend it.
author: Charlene S.

description:
A new item for me - black cod.  WONDERFUL!  I am glad that I tried it.  so soft, they call it silky..

It was a week night and not overly crowded.  Nice for us.

Server was great and we engaged with her.  nice.  

It is not cheap but we knew that having been several times before.

Great ambiance.  That old swimming pool environment is cool.
author: Tom M.

description: I liked this restaurant, it was very nice.  We went for dinner on Sunday and I have to say I had a very pleasant experience. I ordered Halibut for dinner and it was awesome. We ate by the bar since our intention was to drink. We ordered a few drinks but for some reason the mixed drinks weren't very good, I don't want to blame our bartender, but he may have been to blame. I ended up ordering a Merlot, didn't want to risk it anymore. But. the food was awesome and the presentation was great. I also like the upscale look of the restaurant. Would I visit this place again? Yes. =)
author: Jaire Q.

description:
First time there Sunday night and it was great. Food was amazing.  Had the oysters for appetizers then crab risotto which was cooked prefect. My wife and I split it which was good because it was rich and half portion was best for us to be able to enjoy more if their food.  My wife had the tuna cooked rare and the sauce that went with mad the dish. I had the short ribs and a Wolf Cabernet franc from Napa which paired great. 

Service was the best part of all. Our waiter Jeremy was on point all night.  His suggestion of trying 2 different kinds of oysters ( 1 fresh water and 1 salt water) to compare turned out to be a great choice. He was entertaining and very helpful. If we get a change to go again we would ask for him again. 

I would recommend reservations and come a little early to enjoy the jelly fish bar.
author: James W.

description: My husband and I came for New Years Eve and it was the best decision!!!!! Everything was amazing!!!! We got the four course dinner each. Each dish was outstanding!! The tuna tartar was an explosion of flavor and unlike I have ever had!! The restaurant also made the holiday so fun! It was a great, great time!!!! Yes, pricey was worth it!!! Definitely will be coming back and recommend for a night out!!!!!
author: Marsha E.

description: Great ambiance, quality of food and outstanding service! Loved the jellyfish lights throughout the restaurant. The seafood is very high quality. I had the salmon and my friend had the halibut, both incredible. Will definitely return! The valet was awesome, too!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Expectations were (and should be) high at a place like this. Our expectations went unmet. 

The meal was disappointing; my bisque was overly salty and muddled with the only discernible flavor being the large dollops of olive oil floating around. Possibly it had over-reduced; by the time we were served it was well after 9pm. The locally-sourced squid appetizer had the potential to be amazing, but the cornmeal crust was again too salty. 

We were seated in the bar area, as the hostess specifically told us that it was "full-service just like the dining room." However, our service was inattentive at best. We spent a lot of time looking around for our server to remind her of a forgotten glass of wine, bread we'd requested, the check, etc.
author: Lea P.

description: Large but multi cornered and cosy restaurant with beautiful decor, amazing food (I had abalone and sturgeon, both excellent) and great service! Thanks to my friend Sunir for a great evening.
author: Journey G.

description:
Their menu changes daily. I guess I wasn't lucky enough to have a premium meal. I ordered the monkfish which as described by the waiter would be cooked rare. Ideally,  as I like it, monkfish is at it's best when cooked rare.  However, this monkfish was prepared similar to seared Ahi. The monkfish was horrible.  It lacked flavor, and was chewey and stringy. I could not eat it. The muhammara  topped the monkfish was ok, not great but ok,  but did not do the trick for me to eat the fish. 
I don't recommend this place. For the price tag, a client should experience fireworks in the brain. This place fails doing so.
author: Marlene A.

description:
Probably the best seafood place I like in the city. Especially if you want to bring tourists or out of towners.

Started with some caviar leading to sashima. Next came some truffle ravioli and then finally lobster tail. Dessert with some cinnamon apples.

I can't say enough about the promptness of the waitstaff, and nice ambiance, and the central location to Union Square - park on the street or in the Union Square parking garage.

Next up - a Farallon Island expedition trip!
author: Julia P.

description: This place's unique interior is worth a walk-in but eating here, despite the good food and service, doesn't quite justify the high  prices; the Albacore Tuna was $36 and the Halibut $35 but there was little else on the plate. We were still hungry when we left. But it's nevertheless worth a visit.
author: Swing C.

description: Simply an experience for the senses.  The decor was absolutely breathtaking. Felt like we were truly eating in the Palace of Poseidon.   The Royal Platter was enough for dinner for two.   Truly worth it!
author: Kristine M.

description: Farallon is one of my favorite restaurants in SF! Amazing seafood dishes, fab cocktails, nice wine list, amazing, knowledgable servers all in a fun, inviting atmosphere. Desserts here are special too! Top notch!!
author: Terri H.

description: My hubby were strolling along to Union Square and decided to pop in. We had heard this was a great seafood spot and noticed it was still happy hour (awesome for holding happy hour daily and until 630!!) so we popped in. We sat at the raw bar and were greeted immediately. The server was extremely nice and fast and overall the service was excellent. We ordered a dozen oysters and it was only $14 and two cocktails also only $7 each. Such a fun and delicious happy hour. Quick, tasty, and didn't rob the bank! We will back to try more soon!
author: Brittany G.

description:
We just celebrated our anniversary at Farallon.
to start off our evening there was an anniversary card on the table. I have never seen that nice touch at any restaurant in the world.
the food was delicious and the service was excellent.
we will go back to celebrate another special occasion there.
author: Richard G.

description: Been here multiple times over the past decade while in SF attending a conference or trade show at Moscone Center.  We've always had reservations here so I can't comment on walk in wait time. The restaurant has been around for decades, and you can tell by the interior design of the restaurant, definitely old school.  I can't really remember what I've ordered, but looking at their menu I probably ordered the Grilled Sterling Filet of Beef which is an 8 oz steak with marble potatoes, broccoli rabe, and black garlic maggi butter for $49.  We would usually order a bottle of wine for my suppliers so the bill is usually a lot. I don't usually order dessert so all I can comment on is the food which was pretty good from what I remember.  The service was also excellent and I don't recall any problems.  The price however is a bit excessive, but from what I've heard, they have one of the best value Happy Hours with scrumptious oysters.  Maybe if I am ever in the city during Happy Hour then I might check it out.
author: Dean S.

description:
I don't know how this place is still surviving in a city like SF that has such great food options. The decor was cheesy, and the food was very dated.

Tuna tartare was bland, presentation was from the 80's or 90's. You can do better.
author: Jessica N.

description: Fantastic menu for the entire course.  Nice wine selection and interesting decor--ie Jelly fish lighting.  Professional and prompt service, too.  Just because there are many $ signs on Yelp, don't let it intimidate you.  It's all worth it!!
author: Hiroko B.

description: We chose their 20th Anniversary Special which was a multi course chef selected dinner.  We have had tasting menus and chef special dinners at numerous restaurants and this one underwhelmed.  It was nice that it include tableside service with every course, however, it primarily consisted of dividing and serving the dish from the single plate it was served on.  I most cases it appeared we got a single entree serving which was then divided up among the three of us.  Nothing really unique or exciting about any of the dishes.  All were well prepared and tasty but in the end it wasn't worth the cost.
author: Rick H.

description: Farallon is really nice inside with its many jellyfish lights or chandeliers. Super cool architectural designs inside. Great bar area as well. Everything we've had to eat here has been on point. I recommend going here for the food and the decor.
author: Kirk M.

description:
A friend was coming from out of town and only gave me a few days notice. In a rush, I tried making reservations at a couple other spots, but to no avail. I made reservations here after a friend recommended it for it's cool architecture and classy feel.

We had late reservations (around 8:45pm) and once we checked in, we waited a few minutes to be shown to our table. Here's the breakdown:

Service: Our waiter did an excellent job. He told us the specials and gave us some time to look at the menu. We eyed a few things, but when he returned, we asked for recommendations. We basically ended up ordering everything he suggested and we were not disappointed. He was attentive, friendly, and totally on par.

Food: We ordered a couple appetizers to start (please pardon my poor memory, since this was closer to 5 months ago). They were pretty good, but nothing that blew me away exceptionally. For our main course, I believe we had the sole and the striped bass. Both were good and nicely done. For dessert, we went with a classic chocolate cake, reminiscent of a molten cake. Everything was solid, no complaints.

Ambiance: When anyone asks me, I compare this place to the interior of the giant sea snail in Dr. Doolittle -- the old classic version, not the Eddie Murphy one. It's like you've been transported under water. There's glass jelly fish hanging from the ceiling and a spiral staircase.  It's definitely more well lit than other date-night places and lingering on the edge between classy and cheesy.

Would I return? For dinner, probably not. I'm definitely glad I got to experience this place with such great company, but it's on the expensive side and I don't think the food was quite worth it. I have heard great things about their happy hour, though.
author: Leana L.

description: Came in on a Sunday afternoon, and will definitley be back! Some friends and I were on the quest for a new spot and we were directed here! We sat at the bar top, where we recieved awesome service and delicious beverages from Kevin the bartender! We will be back for sure!
author: Ashley L.

description: Beautiful decor and excellent food. Had to send the Skate back and service wasn't the fastest but it was such a cool place it deserves 4 stars anyway.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
When I was little, going to see King Triton's Palace in Disney's The Little Mermaid was always a dream of mine. I had no idea that a couple decades later, I would find myself in the dead center of this palace. Guess where it is! The heart of San Francisco, and it's called Farallon's! The chandeliers at the entrance have jelly fish lining the bar. Wait they are not just lining the bar. They actually serve a purpose and light the bar as well, and they look so realistic!  Every lighting fixture looks like it came from a tide pooling excursion, but then it's huge and life sized and elegant all at the same time. 

My friends and I made reservations here on the night prior to doing our Nike San Francisco Women's Half Marathon. We couldn't have any alcoholic drinks since we were running the next morning, but the sommelier had the bartender whip up some wonderful refreshing non alcoholic drinks to enjoy the night. The drinks were very mojito-like with ginger beer and hints of mint leaves. 

Our waitress, who had run the Nike Women's Marathon several years in a row, was very excited for us so she was very animated and very informative about the run. She spent so much time with us and treated us like we were the only guests of hers in the restaurant. Of course, that was not the case the entire time, since the restaurant was a "full house" that night. She was so talented and I almost wanted to ask her if she was an actress because she seemed to adapt so well to each restaurant patron at each table. (The table next to us had two older couples and she seemed to tone down her energy and act more professional with them). Yes, I understand every waiter or waitress at each restaurant must do that, but she was different. You almost had to see it for yourself! She is part of the reason why I think the service is close to impeccable here. 

The portions are smaller, so it is recommended that you order at least a couple of "courses." I ordered the molasses glazed pork belly, which came with a white corn cake to start. It was tenderly cooked and almost melted in your mouth when you ate each bite. 

For the main course, I had the seared local petrale sole, which was served with Yukon gold potato gnocchi, roasted butternut squash, and lobster consommé (a soup or broth made with lobster). The gnocchi is what sealed the deal for me on this choice since I needed some "carb loading." It's robust flavor and texture was harmonious with the thin flaky soft simple sole. I really enjoyed this course. 

In between courses, the chef offered a small amuse bouche sampling of a fire roasted tomato soup. It was one of the best tomato soups I've had. It wasn't too thick or watery, but the flavor was so strong it was almost overwhelming for some of my other friends. I love when the flavor is spicy and robust though!

I cannot wait to return to San Francisco and bring my husband here! Not only is this restaurant breath taking inside, I love the quality of food and attention to detail and service. Plus, there are just so many more courses and dishes I would love to try here!
author: Jennifer H.

description: I left here thoroughly impressed. This place definitely isn't light on the wallet but lives up to the bill. All of the dishes had great flavor and were uniquely prepared. The cocktails were on point and not too pricey. I had the sautéed squid, the soft shell crab, and the pork cheeks. The squid was served in a tasty, creamy tomato fondue with squash. The soft shell crab was probably my favorite because of the bacon and avocado purée. Again, dishes were made exceptional by the way they were prepared and the amount of flavor in each.
author: Nate T.

description:
Listed on SF Gate's 2013 100 Best Restaurants list.

Farallon is one of those restaurants that is an institution in San Francisco, and has been around forever. They are known for the gorgeous underwater theme, and the jellyfish light fixtures in the main dining room are still beautiful, although you can see the age of some other parts of the restaurant. However, I think they run the risk of losing clientele based on the quality of food I had on my first visit- my dining experience was really disappointing, and I would not be inclined to eat here again. I made reservations for a 7:30pm dinner on a Thursday a couple weeks in advance, and they were very accommodating when we ran half an hour late, which was a plus. We were seated at one of the tables right by the open kitchen, which was interesting since you could watch the chefs work. However, our experience went downhill from there. We tried:

-Complimentary Baguette, Sourdough, & Butter (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA): Delicious! I love when a restaurant has good bread and butter, and it was difficult to stop eating this.
-Cornmeal Crusted Monterey Bay Calamari (Piquillo Peppers, Balsamic Poached Artichoke, Green Goddess Emulsion, $16, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#RK_5MRzrJonc1Mp1j6HK4A): Good, but the portion size was on the small side. I also wish the actual calamari pieces were larger, since I felt like you barely had anything to chew on. I would consider ordering this dish again since the green goddess emulsion was really flavorful, as was the cornmeal crust.
-Maine Lobster Salad (Scallop & Prawn Sausage, Farro, Cippolini Puree, $21.50, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#2wPO_BHqLI1GW3g9HjDjNQ): Good, but not amazing, and I thought the portion size was small for the price. Although the lobster was cooked really well, I wouldn't order this dish again.
-Steamed Alaskan Halibut (Porcini Spaetzle, Organic Baby Artichokes, Roasted Maitake Mushrooms, $28, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#87zP1A86WYRPsrfna5HcQQ): Yuck- the entire dish was super bland and not good at all. To boot, the halibut was overcooked! Our server asked how we liked this dish since it was something new they were trying, and we gave him this feedback. Although he apologized that we didn't love the dish, they didn't comp it for us, which was disappointing.
-Whiskies of the World Tasting Flight ($27, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#8ildEPvyrdE-q2AwsntrjA): This was one of the best parts of dinner. If you're a whiskey/scotch aficionado, make sure you ask to see their list! They have a selection of whiskies throughout the world to choose from, along with rare scotches. This particular flight was ok- you got to try whiskies from Belgium, Germany I think?, and Tasmania. Although it was interesting, I wouldn't order this again.
-Salted Peanut Caramel Sundae (Popcorn, Peanut Brittle, Hot Fudge Sauce, Vanilla Ice Cream, $9, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#h-PaCfSgjwTutWKfhCC75w): Yum! The flavors in the sundae work really together, and the fudge sauce was delicious. Recommended!
-Carrot Cake (Burnet Orange-Wild Turkey Rye Ice Cream, Turmeric Candied Carrots, Pecans, $11, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#EXt5iUSYmnI8llXWYvdHAg): Although this was on the 7x7 100 things to eat before you die list for 2013, I thought it was just ok. The carrot cake itself was fluffy and moist, but the cream cheese frosting layer overpowered the cake, and we didn't like the rye ice cream. I wouldn't get this again.
-Complimentary Grapefruit Pate de Fruit (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/farallon-san-francisco?select=dztRLDQnxIdTifVoZ7qNgA#GwdYu-_8AQ7JwiCbcpjlEQ): Yuck. I'm not a fan of pate de fruit, so take this review with a grain of salt, but neither of us liked this.

The negative part about sitting next to the kitchen is that we heard some harsh words exchanged between the staff a couple of times, which made it a bit awkward for us. The service was also lackluster- when our server was around, he was very helpful and attentive. However, he would disappear for long periods of time (we saw him at other tables, so he it seems like he was overstretched), and it was difficult to flag anyone down at times. I think it took over 2 hours to finish dinner, since the food was also slow to come out, which I thought was a little ridiculous. 

As I mentioned earlier, based on the slow service and mostly average food, I doubt I will be back to dine at Farallon again. The portion sizes are also on the small size for the prices compared to similar restaurants in SF. Parking in this area can be very difficult, but limited street parking is available.
author: Amy D.

description:
Come here with the mind set that you are going to spend money... and that's okay, because no one can really afford cheap seafood.  With this aside, hit the raw bar hard and enjoy some of the freshest seafood you are going to find.

If its a big occasion, then do what you can to ensure that you are seated in the far back under the beautiful fresco and then let their experienced staff serve you strong drinks, good wine and the aforementioned seafood.
author: Ronald D.

description:
I had dinner here with a large group before a play. Due to the timing we weren't able to go with the prix fixe; that probably would have been the better way to go.

When we were seated we ordered drinks while waiting for the rest of the party to arrive. The drinks were slow to arrive and mine was on the warm side. When the rest of the group arrived an ordered drinks they were mixed up and had to be sent back. Apparently the bartender was new, but that's not much of an excuse.

Overall the food was good and the service finally got on track with the delivery of the entrees, all ten at the same time. However, for the price everything should have been on track from the start. With so many options in the City I'm not sure I'd give this place a second try, but the atmosphere was very good and I think it would work well for a party of two.
author: Justin W.

description: The restaurant itself is gorgeous with its underwater themed lights and décor (the jellyfish lights in the bar are true showstoppers).  At the end of the day, though, it's about the food; and the food is pretty good.  I have been here several times and while there have been a few missteps, the way in which they were handled was a class act all the way.  If there is something you are unhappy with (food, drinks, service), please speak up; they will make it right.  They don't have a tasting menu, which is surprising.  My dinner date and I created our own, and they were very accommodating splitting all of the dishes for us.  The menu changes, but you cannot go wrong with scallops or salmon or steak.  I like Farallon and highly recommend it (especially if you want to impress someone).
author: Donna G.

description: Great restaurant, plated were a nice size, not to small not to big. I ordered a yellowtail very fresh, and my husband ordered a bacon wrapped chicken. The french wine we ordered was the best we had on our trip, it was rich and full bodied. The waiter was very helpful, and recommended the wines and food. They serve the butter with a Hawaiian salt with it AMAZING! Definitely recommendable
author: Katha N.

description:
Conveniently located just down the street from union square, it is a good spot for an upscale seafood feast after a day of shopping. The decor is unique and reminds you of a classy Disneyland restaurant.

Unfortunately for us, it was not the happiest place on earth service wise. It was unclear if our waiter was just a prick that day or just shouldn't be in the service industry. He would put down plates without saying a word or he would somehow state what some of the dishes were but not all. At the end we had 3-4 desserts and all were brought to the table at the same time. He explained 1-2 of the dishes then stops and walked away. Totally bizarre...
author: Schelly Y.

description:
Handsome date. Yep.
Quietly hum "Under the Sea" to myself as we're being seated. Uh huh.
Mouth-watering fresh oysters. Check.
Friendly waitstaff. Sure.
Attentive, though? Not really. 
Any other food good? Um...

We drive to the place and already there's no valet attendant in sight. My gentlemanly date asks me to wait inside as he finds parking. I wobble out in my heels, trying to sprint indoors while battling the crazy wind and not flashing cars nearby in my slinky dress. With my hair a wild mess, it's a wonder the host doesn't treat me like I'm a hobo who just fell into his restaurant. He apologizes for the lack of valet ("he's here somewhere," he says with a wave) and I wait until my date comes back.

When he arrives, we're seated immediately and order:
+Some freshly shucked oysters on the half shell. "Surprise us," we tell our waiter, and he brings back some Beausoleil, Kusshi, and Shigoku: all delicious.
+He opts for the baby spinach salad (with strawberries, pecorino romano, and grilled red onions in a tart balsamic vinaigrette)
+I go for the Mediterranean shellfish bisque with a cognac chantilly, chives, and dots of extra virgin olive oil. First taste: whoa, salty mama! Second (hesitant) taste: OK, I can't do this. My date tries it, puckers, and sucks it up. He trades my soup with his salad (which is delicious, by the way) and pretends that he likes his soup salty. The waiter notices the trade and comps the soup. Very nice of him.

The rest of the meal was just OK. Nothing exciting or terrible: it was just OK. For spending as much as we did and all the rave reviews, I expected something better, when it sort of just fell flat.

Oh, well. Good to know.
author: Adena B.

description:
Just had a fabulous dinner at Farallon! To be honest, and after reading the Yelp reviews, did not have very high expectations. 

My experience here was stellar! Shared the mixed greens salad and fettuccine as appetizers. Both were delicious, which set the tone for the evening. Ordered the Petrale Sole for main course, and my companion had the Florida Prawns. We enjoyed all of it.

The restaurant is quite something to see, so we were prepared to chalk it up to that. But the food was great. The service was exceptional; they were beyond attentive, but were not obtrusive in any way. 

So, if anyone asks if I'd like to go to Farallon, I'm gonna jump for joy!
author: Elizabeth Q.

description: There is $13 valet, which is amazing as you don't have to waste time driving around looking for parking and is much cheaper than most private lots. The decor is in absolute harmony with the seafood theme, complete with hanging glass jelly fish and cave-like walls. The bread was good, but the butter was amazing. It was sprinkled with sea salt and was very smooth. The oysters, mussels and scallops were all fresh, and the portions weren't too crazy big or too small. Overall, the food is not too expensive but a simple bottle of wine can equal the entire cost of the food.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Had someone's birthday dinner here. Nice decor with jelly fish and sea shell light fixtures and dining room like a fish cave grotto. Noise level was very loud because of acoustics. Appetizers, entrees, and dessert were all excellent. Quality of seafood was excellent and fresh. Quantity was small like the commercial where you get a large white plate with small 3 oz entree docorated with a sauce smear. Lucky we were on diet and eating late. Prices per person estimated:  appetizer 20, entree 35, desserts 10, drink 10, 18% tip, 5% employee mandate, sales tax 9% or $90-100 / person. Not bad, less than political fund raiser or if on business expense. Parking in garages but street underground construction makes navigating here difficult. Not sure that I saw valet in front. BART Powell St. Stn is few blocks if you want take transit or taxi /Uber here.
author: Clifford W.

description: Nice happy hour drinks and appetizers.  Oysters were good, but ceviche was incredible.  A very nice atmosphere and great service.  Good value.
author: Cris F.

description: Friendly, attentive and professional service throughout our meal. We ordered the melon/crab/salami appetizer which was very flavorful and creative.  The tuna tartare was competent but not memorable.  The grand platter, with an array of shellfish was super fresh, but to be honest did not hold a candle to our favorite raw fish platter in Boston at the Island Creek Oyster bar, where the shellfish tastes like it was harvested ten minutes prior to being served.  May sound haughty, but we could not but compare the two experiences.  Delicious sorbet trio, the highlight being the chocolate.  Overall, a good meal in an elegant setting.
author: Anita B.

description:
I took a friend out for dinner and we decided on Farallon. I made reservations via their website. They called me the day prior to confirm but each time I called, no one answered. It was frustrating. Finally the next day I called very shortly after their reservation line opened and was able to get through. I'm not sure why the confirmation is even needed or why they can't do it online. The calling system is tedious and annoying. 

The restaurant itself is absolutely gorgeous and very interesting, I've really never seen anything like it. However, the tables are kind of cramped. My friend and I are over 6 foot tall in heels and we were trying not to play footsie because there was just no room. It kind of takes intimate to a new level. 

Anyway, this is one of the only restaurants that actually give you water without asking. In the Midwest, the first thing you get is water on the table but it seems here you have to ask for it or you don't get any. That was not the case here which was welcome. Their wine list is absolutely insane, it's like a novel. Luckily the waiter was very helpful and I cannot complain with his service in the least, he was great.

I ended up getting the endive salad and the lobster entrée. The salad was good but the parts didn't seem to fit together. The salad itself was kind of messy to eat and not overly flavorful. It was served with a large slice of a very mild cheese which didn't necessarily complement it well. The brandied cherries and the plum slices were awesome though. 

The lobster was already taken out of the shell and was served with a potato and sweetbread hash. The lobster itself was great, though slightly overcooked. I'll honestly admit I've never eaten sweetbreads so I don't know what it's supposed to taste like but it made the potatoes insanely salty. 

My friend and I split dessert which was a bittersweet chocolate tart with sassafras ice milk. It was pretty good, not too heavy and it was kind of salty and sweet. The bill came to $210 without tip so while the food was pretty good, I probably wouldn't come back. I want to be blown away for that kind of cash. Also, they charge $40 to open a bottle of wine for you, FYI. I didn't know that and it deterred me from buying a bottle. Why do I want to pay half of what a good bottle of wine costs just to uncork it? A little pretentious if I do say so myself.
author: Megan K.

description:
Between getting rush tickets at the Curran Theatre at 6pm and waiting for the show to start at 8pm, my date and I went to Farallon for Happy Hour. Everything on the menu was $6. Here's what we had:
Bass Pale Ale - yes
Hemingway Daiquiri - no; it had a fake funny aftertaste
2 orders of Drakes Bay oysters - yes
fries - yes; but will not order again
duck paté with charcuterie - no; paté had a strong cognac taste
seafood soup with cognac cream - yes; accompanied by great bread
beef sliders - yes; comes with fries

Our servers were friendly and attentive.
author: Monica S.

description:
Farallon Restaurant, San Francisco: A Review
When one thinks of Seafood and San Francisco, the Wharf area immediately comes to mind. Imagine my surprise when my Search for a seafood restaurant for a Good Friday night dinner directed me right around the corner from my Union Square hotel, listing the Farallon Restaurant, (named for the windswept islands off the coast of San Francisco) just a block away at 450 Post Street. The restaurant's history gleaned from the website intrigued me: located in a historic building that was originally built for the Elk's Club, and featured in the first issue of Architectural Digest in 1922, it sits on a floor built above the original salt water swimming pool, still in use a level below, but now using the original ornate ceiling that had been built two stories above the pool. And what a ceiling this is! Originally created to simulate a seascape scene, it has been recreated by the current owner restaurateur/designer Pat Kuleto in a whimsical manner to recreate sea urchins, jellyfish, coral, seaweed, shellfish, a nautilus cross-section and sand...
The visual feast on entering the restaurant adjacent to the Kensington Lodge Hotel (also an Elks Club property) and being shown to your table in the Jellyfish Lounge or the Pool Room is only an entree to the gastronomic one to follow, what has been termed "coastal cuisine", artistically created by Executive Chef Jason Ryczek and Chef/Owner Mark Franz. We (very briefly) considered starting with an indulgence in an ounce of Imperial Osetra Caviar, but at $280, took a pass. We weren't disappointed in the alternative with the Nicosia Valley (http://nicasiocheese.com/, an hour north of San Francisco in Marin County) Dairy-supplied delicious Locarno cheese (discovered by Chef Ryczek, on a weekend outing with his wife), melted into toast, topped with mixed greens, pistachios, and rhubarb-fernet dressing. We complemented this with an order of Pappardelle Aglio E Olio, consisting of smoked hedgehog mushrooms and bottarga, topped with a slow cooked egg, that I gently broke the yolk in order to garnish the pasta! 
The Farallon offers an extensive (24 page) wine list, ranging from less than $100 bottles, to the Bourgogne Rouge La Tache Domaine de la Romannee-Conti 2012 at $3650. I, as always, opted to bring my own. After leisurely slow-dining over the appetizers, sipping down a lovely bottle of Le Monferrine Piemonte Barbera ($30/bottle corkage charge, 2 bottle limit), we (slowly) savored the Local Ling Cod, wrapped in smoked pork belly and purple pozole, served in a huge black deep bowl with artistic swoops of "avocado puree", colorfully topped by greens and radish sections. The artisan breads, topped with butter sprinkled with Hawaiian sea salt, gracing the meal could have been a meal unto themselves, accompanied by the blood-red Barbera wine, for this Good Friday Eve meal. 
The Dessert menu was tempting, with one ounce Artisan Cheese portions (including Ewe Calf To Be Kidding Wisconsin Bleu) cheese with wine pairings, served with freshly baked walnut bread, to Bergamot Angel Food, Panna Cotta, Fennel Pollen Flan, White Chocolate Mousse Cake, Carrot Ice Cream Cake, Nutella Chocolate Bar, to Sorbet Trio. Fully sated, albeit tempted, we passed, aiming for dessert back in our Grand Hyatt room. 
As we concluded our delectable seascaped culinary sojourn, we enjoyed visiting with Executive Chef Jason Ryczek, and complimented him on his creative, imaginative, and both visually as well as gastronomically artistic offerings. This restaurant is worth at least several visits, even for out-of-area diners like us. I eagerly look forward to my next fine dining experience at Farallon!
author: Kim S.

description:
Not only does this place have amazing seafood, but it's also one of the best happy hours in town. 

ATMOSPHERE:  A
Very classy atmosphere, but not pretentiously so. They have a beautiful 'jellyfish lounge' downstairs, which is a lounge area underneath large jellyfish-shaped chandeliers. It's very comfortable and great for a small group of people. The bar is also fun -- and you can sit at the oyster bar or the wine bar right across from it. Perfect for a drink and appetizers with a friend, a date, or coworker.

DRINKS: A
The happy hour menu had 4 cocktails, 3 wines, and a beer on it. For $6 each, it's an amazing deal in this town. I really enjoyed the Manhattan personally, but you could also get a Moscow Mule, a Daiquiri, or a Margarita. Or a wine of course.

FOOD: A+
The food here is fantastic and the happy hour prices are unbelievable. Every day 4:30-7pm, they have the SIX UNTIL SEVEN where everything on the happy hour menu is $6. Highly recommended are:
- Oysters (6 for $6 and delicious)
- Seafood Soup (daily special which might vary),  this bisque was to-die-for.
I wouldn't recommend this place for steamed clams unless you're a big fan of salty food (the chorizo adds a great bacony flavor, but it also makes it way too salty instead of buttery and steeped in white wine). 
I can't wait to come back for a 5-course chef's specials dinner. 

SERVICE: A
Very prompt, very professional.
author: Natalia S.

description: I have been going to Farallon for special occasions and the occasional post-shopping drink since they opened.  Yesterday I happened into Happy Hour and was very happy indeed to get an ounce of caviar at half price. However the cava being served for happy hour was flat and undrinkable, so I ordered a real champagne to do the caviar justice.  The cavier is served nicely on a bed of ice and traditional accompaniments included sour cream and chives but no chopped egg or blinis. Instead they serve it with toast points, which were good but kind of thick. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it immensely at half price but would not have liked to have paid full price.  I ordered an entree off the regular menu of john dory over seasonal vegetables (which consisted mostly of onions) as suggested by the waiter, and it was served nicely with a foam and sauces smeared on the plate and a dab of bearnaise sauce. The fish was nicely pan seared. Unfortunately the whole dish was over-salted even for a salt-lover like me...not enough to send back but enough to dampen my enjoyment, though I ate it all with a great pinot noir off the regular menu. Dessert was fanciful and creative and tasted good but the presentation made me laugh. Pretentious and outdated.  The decor at Farallon is unchanged over the years and is still fun and silly but I like it.  There was a nice crowd but not too loud. The wait staff was superb.
author: Pam B.

description: This restaurant is just beautiful. The decor is amazing! The ambiance is sophisticated, elegant and swanky. The staff at the front door had warms greetings for us last night. We went to dinner with work colleagues, obviously late as work never ends. The hostess made us feel welcome even though we were 30 minutes late. They sat us in a booth in the corner of the restaurant! Thank you! Fabulous table! We were able to do our business in a private setting! The food is incredible! We ordered the butter lettuce salad, the gnocchi, the egg in bread appetizer. The gnocchi was my favorite! For an entree I ordered the stuffed quail with Foie Gras. There are not words to describe how good this dish was! It was cooked to a perfect medium. The foie gras was seated to perfection. The only other time I have had better quail was in Las Vegas at Craft. My Husband ordered the dungeoness crab. He said it was perfect, finger licking good! For dessert we had some Inniskillin ice wine and the profiteroles! YUM! Service is top notch. Our server was quiet, efficient, never rushed us. Honestly we talked the entire evening and you would never even know the staff was there! Great job by a very capable team.
author: NY F.

description: The oysters were great. The jellyfish chandeliers are worth seeing. We had a nice upstairs table by the window. My tuna was spectacular. Service was slow and with an attitude.
author: Joel N.

description:
Farallon is a good choice for upscale seafood dining near Union Square.  On a recent Saturday evening, the place seemed to be mostly filled with tourists seeking a great meal in San Francisco and locals out for a special occasions like birthdays.  I'll round my review to 4 stars even though I feel it is more of a 3.5 star experience.

The interior is designed to look like a Disney-esqe version of the Sea with Jelly Fish lighting and sea shell dining tables.  I would categorize the ambiance as Retro Fantasy.

The service is outstanding, the service staff works hard to ensure that each diner has a great experience.

For starters, the seared duck breast was tasty.  The heirloom tomato salad was simple, fresh and delicious.

I had the grilled lobster and found it to be well prepared.  Veggies were served in the lobster shell alongside the tail and claw meat.  I would order this entree again.

For dessert, I had the grape pie serviced with peanut butter ice cream.  The pie was served warm and was very tasty.

The wine list is also comprehensive with many options by the glass and in half bottles.

Next time that I have a special occasion or friends visiting from outside the Bay Area, I'll consider Farallon again.
author: Lance W.

description:
What a fun place! First off the Jellyfish Lounge is such a lively area! I went there last night for an early dinner without the Mr who was still slaving away. I haven't had dinner alone in a fine dining establishment in a while, and really wanted to just be alone so I opted out from sitting at the bar. 

Since I was dining alone, I was able to take as many photos as I wished which I excitedly did so! And they are here! :) 

I started with the duck liver mousse, they give you a lot of crostini to go with it, pickled baby vegetables and a spoonful of mustard with seeds. What I did first was I ate the mousse with the crostini first. Then I topped it off with the pickled vegetables, then I spread a bit of mustard over the mousse and topped it off with the vegetable. I liked eating all three together best. This definitely could have been shared between two people. I did not finish. 

The second course I picked the diver scallop. Yes you read that right, you get one. But it's AMAZING!! It could be that because there's only one that made it taste all the more amazing and leaves you wanting more but nonetheless I highly recommend this. The gentleman sitting across from me who came afterwards also ordered the scallop. 

The third dish for my entree I had the striped bass. The skin was very crispy and the filet was about half the size of my palm, I loved the little sunchoke that accompanied the dish. 

With a glass of wine, everything came out to about $100 for me alone. Salud! 

I didn't realize that it's right next to a theatre, next time I am up here I will check out the theatre next door!
author: Nancy N.

description:
It was my bf's birthday and I had an online deal.  I hadn't been here for dinner in a long, long time and we live close - so this was a great treat!  We ordered half a dozen oysters, including some Drakes (don't know how much longer they will be around), miyagis and an olympian - mmm, fresh, lovely, and thoroughly enjoyed.  We also got some tasty prawns to share.  For our entrees, we ordered yummy salmon with housemade pasta and the sole - mmm, we completely enjoyed our entrees, good.  For dessert, we got ricotta cake and chocolate bites - a nice, sweet cap to our meals.  I also got 'grape juice' or non-alcoholic gewurztraminer wine - this was a nice alternative to wine to go with my meal.  

Service was really nice, thoughtful and explained the menu as we went along patiently.  

I hope to come back very soon!
author: Maile N.

description: There are few perfect restaurant experiences in a lifetime and, when they occur they should be noted. Our experience at Farrallon last night was one of them. We sat in the Jellyfish bar and had the immense pleasure to be served by Alec. An amazing server, knowledgeable and funny, he made an excellent evening unforgettable. From the Fruits de Mer shellfish platter and oyster sampler to the scallop and ribeye entrees, it was just perfect. When we left, I gave Alec a bear hug, that's how good it was. Oh, and they make a killer Sazerac, too.
author: Jason S.

description:
Based upon previous reviews I was looking forward to a great food experience in San Francisco with my sales and clinical teams.  Sadly, this ended up not being a the case.
The Good:
Service was excellent
Visual ambiance was excellent - Very pretty lighting, ceiling, open kitchen design
Wine list was outstanding (somewhat over priced but outstanding none the less)
Tasting of Mushroom Bisque.  Wonderful and incredibly rich.
Breads, and the accompanying salted butter, were outstanding

The Bad:
Pork Chop was so overdone that it had to be sent back.  I couldn't even cut it with the steak knife (first meal I have sent back ever!)  Every one at the table was done eating before I received a replacement meal.
Sides if "hearts of palm"  had an unpleasant taste and the mustard crushed butter ball potatoes were dry and over done with mustard.
Others meals were "okay" at best with the exception of the Striped Bass which was rated as "outstanding" and the Snapper which was rated as good.
Lastly, as beautiful as the restaurant was the acoustics made it incredibly difficult to hear and carry on a conversation over the din of a crowded restaurant.

Sorry but I won't be visiting Farallon on subsequent business or pleasure trips to San Francisco
author: Mike K.

description: Excellent food. Dined with group of 5 and all entrees, sides, wine, etc were great. The two star rating is based on terrible service. Waiter was very curt,impatient, condescending, and downright rude. This was a business dinner and everyone was expecting a great experience. Big miss with the service. Will not return. Many great restaurants in downtown San Fran that I'd suggest over this one. This was a suggestion from concierge at Ritz Carlton. Will let the Ritz know as well.
author: John D.

description:
I was really looking forward to dining at Farallon for our wedding anniversary. It's long been one of the best rated restaurants in San Francisco and plus they have a new chef that has been getting lots of publicity.

The atmosphere and aesthetics of the restaurant are absolutely beautiful and unique
I love that it's in a historic building. The jelly fish chandeliers are lovely -- they get 5 stars. And,the wine list is extensive and great stair step in pricing...you don't have to spend a lot on a good bottle at Farallon.

The service was just so-so.The staff was super nice and attentive but not quite as efficient as other SF restaurants (yes, we are spoiled and have high standards in this city) I was dismayed that our shellfish appetizers arrived before we had the proper utensils and plates to eat it with. We actually had to request the shellfish forks, crackers, and plates --- they must have forgot that we needed them! My champagne was delivered sometime after the appetizer as well even though I ordered it at the same time as the shellfish.

Our dinner entrees included Lingcod, Sablefish, and a side of the squid ink pasta. All were very good. But, the fish portions were considerably smaller than other places we have dined in SF. I wasn't wowed by the Blueberry marble cake dessert either. 

Perhaps Farallon gets most of their business from tourists....but living in San Francisco there are just too many fantastic restaurants with better service and food to recommend Farallon to others or ever personally go back.
author: Katie S.

description: What an awesome restaurant. Food is always on point, service is great, and even though they are a seafood restaurant, their steak is really good.
author: Shanzay H.

description:
This restaurant is good, but not great. If you're near Union Square and want a good fish dinner, go here. But be prepared to spend some money.

-Their wine guy was helpful with reviewing our choices. He was a bit over our heads though, ie he was discussing the soil in Italy and how it affected this one white wine. We are not so advanced. In any case, we got one he recommended and it was good

-The bread they serve you is good. And they'll bring you more if you ask

-The baby spinach salad was really good. I loved the crostini on top, and the grilled red onion with the strawberries

-The warm dungeness crab appetizer was awesome. The real star of the dish was the fried green tomato though

-For my entree, I got the branzino. This is where I went wrong. This was super bland. I was really hoping for more flavor

-For dessert, I got the chocolate bites. This is a great choice if you want just a little sweet something at the end of your meal

When all was said and done, I think our bill was near $300. Two of us. So, yeah.
author: Kim H.

description: Fun old school under the sea experience.  Good food, creative presentation.  Service was great.
author: Leslie E.

description:
So I've come to the city for the first time and all i had on the mind was seafood. After visiting a neighborhood bar, i ask the guys behind the bar for a recommendation. Both said to come here... so glad I did. 
To start off, you must stop in and have a drink with the bartender Mark. He's from east coast, not sure the last name. He was so inviting as well as the entire staff. 
I had the oysters and bisque to start, then followed by the pork. AMAZING!
If your looking for a great atmosphere, oysters and bevs. Go here, you won't regret it.
author: Ruben V.

description:
This review is purely for the carrot cake dessert! It was listed in the 7x7 magazine, so of course we had to try it! I, who personally do not like carrots, loved the carrot cake! The actual cake was the perfect texture, moisture and also balance between the ingredients. What I did not like too much was the buttercream ice cream with it. I think vanilla ice cream would've been better. The ice cream they had, lacked sweetness and flavor. It did not taste like buttercream at all. 

Overall, its a fancy restaurant if you wanna bring someone for a date. :)
author: Mo W.

description:
Happy hour at it's best! I've been here twice for happy hour and both times were great. Love the service. Even though we ordered only from the happy hour menu we didn't feel that we were treated differently from others who were there for dinner. Our water was always full, bread came so often that we had to say no a few times, our flatware was changed between courses and our server was always there when we needed him.

The happy hour menu is limited but it's good enough for a meal (full happy hour menu is on their website). Everything on there is priced at $6/ea. I also like that their happy hour is until 7pm not 6pm like many other places. Everything we ordered was great, especially the clams.

I never had considered coming here for dinner but the happy hour experience changed my mind. I will be back soon.
author: Andy W.

description: I ate here after backpacking in Yosemite as a reward for eating oatmeal, jerky, and hummus for a week. It was amazing. I ate the seafood sampler for 4 by myself. The wait staff is friendly, the ambiance is warm and welcoming, and the wine prices are reasonable, even if the food prices are inflated.
author: Ian V.

description:
My husband and I decided to come here since we were craving for surf & turf. The reviews seemed mixed bag, but thought we give it a try and make our own judgement.

Bottom line I'm giving a one star for these reasons:
*The cocktails came 25 minutes late; it was nothing to brag about
*Had a dozen oysters but where was the horseradish, and tabasco sauce? It only came with champagne vinegar with herbs?? Eewwww..
*Our main waiter never bothered to check up on us. Why.. because we look young & didn't deserve equal treatment as other hoity toity folks? We both were impeccably dressed.
*Water glass was filled after we finished our water. Why do we have to wait until we finished our water? I can understand the water shortages in Calif., but seriously! 
*The Mains were disappointing. Lobster was masked with too much bearnaise sauce and it was overcooked. The dish looked like it had a lot of lobster meat. However, the lobster shells disguised it where it made you think you had a lot on the plate. 
*Desert -- Very disappointing. Can't say much about their homemade sorbet and lackluster carrot cake. Cake tasted like wholewheat masked with icing. Never had carrot cake that tasted dry.
*WARNING: DO NOT USE THEIR VALET SERVICE. THEY DINGED OUR BMW REAR RIM. CALLED THE RESTAURANT AND THEY ABSOLVED THEMSELVES . SO NOW WE HAVE TO CONTACT THE VALET COMPANY AND DEAL WITH IT.

***ONE STAR FOR WASTING $400 DINNER ACCOMPANIED BY A CURB RASHED-RIM WHICH WILL COST $500++.
author: Hope T.

description: The food was great, but a bit overpriced! They change the menu daily and I had the sole that was delicious. The atmosphere was a little cheesy kind of reminded me of an old Hollywood club...curved booths, tiled ceiling, etc. service was good as well.
author: Lowndes M.

description:
I thought the fish had no flavor and undercooked also over priced and not worth going back to!! Chocolate dessert was awful! I ask,  how can chocolate be not good??
 go here and you'll know!
author: Theresa M.

description:
Bday dinner last night. Steve, our server, absolutely killed it. We had a great meal & Steve got us out of there an onto our theater night without seeming rushed at all.

He even turned me on to a new cocktail, a Vieux Carré.

To the MGR that reads this: Tell Steve thanks. Ry & Mer
author: David R.

description: WOW!  The ambiance is marvelous.  As a guest, you're taken into another world.  Loved the immense glass jellyfishes suspended from the ceiling and the underworld carvern of the dining room.  It was great fun.  We appreciated the excellent service; not interrupting our conversation and pacing the meal.  Our meals were beautifully presented and delectable.  Truly a memorable evening.
author: Erin K.

description: I come here for happy hour often.  They have the best oysters!  Their happy hour used to be $6 before 7pm but they upped the price ($7) and cut the hours (4:30-6) so I had to knock a star.  The bar area is very cute and I like the jellyfish light fixtures.  The service there is awesome. The servers are always very nice and attentive. The oysters are a must have, but I also enjoy the sliders on occasion. Also, the bread and salted butter is addicting! Add a happy hour cocktail (or two) and that's all I need to turn my crappy post work attitude around!
author: Nicole C.

description:
Stop #15 was our fanciest meal of the trip.  We had actually tried going somewhere else (they were closed on President's Day) but we really wanted a nice seafood restaurant so we took the concierge's advice and came to Farallon.  Aside from some of the tacky interior (a bit too much of the seafood theme) the food was really good.  You don't eat the interior.

We called here on our way back from our failed first attempt at getting dinner to make a reservation.  We were quite happy when they said they could accommodate us when we arrived.  As soon as we arrived we were seated in the large back room.  Upon walking into the restaurant, I honestly thought the front room was the entire restaurant.  That is not the case.  The back room is pretty spacious and that is where we ended up sitting.

We started out with the Roasted Baby Heirloom Beet Salad ($14) which the split in half for us.  This came with dungeness crab, gremolata (a chopped herb condiment typically made of lemon zest, garlic, and parsley) and curry crème fraîche.  This was a very nice dish.  It was difficult to taste the beets and the crab at the same time, but separately they were very good.  I think we both wanted more of this dish.

For mains Sue had the Grilled Double R Ranch Petite Filet of Beef ($36) which came with hedgehog mushrooms, fondant potato, haricots verts and a béarnaise sauce.  Ordered medium rare and it came out medium rare.  I tried a bit and you could cut that meat with a spoon.  I had the Cedar Grilled Cascade Mountain Arctic Char ($27) with braised dino kale, roasted turnip and celery root remoulade.  This char was similar in color to salmon with a taste somewhere between salmon and trout.  I decided on the char as it is a fish I don't have very much experience with.

For dessert (save room for dessert) we had the Milk Chocolate Hibiscus Mousse ($10) which had dark chocolate-zinfandel ice cream, candied kumquats and hibiscus cake.  What a phenomenal way to end a meal.  Possibly one of the best desserts I've ever had.

Our server (Leyla) was very attentive to our needs.  She was very knowledgeable about the food as well as the wine that Sue ordered.  She was very friendly and very good at her job.  You would expect that of a place like this, but that isn't always the case.

You will spend money here, but you will also eat well.  It is worth a try.
author: Dan H.

description: I'm giving this place 5 stars because the bartender was awesome. Unfortunately, because I had 5 vodka sodas I don't remember what my food tasted like. I will definitely be back and hopefully won't drink so much so that I can remember what I ate and not be pissed off at the amount of money I spent!!
author: Shawn M.

description: Giving two stars only for the chef and the tasty meal. The service in the main dining room was terrible. Don't get me wrong, we can appreciate fine dining. Our server, was a pretentious prick. Our experience was cut short by his terrible attitude. The bus boy was 10 times better than our actual server.
author: Mara D.

description:
I like how the waiter offered to exchange our white napkins for black, when we sat down.... we were dressed in black, so no white lint.   Very smart.

Great food, nice wine list, wonderful atmoshphere, impeccable service.  All you can ask for.
author: Jim R.

description: Upscale, tasty, formal service, fresh seafood! Yum! We loved the decor, the mural in the back room, the ambiance, and the food. Our table was near the kitchen which was bustling, but appropriately quiet.  Our waiter was helpful with the menu, and the service was highly attentive and timely without being invasive. We'll come here again for a special occasion.
author: Laurie R.

description:
My friend and I were really excited to come here for the oysters and expansive scotch menu that we saw at their booth during SF Drink. We hustled over to catch the happy hour before it ended at 7 pm. There's a variety of appetizers and drinks for $6 each. We didn't try any cocktails, but the appetizers were unimpressive in size and taste. Beware, you'll get only two greasy sliders that look like the microwaveable kind, or three small pieces if you order the potato croquettes.

My biggest problem with this place was the service. The waitress for our area (seat yourself around the bar or front booths if you don't have a reservation) passed through many times and seemed to be pointedly ignoring me. I hate flagging people down because it feels vaguely rude to me, but I was worried we were going to miss the HH. After twenty minutes, I finally I got the attention of the busser, and he ended up taking our orders and serving our food! Poor guy didn't know what the soup of the day was, so he said he'd have send over our server with that info and the reserve scotch menu.

She checked on us exactly once, at the end of the meal, probably to hustle us out. He was very helpful throughout, and even ran out when I forgot my phone in the booth. I wish the tip went to him.
author: Cat N.

description: Terrible food, overspiced, etc. Small portions for huge prices. Servers very nice. Avoid, avoid ,avoid.  Very poor selection of fish.
author: Sheila T.

description:
Without a doubt, my favorite restaurant in the City. Fabulous food, attentive service, great vibe, and creative cooking under new chef Jason. We have a standing reservation every Saturday night ("date night", still going strong after 6 years at Farallon). 
Highly recommended. 
And for those who previously were underwhelmed for any reason in the past, please give it another try- otherwise you'll be missing out on something really good....
Jeff & Shelley
author: Jeff B.

description:
Farallon may not be the hippest or the coolest or the most of-the-moment place to dine in SF, but it certainly is one of the loveliest, one of the classiest and one of the most beautiful. My husband took me here the night we became engaged several years ago, and we returned recently to celebrate yet again, and it was just as special and memorable as the first time. 

What sets Farallon apart is the impeccable service and attention to detail the staff provides. They elevate this place from another seafood restaurant to an actual experience -- one that you'll want to repeat on special occasions. 

In terms of the food, it's fantastic. You're definitely going to want to sample some of their seafood -- the raw bar is one of them most impressive I Have ever seen, and the wealth of options is incredible. Crab legs, oysters, cherrystones or squid, they have whatever may tickle your fancy and a smattering of things you didn't know you wanted. Do yourself a favor and try it all -- it doesn't get fresher or more expertly prepared than it does here. 

The entrees are always awesome and aren't exclusively seafood -- I have had lamb here and it was outrageous, but nothing compares to the varieties of fish, in my opinion. The chef has a way of pairing components and plating in such a beautiful way that the meal itself is artful and appetizing all at once. This is food you want to look at AND savor. 

It's not inexpensive, but you're paying for, as I said, an experience. Their wine list is also incredible, and if you find yourself lost don't hesitate to call over the sommelier -- he knows his stuff and will help you select anything from a glass to a bottle with the same attention and grace.
author: Hilary H.

description: The Oysters are amazing. And so is the bread. Prices are high so expect it. Wonderful ambiance!
author: SJ B.

description:
Aside from the starters, such as the scallops, and the seafood platters, all the other dishes are mediocre without anything special.  The crisp Chesapeake Bay softshell crab and poached Nantucket Bay scallops are delectable to warm up your appetites even with the white wine braised Mediterranean octopus.  The seared New Zealand Tai snapper is one of the better dishes compared to the grilled Hawaiian ahi tuna, cast iron fried local king salmon, and grilled Creekstone Farms petite filet of beef.  You would dine here with large groups of seafood aficionados and the experience would probably be great and expensive.  The bittersweet chocolate malt gateau is solid for ending your meal on a sweet note.  

Parking is tough on the street  and expensive at local garages.  The ambiance is cute with a seafood theme of squid lanterns.  The service is friendly and creative for celebrations, but it can take awhile.
author: Jenny L.

description: Very nice Victorian ambience and great wines . Food is good but quite like any other place , perhaps I expected the fish to be really exclusive . A bit pricey but you feel special . Try their private rooms for a group dinner . Friendly and knowledgeable staff and their location is e cel lent , near union square
author: Vin M.

description:
Went here once for a company holiday party, and I got hammered.

Toward the end, the open bar closed up in our event room, but a couple of us wanted a drink, so we went behind it and got one. I grabbed a beer. This rude-as-f!@# staff woman went around shaming us in front of coworkers for doing it.

Note to Farallon: I get that dealing with drunk people sucks. But as our office admin pointed out to me later, you could have just charged us for the individual drinks instead of reaching for the embarrassment card. Our company would have paid for them.

Having said that, staff was very patient on another visit when my group went for oysters. They're $6 for six oysters during HH. We got a TON right before happy hour ended, and the waiters were perfectly accommodating. Good oysters, too. Nice atmosphere. Decent drinks. I'd still come back despite my cruddy first experience.
author: David S.

description: Atmosphere is intriguing however all the food we tasted was beyond sub par. The bread was the most difficult to chew bread I've ever experienced. Not only did they mess up our very simple order, but they made no attempt to compensate us in any fashion. The wine and oysters were delish, but then again how can you mess that up! Definitely would not recommend this place. Super over priced for the quality and service. Disappointed the hotel recommended this place out of all the seafood in this city. We still can not get the horrible taste out of our mouths. While we laughed about the terribleness to quite an extent, it still did not make up for the $300 dinner of great disappointment. We will not be returning!
author: Sheila M.

description: Highly recommended for HAPPY HOUR Daily 4:30pm-6:00pm.  Also recommended for dessert at the bar.  Most beautiful whimsical restaurant I have ever been in.  I have had reasonably okay entrees here, but never worth the price.  That was years ago, and may have changed, but I expect a lot from a restaurant this expensive.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Farallon is a wonderfully quirky seafood restaurant away from the tourist traps that run along the shore. The food is of excellent quality (and priced accordingly; expect the bill to exceed $100 per person if you enjoy alcohol). Service in our case was excellent and the waitress was spot on with her recommendations.

Their kusshi oysters from British Columbia are so delicious that ordering a variety of types feels completely unnecessary - none of the others compared. The black bass was probably the best I've ever tasted, though I'm less impressed with their tombo tuna. All in all it we had an excellent dining experience without paying an exorbitant price.

If you plan to come here on a weekend, do yourself a favor and book the table as early as possible - all the good times get reserved rather quickly!
author: Matthew B.

description:
A worthy splurge for the wise. There is nothing ill to say. 

For a special night out we started at the bar to take advantage of the Jellyfish Bar happy hour menu. Extremely well-rounded (not to sweet and not to briny) oysters and cocktails welcomed us (and for a price we would jump for again). The Oysters and the Hemingway Daiquiri were the winners of the happy hour.  But alas the menu of inspiring cocktails wooed us off of the six dollar page. They had clever little names that I can't recollect but the best one (peach blossom?) was simply divine with gin, peach, herbs and sparkling wine. 

On to dinner, where we shared the Paprika Octopus which the menu claims to have been braised, but it was so tender and velvety that I began to doubt their description. 
The octopus was so plump and soft that it compared in texture to the plump raisins. 

Next we had the Gnocchi and Sweetbreads. Both were a great take on comfort food. The gnocchi was supple-soft and earthy delicious with crunch from the pomegranate seeds. The sweetbreads were like chicken nuggets from heaven. Softly fried and silky with an apple puree as a compliment. At this point we were close to being full, but we had yet to try the pancetta wrapped rabbit and yes it was as good as it sounds. And came with a to-die for rabbit liver mousse on a crostini. The herbed faro and sauce rounded it out into a great ending note. 

My only regret was that we were too full for desert (the first and second plates aren't all that small).  

Just look at a few pictures and you can see that the atmosphere transports you into an underwater realm (I recommend the google tour if you need further proof). The service was equally outstanding, even after a table mishap the server was patient and accommodating. All said 5 stars all around!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
450 Post St. (between Powell and Mason streets), San Francisco
(415) 956-6969
HOURS: Open for lunch 11:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m. Monday-Saturday; dinner 5:30-10:30 p.m. Sunday-Wednesday and 5:30-11 p.m. Saturday. (Bar open later). Full bar. $12 valet at dinner.

Difficult street parking.

A real treasure. Main menu items $37, Appetizers $15. Easy to spend quite a bit the food is equisite here as is the wine list. The wine steward is terrific at finding just what you want at a price you can afford. Service is exceptional and on a large group, the gratuity is rolled into the check at 18%. The dishes were each a perfection of flavor, smell, and presentation. 

This could easily become my favorite resturant.
Dinner for 5 including three modest bottles of wine in the $60 range was $650.
author: Steven S.

description: Amazing!!! This place deserves 10 stars. My husband and I went here on Saturday 2/18 and it was our first time. The minute that we walked in I already knew we were going to have an excellent night. The hosts greeted us with their beautiful smiles. We we sat at our table our server immediately greeted us and we told him it is our first time and he came up with spoon taste of a delicious sturgeon as a welcome from the chef. Our server was so knowledgeable and attentive. From the wine, to the appetizer, the entree and to the dessert everything was absolutely exquisite. We had their appetizer that consisted of crab, oysters, prawns and lobster with their mouth watering sauce. My husband had the cod and I had the sturgeon with shaven truffles, grits with bacon that was aged for 6 months, bacon with sea urchin hollandaise sauce. My gosh is excellent. For dessert we had their white chocolate mouse with pomelo and ice shaved blood orange it was perfect. And the best part of it executive chef Jason came to our table and welcomed us. I highly recommend this place. Thank You for a wonderful experience.
author: Heidy K.

description: Not all its made out to be.  We asked the front desk attendant for a recommendation on a good seafood place and she recommended the Farallon.  When you walk in you'll notice a unique decor that might distract you from the obvious.  The obvious being the the standard service.  Although this might not sound that bad you might want to think twice once you see the pricing. I'm not at all opposed to paying top dollar when the food and service are spectacular, which this wasn't. If you're looking for a decent meal with under whelming service and over extended wait times for your dinner than this is the place for you. When you receive your meals they are prepared as ordered, or at least we did. The manager also seemed to care and apologized but the server blamed the order on a miscommunication.  I hope our experience was a fluke but if anyone out there decides to visit this establishment dine at your own risk.
author: Steven E.

description: As an out of towner I was on a mission for some great seafood and I certainly found it here! The under the sea themed decor was a little funky but overall I had a great experience! We started with caviar and an assortment of oysters that were pretty great. I also had the lobster bisque which was phenomenal!  I had the sea bass that night, which I am a big fan of sea bass in general but it was very good. Additionally, they have a great wine list that is very extensive.
author: Claire M.

description: This review is for the bar in The Farallon ....Best happy hour ever!! Right off Union Square in SF.  The Jelly Fish Lounge in the Farallon is beautiful, has great service and the food is phenomenal!  Happy hour is daily  from 4:30-7:00 with everything on the menu priced at 7.00!  Sliders, lobster bisque, truffle fries, and half dozen oysters!  The drinks include Manhattans to margaritas and great wines....it feels like a treat for not too much money. It makes for a nice end to a day of shopping or a great meal before a show. Or an after work meet up.
author: Teresa B.

description:
I'm a SF local, 10 years ago, this was the "to go" place.  In the past 10 years, thousands of other restaurants have popped up and are so much better.  

Only went here because my brother had his birthday dinner here.  It was one of the only places that could take 7 people with a week's notice.  When you look around, you won't see any SF locals.  Mostly tourists.

We started with the royal platter and caviar.  I love caviar and this was pretty good.  As for the platter, it was ok for $130.  It had lobster, shrimp, crab, oysters, clams, etc, but only had cocktail sauce and the vinegar sauce you typically get with oysters.  Come on, I'm not dipping my lobster or crab in cocktail sauce.  Should have asked for butter but our waitress was absent for a while.
