As for appetizers, we ordered linguine with clams, salads, gazpacho, corn risotto, etc.  The waitress raved about the linguine so a few people ordered it.  It was on the salty side and just ok.  The gazpacho was also a little salty.  The corn risotto with truffle oil was the only thing we liked.  

As for the entrees, we ordered lobster, filet mignon, salmon, and pork cheeks.  Lobster had holladaise sauce on it, don't think anyone enjoyed it on their lobster, plain butter would have been a million times better.  Most of the side dishes to the entrees were salty and not memorable.  The waitress raved about the corn tortellini with my lobster, they were not that great and sprinkled with something unidentifiable, in a bad way (like plastic fake bacon bits).  Pork cheeks were ok, a little dry.  But, my husband did enjoy his fillet mignon but didn't like any of his side dishes.

As for dessert, we ordered the smore sundae and chocolates.  The sundae was good but the chocolates were not that great, a few tasted stale.  How can you mess up chocolates?1?!

As for service, on the slow side.  There was about 30 min wait between our appetizers and entrees.  In addition, it took 30+ mins to get and pay for our check after dessert.  It was a 3.5 hour dinner that really should have been shorter.  

If you are a tourist staying in Union Square and don't want to travel far, this might be the place to go.  But, I would rather take a taxi to another area of town.  For the price, you can get a much better meal.
author: Shelly W.

description: Wow. Where should I start? The bartender was amazing. But the hostess made us sit at the bar for a half an hour and when the bartender went to check on our reservation, she said oh I was looking for you, not in so sorry this took so long. The sommelier was great came right over and brought us our wine. Then that's when we sat there for over an hour waiting on our appetizer. The salad was great. The. We waited forever for our food to come. And when it can it was way too salty, spicy and undercooked! I saw our waiter speaking to a manager about his last table that got up and left and then both had a big laugh about it. Then I watched the oyster guy crawling under the bar on his hands and knees multiple times and then carrying food. Gross! Not going there again. Worst experience ever
author: Oksana I.

description: I heard such wonderful things about it and the reviews were amazing, we went in looking forward to the dining experience but sadly left laughing. The over priced menu was not the issue, I have no problem spending money on quality but this was not quality. We started with the sea urchin as the appetiser, it was far from the best I've  ever had, good thing we have a sense of humour since it was about $90. Then came the main course, I had the tuna, it lacked any type of flavour and was dry. My wife had the steak and lobster, with a side of some sort of undercooked flavourless potato au gratin that were literally raw. The lobster tail was the size of a tootsies roll, however it did have flavour and was cooked well! The steak was by are the best part of the meal, it was cooked perfectly and was very tender and delicious. The server Jeremy I think was a broadway theatre actor or just had a incredibly snobby attitude! But ever that we were able to roll with and don't blame him for his lack of personality. Thank goodness we can afford the $400 dinner for two and laugh about the experience, just wish we went in here with no expectations, if we had done that we would not have been so let down. I'm sure many will enjoy their dinning experience here, sadly we had an awful experience. So do with this review as you wish, but it came from a very honest point of view. Cheers!
author: Patrick H.

description: This restaurant was a huge disappointment. I am a restaurant server myself and was very unhappy. Me and my boyfriend took his parents out for a nice dinner on our vacation and it was really unsatisfying. First off our Server was very inattentive and took nearly 20 minutes to take our order after greeting us, between which she stood in plain sight doing nothing by the server computers. Our oysters came out late, our food came out almost 50 minutes late, and cold. The bill was very expensive and they incorrectly charged us for things hoping we wouldn't notice. Would never come here again. The food is not worth the hassle. Spend your time and money elsewhere.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Really good never had a bad meal here the menu is great and diverse the freshest oysters and great clams the Sea Bass was the best I ever had
author: Emery L.

description:
Not as wonderful as they used to be, but still a good staple for seafood in SF. 
Good service and good shellfish bar. 
Nice wine list and the decor makes you feel like you are in a sea womb lol.
author: Fins L.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner and was wowed by the ambiance (Monterey Aquarium meets Arabian nights): incredible Chihuly-esque sea urchin and anemone hand blown glass lamps, jellyfish sea urchin chandelier sculptural chandeliers and gentle Renaissance masters palette of umber.

The food did not disappoint (although service was a tad pretentious). Perhaps the most perfectly seared scallops I've ever had, delicately crusted, moist barely blush. Lovely.
author: Pamela F.

description: We have been to the Farallon twice, once with friends, and this last time just the two of us. The decor inside is beautiful. They really outdid themselves with it. I cannot think of another restaurant that has put so much effort into a thematic ambiance. The paintings, light fixtures, sconces, chairs, everything is sea themed. For drinks, my partner had the Wolf Family Cabernet Sauvignon and thoroughly enjoyed it. I had a couple of drinks. The first was on their cocktail menu, and I believe it was called a Saint Benedictine. It was a slightly sweeter version of a Manhattan, and, while it was delicious, came in a glass that was half the size of a martini glass. Then, I decided to have a Manhattan and it was pretty good. For food, we shared the a Abalone with Chestnut Ravioli, Lobster Tail with Burrata and Beets, and the Lingcod with Rustic Ratatouille. The Abalone literally came with three tiny ravioli... for the price of $29. It was delicious, but the portion could have been bigger. The ravioli is filled with chestnuts in brown butter. It was really small, though. For $29? At least add a few more ravioli. The lobster tail with beets was a good portion, but bland tasting. We would try something else next time. The lingcod with ratatouille was a great portion and delicious. I highly recommend it. For dessert, we had the grilled banana bread with coconut ice cream and caramel. It was good, but it didn't taste like it was fresh. The banana bread was dry, but the portion was good for two. Our server, Kirsten, was great! Thanks for all the help and great service.
author: Lucas S.

description: Went for happy hour. Had a few drinks and some oysters. Oysters were ok, nothing special. Would go for drinks tho.
author: Josh Y.

description:
The decor of this restaurant reminds me of a high school prom in the late 80's in a rich part of town.  The under the sea theme is very appropriate for this seafood restaurant--scalloped shell booths and areas with catchy names such as Jellyfish lounge and Belluga room. 

They offer happy hour in the lounge til 7PM daily. The restaurant is open and bustling. Don't let the appearance fool you, this is a fine dining restaurant so expect to pay high prices for small portions. The portions are perfect for 3-4 courses per person. 
 
This seafood is expertly prepared and refined. It's not just some fish streamed, broiled or fried.  The accompanying sauces, broths, foams of each dish enhances, but doesn't compete with the delicately prepared seafood.

The refreshing summer melon salad with house cured duck prociutto and the pan seared Alaskan halibut with a flavorful lobster broth were two standout dishes for me.
author: alicia k.

description: Great food, very mediocre service....Our server ignored us for some reason as I think his shift was ending.  Was very dissapointing
author: Brett B.

description:
We keep winding up here before shows at the Curran and usually have a pretty good meal.  The menu is variable; this past week, even though this is a seafood restaurant, they had this fantastic mushroom bisque.  Want.  

Obviously, they really know how to cook fish.  Things come out with perfect crispy seared skin.  Good stuff.

We had a 6:15 reservation on OpenTable and made sure they knew we had an 8 PM show, and they took care of us in plenty of time (though we didn't order three courses each).  Service was friendly and attentive.

It's not cheap, but you knew that.
author: Michaela L.

description:
Haven't been to Farallon in years and I, mistakenly, thought it was going to be dull (it wasn't my choice). I was so, SO wrong - Farallon is fantastic and deserving of San Franciscans' rediscovery. 

The service was impeccable, both our waitstaff, as well as the wine director, were on top of it (but didn't hover). The food was incredible, especially the trout entree. 

This is a gem of a restaurant that I was so glad to rediscover.
author: Layne G.

description:
OH MY SEAFOOD GODS, is it ok for me to be disappointed in this place?

The bf brought me here last weekend for my birthday. I used to believe this was a super fancy smancy restaurant that served nothing BUT mouth watering seafood. I was wrong. Maybe because I went in with such high hopes? That's probably why I came out with crushed dreams and a salty taste in my mouth.

So, they do a 3 course menu and you get to pick from each category.
Let's start off with the bread and butter, cold bread + hard butter = sizzlers.

First appetizer - I had the shrimp cocktail which was actually really good. Probably the only reason why I'm not giving Farallon 1 star. The bf had the scallop sashimi which was a little different, but good. It was like they made a scallop sashimi sandwich? they sliced the scallop in half and put some white tangy sauce in the middle.

Second course - I had the linguini and a side of regrets. It was soaked in broth that tasted like salt water. I couldn't even finish it! It was really terrible.. The bf had the soft shell crab and I took a bite..it was definitely better than mine but still not what I had imagined Farallon to be.

Third entree - I took the waiter's suggestion and ordered the pork cheeks that he called "awesome". DRY SALTY CHICKEN? no, supposedly, it's pork cheeks. SIGH....the bf had the salmon, which was eh..can't really mess up salmon..CAN YOU? but the mash UNDER his salmon was O.M.G.. I wanted to devour the mushy potatoes. But I kept my composure and only took a few bites. 

The sweet, sweet waiter, the other reason why I'm not giving 1 star, brought ice cream out with candles and all for my birthday. I'm sorry buddy, I'm lactose.

$212 later, GOODBYE FOREVER FARALLONnnnn
author: Lily K.

description: This place was fantastic! Came here for dinner with my boyfriend and we were both incredibly happy with it.  Started with a dozen oysters, variety chosen by our waiter JD who was great! I had the scallop sashimi, linguini with muscles and squid, and the Hawaiian tuna.  The boyfriend had the melon salad, corn and shellfish bisque, and the halibut.  Ended with a grape tarte.  Everything was delish! Thanks for a great birthday dinner!
author: Morgan G.

description: The Happy Hour at the Farallon's Restaurant is awesome.  Kevin, the friendly bartender is AWESOME!!!  I will be back.
author: mary f.

description: Good service. Came here for happy hour to eat oysters with the boys. Oysters were tiny. $7 / half dozen. We all didn't think it was worth it. Nice ambience and good service deserves the 4 stars for the limited experience I had.
author: Marc D.

description:
This is one of my favorite fine dining places in the city. The best dishes are the fruits de mer, which is a cold platter that contains a wide variety of shellfish and the caviar. Everything else is above average but nothing really stands out. 

Besides the good food, the one thing that makes this place really 5 star worthy is the atmosphere. I've been here several times but I always get dazzled by the oceanic decor. It really puts you in the mood for some fine seafood.

As expected, the service is top notch. Most of the waiters are genuinely nice and really helpful. 

The last thing that I have to mention about this place is their scotch selection. I'm not a huge scotch person (so don't take my word for it) but people say this place has one of the best collections in the city. I have tried several here based on recommendations and really enjoyed all of them.

The price is, of course, really expensive but not outrageously so. Even though I end up spending a lot of money every time I come here, I always leave feeling satisfied.

Overall, this is a fantastic place for a fancy date night.
author: George Z.

description: Food is underestimate due to the rising restaurants that serve Michelin star dishes in San Francisco.  But I can honestly say that the food and service is up there with the biggies (Benu, Sasion, etc)
author: Sammy S.

description:
Cash only valet had me running to the ATM. The front desk staff gave my girlfriend a dirty look when she checked in for our reservation. Later the hostess walked us to our table and gave my girlfriend a nasty glare. 

Then the worst part of our night came with our waiter, who was condescending and arrogant. He killed the experience.

It's unfortunate that when the service is so poor, the food doesn't leave the impression it would have otherwise. 

The humble bus boy was the only one I liked from this experience. 

Also I'll never understand the logic in being a jerk waiter yet relying on tips... is it so hard to fake being nice?
author: Mo T.

description:
Take me under the sea! the inside decor is so fun!

I ordered the sashimi for appetizer and filet for dinner. The steak came with roasted garlic cloves with a hash brown type potato. i often relive this meal in my head.

only complaint is the noise level on a saturday night. very hard to hear anyone!

Dessert: Made in house: Mint chocolate chip ice cream + brownie was amazing. It was like eating fresh mint leaves. If you want to just indulge, come here for dessert only. you won't be disappointed!
author: Kailey O.

description: Fully enjoyed the tasting menu! Can't remember much of what I ate, but remember that it was all delicious!  Great service, comfortable/ welcoming environment.
author: Michele L.

description:
Hubby and I just had a disappointingly mediocre dinner elsewhere in honor of our anniversary, and decided to walk around Union Square in search of dessert.  We popped into Farallon on a whim and were so glad we did!  We sat ourselves at the bar and had the nicest time sharing a delicious s'mores sundae, and sipping on absolutely inspired cocktails by bartending maestro Jaime.  The man is a genius when it comes to mixing drinks.  Do yourself a favor - go to Farallon and put yourself in Jaime's hands.  He will make you something to delight you, and when you ask him what it's called, he'll probably tell you he doesn't really have a name for it.  But it'll be so good, you won't even care.  

Hint: Ask him for his spiced pear cocktail-truly unique and truly delicious.  But then again, he might have no idea what you are talking about because when I asked him what this amazing concoction was called, he answered with a shrug, "spiced pear cocktail?" Give it a go, let me know what you think!
author: Cindy W.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for almost 20 years and just went to Farallon for the first time. It will not be my last! 

It truly is like walking into a fantasy underwater world, extravagantly but tastefully decorated and set in a historic building with gorgeous mosaic vaulted ceilings. (We read that the vaulted room used to house the swimming pool of the old Elk's Club.) The setting alone is worth seeing, almost like dining inside a Gaudi building.

The food was absolutely every bit as good as a special evening out should be. We had the shrimp cocktail as a starter -- amazing sauce. For entrees, the branzino and the halibut, both creatively and perfectly prepared with imaginative flavor pairings. Fantastic wine list, including half-bottles, which we appreciated having available since we started with cocktails and didn't feel the need for a whole bottle. As for value, I've absolutely spent more for inferior meals in San Francisco. 

The one thing I would critique, although not enough to remove stars (since it was hopefully a one-off experience), was the service. Our server was strangely off with the timing, so our food arrived before we had a chance to select a wine. Kind of annoying to have our food in front of us and unable to eat if we wanted to wait for our wine to arrive. Fortunately, we didn't have to wait for too long. It seemed like he was either new to the restaurant or new to waiting tables. Strange for an upscale restaurant.

I just found out they have happy hours at the bar there.  Looking forward to an excuse to come back.
author: Leigh A.

description: Great happy hour from 3-6 daily. We had a half dozen oysters for $6 as well as a charcuterie plate for $6. Both were good. The oysters were so fresh! They also have drinks discounted for $6. It's a cool little place. Not everything on the charcuterie is delicious  but it's still a decent deal.
author: Andrea K.

description: This restaurant is top notch. The professional and warm service, amazing food, and spectacular ambiance all make Farallon one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Lynn G.

description:
We had an outstanding meal at Farallon, superb seafood and good wine. However the entire experience was nearly ruined by the extraordinarily poor service, all due to one extremely rude and pompous waiter. When asked for reasonable wine suggestions in the $70 or less range, the waiter recommended a large bottle serving 8, which would have cost $480 had we been foolish enough to listen to him. He tried to tell us that a type of wine we were looking for was only used for blending. He returned several times to "answer any questions" and try to rush us into ordering before we were ready. After choosing two reasonable bottles--one red and one white--which we asked him to open and leave on the table so each could pour what he or she wanted with whatever course he or she wanted it with, he said "No Miss, that's my job" and removed the two bottles to the other end of the table, pouring too fast and heavily and completely inappropriately, again, rushing us and clearly trying to encourage us to buy more wine. At the end of the meal he told us that the restaurant did not have any herbal teas, but could serve us chamomile, he insisted that chamomile was not an herbal tea (?) in a brusque and superior fashion. The final, unforgivable offense was that our check was brought to the table...without requesting it. It has been so long since this happened to us at any restaurant above the level of fast food, that our jaws dropped. 

Truly, for a dinner for 7 costing nearly $100 per person, we should have received friendly, competent service, rather than the egregiously rude treatment we did receive.

The stunningly poor service is truly the only reason for the low rating. I wish it were possible to rate separate aspects of the experience separately, because the food was truly excellent. The Branzino, the gnocchi with chevre-based sauce, and other items were all well prepared. The oysters were delicious. 

In addition, the decor at Farallon's is wonderful! There are glass jellyfish fixtures hanging from the ceiling, tiled floors in the rest rooms, lamps formed like sea urchins, furnishings which looked like Ariel herself would have been at home there. For this reason alone, it's worth a visit.
author: Ann S.

description: I spent the past Valentine with my bf here. We had a reservation at 9:30pm, but due to traffic we were late for one hour. And we were so happy that they still let us in, and even though we were the last couple that day, they were waiting patiently for us to finish. We took their Valentine's special with wine pairings, plus a small seafood platter. The ahi tuna poke was my favourite, it was so delicious. The seafood were all fresh, I loved the oysters and the crab meat. The snapper was also great. Not only their food was good, but also the staffs, the ambience and design of the restaurant took the whole dining experience to a top level. It is a restaurant that I will definitely go back again (:
author: Shirley X.

description: Went to Farallon sometime last year with my family. The food was very good but everything took 20-30 minutes to reach our table with plenty of wine refills during the wait. First you wait 45 minutes from placing your order till food begins to arrive, then another 20 minutes for the next item and so on. Very expensive place; I think the bill was something like eight hundred dollars for six adults and my then four year old niece; but hey! nothing's too good for my sister in law's birthday! and they can afford it so why not I guess! I can't even remember what we ordered or what I ate anymore but I remember the food was quite good though and the decor of the restaurant was very interesting, it had like an aquatic theme. I felt like I was in Gotham City or something, pretty cool!
author: David A.

description: This is the worst service I have received in my trip to San Francisco. We came with 2 more friends because the place had been highly recommended. My husband and I asked the testing menu. It took a total of 2 hours and 10 minutes for all the plates. By the time the next plate would come we were full, the food came cold and it took forever. The waiter forgot my husband's wine. When we expressed concern about each food taking too long the waiter said it took long because the lamb was well done. All plates were delayed. Horrible service. Bottom line, very disappointing experience.
author: Vivi M.

description: Had a dinner at Farallon with a relatively large group (8 people). The interior decor looked great and was a nice fit for a place focused on seafood. They have an excellent and large wine list here and I was able to enjoy one of the best Rieslings that I've ever had. They also are great for cocktails. The quality of the food was great. Scallops were perfectly cooked/seared and full of flavor. Service was very good: the staff were attentive and were able to answer any of the questions people had. Fish was excellent here. They have great desert options including a smores sundae.
author: Matthew S.

description: I try to eat here a couple times a year with customers. Last night I was a bit disappointed.  The service was slow and inattentive.  The menu was mostly prefixed and the ala carte side was limited.  Food was good but all the above tarnished my experience.
author: Tim M.

description:
A celebratory dinner for a close friend. Our first time,  we arrived early on a Friday night around 8. Waited at the bar while enjoying a glass of wine  ($12.50) seated quickly we ordered and our first course was ahi tuna tartare ($13) and seared dayboat scallop ($23)..tasty and beautiful we moved to the entrees
.I had the seared Halibut  ($33) and she had the oven roasted trout ($35)..a side of fettuccine was ordered at the recommendation of our server..it was tasty..overall a $250 evening. .a little pricey..but it WAS a celebration : )
author: Mike P.

description: After reading so many great reviews on this place I was some what let down. The interior of this place is beautiful. Staff was friendly service was slow even after we asked them to pick up the pace. Almost every item yelped about it no longer in the menu. Our dishes were good but nothing to rave about. Not sure if we will be back
author: Jacquelyn L.

description:
One Star for the service, they seem to really care and are well trained.

One Star for the environment, it is very welcoming and cool. Somewhat retro. 

The menu and dishes get No Stars, just about the most uninviting imaginable, and retro in the worst way..  My party spent a few hundred dollars, and then ended up having its dinner elsewhere.  It's simply that bad.  If it was 1962, I might be impressed, or fooled.
author: All T.

description: The quality was good this time, not superb as usual. The grand seafood plate seemed not as tasty as usual and the oysters were so-so on a Thursday evening.
author: Jade L.

description: The bread, butter and salt (Hawaiian cave) were amazing!  The Atlantic oysters were not too bad either. But, I'm not sure what all the rave is about.  Our entrees (main lobster and tuna) were just okay.  The servers are not interested in creating an experience, in fact, they contribute to the feeling of "stuffiness".  $212.13 later, I'm not that impressed.
author: F H.

description:
Best happy hour in San Francisco.

$7 for each item including a 'slider' that is larger than most restaurant burgers.  You get two very large sliders on the best hand made patty I have ever seen (almost an inch thick).  You get a large mound of fries... and only $7.  Insane!

The candied walnuts are amazing, the crab dip is perfect.

The place is very class and in a wonderful location very near Union Square!!!
author: Edward H.

description: The menu posted outside the restaurant stated happy hour starts at 4:30 p.m. I waited until 4:40 and knocked in the window and the host stated they open at 5:30. He say me and another person standing there waiting and didn't take any initiative to tell us this.
author: Robert P.

description:
Don't go here for dinner... go here to Dine!  First, the ambiance is completely unique.  The history of the space, coupled with the whimsical and fantastic nautical themes and decor are magnificant. 

This is a true 3 course Fine Dining experience which could easily be expanded to 5 by adding fresh shell fish starter and dessert.  Although we did order from it, the restaurant also boasts an outstanding wine list full of the possibility for sumptuous food and wine pairings.  There was a Chef's Pairing Prix Fixe multiple course offering that looked amazing.

All of the items we enjoyed during our dining experience were both delicious on the palate and beautiful examples of 'food as art' presentation that were visually impecable and emotive. 

Just go.  Its expensive.  Its worth every penny.  The ambiance.  The service.   The menu.  The presentation.  And the food... the food is amazing... its transcendent of 'a great meal'... this experience cannot be recreated.  Brilliant!
author: Bryan W.

description: I loved the decor.the food was decent. Do u want to impress a date take them here. The place has a very upscale feel to it
author: Cara L.

description:
My boyfriend and I stopped by Farallon to check out their happy hour, which is every day from 4:30 to 7:00 p.m. each day in the bar area.  We grabbed a seat on the cushioned benches and were pretty quickly greeted.  We were given water a few minutes later and then put in our orders:

-Hemingway daiquiri ($6): my boyfriend and I just wanted to try out one drink and we wanted to just share.  The waiter was nice enough to split it into two glasses for us.  This was a pretty tasty drink with plenty of flavors (but not the typical super sweet syrupy flavor of most daiquiri's we imagine).  

-Beef sliders ($6): two small sliders and a fair portion of fries.  It's not enough for a meal, but definitely a nice snack.  The sliders were topped with some arugula and a nice creamy aioli.  The bun was very soft and a bit sweet.  As my boyfriend put it, the fries resembled in-n-out fries (just simple potato slices) and were pretty tasty.  

-Half a dozen Drake's Bay Oysters ($6):  I don't usually eat oysters, but I believe this is considered to be quite a deal.  I think that usually they are about $3.50 each.  The oysters were nicely plated on a giant plate of ice and served with a couple of lemon wedges and some vinegar mignonette.  The oysters seemed fresh and I didn't gag (as I have in the past when attempting to eat oysters).  Honestly, I don't have much to say because oysters just aren't really for me.  But the table next to us seemed to like them a lot.  After finishing their first dozen, they ordered another dozen.  

Overall, this seems like a nice bar to have a drink and get away from the bustle of Union Square.  The staff is pretty helpful and the place is "pretty" to look at.  They have some jellyfish lighting fixtures and some nice metal (wrought iron?) accents throughout the restaurant/stairways.  It seems like happy hour is a good deal if you like oysters, otherwise it's so-so.  I think I prefer Morton's happy hour (which is next door).
author: Samantha L.

description: We made reservations to celebrate a "special occasion". We were seated next to a family with 2 rambunctious kids & the restroom.  The waiter never checked on us. Food was ok( at best) the drinks arrived way after our entree . The best part of my meal were the olives in my drink. Such high expectations & high disappointment.
author: Laura I.

description: $300 check for average food and terrible service.  Living off the name only at this point.
author: Alex I.

description: The food I had was pretty delicious however it is very expensive for seafood. I had the abalone starter which was delicious. For my meal I had the curry scallops which were incredible. I tried the lobster which was good but I'm not a huge lobster fan so I can't say if it was better than most. Dessert was the panna cotta which I normally love but this one was nothing special. I expected the service to be a lot more on point then it was based on all the other reviews. Our waiter seemed irritated with us the whole time so that was a letdown. Based on all the incredible restaurants in SF I probably will not go back to Farallon.
author: Angie C.

description:
I've had a love affair with Farallon for over 10 years, I find I'm still in love, but hoping for a bit more. In last week, we had decent service from the waiter (although I wish they'd ask if we need something when there's a natural break in the conversation, versus when someone is in the middle of speaking). The cocktails are still frou frou, the dessert even more, and while I'm not sure it's entirely fair to judge the restaurant based on one night's menu, I wasn't overly inspired by the last menu we saw. The food was good, it just didn't seem up to the ideas/previous experiences I'd had at Farallon. We'll give it another try in a month, and see how it goes then.

I will say this though. The rye whiskey ice cream that came with the carrot cake should be an item all by it's lonesome on the menu. We ordered 4 different desserts, and that ice cream was by FAR the best of the 4. 

Farallon - what's up with the 2% only milk? After dropping over $300 on dinner, I've love to have a non fat cappuccino, and in a city no stranger to food allergies, it can't be too much to ask for non fat milk in the house. I love you just the same, though. :)
author: Maria C.

description: I stopped at Farallon while on vacation in the Bay Area! I just love the knowledgeable staff. I enjoyed the service and felt overwhelmingly welcomed. I had three different types of oysters, they were incredible. I'm not typically a fan but the server helped pick out the least brine of the whole lot. Dinner was spectAcular! I ordered a yellowtail dish, while my partner ordered the halibut. The fish was incredibly fresh, and I felt like a responsible consumer as the majority of their fish is caught under sustainable fishing practices. The ambience is lovely, the under the sea theme reminds me of one of my favorite Disney movies. If you're in sf, do yourself a favor and     Dine here, you'd be doing yourself a favor! Cheers! The only down side is that I spent a pretty penny, but I believe it was worth every last bite.
author: Cee T.

description:
I've been to Farallon twice. The food is awesome. The food I've had:

Raw oysters - I love their selection of oysters. Also, both times I have gone with their recommendations of oysters to try and both times I have been very happy with what I ate.

Duck Breast dish, and the Scallop dish -- ahh I wish I could remember the names of the dishes or what was exactly in them because the menu has since changed. However, i was impressed with how delicious their duck was, considering this place is typically known for their seafood. It was the #2 best duck I've had in the city (Jardiniere being number one). The scallop entree I had was the best scallops I've ever had anywhere. The entire dish from start to finish was great.

The only reason why Farallon doesn't get a 5 star is because of our service the second time I was there. Our server was not engaging at all with my table and didn't even explain what our amuse bouche was. He just plopped it onto our table and walked away. Luckily the other staff were super nice and sort of made up for his laziness and rude mannerisms, but still put a damper on the night.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Fantastic experience. I got reservations for 4 on Open Table the previous day, did the tasting menu, prices were steep but not ridiculous, great food and service. We parked in the Union Square parking lot. Highly recommend going here for a fancy-ish occasion.
author: Sonia V.

description:
Love this place especially for happy hour. Glass of champagne $6 and sliders (come with crispy shoe string fries) $6, yes please. 

The decor is pretty unique and fun. 

Bartenders are very nice and chatty.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Don't sit at the Jellyfish Bar.  You'll want everything that you see them preparing.  Especially the ginormous lobster plate.  Seriously, don't do it.

The Happy Hour food and drinks were $6 before 7PM.  The small Drake's Bay Oysters (half dozen) were like slurping salt water and couldn't be masked by the lemon or champagne mignonette.  The Littleneck Clams were ginormous - almost as big as the small oysters, but the chorizo was a bit hard.  The accompanying toasted levain (sourdough) was great for soaking up the delicious clam juices.  (There's also salad, truffled fries, potato croquettes, sliders, and ham on Happy Hour.)

The Caipirinha wasn't too sweet and had some undissolved crystal sugar at the bottom, which I loved.  The Hemingway Daiquiri tasted good and fruity from my brief sip.  We topped off the night with Hungarian Sparking Wine, which was FAB-U-LOUS, as always.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Great spot, if you have not been here yet - go.
Intriguing Interior, Delicious food.
Good date spot or whatever spot.
Prices reasonable for an expensive restaurant.
An SF must.
author: Misa A.

description: Visiting from Scotland so just popped in for drinks and happy hour nibbles a few times, great service, nice spacious bar area. The sliders and parmesan truffle fries were great accompaniment to our wine and beer. Good for a relaxing drink before heading out
author: Laura M.

description:
So after reading such great reviews I wanted to try this place.  My reservation was for 7PM on a Tuesday night and waited 10 minutes for my table, so that was a first strike.  Then I was seated with a waiter that was less then friendly.  The only thing I got to try were the Oysters.  My waiter was less then attentive, so I asked for the check and was on my way...

Needless to say I will not be returning....Over priced food and bad attitude wait staff is not worth the time.
author: Christine B.

description:
Wanting to go to a nice seafood dinner in SF our concierge recommended to go to this restaurant. I wasn't so sure what to expect but everyone we asked confirmed that it was going to be good. 

We arrived on time and our table was ready just a few minutes later. We walked in and I was very impressed with the the dinning area. The decor and the layout was different than other places. It definitely had a nice feel and great ambiance. Our waiter was super nice and helpful. My boyfriend wanted oysters for himself so he ordered half dozen. Two each of 3 different kinds. Drakes bay, blue points and olympias. I ordered the Cornmeal Crusted Monterey Bay Calamari for an appetizer.  Just the perfect amount if time later they arrived. My calamari was really good. Not too greasy although it was fried. It was perfectly done and the sauce that was underneath was called green goddess emulsion. It was garlicky and different than any other tomato based sauce I've had. The dish also had small peppers and a nice slice of artichoke. The artichoke was a nice balance with the friedness. 

For our main course my boyfriend ordered the Roasted Karlonas Farms Quail and I ordered the Steamed Alaskian Halibut. I asked if there was any way they could grill the Halibut instead and they did! I was very happy that they did and it was just perfect. My halibut came on a bed of porcini spaetzle which is made in house and just delicious. There was a little more in the plate that I feel was needed because it's so rich in flavor but too much is better than too little. It also had artichokes that were prepared perfectly and added a nice fresh event  along with the arugula. Also,it had maitake mushrooms with the arugula. Nice touch. Everything came together and was just delicious. I personally am not a fan of quail. Haven't really tried it and don't really care to order it. My boyfriend has me try a bite and it was scrumptious. Cooked perfectly, flavors were on point and the presentation was good  

It was my birthday so my lovely boyfriend requested to bring out a dessert and knew I wanted the carrot cake so he requested the that instead of the standard chocolate or whatever it is. They brought it out with happy birthday written and a candle. First bite. Show stopper. Light, fluffy and moist. My experience with carrot cake is typically heavy and thick but this was done just right. Right enough that we ate the entire thing. I'm not a dessert person so that's saying a lot coming from me! 

Overall. Great place. Not a super high fine dining place but just as good as other fine dinning places and the price points really are fair. We are from the LA area so we are used to paying maybe around $300-$400 for a type of meal like that. Also considering since we each got 2-3 drinks each!  Our final bill was $184 before tip. NOT bad!
author: Ida A.

description: I meant to review right away but made sure to give this place the credit they deserve! Let's start with the service!! The waiter did not only strive to be perfect but was. He knew the menu and wines forward & back and was spot on with his recommendations from the oyster bar. I went with 4 family members so I ended up trying at least a bite of 3 appetizers, 5 entrees & 2 desserts and every single one was delicious! Dress nice, bring the wallet, and enjoy everything this restaurant has to offer! Would go back no questions asked
author: Kevin K.

description:
Best meal we've ever had. I ordered the Hemingway daiquiri, cornmeal crusted local calamari and cast iron roasted Maryland striped bass. He had the Maine lobster salad and the grilled Hawaiian tombo tuna. The waiter brought out fresh bread with a thick square of butter, sprinkled lightly with "volcanic sea salt" (amazing...). Let's start with the appetizers:

Calamari: green goddess emulsion was so flavorful. The calamari was fresh and the cornmeal coating was perfect - light, crunchy, and well seasoned. The balsamic roasted artichoke heart was so tender, even the stem was edible! Incredible flavor composition and very aesthetically pleasing.

Lobster salad: holy cow. The sweetest, freshest lobster I've ever had the pleasure of eating. The scallop and prawn sausage was so darn good, and definitely had the consistency of a *soft* sausage. Farro was well cooked and the cioppolini puree was great.

Tuna: melt in your mouth seared tuna, with just the most delicately marinated miso mushrooms. Best mushrooms I've ever had, they picked up the flavor of the miso broth so well. Amazing.

Bass: I don't know how they do it, but the outside was potato chip crispy, while the inside was soft, moist, flakey, and tender. The pearl onions gave a nice sweet crunch and the sunchokes were flavorful and chewy.

Hemingway daiquiri: Fallaron can definitely make a drink. This is a must have when we come back. Tasty, tart, and easy to sip. The daiquiri came in a martini glass and was accompanied by a petite cherry (at least that's what it looked like, I didn't eat it).

We were so impressed with our appetizers and entrees that we absolutely were dead set on trying their dessert menu. Here's what we had:

Espresso Sambuca: like an espresso laced black liquorice fire shooting down your throat. Not for the faint of heart. We both enjoyed this one.

Carrot cake: beautifully creamy frosting, moist and thick carrot cake. Small dollop of vanilla ice cream. This was the winner of the desert round!

Ice cream sundae: crispy crunchy peanuts on a bed of vanilla ice cream, lightly drizzled with fudge. The fudge was the best part, in my opinion.

Total bill was $150 for two. The wait staff were very kind and polite, but we felt like the timing was off between the appetizers, entrees, and desserts. All in all, a wonderful meal, we'll definitely come back.
author: Chris O.

description:
FOR PRIVATE PARTY ONLY

Booking the event: very easy. Alanna and Lisa are pretty responsive and accessible.

Venue:
 They have 3 private rooms on the 4th floor of the neighboring hotel. It's pretty old school, cosy and warm colored. Unfortunately, it's not as classy as I thought it would be from the photos of the main restaurant. The paintings on the walls are kind of corny cartoony. Ceilings are pretty high though and overall it was fun to move around the whole floor because we rented all 3 rooms out

Food:
Not sure how great the food is for normal dinners, but the private dinner was really underwhelming. Maybe it's because we had a group of 100+, but the food was cold and the Bass was SUPER dry :(. Sad because I had high hopes. 

Service:
Really good. We had a reception and open bar. The waiters made sure that no glass was left empty ;)
author: Cheri K.

description:
If it would not have been for the cold and snooty hostess, our dinner at Farallon would have been enchanting. 

THE HOSTESS:
Four women who arrived on time separately. One similar experience of cold treatment by the hostess.  I arrived first on time for our reservation. The hostess at the door "greeted" me without any eye contact, no smile, no "Hello" or "Good evening."  She handed me over to a server like a piece of unwanted Christmas fruitcake.

One of my gf arrived next and she looked her up and down. Our two other friends received the same cold-shoulder reception.

We are a group of appropriately dressed young professional women with nice manners to match.

Her demeanor would have set tone for the evening if not for the great service we received.

THE SERVERS:
Our main server was a delight!  Very professional, genuinely friendly and patient.  The busperson was the same as well as the rest of the service team.  He gave my friend a complimentary drink after her drink spilled a couple of drops.  

We received a second order of complimentary amuse bouche when he thought our order was taking a little bit too long. He made sure that my vegan friend got vegan amuse bouche and entree.

UNDER THE SEA:
Decor is "Under the Sea".  I do not know how to exactly describe it but if not for it being in SF and given the fine dining status of Farallon, it would have been on the gaudy side. However, Farallon pulled it off. It was classy despite the "coral-inspired gray spiky" ceiling mimicking being "under the sea". However, the open kitchen, elegant leather booths and white linens gave the restaurant an elegant look and feel.


SENIOR SET:
My friends and I are no longer in our 20s but we do look young. We felt like students in our Catholic school days -- being surrounded by a much older crowd in their 50s, 60s and up --and  were expected to behave, be seen but not heard.

At first the ambiance was stuffy and we were afraid to make any noise. Luckily the restaurant got noisy as it got crowded and we felt more comfortable to celebrate the holidays.

ATTIRE:
Everywhere we looked were debonair grandpas and elegantly-dressed grandmas. 

We were here our our annual girls' holiday party and luckily we were nicely dressed. Attire is definitely business-casual. 

DRINKS:
I  only had one cocktail which was the  "Diabolita". It was well-crafted, delicious and strong. Too strong that I could not drink another one. Between my 3 friends, they had NINE cocktails including La Paloma. I had a sip of their drinks which  were good but not the best I've had. 

FOOD:
2 complimentary amuse bouche of salmon tartare and phyllo triangles and  1 vegan soup

2 Winter Salads (14 each) which were just simple greens.

STUFFED MONTEREY SQUID ($15) roasted maitake mushrooms, petite frisee
*My friend and I shared this. Our server was nice enough to serve this to us on 2 separate plates. We got 2 stuffed squids each and they were delicious!  This was a better value than the small winter salad.

OVEN ROASTED ALASKAN TRUE COD (29.5) dungeness crab, linguisa,  kale 
*My main dish. The skin was perfectly crispy while the fish itself was fresh. Overall it was salty and was one dimensional in flavors although not in texture. It was good but not memorable.

My friends had the AHI TUNA (29), STEAK (36.5) AND SCALLOPS (28).

We were given a complimentary dessert of fruit gelatins which were very yummy. We skipped dessert but ordered an expresso and latte.

Our final check was $400. 

PARTING WORDS:
I believe that every staff of an establishment is the face and representative of that business. Either re-train your hostess whose function is to put every patron at ease or replace her with a friendlier face with a kind personality to match.

Businesses do not gain anything by being arrogant or unapproachable. As much as I found the food at Farallon to be just fine but not exquisite, the impressive service and nice ambiance would have been an incentive for me to return with my partner and other friends. 

However, I do not want to experience again nor subject my loved ones to the same cold treatment we received from the hostess. Nobody wants to feel like they were being looked down upon most especially if you are dropping hundreds of dollars for a meal.  It makes the mind wonder: is it because we are young, women of color, or we are just not cool enough?  

Lady, we are cool. Too cool for your attitude that we did not let you ruin our evening. 

It was still  a lovely dinner and cheers to those who made it possible -- our server and those who assisted him.
author: Foodie F.

description:
What an unexpected enjoyment.

Came here for restaurant week with the hubby. Hubby got the restaurant week tasting (which included wine pairings).

Beet salad with Chardonnay: super tasty and not puny. 4.5 stars

Tuna with pancetta and potatoes (and Pinot noir?): SOOO good, 5 stars

Black bass: very tasty but a little salty, 4 stars

Marscapone mousse with basil: amazing flavor combination, very elegant and unexpected. 5 stars

Our waiter was very easy to talk to and very helpful. While the portions weren't huge, they were appropriate. Might be a little hungry 2 hours later.

We will definitely come back.
author: Hazel J.

description:
Pros:
Good ambience
Good to show off that you can afford this place

Cons:
Average food & OK drinks
Price definitely not worth the food

Tried scallops, salmon; I was so disappointed that we didn't even order deserts
author: Madhuri S.

description:
I've been here more times than I'd care to think about over the years. The interior never gets old, it's like a Little Mermaid underwater fantasy but a little more adult-style. Everything about the decor here is custom made, unique, expensive, with a touch of baby boomer sensibility. The food has been consistently top notch. Service is professional and San Francisco quirky, although not always the warmest or most reassuring, it depends who you get.

Nothing I've said before prepares you for

... wait for it ...

Dollar oyster happy hour!  That's right, seven days a week, long hours, and they do not skimp with lesser quality oysters, these are the ones that would go for $2.50 to $3.00 each. Delicious, great preparation.

The other happy hour items are equally good, sliders, bar snacks. Their $5 happy hour wine is actually a decent name-brand Napa or Sonoma varietal.

Pre-theater, after work, or just hanging out, they've got you covered. Or if you want a more complete dinner experience, you can have that in the back.
author: Gil S.

description:
I wish I could tell you that the most expensive meal of my life was the best meal of my life.  Sadly the meal will only be memorable for the price. That's not to say the place is bad in fact I think this place is quite good and has many positive aspects to it. 

Starting with the ambiance this place is gorgeous, a bit like little mermaid meets Ritz Carlton.  Really an amazing space, our seat by the open kitchen was awesome and we enjoyed the din of the staff and the chef as they prepared the orders.  For some strange reason this place has a dump for a bathroom.  For as much money as was lifted from my wallet at this place I want to be transported when I tinkle.

Onto the wine; wow what a list.  Our server pointed out his favorite $200+ bottles of wine that I am sure he's not actually drinking, although he seemed quite knowledgeable about them and he's likely making a grip serving an overpriced experience to tourists like myself.  When I asked for him to point out a less egregiously priced bottle we settled on a 2009 Beaune which I thought was fantastic even at $100.00.

The food was all over the map here, the prawn cocktail had 4 shrimp [not prawns] with heirloom grape tomatoes; sounds good; it wasn't.  Stuffed calamari was quite good and the pork belly with caviar lentils was excellent.  If your going to do a three course meal I would highly recommend just ordering three of these.  The lobster sounded good "Warm Half 2 lb Maine Lobster", try 3 ounces of slightly overcooked lobster on a bed of the coulis of the day I am guessing.  Desert was one of the best parts of the meal. 

The service was quite good, lots of teamwork and some friendly staff.  The chef was burly and regal as he masterfully controlled the kitchen. Our waiter seemed a little more busy than the other staff impressing the customers with his knowledge of pairings and such.   Lots of good stuff about this place but for the money there just needs to be more.
author: Leonard S.

description:
Absolutely perfect!! We were there for dinner on a Saturday night, despite the fact that we got there late, the service was absolutely perfect and we had an incredible time!! 

The food is excellent (I am French and pretty picky about food) everything was perfectly cooked and absolutely delicious. 

I highly recommend Farallon for a special occasion, these people definitely will make your time even more special. I can't say enough good things about it, we are definitely going back!!
author: Tristan M.

description:
First off, I just want to say I really enjoyed this place. From the waiting staff, to the food, to the decor.... It all just flowed extremely well.

I took my brother and his girlfriend out last night. I wanted to treat them to something nice. After a little research, I decided that Farallon it would be...

We took Bart in, and it wasn't too bad of a walk to get to the restaurant  from the station. Once we walked in, we were greeted by a nice hostess, and she checked our coats for us. (We are a younger group, and even though we are willing to spend money, we are sometimes overlooked or not treated with the same respect, so that was a major plus for me). We sat at a nice sized table with comfortable chairs. We ordered their smaller of the two chilled seafood platter as an appetizer. (About $70, but worth every penny). It was DELICIOUS. The oysters were fresh, the lobster was juicy and succulent... Not one bad thing to say about it. Then came the entrees..... Everyone tried a different fish, and we all shared a little with each other. Everything was cooked perfectly, with excellent texture/flavor. After all of that, we decided to go for some dessert cheese platter action.... Every cheese we had on the platter was excellent and plentiful. It came with nice warm bread, pear slices, dried apricots, and cranberry jelly to pair. Delicious.

Overall, we all really enjoyed the experience, and look forward to going back. Great food, great decor, and most importantly..... A great night out.
author: Zach C.

description:
Paddlefish caviar. It was so rich and decadent, it will haunt my dreams...

The lobster was incredible...of the trio of sauces the avocado mousse was my favorite. 

Chocolate tart for dessert with sassafras ice cream, banana jam, and pretzels. Seemingly these things would be harmonious, but none of it was complimentary. Everything else was too good to care about this lackluster dessert. Plus a spiked coffee with caramelized sugar. 

Excellent service, great lighting and ambiance.
author: Jane R.

description: Very unique and pleasant experience here.The jellyfish decoration really adds to the atmosphere making it fun and classy at the same time. We went there for their happy hour and the oysters were top notch. We also go the stuffed squid with mushroom sauce and it was one of the best dishes I've ever had. The only thing was service was a bit slow for us and I felt that the happy hour area didn't exactly feel like a bar nor a restaurant. So I was a bit confused by the happy hour atmosphere. Overall, great food though and highly recommend the stuffed squid.
author: Chloe Y.

description:
My boyfriend's family took me here for a post-holiday dinner, which worked out for me since I love seafood. However, this place was a little too bougie for me, but every once in a while a girl's gotta get her fancy pants on. ;)

Is it just me, or are their decorations a little tacky? There's a ton of fake sea shells, coral, and star fish plastered on every wall and column.

What I ate:

1. APPETIZER: Dozen oysters on the half shell
I wish I knew which kind they were! Yummy, but I'd rather have my oysters from Hog Island.

2. APPETIZER: Chilled  1/2 Local Dungeness Crab
Delicious! Wish there was more meat.

3. FIRST COURSE: Local Dungeness Crab Salad
Absolutely delicious with the heirloom beets, but I was surprised that there weren't more greens for the "salad". It's literally just a pile of crab meat (which isn't bad at all anyways).

4. SECOND COURSE: Perigold Black Truffles
The chestnut risotto is to die for, and the truffles weren't too overpowering, so overall a very well-balanced flavorful dish. However, it's a little heavy, so I was a bit too full for my third course.

5. THIRD COURSE: Seared Australian Barramundi
This was my favorite dish by far, and I wish I skipped second course just so that I could enjoy this course more than I already did. The butternut squash added the perfect warmth to the dish, and the fish was delicious as well.

6. DESSERT: Pear Sorbet
Freaking. Delicious.

If you make reservations, make sure to request a table in the main dining hall. We were seated on the second level balcony right by a serving station, which took away from the dining experience in my opinion. I hear there's a jellyfish chandelier in the main dining hall.
author: Denise B.

description:
Seriously the fanciest happy hour I've ever been to. My friend really wanted $1 oysters for happy hour and we came across this place from a list of restaurants we found on the internet. We didn't know much about the place but when we arrived we were like uh... O.O is this the right place?!? The restaurant decor and environment is super nice and we were definitely not expecting that. 

They serve oysters by the half dozen but it's pretty much $1 per oyster. They don't have much variety in their drinks list for happy hour, just a couple cocktails and a beer. Each happy hour dish is $6 and the dishes all sounded super tasty and I was thinking to myself like "Wow for such a fancy restaurant, they have pretty good pricing on their happy hour dishes!"

My friend and I ordered 2 dozen of oysters, the sliders, the potato croquettes, and a couple drinks. The oysters were really fresh and yummy. I'd definitely come back if I had an oyster craving. The potato croquettes and sliders were also really good, but what bugged me was that the servings were TINY. So I guess it really wasn't a great of a happy hour deal as I thought it was. So..do not come here hungry for happy hour! 

I also don't recommend coming with a large group, I'd say come with maybe a group of 2-3 because there is very limited seating and the tables and bar area is not that big.
author: Ann N.

description:
My girlfriend took me here for my birthday. After reading the reviews I think a lot of people complaining here on this website are just cheap!!! 

This has been the coolest place I have ever eaten. I decided since it was my birthday we would try a variety of things. 

We started off with getting a half of a lobster with 6 oysters randomly suggested by the server. I have never tried lobster and I wanted to experience it at a nice restaurant. The lobster and the oysters were served cold, and they were served on an ice tray. 

The oysters and the lobster came with a variety of sauces and spices, which complimented the oysters and lobsters nicely. I can say however I would have enjoyed the crab better, however the lobster was really well done, and fresh. All the tools came to crack the lobster and get all the meat out. 

My girlfriend had the clam and seafood stew, with bread. It came out sizzling hot, and everything tasted fresh and wonderful experience eating. 

Afterwords I ordered the fettucini pasta and it was nicely arranged on the plate. Everything was beautiful and nicely decorated.  

What made the restaurant stand out was the ambiance of the place. We sat in the booth. It looked like we were under water. It wasn't done in a cheesy restaurant style way like on the fisherman's warf. My favorite part was the artwork on the walls, and the jellyfish as lights, each one being different. 

The bread was made fresh and delivered with butter and everything was delicious. We had the best seat in the house. 

The waitress was really friendly and positive, and knew what we would like, and offered suggestions and had a good smile. She even took our picture with our camera. 

Afterwords we had dessert which was a white chocolate mousse, and some cake with some little eggs on top of the cake. 

The restaurant was expensive, however the prices for fresh fish and seafood are comparable to other restaurants i've eaten. I left full. 

I went to another seafood restaurant in San Francisco and paid $25 for a little square cube of fish. Here I got the full shabang and more!!! 

This made my birthday a wonderful surprise, I will recommend this place to my friends and family.
author: Daniel S.

description:
SO expensive, but worth every penny.

Scape up pennies al year or as long as you have to, to have at least one dinner here.

The experience is worth every penny.  I haven't had this level service since Chicago.

The food was great!  Not the most innovative, but what they deliver is a solid show.

The service is top notch.  We had a 4 course meal with drinks and dropped over 3 bills.

But we had 4 plate servings, with a small army of people looking after us.  

I can not recommend thi place enough. 

We walked in with no reservations and were treated like royalty.

Thank you Farallon for a most memorable evening!
author: Spanky M.

description: Horrible service. Horrible food. Decent wine. I will never go there again. Our waiter spilled wine from our expensive bottle all over our table and drenched one of our friends. The waiter also broke  a wine glass on the table. He did not apologize but simply said that if he wine where red, he would offer to buy a new shirt. The food also left much to be desired. Portions were tiny and fish dishes were dry. Everything was too expensive for the quality of the food, or lack-thereof. The only saving grace was the wine and wine selection from the Sommelier, Luke. He was the only person who was truly service-oriented. I suggest that  this restaurant better-train its service staff, and review their policies with them because the restaurant is clearly exposing itself to legal liability!
author: G G.

description:
I came with high expectations. More fool
Me. 

We ordered the risotto and red lettuce salad. The risotto was too wet. It ended up looking like a soup rather than a risotto. It was ok. These lad was the best thing I ate that evening. 

We ordered the bass and tuna main. The bass was a huge let down. There was no component bringing the dish together. Everything was just bland and dull. The potatoes were under seasoned, the linguisa was over cooked, the soup had no place on this dish. 

The Tuna was cooked well. But again, felt like a random assortment of items on the dish. 

An overpriced, over rated restaurant. The star goes to our server who was lovely.
author: Jay S.

description: Loved the interior design! So unique and fabulous! Food was delicious and dessert was phenomenal! Service was excellent and I couldn't have better company :-) I've only been here once but I would love to visit again!  I recommend!
author: Michelle C.

description:
We had eaten here once before and remembered it as not being too bad so we tried it again. We had a small group of 6 of us for dinner before a show last evening. Things starts off alright but soon went down hill. Our server was obviously a novice. Tried to be very formal in his presentations but lacked any real warmth or authenticity to make us feel very welcome. In his haste he managed to spill my wine all over me and break the glass in the process. It was white wine. He told me that if it had been red he would have had to buy me a new shirt. I was still left soaking wet. And big deal, he wanted to just give me another glass of wine
The food then arrived. We ordered mostly the sable fish and one order of crab and clam cioppino.  The portion sizes were tiny. I ended up eating more bread than fish to try to satisfy my appetite.  The flavor profiles were disappointing especially coming from such an upscale restaurant specializing in fish. 
We were all very disappointed in the food which was not very good for the high prices they charge and which left you still hungry. Service was very disappointing. I would say to those thinking of this place for a fish dinner to skip it!  Save a lot of money and find somewhere else to eat. Hopefully where you walk away satisfied and full.
author: Marty F.

description:
I've been to this restaurant about five times, and each time I was very pleased. This time around, we had a flight of Canadian oysters, twenty in all. Most of them were great, but the ones that weren't were the oyster's fault, not Farallon's.

The sommelier listened to my questions about their wine selection and then helped me to select a gorgeous 2006 Chassagne Montrachet. The first bottle smelled of cork taint, which the sommelier readily confirmed and graciously replaced. The second bottle was perfect. He continued to provide helpful comments and feedback throughout our meal.

My second course was the baby beet salad -- I can never turn down a beet salad -- which was really quite good. My third course was a pan-seared striped bass, which was cooked absolutely perfectly.
author: Cory K.

description:
Stopped by for happy hour and was not disappointed. We had oysters, truffle french fries, wild mushroom streudel, Hemingway Daquiris and bubbles, all off the hh menu. We finished with the triple chocolate budino. The french fries were a standout for us - thin cut with just the right amount of truffle. The streudel was also delicious, I just wish there had been more than 5 bites. The drinks were great and the bartender never let our glasses get to empty. 

The atmosphere was wonderful. We sat at the jellyfish bar - bubbles and icicles were also strung overhead. I love a good theme. It got super packed around 6, so get there by 5:30 if you want to guarantee a seat at the bar. 

Knocked a star off because I had to ask for the hh menu - only the regular menu was originally offered to me. That really bugged me for some reason.
author: Ariel H.

description:
We had the private dining room in the back for a friends bday. It was a weird set up given that you have to pass by our private dining room to go to the wine and back office. So we kept having random servers going in and out of our room. You can imagine how that's a bit uncomfortable and annoying considering we're paying a min to use that room. 

Anyhow let's move on to the food.
We order the seafood sampler for $130. 
The lobster was sweet, some shellfish were better than others, all in all it was ok. Would I order it again, prob not.
There was 12 of us so we all ordered a variety of dishes, given that my exp was meh, I will only highlight the 2 dishes that was good.

Soft shell crab- do it! 4/5
Corn cake dessert-omg, I can eat like 6 of them at once.5/5 seriously super yum yum!!!!
author: jasmin t.

description:
Overall good place. Tried it out due to the reviews and my partner loving seafood. While the food was tasty I thought the menu was a little limited. There were lots of flakier white fish but no salmon, swordfish, sea bass etc. Overall I was satisfied with the cod, just wish there were more options. The oysters were fantastic though. Good variety as well. 

What really made the night was the exceptional service we had. Our waiter was knowledgable and provided good service without being intrusive. Decor could use a little bit of a redo. Not horrible but felt a little dated. 

Last, this place has excellent cocktails and is a scotch lovers dream. The only place I can think of that I've been where the whiskey/scotch/bourbon list was longer than the wine list. They had some awesome and rare selections. A must see list for sure. 

Overall, would I go back....yes....but there are several other places I'd try out first before returning.....except for maybe a scotch or cocktail.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Food was good.
Had the seafood bisque, which was very smooth and perfect. So was the tuna sashimi, which was extremely fresh and soft, really high quality.

For main dishes we tried the halibut and surgeon. Both were good, but not as amazing as the appetizers!

Very much liked the decor and the set up of the place, nice theme!
author: I B.

description:
My husband wanted to go to Farallon for his birthday because he had always dreamed about having the large shellfish tray. He wanted to binge.    When I called for my reservation I asked him about the tray. It was after all 130. I wanted to find out if it was worth it. The woman I talked to a shirred me that it was enough for 5 people as an appetizer. There were shell fish crab shrimp lobster and so forth. When we got to the restaurant we again asked our server about it and he assured us that it was enough for an entree and perhaps a small salad for two people. Let's just say there wasn't. We were disappointed in the lack of opulence and after spending $130 on that went back to look at the menu to see what else we want to have.  

We both ordered the soup which was a seafood bisque. I thought it was a little too spicy, it really covered up the wonderful seafood flavor. But I did like the smokiness. They topped it off with a little bit of virgin olive oil and a cognac Chantilly which is just basically heavy cream and cognac and was a great touch.

I ordered the sautéed salmon with mashed potatoes and sautéed gypsy peppers.  The peppers were so spicy that they overwelmed the salmon (which was obviously farm raised).

The chef ask me how I liked it, & I told him about the peppers and he told me that the batches of peppers very on spiciness. It's hard to maintain the flavor because of that. The struck me as just wrong. If you can't maintain the flavor of the dish because of seasonal ingredients then you need to change the dish.

We did not order dessert because of the stream of the flavor combinations. There was nothing we recognized except for a somemore ice cream sundae and a peach sorbet. The desserts were complicated. I'm a pastry chef and instructor, and I've been doing it 30 years. I teach my students that in creating a pastry menu you need to push the envelope, but you also have to keep its familiar.    I wanted chocolate and creamy, my husband wanted custard, there was nothing recognizable as such.  Chocolate with cardamon and wafer...

Also wanted to mention that the salad dressing was all vinegar.  Very unbalanced.

I understand why Farallon does not have a star.  The attention to detail is lacking and they believe their on hype, which for a restaurant can be a serious mistake.  The chef needs to spend more time checking up on his food and staff then pacing in front of the show kitchen.  We will not be back
author: Stephanie G.

description:
One of my favorite spots to frequent for any special occasion!

The dining room features classic and whimsical underwater decor with the culinary team serving up Surf & Turf dishes from an open kitchen. 

Their menu is fresh and changes depending on what's available of course. Ironically, I almost always go for their Turf option (the steak) but will consistently order their Seafood Platter or at least a Dozen Oysters to start.

Don't skip on dessert! Depending on your celebration, the pastry team will also write on your dessert plate and add a candle as warm wishes.

Enjoy!
author: Cora M.

description: My favorite seafood restaurant in San Francisco. The sea bass almost melts in your mouth. The ambience is elegant, the service was attentive. Always a good experience.
author: Gogo A.

description:
In short, the food was a little disappointing because I expected more out of such a nice restaurant.  The reservations weren't easy and the service was good.  Everything was on point except the two fish dishes that were quite forgettable.  

The best part of the experience was the restaurant itself. Great decor and space with a lively crowd.  Unfortunately, I've had better food at much better prices.
author: David M.

description:
Was in the city and decided I was in the mood for good seafood. Chose Farallon's because it was close and had fabulous reviews all of which are deserved. 

I sat at the bar, started with happy hour $6 half dozen drake bay oysters ...yummy!! They were fresh and came with a delicious champagne mignonette sauce on the side which complimented and enhanced the oysters. I kept the sauce to use on my entree :) 

Second course was a heirloom salad with burrata mozzarella - $16. Tomatoes were fresh, great consistency not too soggy or overas is the case at many places. The mozzarella was fantastic, soft and gooey deliciousness! 

My third course was the Seared Patrale Sole with Yukon potota gnocchi, butternut squash and lobster consommé -$26. The fish was light, flaky and moist as it should be. Gnocchi was delicious, not a huge fan of butternut squash but it was better than I expected and the lobster consommé was epically delicious. 

I ended my meal with Valrhona triple chocolate budino - $10. The cake was moist and flour less for you gluten free peeps, the chocolate nib ice cream was creamy and complimented well. The chocolate pudding put it over the top in chocolateness for me but was to be expected when you order a dessert with the word triple in it. 

Over the meal was excellent and my total bill came out to around $68 with an ice tea and tax plus a 20% tip because service was excellent. There was never a dirty dish or empty glass which I was grateful for. 

I would come here again and try a few of their other items. And their happy hour menu is good if I had wanted to have a cheaper meal I could've easily done so but I decided to splurge and don't regret a single bite!
author: Rose S.

description:
Happy hour here was fantastic!

The staff was very accommodating for gluten free friend and it was just good... Classy yet not too expensive.

We came for the oyster happy hour - 4:30 to 7 apparently, though yelp said it didn't open until 5:30 pm.

We got: spinach dip with taro chips (usually a crostini type thing but we asked for gluten-free chips). We got two refills of the chips which was really nice!

Dozen Drake's Bay oysters - yum - mignonette was strong, just like I like it.

Parma truffled fries with aioli - so good; small and just well done enough.

Cocktails - Hemingway Daiquiri and margarita. Both great, not too sweet and strong.

$6 per item - for each drink, each food item.

Atmosphere is fun, jelly fish decor, though outside you wouldn't be able to tell.

I'll be back, Farallon!
author: Jen B.

description:
Very unfortunate experience with poor service. From start to finish, the hostess, wait staff and even the manager were haughty, inefficient, and flat out rude at a certain times.

Requested seating with hostess only to be bristled at and asked to wait...but no one else was there and there was an abundance of seats available. 

When it was obvious my party was only there for appetizers and not a full meal, the first waiter we were assigned just walked away from our table. We choose to move to the bar, and our wait staff there was not much better, having had to ask multiple times for items and even the managers who were constantly using the register positioned exactly next to our seats seemed to care less about our party, never asking once if things were ok. Very uptight and strange ambiance with cheesy decor. Odd experience entirely.

Also they have an advertisement out for happy hour served everyday, though it seems they have changed that policy to specific days. 

Spoke with manager post experience. He was kind but unhelpful and not terribly reassuring. Sadly it was my first poor dining experience in pretty much the greatest city in the U.S.
author: Peasy P.

description: Wow, my experience was disappointing! My husband and I made plans for The National Caviar Day special that Farallon was hosting Monday . We made reservations, had one for 8:45 pm. We sat down and when we ordered Caviar our server said they only had 2 kinds to choose from left. Of course I was disappointed as we chose to go here that night specifically for that, they advertised on FB they were having caviar for half off per ounce. They should have mentioned that the caviar was limited per supply , at least we would of knew prior to booking our later res at 8:45 pm. I did order the Ostera and was delicious, ok so we let it go. We ordered dinner, this gets worse. I got the Dungeness crab meat with Bone Marrow and side of bread to eat with, I get my Bone marrow, scoop my spoon in, the bone marrow was like cutting into cold butter and was truly disgusting!! The Crab meat was on top of it so I did not notice that it was hard underneath. It seems as they did not cook that marrow. I have had marrow many times and I was surprised that they would allow for this to come out of their kitchen. I SENT it back and our server who was great, totally understood. While my husband was picking on his meal they served me a small taste of soup to keep me occupied while they cook my food. We spoke with the manager and he said that we were not the only customers who have complained that evening. Why would he even say that, it made us feel worse by choosing this venue for our date night,  not a good sign for us , really made me lose confidence with the restaurant. I finally received my dinner 15 min later, it still was Awful!! I just sent it back and we ended our time with them. They did Comp us for our meal as I did Not have a Meal!! We have been here many times for over 8 years, this restaurant has gone Down Hill and will not be back again! It literally gave me a bad taste!!
author: Vivian C.

description: Was able to get in without reservations however the snooty host only allowed it after grueling us for a few minutes like it was a huge deal. Good quality was great although portion size was minuscule. Bread and wine selection also good. Waitress was polite and friendly as well, host could learn from her for a Saturday night.
author: Jason F.

description:
I totally did not expect this from the outside!!!!

So I have monthly leadership team meetings with my crew from work and I'm always looking for hot spots for dinner.  For the past few months I've passed because I'm trying to watch my girlish figure.  Since it looks like my muffin top isn't budging and dinner is on the company dime, I might as well indulge w/the rest of my folks.

I found Farallon...where else but YELP :)

The minute you walk in the decor is to DIE for.  It's dimly lit with sea creature fixtures hanging from the ceiling.  My crew and I sat upstairs in a semi-private area.  Hands down it was great because we had our own bathrooms up there :)

The service was IMPECCABLE!!!!!  We got tons of great recommendations and they were to the tee.  Our food came out with such ease and quickness.

The food was nothing less of IMMACULATE!!!! Before I knew it there were oysters, shrimp, halibut, steak, drinks, you name is going around the table.  

I had the time of my life!!!!!!!!!  

Words can't express so I'll let the pictures speak for themselves.

You've GOT TO TRY THIS PLACE :)

Damage for 7 people + a crap load of food = 1300 w/tip.
Thank God this was on the company :)
author: Sandra S.

description: Just gonna say this is a 5 because of the service.  Top notch seafood & decor.  Can't go wrong on business dinner or on a special date.  Worth every penny.
author: Kim H.

description:
Mu Husband and I had dinner there on New Years Eve. We are huge foodies and are in many Gourmet cooking groups. We had the 5 course wine tasting menu. This was the best meal we have ever had. From the crab truffled beet salad to the lobster tail in a celery root sauce.
Lynn and Steve Putman
author: Steve, Lynn And Kaitlyn P.

description:
we went back for New Year's Eve.

Dinner was really good.

We had two toddlers that were making so much noise that it was hard to enjoy the dinner.

Waiters said they talked to them, but it did not seam to help.
author: D L.

description:
Great place !!! Great atmosphere ! Had the grand appetizer . Was excellent. The ahi tuna was like butter. Service was excellent ! atmosphere was wonderful : )
They had a rabbit dish that was scrumptious.The only thing is the parking, they do have valet and we did not realize it till we parked in the Union square parking garage.  No biggy big, the walk was a breeze.
author: Cara L.

description: The Farallon is simply amazing. Probably the nicest/fanciest restaurant that I have ever been to. I came here for a special dinner and was blown away by the gorgeous interior and delicious food. I ordered mahi mahi with cauliflower and it was probably one of the best seafood dishes I have ever had. The oysters were fresh, and they had a great wine selection. My date thought that the portion sizes were small especially since this is a pricey place (we got out of there around $280 for the two of us), but it was just right for me. I am anxiously waiting for another special occasion to come along so I can go back there again.
