author: Kim V.

description:
20th anniversary. 

Great night...great staff. 

We are from ATL and loved that this was not a tourist spot. Lots of locals. 

Octopus was amazing!!!
author: Troy H.

description:
The only thing more exceptional than how excellent Farallon is...is how it's managed to be this way in one of the world's great restaurant cities, for a decade+. Truly remarkable. 

It has long been one of my 'go-to' places in the City. One year, I had VIP client come in for a Trade show, and took them there. Little did I know, they loved it so much...that they took THEIR clients there the next 2 following nights! And then told everyone else around the globe about it. Needless to say, I scored huge points on that one. Enough said.
author: Ken N.

description:
Very deceptive cancellation policy for parties more than 4. Beware, they will charge you $20 per person for any party larger than 4 for any cancellations that are made less than 2 full days in advance! 

This policy was not clearly laid out and is very unusual for a restaurant that should have no problem filling out seats in the city--they were completely inflexible despite my party having food sickness.  

They are not getting my business again.
author: Mike P.

description:
This is a mixed review for me. We had a dinner reservation but decided to go a little earlier to take advantage of the happy hour. The happy hour is fantastic. All of the HH dishes are $6 and decent portions, plus $1 oysters! The bar area servers were all really kind as well. 

After we were finished in the bar, they seated us for dinner. Here is where things became worse. Our waiter was not necessarily rude, but seemed very distant and not interested. The food was also sub par. They bring an amuse, but it wasn't anything memorable. The snapper dish was flavorful, but make sure you avoid the ono. The dish had absolutely no flavor. The fish was also first served WAY underdone and two of us had ordered it so we had to wait for them to recook it. This took a lifetime and everyone else at the table had finished their meals long before the ono was brought back. It was also clearly overcooked by this point and very dry. We were very unsatisfied by this dish.

For dessert, the black velvet cake is rich and pretty good, but wasn't enough to save the mistake from the entrees. So after some serious $$$ we left not very satisfied. If I were ever to go back, it would only be for happy hour. They definitely do a good job with that, although the menu selection is somewhat limited.
author: Kathy A.

description:
I will do my best to start with the positives:  great atmosphere. Good location. Terrific (but super pricey) fresh shellfish appetizer. Super fresh. We sat in the domed room which someone said was an old bathhouse. Beef tartare was great. 

Cons:  loud!  Like super loud!  Bisque...leave it. Is it possible to have tart bisque? Dessert...not special. Goat cheese cal was forgettable. Price was ridiculous. They say it's sister restaurant is the Waterbar, perhaps you can find a more memorable meal for $125 per head over there. It was simply forgettable and bland here.
author: Robert C.

description:
Ended up here on recommendation for a birthday in San Francisco. While the food was solid, service was acceptable, and wine selection excellent it lacked the star power/punch that it has had in previous visits.

For a restaurant that tries to e something special, I was left with this overall felling of being unsatisfied.

I have been to Farallon many times in the past and I am sure I will visit in the future.  I hope my future visits are more reflective of my historical dinning experience and not of my most recent visit.
author: Patrick T.

description: I was expecting so much more on my 2nd time here after the reviews.. The wine menu was great but the food was average at best. The staff was excellent but again the food was not what I would expect for such high rating. the veal sweetbreads was bland and not seasoned well. The bass was disappointing..:
author: Ben S.

description:
I love this place! My bf and I came here for date night on a Saturday for dinner. We were seated at a nice little booth upstairs where we were positioned side by side and looking at the decor of the restaurant. Our server was very helpful and attentive, we told him we had no idea what to order and he accommodated us very well. He suggested the 5-course dinner they were offering that night and explained to us that they were all perfect portioned and that we would not be in a food coma afterwards. My bf and I have a bad habit of ordering half the menu and half the appetizers. He also suggested the wine pairing that came as an option, we decided to go for it for and be civilized people for once. We also had already ordered cocktails and liquor beforehand... Bad idea. Haha. 

Sorry, I don't remember the exact names of the dishes but here goes..

First course - sashimi assortment with some ceviche. Yummy! It was very fresh. My bf is from out of state and land of the better sushi so he knows his stuff. 

Second- some kind of pea risotto with giant prawns. Delicious. 

Third- some kind of fried fish on top of a bed of snowpeas... YUM. 

Fourth- steak with veggies. (I had rare and it was delicious) whatever sauce they used for that steak.. I need it. 

Fifth- some kind of chocolate cake paired with dessert cognac. Yummy to the cake! 

In total there were 5 glasses of wine/cognac with the 5 courses. I am not at all a wine person but I think they went well with the food. My bf is also not a wine drinker, we just wanted to give it a try. By the end of the night, our tummies were filled just right. Wine made us sleepy so we just went straight back to our hotel and KO'd. All in all, great experience and the bill came out to be around $350 or so. Would come again!
author: Rosanna T.

description: Beautiful space with interesting history, but flavors were lacking, portions left us still hungry, and overpriced. Great service, but sad experience.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Oh Farallon. :)

So the boyfriend and I just felt like having a fine dining night one day, no special occasion or anything. I took a couple of hours to get ready for this and we were off! I made reservations for around 7:15pm on October 1st. We got there just in time and were quickly seated. Beautiful jelly fish decor filled the ceilings, I knew I was in the right place. I looked around near the bar (unbeknownst that it was the bar) and I felt a little overdressed... heading further back into the restaurant, I felt less overdressed.

My first course was the Happy Boy Farm heirloom tomatoes with petite opal basil, toasted almonds, mozzarella, cavedoni balsamic, second course was the Seared Georges Bank Diver scallop with sweet corn puree, duxelles stuffed squash blossom, marinated cherry tomatoes, third course was the chicken entree with black mission figs. (Not sure why the name isn't on the online menu) Teammate had the Chilled 1/2 Pound Maine Lobster with haas avocado mousse, salsa cruda, lemon aïoli, second course was the Seared Georges Bank Diver scallop with sweet corn puree, duxelles stuffed squash blossom, marinated cherry tomatoes also, and the third course was a steak with artichokes (name is also not on online menu). We were way too full for dessert so no dessert for us. :( Of course we also got the bread and butter as well as a complimentary cute little cup of soup. The little cup of soup even had a little dollop of truffle oil in the middle, mad good.

Our waiter was very attentive and nice. What a nice restaurant to spend a date night, I'll definitely be back.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Been here twice, but the second time was not quite as good as the first. My first experience here deserves 4.5 stars. Service was great. The shellfish bisque was amazing, and so was the scallop with tongue and cherries dish. Also got the steak with potatoes - these potatoes were the most delicious potatoes I've had in my life (they were mashed with cream fraiche)! The dessert (peach sorbet) was my least favorite part of the meal. I tried everything on their happy hour menu the second time I came here, and the only thing I enjoyed was the slider dish. The shellfish bisque tasted different from when ordered from happy hour menu... which could just be because it was the second time (however my partner and I both felt it tasted significantly different from the first). 

A great restaurant overall, with some super tasty menu items. I will definitely be back again, just not for happy hour.
author: J L.

description:
Great food A excellent presentation!  Cocktails amazing!  Waiter knew the menu with excellent explanation of everything from apps to desert!  Had the lobster with filet - excellent!  Desert was also excellent!  The decor and architecture is very classy!  Wine list is LONG!

One downer - $31.00 for truffles for our excellent desert!   The pricing for the menu was actually amazing - but 31 dollars for truffles was a bit of a surprise - all in all I can recommend it!
author: Paul A.

description: Yep... OK.; perhaps good but not great. Service was friendly & efficient; food was generally disappointing (given the high expectations).
author: Gary C.

description: I'd be suspicious of the 4-5 star reviews here. The prices are far above what the quality of the food offers. The service is solid, but they charge a San Francisco fee that can be as high as the tip!! They say it is to pockier their costs for insurance and health care for their employees. But, at times, this place is the only restaurant you can get in to. The price is so high that people trend to avoid them. We had dinner there because we were staying at the St. Francis Hotel and decided we could justify the cost by not taking Uber to Waterbar or Epic.
author: Average Guy R.

description:
The food was good, the decor was 80's and retro cool, and the service was fantastic. 

They print a new menu every day so no point in suggesting what to have, but both my wife and I were happy with our orders, as we were just walk ins and had no idea what to expect. 

Price was Ok for a big city resturant. My wife had a lovely soup and a glass of local wine and I had a starter (melon salad ) and a main (fish) with a whiskey & dry (strong) and it came to $87usd + tip.
author: Richard E.

description:
With Feb.14 about 3 weeks away I decided to start the V-day treatment a bit early by taking the GF to Farallon this week.
Trying to make reservations at Farallon about 3 weeks prior to V-day was a failure.
Making reservations @ 8PM 3 weeks prior to the day of = success!

We arrived at about 7:50PM and were informed that our table would be ready in 5mins.
I guess that's acceptable since we were a little early.
Unfortunately we were seated in the middle room hence our view was of the humongous column to one side and the bottom of the stairs to the other.
Next time I will note to make reservations in the big back room.

Our server, Layla (I may have mispelled her name) was fantastic.
She was very attentive, informative, energetic and very helpful!

The decor and ambiance of Farallon is very pleasing. Especially with the level of noise. 
It's always nice to be able to hear the person across the table from you without having to speak above others.

On to the evenings decision of food and wine!

This being our first time dining here, we decided to start the evening with caviar, oysters and white wine.
All per the selection of our server.
We ended up having the half a dozen oysters (2 of each: blue point, stingray and st.simon) and the 1/2oz caviar with all the accoutrements along with some French 
white wine that was a favorite of our server.
Never having tasted caviar before I didn't expect much. Nor did the GF and unfortunately she had a cold.
Overall it was an enjoyful experience for our first time.

Next up we ordered the Arugala salad and Beet salad.
Now those were some proper salads! Well done Farallon!
The GF and I make a pretty good Arugala salad so our expections were pretty high and Farallon delivered the goods!

Our 2nd course was lobster bisque and the butternut ravioli.
The bisque was more a lobster stock with olive oil.
Neither of us had a liking for it.
On the other hand the ravioli was inhaled!
Absolutely done right and delicious.

3rd course
Branzino for the GF, White Bass for me along with another glass of a different white wine per our server's recommendation.
Both fish dishes were amazingly tasteful.
Very complex in flavor yet not over powering to the point where it becomes over powering.
Although I am not a fan of the gnocchi that came with my white bass.

Desert: carrot cake and cappucino.
I usually opt for any type of chocolate, but I left it the GF to chose and I am glad she did.
The carrot cake was sweet to the right degree that it satiated my need for chocolate.
As for the cappucino, mmm mmmmm mmmmm.

Overall the dining experience at Farallon was very pleasing and enjoyful.
We look forward to dining there again.
OH! As for parking, paying the $12 for valet was well worth it.
I usually come out to the city about 3 times a week and hate having to try and find parking anywhere in SF.
So $12 for 2.5hrs of parking was well worth it.

As for the total bill of the evening. $257.84.
Still a hell of lot cheaper than dining at Alexander's on V-day.
Pretty much half the cost. Which we'll be spending it on next week at La Folie! = )
author: Paul U.

description:
This restaurant was recommended to me by one of my co-workers and I am so thankful I had a chance to visit.  I absolutely love seafood and everything was extremely fresh.  I had the halibut and my husband had sole.  We also ordered the risotto as a second course and it was delicious. All dishes were phenomenal and the presentation was excellent. Prior to our dinner, we were also given a small plate compliments of the chef. The ambiance is romantic, as you walk in, there are jellyfish decorations hanging from the ceiling and the pillars are shaped like shells.  Very elegant and detailed.  

Also, we headed up to SF a bit early as we were not 100% sure how the traffic would be on the bridge. The staff was able to accommodate us and get us seated right away. The service was pleasant and I would definitely bring friends and family here.
author: Sam M.

description:
Table of seven, generally mediocre food and terrible service, in a delightful (and convenient) venue. Sashimi appetizers were unimpressive. Salads, as usual, were not much to speak of. A tomato agnolotti was excellent - fresh, vibrant - but only one party ordered it. Fish entrees were all overcooked.

Perhaps we offended the waiter somehow, as he rarely checked our table and it's difficult to understand why so many separate fish dishes were all overcooked, when the waiter had specifically said they would be seared rare. The fish - the one thing this restaurant is known for - has never been so bad, in many visits.

One good thing about the restaurant was the venue. We had a beautiful seat by a roaring fire, one of the better seats I've had in the city recently.

I could give this place one star for ruining an evening with seven people, an evening that took a lot of planning. But the fact is, the tomato agnolotti was excellent, and the salmon entree, with the exception of  being overcooked, was well-prepared with good quality fish.
author: Hungry S.

description:
Work like a dog...eat like a king.  That seems to be the mantra of most of my friends nowadays.  Unfortunately I seem to share this mantra as well.

On the bright side of things, I have at least had the opportunity to try restaurants that I used to feel were way out of my league.  I remember when I was still in my training days, one of my supervising mentors was a self-proclaimed foodie and he basically told me not to even bother with Gary Danko or Farallon on my resident paycheck back in the day.  FFWD and now I've finally had the pleasure of enjoying both spots.

Gary Danko is probably my favorite all-around SF restaurant...but Farallon is really a good go-to if you are in the mood for some quality seafood.  When we recently went, we had Kumamoto oysters, lobster and fish.  All of these delicacies were super fresh and delicious.  Coupled with a comfortable under-the-sea theme, good drinks, tasty desserts and excellent service...and you have a gem of spot for a really great meal. Cheap?...no.  Worth it?...yeah. Bon appetit!
author: Justin L.

description:
Went here last night for drinks and the experience was one of the best I've ever had in SF. Even though they had been slammed all night by Dreamforce convention people you would never know by their positive and very upbeat personalities. Seriously the nicest bartenders (Mark and Freddy and Renee!) 

They make you feel like VIP ! Will definitely be back again soon.
author: Leslie S.

description:
I was here on with customers just last week. It was perfect for that... 
Wine selection very good, wait staff really wonderful and consistent. 

What i noticed, is that everyone in our party seemed to gravitate to the same menu selections...  appetizers were calamari or the halibut sashimi. I had the sashimi which was lovely.  For Entree I had a light Hawaiian fish (who's name escapes me) prepared as you would a tuna steak. Seared and rare... it was lovely.

I wasn't familiar with the specific wineries, but I found it interesting that as lovely and professional as the wait staff were, they were completely upside down on the wine recommendations. Meaning... where he said that the cab would be "meaty and heavy" it was actually light and fruity... lovely, but not as described. I was happier with the Russian River originating first "by the glass" I chose, which was the kind of "meaty" red I enjoy.

When each course arrived... a parade of well dressed staff set the plates down simultaneously... that was lovely.  Excellent dessert selection, although the one I chose had the poached pair featured in the description but arrived featuring the cheese tort with just a tiny garnish of the fruit. I did enjoy a lovely cappuccino that had a very thick froth which was completely separated from the espresso. Very well done. I usually enjoy my cap "bone dry" and had forgotten to mention that, but I was not disappointed.   

So all in all... lovely food, lovely service and no 'crimes' of note committed. ;)
author: Rosie S.

description:
Let's start with the food.  

Oysters were good but not as tasty as I have had at Hogs in SF.  Then I had the tasting of ahi tuna, which was disappointing.  They had three different (small) preparations and none were that good.  It was almost as plain vanilla as the appetizers at the Cosmopolitan in Soma.  

The entrees were all very good but not exceptional.   The seared black bass with pea sprouts and tempura spring onions was very tasty and the best of the entrees we tried.  I ordered the roasted striped bass with mushroom gnocchi, shiitake, and a porcini fondue.  Flavor was really good but it just didn't taste that refined.  Last we had the Dover scallops with lentils - again very good , just not amazing.   Our wines were fine. 

We really liked our server although were disappointed not to be in the main dining room.  At least we weren't in the front area near the bar.  But the first table we were seated at was very distracting as I could see the kitchen door swinging open every  few seconds, so we moved to a different table still in the area outside the main dining room.  Decorations are whimsical - personally I'm not a big fan of the decor but all my friends love it.  The restaurant is way too loud to be really romantic. Felt a bit like a family style restaurant.  The main dining room is darker so that's better than the other rooms which are far too brightly lit to be romantic.  

We had trouble parking and even getting to Union Square because of the Chinese New Year festivities and a number of streets were blocked off.  In fact Farallon wasn't even operating valet because Post Street itself  was blocked off, and you couldn't easily get to several of the Union Square garages.  But when we called ahead to say we would be running late (before our scheduled reservation time) the hostess was unaccommodating - she said they knew about the traffic and parking issues but would only hold our reservation for 15 minutes.  We rushed helter skelter to make it but it was not a great start to the evening.  

Overall, good restaurant but not what I would consider a 5 star dining or special occasion experience.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Food 3 stars. Service 4 stars. Value 3 stars.
Dungeness crab salad tasted fishy and not fresh.
Beef filet was tough and lacked flavor. Mushroom duxelle too salty and oily.
author: G L.

description: This place is amazing!!! Great wine and delicious seafood! The decor is very interesting and different and all of their food and seafood is fantastic. Their pastry/dessert chef is a James Beard award winner and the Nutella chocolate bar is like chocolate fudge hazelnut heaven! The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because our waiter wasn't very friendly and slightly standoff-ish, but otherwise this place is great
author: Dar O.

description:
probably a 4.5 stars. all of the dishes are top rate with the best ingredients. Just short of 5 because nothing was surprising but solid delicious food. Ambience was quite whimsical with undulating ceilings, reminding me of seaworld or aquarium a bit.

oysters are super fresh, good selection -- I personally really enjoyed beausoleil. Fois gras is delicious. Sturgeon was excellent.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Happy hour secret!!!  1/2 dozen oysters for $6!  Offered other items for $6 including some croquettes which were off the charts and a hearty bowl of lobster bisque-all delish.
This accompanied by a good friend and several glasses of Pinot Grigio-added up to an $80 bill total inclusive of tip-let me clarify-4 glasses of Pinot, 1 1/2 dozen oysters, croquettes and 2 bowls of lobster bisque-$80.
Happy hour ends at 7pm and that's when my visit did also as regular pricing kicks in and it is a bit high-but, I'm sure the quality is good.
Pretty décor.
author: K B.

description:
Being inside Farallon is like being transported into some fantasy world that is part the Little Mermaid and part something else (idk what yet), and there's no skimping on the decor: from jellyfish lights to the ornate ceilings. I've been here a few times and the food was always solid but not mind-blowing because I can't remember anything I ate, but just that it was good and fresh. 

The service is mostly great, but at times can be hit or miss. I was here on a dinner date (which we made a reservation for) and was seated at a table close to the kitchen area and under a bothersome glaringly bright light. We saw open tables and asked our waitress if we could move, but she said no rather curtly, and that they were reserved for other people. I'm not sure what that even meant, did guests call ahead and specify which table they wanted? Luckily another waitress dropped by and acknowledged the bright lamp, and said she noticed we looked uncomfortable. She promptly seated us at another table and became our server. Thank goodness, or else my date would have to stare at all my face pores illuminated by that stadium light throughout dinner. Our new server was very friendly and knowledgable about the food and ingredients. She even complimented me. I think I love her.

Anyways, SF has a lot of beautiful restaurants with great decor, but this is the one that always comes to mind . It is romantic and ideal for a special date. It is pricey but if you have some money to spare, Farallon's is sure to impress. It's a perfect union of solid food and ambiance.
author: Nan L.

description: This place is amazing! I've been here about 10 times now and I keep returning. The food and service is always excellent! Sometimes I go all out for date night or we just hit the happy hour bar. I'm always happy dining at Farallons and I enjoy their jellyfish decor. I just love their uniqueness without being cheesy. It's also great for all occasions! My family came to visit SF for the first time and I had to bring them here.
author: Dasa W.

description:
Loved it.  Except the sound.

Friends were visiting from New York and suggested we join them.  We were a party of 4 with reservations and were seating quickly.  The decor is super cool, as I understand it's an old bath house that was converted.  But the sound does weird things in there.  Somewhere near us, there was a rather tipsy woman with a horrible and loud LOUD laugh.  Due to the way sound travels in the restaurant, we could not figure out where it was coming from, but it sounded like it was right next to us.  It was so loud and distracting for so long, that we finally started talking about asking our server to ask the woman to please keep it down.  Eventually the party left (after about an hour).

Everything we tried was delicious.  Two of us had the lobster.  We all had dessert.  FANTASTIC!  Would go again!
author: Denise B.

description:
1. On vacation from Vegas to Fresno, Yosemite, then Sonoma and finally to San Francisco. En route, we located what we thought would be a great place to dine in the Union Square area. Clearly we knew parking would likely be problematic so there is no lowering here based on parking.

2. We enter the small, intimate restaurant, adjacent to another structure under renovation - still, just happy to be there. Hostess asks for reservations, we have none but says 1 of 3 small 2-person tables at the window is available so we 'bite.'

3. Waiter, seems normal at first. Menu is normal with a few neat items. Strange, no chowder dish. Not sure why. 

4. Problems really start with waiter number two/assistant, who hits my phone with the plates he sets down. It came out of the blue from my side and he did not warn me, then hit it, then said nothing. Not okay. But moments before he wiped right in front of me and my wife - without telling us he was reaching right in front of us. Strange. Simply say 'excuse me' or similar.

5. We order a recommended soup, white bass, and basically schnitzel or lightly-breaded pork chops, with water and iced tea.

6. The white bass was 4 bites in size - very minimal. The schnitzel was a normal portion size. The bass was okay. The pork was normal.

7. But before it arrives, we wait, and wait, and wait -- 45-50 minutes before we receive our main entree. To be fair, we did receive the soup after 15 minutes. So for 1/2 an hour, nothing, literally. No service, no bread with the soup, no water service. No ice tea refill.

8. Deep into the wait, maybe around 38-42 minute time frame, I got up and tracked down the waiter. He says literally the cook just said it coming out in 2 minutes - okay. At 50 minute mark, finally, we get service, and some ice tea and water refill.

9. Apparently bread is reserved for certain people. We were never provided/offered/suggested any but again, noting other reviews, it's a draw. 

10. Minor note - While only $78.04 - a lot for us but okay because it was special for my beautiful wife - I really didn't like the add 4% surcharge. 

11. I note from glancing at additional reviews that service problems seem to have similar complaints.
author: M D.

description: Okay just the ambiance walking in the door could give this a 5 star review but I could not do it last night. The customer service as always is great here, this was my 2nd time dining here. We started out great with the sommelier recommending a great Chardonnay Stony Hill 2009. We placed our orders and the 1st course was the lobster bisque. Now I have eaten lots of lobster bisque in my time but when my 11 yr old states that it is too salty there is a big problem. Of course he was right both my wife and I tasted the same thing it was way over salted hence my reason for not giving 5 stars. However the tasty bread and the 2nd course/ entree made up for the soup. We all had the Salmon and Sea Bass Pillows which were Phenomenal. Then we followed that up with the 3rd course/dessert, 2 of us had the strawberry shortcake and 1 had the blueberry cheesecake. Everyone enjoy the yummy desserts!  In the end we had a bump in the road with the bisque but Farallon more than made up for that misstep with the great entrees and desserts!
author: Dr. Scott C.

description:
Food: Average;
Service: Good;
Value for the dollar: Average.

Dinner on 30-NOV-2013.  Reservation honored, table available on time.  Reasonably good waiter: did a touch of up-sell - not too over the top.  A special request made at the start of the dinner was not forgotten but executed exactly as requested.

Cocktails were made promptly, correctly, and as requested. Prosecco served at a proper 45 degrees.  The star of the show was the busboy - water glasses full, bread replenished, not a crumb on the table cloth.  The busser came to our table actually more often than the waiter.  Good wine list - fairly over-priced, in my opinion, so we stayed with cocktails.

Food:
- Ahi Poke - fresh, well seasoned, a little heavy on the sesame oil.  
- Octopus with sweetbread hash was - the waiter did not know this dish and mis-characterized the hash - cannot comment on the taste of this dish as I did not try it.
- My petite fillet was a touch overdone, instead of medium rare it was medium.  Potato gratin that came with the steak was overdone and under-seasoned yet chanterelles were very nice. 
- My wife's agnolotti dish was OK
- Presentation of most dishes served to us was a bit on the sloppy side, with the exception of the Ahi, which was nicely presented.

Overall, not a "wow" by any means - still, a reasonable dinner.
###
author: A1 M.

description: Butter-drenched risotto and lobster roll. Tasted good but hard on the stomach. Sliders were not very good. Servers were good.
author: Sara L.

description:
Completely awesome mermaid palace experience. 
Food: Awesome. I had salmon, husband had sole, too much dressing on the mixed greens, but excellent poke- get the caviar with "traditional accompaniments"- yum!
Wine: very wide selection, very helpful sommelier, also a reasonable selection of cocktails, and a wide variety of scotch
Service: Natural, fluid. Our server was a little stuff, but the supporting staff (food runners etc) were very smooth.
Ambiance: We were there when there was a huge birthday party, so it was way too loud for me. As soon as the room emptied out a little, it was much better. They could probably afford to install some acoustic tiles in there.
Price: As expected, not cheap, but then we did have four courses, a bottle of wine and two cocktails (two people $250)

Bonus points for actually employing a pastry chef (interesting dessert! Recommend the sundae). 
Also bonus points for decorating my dessert plate with a happy birthday and presenting me with a birthday card from the staff (very sweet).
author: Meredith K.

description: You must open in Vancouver. One of my best experiences in my whole life. If you love sea food go there :)
author: Aalsheha Z.

description: I give it a 5 .. from the time we checked in for our reservation at 6 pm as we were hosted to our table. The restaurant is very elegant. The service was superb. Ambiance was awesome! The food was delectable!! We were treated like royalty & the attention to details were excellent! My husband & I celebrated our 8th year anniversary & we are going back!
author: Jo G.

description: Such a romantic and beautiful place. I have to say everything about this restaurant was just perfect. MY GOD! the lobster was amazing. I would go back just for the lobster.
author: Melanie P.

description:
Soft shell crab 8/10 - good flavor and seasoning, cooked and prepared perfectly

Tortellini 6/10 - perfect pasta but flavor was sweet and unappealing. 

Short rib - 7/10 - well executed but flavour of plate was a one sided and heavy. 

Chocolate Gonache - 9/10 - malt ball delicious
author: David S.

description: Great ambience, preparation, service. Great for family gatherings or business affair. Fresh seafood and oyster.
author: Eric L.

description:
While in Union Square in San Francisco you should make time for a  meal at Farallon. Make reservations and ask to be seated in the main dining room which features a high dome-shaped mosaic tiled ceiling which dates back to 1928.

I've dined here twice now and both encounters were outstanding.

The bar features a mixologist who puts new spins on old fashioned drinks.

Our service was impeccable, the food was supremely tasty, and our wines were a perfect match for our meals. The most notable wine we sampled was a 2011 Falanghina Marisa Cuomo Furore from the Amalfi Coast of Italy which reminded us of vanilla creme perfume with lavender.  Stellar white wine paired perfectly with our seafood.

I've said this in another review and I'll say it again. At a restaurant like Farallon patrons are not buying a quantity of food. An experience is what is for sale here highlighted by preparation with focus on  flavors that compliment each other, and ultimately,  presentation of culinary skill as art. 

We had the 6 pack sampler of oysters which varied in taste from mild to strong - all enjoyable.

I went with a 3 course meal to include lemon scented asparagus, warm dungeness crab on a bed of truffled Yukon gold potato puree & butter accompanied by a touch of alaskan salmon caviar. The crab dish was served in a real sea shell and the combination of flavors was superb.

For an entree I went with the grilled scallops which pretty much dissolved in my mouth, no chewing required. Likewise, my wife had seared Mediterranean Branzino which proved equally tender.

Dessert was a confection perfection milk chocolate hibiscus mousse which included a  dark chocolate-zinfandel ice cream and candied kumquats. Heaven.

An amazing meal. I highly recommend Farallon.
author: Steve P.

description: Very touristy. Cool interior but the food is lacking. Our server was very impatient and rude.
author: Joy A.

description: Great restaurant! My wife and I went to Farallon for dinner on the night of our wedding and it was great. The staff was so nice and really went above and beyond to make our dinner special. The food was prepared and plated perfectly. We'll definitely be going back some day.
author: Glen H.

description: Excellent food and service.  Made a same-day reservation via Opentable for 6:45 PM for 3.  Was seated right away upon arriving at the restaurant, in a cool semicircle booth.  Service was prompt.  The sommelier came over and introduced himself and offered any help if needed.  The food was superb.  Great atmosphere.  I highly recommend.
author: Rachel B.

description:
My girlfriend and I came here for the first time on Valentine's Day and we definitely left happy. It was a bit of a risk too, knowing my girlfriend was not the biggest seafood fan since she has never really been blown away by seafood meals. But she absolutely loved the food here and proclaimed it to be the best seafood she has tried. I have to agree, this was some top notch food. 

For parking, we actually parked in the structure for the Westfield Mall, and after hanging out around Powell and Union Square for a bit just walked over to the restaurant.

The ambiance here was great. We were seated upstairs so it was rather romantic, but the ocean theme of the restaurant makes the place feel fun and not overly romantic as well (thank you jellyfish lamps). Our service started off great, but I have to dock some points since by the end of the meal our service was rather slow and our waitress seemed stoic and unhappy. Maybe she got some bad news mid-meal...not sure.

We decided to stray away from the prix fixe menu, and ended up ordering a lot of food. But the portion sizes were perfect for us to be full enough by the end of dinner so that we did not want dessert, but were still able to walk and not feel bloated. As a starter we ordered the grand platter, which included some of the freshest raw shellfish I have tried. The lobster was very juicy and fresh, and came with a champagne dip that complimented it nicely. The oysters and shrimp were also amazingly fresh and delicious. The crab was probably my favorite, though as far as shellfish goes.

As an appetizer we ordered the truffle linguini. The pasta was well cooked and not too hard or too soft. The truffles were a wonderful compliment to the pasta and its garlic sauce, and overall the dish tasted buttery but not too salty. My girlfriend and I really enjoyed this dish, and found ourselves using our bread to soak up any remaining sauce on the plate.

Our entrees were the pan seared local petrale sole and the roasted Alaskan true cod. The sole came on top of a risotto and some melted leeks. The sole was perfectly cooked, crispy skin and a very light crisp on the top side of the fish, but soft, flaky and not too chewy otherwise. The risotto, though, was a little heavily salted and really needed the vegetables to be balanced out. The cod was also perfectly cooked like the sole, but had a weaker flavor overall than the sole did. However, the chowder that the cod rested on top of included some pancetta and corn, and complimented the fish a lot better than the risotto did with the sole. So overall, both dishes were delicious, and at this point I am just nitpicking. 

I only hope that the service is a little quicker next time, since our service was a bit slow. I definitely recommend Farallon to those who enjoy seafood and have some money to spend (the meal isn't exactly cheap but not unreasonable either).
author: Eric S.

description: This is an interesting place. The ambiance is reminiscent of a Little Mermaid meets Titanic movie set. The food was delicious! The upstairs dining experience was interesting as it makes the place feel small, but the ceiling downstairs is quite high. Overall, I had a great time/experience.
author: Michael G.

description: Service was fair and the food was very uninspiring.  There were two of us and we both have the same opinion. I've been before and have had a fantastic evening.
author: Todd A.

description:
After dining at restaurants at a dozen or so countries and many states, I can confidently state that this place has the slowest service I've ever experienced. The dinner took 3 hours and I left before they served the desert. 

Also, their $90 tasting menu is really - and I mean it - really tiny. We were joking of going to a McDonalds afterwards. Food was ok, but nothing spectacular at all. Quality and presentation was kinda what you expect at "a restaurant."

Finally, the service was also fairly inattentive, apart from being the slowest I've ever seen. People at  our table frequently had empty water glasses and one person had to ask for a glass a few times. And, no it was not a Saturday night or other super-busy time.

In general, a big waste of money and a much bigger waste of time.
author: Anton C.

description:
My first time here was truly disappointing, but that was my fault since I ordered the wrong items :(

The first time I tried the shellfish bisque here, I couldn't even finish it........
Ehmmm, I can still remember how it was like. :|  (thank goodness the lobster in the end saved the night)
The strange thing is...I had the bisque again, and it was a completely different experience. I actually enjoyed it this recent visit. (was it the alcohol?!)
I don't know if it was an off day, but anyway I'll skip the details and say I do like this place. The food isn't exactly stellar, but overall I'd visit again. 3.5.
author: Cha C.

description:
Three of us spent a night in San Francisco for a girls' getaway.  I live in the Bay Area but don't get out to dinner in SF very often. Since our hotel was near Union Square we decided to select a restaurant within walking distance. I selected Farallon based on the great reviews of the food and atmosphere.

The atmosphere is indeed lovely.  The light fixtures, finishes, and booth designs provide an elegant under-the-sea dining experience.  The restaurant was very busy and bustling even at a very early hour (our reservations were for 5:30).  Personally, I much prefer a busy location to a quiet, empty location.

The service was very prompt and attentive. Perhaps too attentive.  Our waiter offered a great deal of help and was very pleasant. However, I left feeling like we had been talked into more dishes than we needed to order.  We were advised that dishes were too small for sharing and subsequently ordered duplicates of a couple items. For three girls, we found that the dishes were excellent for sharing and ended up feeling very full by the end. 

The food itself was very good. Nothing mind-blowing but it was all yummy and beautifully presented. 

Overall we very much enjoyed our dining experience and I would recommend this restaurant to friends for this type of occasion or for a date night.
author: Elisabeth F.

description:
we went to this place because we stayed at a boutique hotel  in union square for our SF trip, this restaurant was right next to our hotel, beautiful decor, ocean themed, perfect for a seafood restaurant. 

we ordered cold shellfish, dungeness crab with amazing sauces, paired with  Robert Oatley Sauvignon Blanc, second course was pasta, since I am not a big fan of pasta, it was just OK for me, the third course was grilled jumbo gulf prawns with jasmine rice, it was sooo good. everything was very flavored , but not salty, just what I liked. 

service was over the top, our server was so much fun, tried to get into my photos a few times :P , until my bf said if you do that again, no good tips for u! hahaha 

it was a very delicious and fun dinner date! a little pricey, the portion is small, but its worth it to give it a try, especially you wanna impress a pretty lady :)
author: Mimi L.

description: Uncrowded Happy Hour place for $1 oysters and drinks until 6pm!  Pretty bar area, friendly servers, delicious fries...GET THE FRIES.
author: Janet L.

description:
The Setting:  Welcome dinner for a coworker, Monday 8pm, no res, waited 30 min.

The Vibe: 3 Stars - kind of reminds me of an upscale version of Little Mermaid.  The restaurant is actually deceptively large, opening up in the back with a lot of comfortable tables.  Crowd is older, dining early, as the restaurant was packed when we arrived but nearly empty when we got our entrees at 9pm.  This being in Union Square, it definitely has that "upscale yet touristy" vibe.

The Food:  3 Stars - Pretty much just OK all around.  The Grand Platter (one lobster tail, two crab legs, 6 shrimp) was pretty good (crab legs especially) but was pricey at $65.  The Striped Bass was good (white bean side was very tasty) but the arctic char was a letdown.  The cocktails (Manhattan, $17 and Pinot Noir, $17) were good but overpriced.

The Service:  3.5 Stars - The Tale of Two Servers....
During our wait for the table, we sat at a small lounge table and had a drink.  The lounge server took 15 minutes, was inexplicably snooty and kinda rude.  We were very confused.  However, once we sat down, our meal server was extremely friendly, knowledgeable, and prompt (although I didn't love the many attempts to upsell).

The Bottom Line:  A decent seafood place that is overpriced and a bit touristy ($110/person for two cocktails, splitting the platter, and an entree, no dessert).  Not many better seafood options in Union square but less expensive options within a mile walk.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Made last min reservations for Valentine's Day.

A 2-story restaurant with the affect of being "under the sea" with the decor of jellyfish lighting fixtures. Love the ambiance and the service was amazing. Complimentary bread/butter was served.

Ordered the following:
-Muscat Beaumes-de-Venise 2007 ($7)
-Cabernet ($12.50)
-Smoked salmon mousse with lemon oil and chives amuse: Cleansed the palate well. Delicate but not fishy.
-Star Route Farms Mixed Lettuces ($11): I liked the oranges and the pistachios that topped the salad. 
-Stuffed Local Calamari ($10): Wasn't a fan...
-Seared Mediterranean Branzino ($27): Never had Branzino but it was really good! Recommend if you like light seared/moist fish. 

5 course Tasting Menu ($90) included:
-Carpaccio de hand line caught Ahi Tuna: I'm a fan of carpaccio and the ahi tuna was fresh. 
-Mediterranean Shellfish Bisque: The bisque had the right flavor and was poured directly into the bowl at tableside.
-Seared Georges Bank Diver Scallops: I thought it was OK. My least fave of the 5 courses. 
-Creekstone Farms Filet of Beef: SO TENDER and flavorful!!! Surprised given it's a seafood restaurant. 
-White Chocolate Creme Brulee and Chocolate Ice Cream Sandwich Trio (mocha, raspberry swirl and cookies & creme): I didn't care for the WCCB, but the ice cream sandwich trio was to die for!!! A great way to top off a great dinner!

Totaled to about $210 with grat. Would def recommend if you're staying in Union Square and in search for a good seafood dinner.
author: Maria C.

description:
I arrived early and waited at the raw bar for my guest. In front of me were 3 guys preparing all the special seafood appetizers (clams, oysters, shrimp and raw tuna)  I started to notice that the guy handling the raw tuna had no gloves. He would handle the tuna, slice it put it on the plate and then use the phone and handle all sorts of other stuff without ever washing his hands. Worst of all he would pick up the scraps and pop them into his mouth! It almost made me sick watching him. 

Had I not seen this I would have rated the place a 4 or 5 star. The 'cooked" food I ordered was excellent and the wait staff and ambiance were all great.
author: George L.

description:
WOW!  I may now be broke, but what an experience.  
Our Waiter (I think his name is Tim) was phenomenal,  Always attentive, without being intrusive.  We never wanted for anything.  I left several of the menu decisions up to him and he never failed.  We had Oysters on the Half Shell, Soft Shelled Crab, SEARED MEDITERRANEAN BRANZINO, PANCETTA WRAPPED MARY'S CHICKEN BREAST, & two fabulous deserts. 
We spent over $400 for dinner for two, but we left VERY happy.
author: John C.

description:
I was here more for the jellyfish lamps than the food:) It's a beautiful place but the design of the room makes it a very loud dining experience. I could hear the guy that was 2 tables away!

The service was wonderful!

The wine we picked was St Clement 2008 merlot. So good. We took the recommendation from our server.

The food presentation is amazing though the portions for the price is quite tiny. My hubby was still hungry.

The oysters were delish!

Dessert was alright, I had the grape pie. Mom had a better choice, it was the sorbet with pear.
author: Spooky E.

description:
I had eaten here before for a business dinner and had a wonderful experience.  So, I brought my family back.

The food is amazing.  I had the Grilled Steelhead trout, asparagus noodle salad, and shrimp cocktail.     The food was creative, beautifully presented, and delicious.  The tab was the most we ever paid for a restaurant meal.

Unfortunately, I ended up getting a horrible bout of food poisoning in the middle of night.     My husband had a lighter case (he only had a small taste of my entree).     

I called the restaurant the next day to report it.  They politely said they'd notify the chef and their suppliers.     

Whether it was from the fish or food handling issue, it is hard to tell.   I don't think I'd go back.
author: Beth K.

description:
The dining room is really nice and original with a fun, underwater decor.
The service is impeccable. The wine selection is good and the sommelier is very helpful. Unfortunately, the dishes were very salty, and it sounded like the tables around were complaining about the same thing.
author: Mimi S.

description: Can't say enough good things about this place. the food was superb, the service was great, and decor is beautiful. Went here for dinner and got the scallops with snow peas for an appetizer. It was absolutely AMAZING, I would have been happy with this as an entree. For main course, I got the crab cioppino which was fantastic as well. The crowd here is great, not touristy, and the dining tables are booths which is great. May be one of my favorite restaurants of all time.
author: Sim H.

description: The BEST Meal I have ever had!  Try the 8 oz Filet Of Beef meal--Chili-garlic Broccoli Rub is amazing and the sourdough onion ring is out of this world good.
author: Ian H.

description:
Wonderful, wonderful place to dine. From the food to the ambiance to the staff, Farallon is just wonderful.

The decor of the restaurant is definitely unique. It resembles an underwater fantasy and the exquisite jellyfish hanging throughout the restaurant really help Farallon stand out. Even though the restaurant is not decorated in a modern style, Farallon exudes a classical feel and upon walking into Farallon, I was immediately immersed in a different world with the dim lighting and "shell-like" seating.

Farallon has amazing seafood. The baby softshell crab is a must-try and if you like risotto, you're going to love the sweet white corn risotto. The lobster, scallops and salmon are tasty but if you like meat, the quality of the filet of beef matches the quality of Farallon's seafood. Finally, for dessert, I personally prefer the panna cotta but I have heard that the lime sorbet and chocolate bites are scrumptious as well.

Definitely try Farallon if you get the chance! Every dish comes out beautifully plated and the staff at the restaurant are more than friendly and nice. Farallon can become a little loud at dinner because of the number of people who dine there/business meetings that take place there so be a little prepared for that! However, this should only show how popular the place is. :) Oh - Farallon is conveniently located around Union Square so definitely park under Union Square if you choose to forego valet.

I hope you enjoy Farallon as much as I do!
author: Erica J.

description: The food was as good as any upscale restaurant.  It was too noisy, and I think it has something to do with the beautiful tile ceilings.  There was also an extremely raucous table of either regulars, or off shift employees...they were a nuisance.  Our waitress who was nice, crossed the nice line right into overly familiar. I'm having a romantic and loud dinner with my husband, I don't want to hear about your life.  For the price, we expected better service, and the whole experience isn't worth it...but the food is good.
author: Sarai J.

description:
In short, spent a boat load of money only to be met with subpar food and a semi- pretentious server.  My lobster was rubbery, risotto was drowned in a thick cream sauce with no seasoning.  Cold seafood appetizer plate was just average- and for a birthday celebration- a "generous" dollop of creme with a few dots and swirls of chocolate syrup.  Really? C'mon Farallon...you're customers deserve better than that.  This dining experience was very disappointing and I felt greatly ripped off.  In my opinion, the taste and quality of the food is just not worth the price.

+1 is for the jellyfish/underwater theme and decor.
author: J C.

description:
Went in August for a couple of happy hour drinks before going to dinner at another establishment.  FIRST - our server Ellie was the best and very knowledgeable for only being there for a month.  She recommended the sliders, in which I was already going to order, nice.  

Three of us ended up having one Hemingway Daiquiri - very good, three Old Cuban drinks - extremely awesome.  One order of Truffled Kennebeck Fries - pretty good and one order of Sterling Beef Sliders (2 tiny burgers & fries) - hella good.  Mom asked a question and bam, we were on a tour of the restaurant (it was slow) --- Fun Fact: The restaurant is above the Elks Club pool from 1925 still in use. --One good earthquake and your going swimming. 

Hope you don't have a fear of jellyfish or empting out your wallet, it's worth it. 

Already placed reservations for a dinner in December before Christmas.
author: Eric H.

description:
Went here for to celebrate my dad's birthday. Nothing at all about our experience was really bad, but nothing really amazing enough to warrant the whopping bill at the end. The Yelp definition of "Meh. I've experienced better" seems pretty spot on.

Walking into the restaurant I felt transported to Disneyland. I don't mean that as a bad thing -- the underwater theme made the place feel fun, though maybe a little bit cheesy. We ordered an assortment of oysters, soft shell crab, tartare for starters; lobster, branzino, salmon, halibut, and bass for entrees. The soft shell crab was yummy but tiny, but again, nobody was really blown away by their entrees (and yes! we love seafood!). 

We did, however, really enjoy our desserts and the service was great. 

In all, we chose the restaurant for the convenient location to celebrate and chow down after the movies; we probably won't return.
author: natalie n.

description:
Meh was the food experience.  I love the interior of this restaurant.  Stunning decor.  Your really feel like you are under the sea.  It is fun to look around the restaurant and look at the cool lamps and mosaic ceiling. 

However, the food was very meh.  The restaurant was busy, but the food was just passable.  I started with the bisque and my boyfriend had the foie gras.  We both liked our starter, but he thought the accompaniments to the foie gras were unnecessary.  The other in out group had oysters which they enjoyed, but all of them seemed to be on the larger side which were not their preference, but were the smallest they had.

To finish we had the pork chop and the snapper.  Pork chop was on the dry side and snapper was well cooked but not so flavorful.  The gnocchi on the side was bland.


We had a fun meal here, but the food wasn't that great.
author: Katharine A.

description: I am struggling with this review. The restaurant was highly recommended. We had a reservation and were seated right away.The man I am assuming was the maitre de asked us what we wanted to drink. We told him water and we wanted to order wine, and asked for black napkins as we were wearing black. We waited quite some time for water. The sommelier, who was very knowledgeable, came over to tell us about the wines. We asked our waiter what he recommended and we did choose a couple of those. We chose the dry scallops and bone marrow with sea urchin apps. The dry scallops were sitting on something that looked and tasted like mud. Awful. The bread was not good, it was hard. They did something pretty with the butter, but the bread was so bad. For our main courses we chose scallops with green curry and sable fish. I liked the green curry dish a lot. It had a lovely bite to it, and the scallops were cooked to perfection, as well as the shrimp and sticky rice. The sablefish needed salt overall, but the items were cooked well. So the negatives to this restaurant was service. Why do we have to ask for water repeatedly? The whole napkin thing, they just handed us the black napkins. I've been in restaurants half as expensive that would automatically know if you are wearing black you need a black napkin and then place it in your lap. Then after I filled out the tip (generous) and wrote a note that we should not have to ask for water, and signed the $300 bill...the waiter picked it up! Service 101! Tacky. They apparently read the small note and started filling our water constantly. Awkward. The only person who spent 2 minutes with us was the sommelier, and on reflection, he could run a reality show called the jaded sommelier. The rest were distant, aloof, my daughter is reading over my shoulder and said snobby. As we were leaving there were a group of young people chatting at the hostess stand. They stopped ever so briefly to look at us, but said nothing. By comparison, other restaurants at every other meal we had besides Chinatown, which is a cultural difference, said 'thank you ladies' and 'have a great evening' etc.  I stopped and asked the young man up front who the manager was. I planned on maybe sending an email to tell him of our experience . Much to my surprise he said he was the manager. That actually made me quite angry. You turned and looked at me, and instead of saying 'Thank you for dining with us', you dismiss me? I gave him a bit of a what for. I wouldn't go back. I hate that that was our last meal on this trip to SF! If we wanted brusque service we could go to Chinatown and spend a fraction of what we spent here and had what we know is fabulous food. I do not recommend this place at all. I know my expectations were very high. The more I am spending the more I expect service wise. The three stars is food, so there you go.
author: Nancy P.

description: Terrible table where they put a chair in the aisle for the 5th person who had to stare at the other 4 of us and the wall behind our heads. I asked the maitre d if there weren't a booth or table for five in the main room. He said it depended on what time your reservation was! So we were the chumps who had possibly the worst table and not even in the pretty main room. The place was frayed and dirty! It needed a good power wash! Food so mediocre & overpriced it was pathetic. This place has seen its day and is running on empty. Totally overrated & disappointing.
author: Suzy O.

description:
As part of our honeymoon coastal drive southwards, our stop in San Francisco brought promises of Sourdough, Clam Chowder, and most importantly extremely fresh seafood. The concierge at our hotel around the corner suggested and then made reservations for us at Farallon stating that it was some of the best in the area and that we should not miss it. I am glad we did not.

Frankly, I'm confused by the negative reviews of this place. Was it pricey? Yes. Were the plates small? Yes, but not exceptionally so. Not unreasonably so. The plates were masterfully prepared and were like little works of art as far as I'm concerned. And this place had a lot to live up to. Only a couple days prior, we had dined at one of Seattle's finest, Altura, and it was quite literally the best meal of both my wife's and my life. This place took and easy second place for our entire trip and that's saying quite a lot. 

Now, we are foodies. We like food. We like eating food, we like talking food. We like everything about food. Our server (I think his name was Bill), was a real foodie too. We had a few questions about some of our dishes and he was so happy to indulge us. I'm pretty sure he went on for a full 2 minutes about where the tomatoes for the tomato salad came from and why they are so delicious. Now that might not be for everyone, but we were salivating with every word. So thanks Bill! You made it an extra special evening.

We started with some fresh local oysters, which I had never had before. Bill put me at ease and gave me some direction and made the whole experience much more enjoyable for me. They were delicious! What a great way to start things off. We continued with the Tomato salad, which was just as delicious as Bill described. And then moved on to the bisque. The bisque was the star of the whole night for me personally. It may have been the most decadent thing I have ever eaten--so rich, with such depth of flavor. Just incredible. My wife had salmon with an asian black bean sauce which was fantastic, cooked to perfection and I had Halibut, which was flaky and crispy and delicious. We finished the meal with chocolate mouse, goat cheese cheesecake, port and sherry which were paired to our desserts by the in-house somalier, which was a nice treat. They knew it was our honeymoon so they made it an extra special night for us. 

I honestly could not have asked for more out of my experience at Farallon and I hope to return one day soon. It was a pricey meal, for sure, but one that I will not soon forget.
author: Gabriel W.

description: First time try this restaurant, we order the seafood appetizer was so good,  will going back.
author: Bebe C.

description:
GREAT SERVICE, GREAT DRINKS AND GREAT DESSERT. Oh and everyone in my party wouldn't shut up about the food. So I kept my mouth closed -- didn't want to be the Debbie Downer of the group.

but

I ordered the Mushroom noodles which is usually right up my alley. The noodles were overcooked (yes I've had fresh pasta & yes I know I was in a seafood restaurant ordering a vegetarian dish), and the pasta was very cold. I know I could have/should have returned the dish, but that isn't my style. 

Had the Divers scallop dish. 1 scallop will set you back $30! for real?Although it was perfectly cooked, Julia Child showed me how to cook a perfect scallop; Thank you Julia!! I'll save my money next time, but a grip of butter and go to Whole Foods and have 10 scallops for that price!
author: Amber G.

description:
Returned to this restaurant on February 13th, our pre-Valentine's dinner. 

It was a terrific experience again! Service is great, food's incredibly delicious! The only minus is that on our  1st  visit they ran out of the lobster appetizer and the second time they didn't have the entree I wanted, so I had to choose different fish which was very yammi. It's just a little bit of inconvenience for the guest. 

Other than that, totally recommend for a speacial dinner!
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Had dinner here a few nights ago and thought both the food and service were excellent. 
We had the caviar to start - very fresh with a delicate flavour. I also had the melon salad which had interesting flavours (duck prosciutto) and the shaved ice added great texture.
I had the California bass which was a tad overcooked but very good all the same, and my husband had the salmon which was delicious.
The deserts were outstanding (chocolate budino and blueberry pie) and our sommelier recommended a wine that we thought went really well with our dinner.
Overall fantastic meal and wonderful ambiance in a great setting.
author: Miss M.

description:
half a star for the food and half a star for the decor. Service is negative stars. 

I came here for my graduation dinner with my parents and my boyfriend. My mom and I have been craving oysters and this place had a decent selection of oysters.  At first I was hesitant to book here because of the price range. My parents encouraged me to go for it since it was such a special occasion. 

Upon arriving the host completely butchers my name. I know it is Chinese, but can't you just call me by my last name if you really have no idea how to pronounce the first? Then he brings us to the wrong table because he obviously confused me with someone else. I say to myself, OK, bad start but the inside is pretty unique and ambiance seems right. 

After we were finally seated it took the waiter FOREVER to come by to serve us water. By that time we were ready to order and also hungry! He drops off the water, does not say a thing or make eye contact, and leaves.  It of course took another forever for him to come back to take our orders. My boyfriend hadn't arrived yet so my mom and I decided we would order two platters of oysters. One for us and one for when he is here.  The waiter was nice to give us recommendations but at the end I thought, why not have several of each kind and then order what we like the best for our second platter? Waiter was obviously NOT HAPPY that I rejected his idea and became very condescending all of a sudden and acted like we knew nothing about oysters. When he was taking the menu away my dad asked him to just leave one for when my boyfriend is here. It was so loud inside so my dad said it twice in case the waiter didn't hear. He turns to my dad and says in an annoyed tone, "I know, I have worked in this industry for many years." At that point I was like WTF! Wow, I couldn't believe the kind of service we were getting. Then the waiter walked away but he left like 4 menus on my boyfriend's seat. I mean, what were we going to do with all those menus? We said one and he left us 4! Unbelievable! 

The food was so so. One of the oysters tasted like soap. The fish was overcooked. Salad was meh. I was talking to my parents about the unbelievably bad service and my mom said, maybe he thinks we are the nouveau riche! Dinner is always fun with my parents and my boyfriend. But the Farallon is terrible and I am NEVER coming back.
author: Lutetia L.

description: Amazing food and service. The desserts were so delicious. We came here with friends and were treated very well by all if the staff.  We will be back.
author: Edna H.

description:
Farallon staff at the front desk were very cordial and my guest and I had a comfortable table. Our food was elegant and service friendly and attentive. This is a very pleasant restaurant in all respects. The impressive entrance into the "Jellyfish Lounge" is a nice touch with weird, jellyfish light fixtures; strange, but creative.

My only complaint is that our food portions were practically microscopic is size. I don't expect super-sized, Midwest diner portions in a upscale restaurant, but my delicious halibut main course was just a tease and should have been at least twice its tiny size. 

I started with the LAURA CHENEL CHEVRE TART which was good but not quite what I expected. My guest had the spinach salad which would have been a better choice and certainly more healthful than the somewhat too-rich tart. 

The halibut was served on a bed of lentils and there were small carrot pieces and a few snap peas on the plate, too. It was a very fine dish but gone after too few forkfuls.

I'd suggest ordering 3 courses as offered on the menu because unless you eat like a sparrow you'll leave here hungry. Would have been best if I'd added a pasta dish along with the other 2. Fortunately, a friendly person came by frequently to offer us bread which was fresh and much appreciated.

To summarize, Farallon is a fine restaurant and ideal for special occasions. Just bear in mind that while you'll receive great service and fine food, the portions are unusually small.
author: IQuack D.

description:
The Dish: I came for happy hour with a friend. We ordered a dozen of oysters, truffled fries, and 2 orders of the beef sliders. The oysters were delicious, but I wouldn't say it's the best I ever had. The truffled french fries on the other hand... we could not stop ourselves from eating more. It was seriously the best fries I've had. The beef sliders as well - they look tiny, but for some reason, so filling. The sauce inside the beef sliders is the same as the dip sauce for the truffled french fries, all of which are to die for. The Manhattan Martini is good as well.

Customer service, as well, is commendable. All in all, an incredible experience with quality food. Try it out (and if you're wallet is hurting a bit, just go for happy hour).
author: Gina T.

description:
We are repeat business customers for Farallon because of their exceptional service, superb execution of dishes and the restaurant ambiance.  We each ordered the Chef's Choice prix fixe.  This is a 5-course meal selected by the chef based upon your likes, dislikes and allergies, etc.  Each course is a surprise unless you want them to tell you ahead of time.  You have the option to order this with their wine pairing selection.  

If there was any menu selection that I would describe as "exquisite", this would be it.  These particular choices are expensive but together they are masterpieces!
author: Chary P.

description:
This place has overpriced food and poor service. I generally don't go to places near Union Square since they are tourist traps but I decided to give this place a try based on the reviews on yelp. We got there right before happy hour ended to get some drinks and appetizers while we waited for our table. The service was pretty poor as we couldn't get anyone to take our order. We were finally able to order one drink by hunting down a server before we missed out on the happy hour and it was okay. 

When we did sit down, we ordered food and it took them awhile to bring it out to us. Our waiter was also odd - something a bit off with her. When our food did arrive, it was definitely below average. It was bland and flavorless and so not worth the money. I had the ono with beans and the beans came out under cooked. Not sure if anyone has had under cooked beans but it is inedible. I could only eat the fish and didn't even eat that as it was under seasoned.  

I wouldn't recommend this place if you are looking for good food and getting your money's worth. There is way too many good restaurants in SF to come back here. I left hungry so ended up going to in N out!
author: Armina A.

description: We ate here for anniversary. Very nice atmosphere and ambience. Menu is a little hard to pinpoint exactly what you'd like. Overall it was a good meal. I would look at the menu online before you go as that's what is there.
author: Gayle S.

description:
Well cross this off the list for good. 

We've been coming here every year or two since the 1990's and clearly something has happened recently - and not for the better. Upon walking in, we both immediately noticed that the decor and clientele - even the hostess' attire - seemed shabbier than we'd remembered. 

Our waiter seemed to have no sense of pacing. He took forever to arrive, and then proceed to serve the rest of the meal at a breakneck pace. He also seemed to misunderstand many of our requests since he forgot to bring various items.

The food was nothing special which for the price is not appropriate. Perhaps the moment that crystallized the poor food and service was when one of the servers came by with the "bread." He all but threw these gigantic hunks of cold, hard bread onto our plates without asking if we even wanted bread. 

Farallon, it was real. But your day is over. We'll never be back.
author: Juniper N.

description:
Wow!  Amazing decor with more than a touch of whimsy (A MUST SEE!!).  

Great service, killer seafood. 

Nice winelist.  Had the 2009 Alsacian Pinot Blanc (Zind Humbrecht). $50 and highly recommended. Even the Californians were impressed!  

Our table was secluded.  For the first time all week, we could hear the other people at the table talk!

Nice, well-heeled crowd. Can't go wrong here... It will certainly be a memorable evening!!! A+++
author: Bob B.

description: Obviously the restaurant is beautiful,  and the food is excellent!  Our server David was great and he was really good with my daughter and brought her some special treats after dinner. I have a feeling that people who submitted negative reviews were jerks when they walked in and we're treated as such by the staff. We were treated nicely by everyone. .
author: Geoffrey G.

description:
You get what you pay for: delicious food, excellent service, and fantastic service!

I've been a regular at the Farallon for almost a year, and have never had a bad experience.

Their happy hour is amazing, you can't beat $6 half dozen oysters, truffle fries, sliders, and their great selection of happy hour drinks.

This is definitely a place I will be a regular in for years to come :)
author: M B.

description: Wonderful ambiance. Good for conversation. Great Service. But the food was not good.  Great Oysters. Great bread. Good wine list (for our limited tastes, anyway). Chef has a peculiar love of cinnamon, so the taste of the food was often weird.  Lovely  piece of Tombo tuna in a sauce wi cinnamon (?) .A pasta dish with leathery pasta and really tasty mushrooms, but oversalted and very dry, very little sauce of any kind.  Nice green salad, hardly any dressing.  Sorbets - meyer lemon that had the overwhelming bitter taste of too much pith, apple sorbet too much cinnamon, no apple taste, and pear sorbet with an actual pear taste and just the right amount of cinnamon.  We probably won't be going there again.
author: Alice F.

description:
Just went there yesterday for a friends birthday dinner. It was ok. The restaurant looks awesome inside, but the food I was not impressed especially for the price. I had the Alaskan steamed halibut not much flavor very blend I should have had the steak. Our waiter seemed bored with his job. Don't think I will come back there is a really great steak house couple doors down on same street. 
Farallons restaurant did not wow me had better food at cheap Chinese restaurants.
Was not impressed one of other members in our group also did not seem impressed with his selection. The desert was ok. Don't think I will be coming back not worth it and small portions I was still hungry after I left:(
author: Sergei Z.

description:
Yum!  Amazing Food!  Love the ambiance.  Looks like an old bath house.  I asked what the building used to be and it's actually the upstairs of a swimming pool house.  The pool is still there below.  

Great service.  Good simple food.  I had the Bass and it was perfect. Went well with my glass of Pinot.  I will definitely go back.
author: Nikki K.

description:
Go here if you want to purposely spend the most money possible on a meal. That's what we did because a friend from college was in town and we all wanted to celebrate the fact that we finally have money to spend and go to a fancy dinner.

Great shellfish and appetizer options, we got the cold seafood appetizer for about $60. But, I have to say, I was under impressed by my fish entree. I really expected the absolute best but I've had better.

The actual building is amazing and they will show you books and drawings on the history if you ask, which happens to be incredible as it was an old swimming pool once. The original ceilings are still standing and they have added some funky modern work-of-art lights for the restaurant.

Service was definitely high class but sort of made you nervous. That did not surprise me as most of the people eating there seemed the same way. I'd prefer to spend my money on something more modern, cutting edge, and down to earth.
author: Jessica V.

description:
Perhaps because it's not a brand new hot spot and doesn't take as long to get into as say, Frances or State Bird Provisions, the gem that is Farallon doesn't get the attention it deserves. Farallon is perfect for parents, out-of-town guests, or a night on the town with a date. Granted, downtown can be tedious at times, but I assure you it's easier and more "classic SF" than lining up in the Mission for the recent opening of what-have-you.

The decor is beautiful, the service is professional yet friendly, the food is fantastic, the drinks are delicious, and you might even get a little history lesson (did you know that Farallon sits in a building owned by the Elks that dates back to 1924 and that there's a full athletic facility and swimming pool underneath?). 

Okay, back to the food: start with the chilled 1/2 Dungeness crab with drawn butter, cocktail sauce, and aioli, or the kampachi sashimi. For mains, try the scallops or artic char. Note: they used to have this amazing salad with cantaloupe granita but it's not on the menu anymore. If you do happen to see it, get it!

Sure, maybe it's not breaking news on Eater SF, but it's a classic and worth visiting at least once, particularly for a special occasion.
author: K H.

description:
Love the jellyfish hanging from the ceiling!
We managed to get in on a Saturday night and sat at the bar which was great watching all the food be prepared! 
Tuna tartare was fab, scallop was lovely shame there was only one. The portions were not enormous so we easily managed 3 fish courses. Wine list good choice by the Boyle and the glass. Great service
author: Claire H.

description:
In September I had another excellent meal at Farallon. I am still shocked that there is such a great restaurant in such a touristy location!

Once again we had a notably friendly and personable waiter who really took the time to listen to us, and gave excellent recommendations. Everything we ate was amazing, but in particular I want to note the heirloom tomato appetizer that my husband ordered. They were artfully presented three different ways. I have always hated raw tomatoes but these were AMAZING. It was a revelation for me and I've been hunting down the best tomatoes at the farmer's market every week since then. Thanks, Farallon!
author: Lynae Z.

description:
Place looks great. Unfortunately it took 50 minutes to serve our starters.
We had a good squid  and a Kampachi sashimi that was pretty tasteless. Our server Austin was really good and tried to save the day but overall Farallon seems waaay overpriced.
author: Gordon G.

description:
@ $90 for a 5-Course Tasting Menu, I truly feel robbed.  I was absolutely stunned by the minuscule portions. As an example, the first course: 3 slivers of fish laid out side by side on a plate. Paper thin (roughly 1.5" X 1.5" X 0.1".)  The food was decent, but to serve 5 courses of mostly single bites of food was almost an insult to my intelligence.    Seriously?  Portion size - truly offensive.

The ambience is rather nice, however, watch out if you sit right by a pillar.  Just like at the Exploratorium, sound carries, and you can hear the conversation of the person on the opposite side of the room as if they were sitting right at your table with you.  It was so bad, I switched seats with my dining guest half way through the dinner so he could have a break and hear himself think.

I have been to many fine dining establishments and have had wonderful experiences.  Sadly, Farallon was an over-priced disappointment.
author: Todd F.

description:
I loved the dinner. We had to catch an early dinner before a flight - food was as stunning as expected, and the wine selection, even by the glass, impeccable. The service was GREAT, friendly and cheecky ;) (thanks Leila), and I just wish we had space/time for dessert! 
I plan to be back. Great fun, and beautiful place.
author: See B.

description:
Big date night for us, and we felt like having seafood (but not of the Japanese type).  Wine list was definitely more expensive than their menu items, so we ended up bringing our own bottle of bubbles for the reasonable $25 corkage fee.   Single glasses were about $15-20, and I didn't see a bottle under $40, so definitely bring your own.

We went on a Saturday night, but we didn't have any of the service problems that a lot of people seemed to have.  Yes, we got bread, and our waiter was very attentive, as were the rest of the staff.  Water glass never went empty, as did our champagne flutes.  In fact, one person apologized when I poured my own glass... I didn't know they had to do all refills, I'm a DIY kind of person :P  

Food was on par with what I expected.  Paddlefish caviar on the buckwheat blinis was good, but they put some magic in the drawn butter that made it addictive, I swear.  Pasta was fresh, his truffled fettucine was DELICIOUS.  The porcinis on mine were nicely cooked, not mushy, and were still a little meaty.  I had the sea bass for the entree, which was quite nice, but I was jealous of the hubby's lobster.  Best lobster I've ever had, no rubberiness at all.  The portions were just barely on the smaller side, but he was full, so it was probably just me.  

Decor was nice, I liked the faded frescoes, and the sea theme wasn't TOO overdone.  A little noisy, but eh, Saturday night.
author: Tamara A.

description: My wife made reservations 2 weeks ago for my 50th asked for a nice table they sat us late under a stair well. Got there at 6:45 for a 7:00 res and they went to seat us 2 times but obviously 2 different regulars came in and they took out seating twice.
