description: Perfect evening with a chef prepared meal. Tastings from the kitchen were the best treat while we waited for each course. The historical ambiance is well worth the price. The dinning room is in the old pool room in the basement of the old Elks Lodge number three. I enjoyed the historical aspects of the building and our waiter brought us a book to tell us more about where we were at. San Francisco gem.
author: April H.

description:
Virginia Woolf once wrote, "One cannot think well, love well, sleep well, if one has not dined well."

If that's true, my meal at Farallon tonight will leave me more intelligent, loving, and well-rested a human being.

Farallon does fish, wine, service and atmosphere to the nines.  It's doubtless the best seafood restaurant in San Francisco, boasting all the allure and charm of fine dining whilst retaining a light, playful air (a credit owing mainly to the brilliantly gaudy design concept and decor).  

I ordered the Mixed Baby Lettuces Salad with fresh peaches, parmesan, candied walnuts and a zesty vinaigrette.  It was very, very good.  I also had the mixed shellfish bisque, which had winning flavors and a superior texture.  I opted for the Grilled Pacific Spearhead with mussels, mushrooms and garlic-coconut sauce as my main.  The elements of this dish deserved the "plays well with others" award for their stellar behavior on my plate.  Dessert was a decadent fried cherry "pie" a la mode.  Need I say more?

I highly recommend treating your significant other to a meal at Farallon.  Or spoiling yourself with this significant treat of a restaurant.  Either way, you're guaranteed to leave satisfied and smiling.
author: Brendan S.

description: Wonderful Food !!! Perfect atmosphere for any special occasion. I and my bf recently went her for our 3 years aniversary.  The food was served not so long after seated. It's one of the best seafood restaurants we've ever been.  and of course some dining like this cost  quite a bit. But it worths it I must said.  The food display is very pleasant. My boyfriend and I love this place and we will be back for another occasion.
author: Venice N.

description:
I came here for Happy Hour with the girls and I can't wait to come back for dinner!

Farallon's happy hour has great deals ($6) and lasts til 7 (amazing!).  The menu is pretty small but everything we tried was great.

The only real criteria for girls' happy hour was dollar oysters - Faralloon had half-dozen drakes bay oysters for $6.  They were fine, but not a string reason to return to happy hour.  The fries, however, were so.good.  Super skinny, topped with a bit of cheese, with a hint of truffle oil, with a delicious lemon aioli to dip.  We also tried the sliders and potato croquettes to much delight.

The $6 also covers a few cocktails (mmm...margarita...) and a few glasses of wine.

Service was fantastic, they are quick to come by before your drink is empty and to take more food orders!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
The oysters were amazing! You can get dollar oysters in a lot of places so $3/4 oysters seems pricey but they had a variety. Im also giving the place a 4 star since they didnt even acknowledge the fact it my was birthday when I made reservations specifically for my birthday on the comments.

4 Stars is fair for this place.
author: Tim M.

description: Service was great, food so so. Everything was a bit over salted and the risotto was not hot. Great ambiance, but wouldn't run back based on the food to price ratio.
author: Bill B.

description:
I made reservations on Sat. for my Boyfriends birthday. Understandably making a reservation on a Sat. night for a party of 5 is difficult in the city on short notice. Farallon as always has an amazing ambiance. The decor it self will make you feel as if you have been transported strait to a scene of the little mermaid singing "under the sea". we should of stopped at the lounge taken a picture & left.

You would expect that a beautiful environment would create a beautiful experience from start to finish, this was not the case.

Our reservation was for 8:30 pm Sat Feb 18. We sat in the lounge enjoyed some oysters & cocktails & were seated about 8:45 PM. The hostess forgot to bring our drinks to us & the server tried to double charge for the missing cocktails.

Our table was upstairs next to the bathroom. The round table was far to large for the space it had been moved to. From the beginning we had to constantly move our seats to keep out of the way of traffic. 

Our server had about as much appreciation for great service & was as engaging as a piece of cardboard. I say this being a 10 year veteran of the service industry.  we were sat at 8:45 we did not see out main course until almost 10:30. the only app we order was oysters. I understand a kitchen can be in the weeds & orders can take awhile if the kitchen is backed up.

 I ordered the filet my boyfriend the lobster. My dish was presented cold & his was over cooked and resembled something out of the rubber family. We ordered a round of drinks (Grey Goose) soda lime ect. My boyfriends dad takes one sip and says("This isn't Grey Goose!) One can argue that you can not tell the difference between Vodka's. I & the whole liquor industry would beg to differ. We were served the wrong drink.

As you can see this was not the best experience. I would say the food is decent but not for the price point their serving it at. I expect my $50 steak to come with a smile.
author: Brandy R.

description:
Went for NYE.  Food was good, really solid actually; service was nonexistent.  I guess you can expect a little of that on such a busy night, but let me give you some examples: table of 8, everyone seated and decided, with menus closed.  No bread rolls or a visit by a waiter for 30 minutes.  We brought a bottle of champagne, asked the waiter to open it for us.  20 minutes later, we opened it ourselves, and he came by to help us after half the glasses were filled.  

The food was good, especially the Maine lobster, and the gnocchi.  Would have given it 3.5/4 stars, but for the service.
author: Daniel Z.

description: Decent food, attentive service, somewhat dated and definitely not some place I would come back to.  It just wasn't memorable... Nothing wrong but nothing great either.
author: P T.

description: Checked here with my friend last Friday, super gorgeous place. The server was really friendly and nice. And talk about the food, it was HEAT. I'd come here everyday if I was not so broke :(
author: Cloud G.

description:
Strengths:
 -Very nice ambiance that made me feel like I was dining in an aquarium

Development areas:
 -Took forever for our food to come, but luckily they acknowledged the delayed service by giving us nuts and cheese and dessert wine on the house
-Ahi tuna appetizer was just about enough to feed plankton

How to get 5 stars:
-Improve service delivery
author: Jason L.

description:
The bf took me here yesterday night for my birthday. We had reservations at 6.15pm. When we got there they kept asking if they can take our coats. Interesting.

We were seated at a booth that reminded the bf of a tub. It was cozy. I thought the place was a bit on the chilly side. 

The waitress was really friendly and everytime we ordered something she said it was really good. I wonder if she just says that or they are indeed very good to her. 

We ordered oysters. Two each of different kinds only to get two of one and only one of the other. The bf tried both and he said they both tasted the same. I figured as much. 

The complementary bread came with butter with sea salt? on top. I liked the salt. The bread was alright. 

We also got crab cakes to share. It was pretty good. I wished they gave more than two pieces of toast.

We also got a glass of fermented grape juice to share. It was realllly good. I normally don't like grape juice but this was sweet and not sour.

I got the shrimp ontop of rice with green curry coconut sauce. The shrimp was good but I didn't like the sauce. I felt like I was in a Vietnamese restaurant. I don't like coconut but I also don't like fish which was ALL their other entrees. 

The bf got some trout with mussels and garlic potatoes. The potatoes were soooooooo yummmy. =] 

We shared a non-petite mint ice cream sundae with brownies. This was delicious. 

I like the decor here. It is very different. There are three stalls in the female bathroom. They also play music in there too. The border around the bathroom mirror is really pretty.
author: Sarah C.

description:
My husband has wanted to come here forever!  So for his surprise birthday dinner, I opted to have a fancy date night...

Let me preface it was a very tasty meal, but you definitely break the bank a bit by going all out.

I'm glad we skipped the tasting menu, only because I felt a little disappointed with XIV's tasting menu when there was so many more yummy things on the menu.  We know what we like and we didn't know if we'd have another opportunity to come back.  Might as well just order off the menu.

YUM
-WHITE WINE BRAISED MEDITERRANEAN OCTOPUS- I could've popped a bunch.  Small plate, but perfectly made.
-CRISP CHESAPEAKE BAY SOFTSHELL CRAB- not amazing, but good.
-SEARED NEW ZEALAND TAI SNAPPER- Delicious!  Cooked with the crust perfectly browned and I could've swam in the mushroom consumme of deliciousness.
-GRILLED ALASKAN KING SALMON- There is something in the salmon.. like drugs, because it truly was the most amazing salmon we had ever had.

Sad to say, but just too much butter...
-POACHED NANTUCKET BAY SCALLOPS- Early girl tomato fondue was more like super buttery tomato bisque.  A bit much.
-1/4 OUNCE OF AMERICAN PADDLEFISH CAVIAR- caviar was delish!  The brioche it sat on was soaked in butter.   

DESSERTS
We were tipped off not to skip on desserts and I have never seen such an extensive menu.  Two pages!  So how could we pass it up?  

BUTTERSCOTCH PEACH SHORTCAKE  SUNDAE- Tasty, but did not like the buckwheat shortcake.  I should've known.  It was hard and tasted too healthy to be mixed with my butterscotch goodness.

YOU MUST GET...
BLUEBERRY PIE PIE- I know, it's pie.  But it's really amazing!  Why?  Not only are the blueberries so warm and round and the ice cream is so creamy, but get this... the pie is made of puff pastry!  Brilliant!  This was meant to be buttery.

Overall, a delicious meal.  Would I go back?  Shockingly to just try happy hour.  The service was great.  The food was good, but not as challenging as we had hoped.. just really fresh and well-made, which is fine but given the price it was a lot of decadence for one night.

ENJOY!
author: Christine K.

description: Unbelievable seafood, impeccable service, unique decor and the ambience is first-rate. After spending a week in the city, this wonderful restaurant remains one of my favorites. Take yourself away from the Wharf and experience what this place has to offer. You won't be sorry.
author: Lisa L.

description:
This review is only for Six Until Seven, Farallon's happy hour.

My friend and I were the first ones there at 5 p.m., even though HH started at 4:30 p.m. Everything on the abbreviated menu is $6. We each had the red wine, the crabcakes and the yellowtail. The food portions were tiny -as expected - but quite tasty. 

The interior is lovely, the service was good. No complaints. By the time we left, just before 8 p.m., the place was more crowded, but it's so huge, it was hard to get any real vibe. 

Will I be back? I won't avoid it, but I don't think I'd make a point of going back.
author: Kim C.

description: Always a fine dining experience. Spotless service, the freshest seafood. When I have a special event, or have an important business meal, Farallon never disappoints.
author: Michael W.

description:
So, admittedly, we went on a Monday night, which might not reflect the restaurant at its best.
On the other hand, I rate restaurants based on, "Given the ingredients they used, could I have done better?"
I've never been formally trained, but I've been cooking for my family and friends for 35+ years now.

The staff was exemplary, as expected, as was the decor. The appetizers (a mushroom bisque, a shellfish bisque, ahi carpaccio, and a little gem salad) were all excellent. My only major initial complaint was my wine selection: I chose a light merlot, and it was fine on its own, but clashed horrifically with the acidity of the carpaccio and my salad. Considering the sommelier himself opened the wine for us, you'd think he would have warned me that my wine selection was poor. I don't appreciate a brown-nosing sommelier; I want someone who knows what the heck he's doing, and warns me when I've made a horrific choice (as I had).

The main course was the first disaster. My black sole was quite good (better than I could have made), but my wife's cod was out-and-out mediocre, and made significantly worse by the fact that they had clearly left it sitting while my sole was completed. To call her dish "lukewarm" when it was served would be generous. At the level of quality I would expect of a restaurant like Farallon, serving one diner's dish cold is utterly unacceptable. Similarly, the bacon-and-Brusssels-spouts side I ordered was quite good, easily as good as anything I produce in my kitchen, but my wife's truffle-and-cheese cauliflower was utterly overwhelmed by garlic. And I *like* garlic! There was no flavor beyond the garlic to be found in the dish.

By the time we ordered dessert, we were already thoroughly underwhelmed. The staff  was utterly impeccable, the decor was delightful to look upon, but the food had so far been worse than a dinner I could have cooked at home. 

Dessert was another disappointment. I got the Devil's Food cake with cherries. I would have appreciated either a deep chocolate flavor or a cherry counterpoint to the chocolate there was. I got neither. My wife got the dessert riccotta. It was perfectly adequate, but nothing to make one's eye's widen.

In short, the staff and the decor were excellent (at least 4.5/5). The appetizers were good (another 4/5). The wine the sommelier approved was terrible (1/5). Dinner was mediocre to poor (2/5 at best). Dessert was another horrific disappointment (2/5). Given the reputation and the price point, I cannot in good conscience recommend Farallon to anyone who appreciates fine dining. There are too many places that are SOOOO much better at the same price point.
author: Joe G.

description: This place is amazing. Ambiance superb. Not as dressy as I thought. Food top is wonderful!!
author: Beth G.

description: Excellent evening!! Enjoyed Happy Hour cocktails, an absolutely lovely dinner and delicious dessert. The tuna with miso soup was amazing and the carrot cake was some of the best my husband has ever enjoyed. Could not have asked for a better staff! Super friendly and very knowledgable. When we are back in town you will most definitely see us here!
author: Katy T.

description: Service here is amazing... beyond comparison. The food was excellent. not being familiar with the sf scene, I was surprised to find such a gem off the street. This is hands down a place that NEEDS to be visited. The upscale environment was absolutely complimented by the bar tender, Mark, was outstanding and incredibly personable. I highly recommend this place for drinks or dinner. You will not be disappointed.
author: Vance W.

description: Quality albeit expensive.  Enjoyed shellfish platter, traditional caviar, and small seafood linguini dish.
author: Barbara C.

description:
While this shows up as a 4 star, I really think its a high 3. One of my colleagues was in the mood for seafood, Dugeness crabs in particular, so my first thoughts turned to Farallon rather than one of the more touristy places at Fisherman's Wharf.. 

I love the decor here. It is King Neptune's realm to the point of being campy.... especially the jelly fish lights. 

The food was good but not fabulous. We had the equivalent of the "Plateau du Mer" which was good, but doesn't come anywhere near those of Europe that have all of those great little shell fish.... cockles and mussels etc.... The crab was actually a tad fishy...

I kind of grazed for the rest of the meal with the octopus in aspic, the pea soup, and the seafood boudin, all quite good. 

When I'm in SFO and someone in the group wants seafood, Farallon will always come to mind.
author: Dennis U.

description: Truthfully it's a 3.5 but tie goes to the runner.  I was too exhausted to go far and afield for dinner but was determined to eat seafood (it is Dungee season after all!).  The interior of this place is beautiful... The jelly fish from the Ceiling were pretty cool and the interior was really well done in general.  The staff was incredibly nice and the selection of cocktails and the level to which they were prepared was perfect.  I was not the only single at the bar and the other patrons were friendly and talkative which was a nice bonus.  The platter of dungeness crab and blue point oysters was the perfect light dinner.  If you are in the Union Square area this is worth checking out.  Eat up y'all!
author: Shane J.

description: I had the Louisiana prawn cocktail for the first course, the fettuccine Alfredo (because it had fiddlehead ferns in it and I'd never had one), and the seared tuna. It was all good but when asked about the tuna I replied that I was glad the table next to me cleared out because then I wouldn't be self conscious that I was moaning while I chewed it. They also enthusiastically sat me at 9:30 when I was afraid about being a jerk walking in 30 minutes before closing.
author: Matt C.

description: Good downtown seafood place. We showed up on a Monday night around 6:30 without a reservation and had to sit in the bar. We got lucky and got a table after a few minutes. I had the crab roll and loved it. Overall, a good place worth checking out.
author: Matt T.

description:
My wife and I at at Farallon before seeing a show at the ACT.  We got there around 6 and got one of the upstairs tables.  This is a fairly quiet area to sit, but after looking around the restaurant a bit (after we ate), I would recommend eating in the back room, which has a bit more of the decor that everyone talks about in the reviews.

The food was excellent.  I started with the Louisiana shrimp cocktail, which was this great combination of shrimp and wasabi-infused (?) cocktail sauce.  A bit spicy, but just great from my perspective.  My wife had the spear fish for her main course.   I had Ono with black bean sauce, which I though was a really nice combination of tasks.  We had the chocolate bites for dessert, which was just the right amount (not much!) after a big meal.

Definitely a place we will come back to!!
author: Richard M.

description:
Farallon is one of San Francisco's finest restraurants, and it is justifiably hard to get a table. We needed the Westin St. Francis valet to get us an early mid-week reservation. The restaurant was empty when we arrived and buzzing when we left.

While I greatly enjoyed my meal, several factors kept Farallon from being a five-star experience.

First, the highlights. Farallon's decor is magnificent, transforming a barrel vault into an opulent bathysphere of a dining room. The wine list is judicious. Most of the food is unimpeachable, and I especially enjoyed my entree of rare seared Oho. Desserts were excellent. I would be satisfied dining here for any occasion, and was especially pleased to be able to impress colleagues with my choice of dinner venue.

But there are some inconsistencies at Farallon. My martini was weak and not served in an icy glass. An appetizer of mushroom and truffle ravioli was merely adequate -- and, most unfortunately, featured exactly the same ingredients and flavor profile as the mushroom-and-truffle soup a muse bouche. Such an obvious sequencing flub should not take place at a fine restaurant with a nightly menu. A fine restaurant also should not take its orders out of place, resulting in every course served first to the wrong person. In fact, the service overall was mismatched to a restaurant that demands ties and pearls. Our waiter, though very attentive, was altogether too informal even for San Francisco, and we never met the floor manager.

Since my favorite seafood fine dining spot is now closed (Aqua), I will likely seek out Farallon next year on a future San Francisco visit. Get a babysitter, bring your expense account, and enjoy a fine experience at Farallon.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Delicious food with interesting ambiance!

Happy hour is great but dinner is where your pallet goes to heaven.

I ordered:
Rabbit Sausage with rosemary potatoes.
Girlfriend ordered the pike fish with corn raviolis.
author: Nathan B.

description: I'm writing this review so that the restaurant will change for the better. It's a seafood house with top-notch and top-quality dishes. Really enjoyed my dinner of oysters.  My party had caviar, crab and lobster -- all very good.  The service was poor.  Drinks went empty and stayed empty.  Appetizers and dinner took more than three hours.  I would go back only if I knew service improves.
author: Steve V.

description:
I so dislike pretentious restaurants.   My husband and I had our Christmas dinner here.
Waiter was always in a great hurry, talking to us while holding dishes for other tables and standing sideways to the table or at a distance as if he is was half way here and half way on the way out to the other guests.   Diner kind of experience in service.  Rush, rush, rush. 
I had dungeness crab risotto.  It was an average risotto but not 'upscale seafood' that the restaurant clams to be.  A little too loose for my taste and missing a flavor that would bind it and differentiate it from any other risotto that I had elsewhere.  My main dish was grilled Tombo Tuna.   I do not like totally raw tuna seared for 30 sec on each side, and that is what I told the waiter.  I asked if the chef can hold it on a grill a bit longer to sear a little deeper, so I still have a raw inside but less of it.  My tuna was easily two inches thick and thoroughly cooked to the very middle of it.  White all the way though.   They called it medium rear.  There was not a millimeter of rear meat in it.  In a good restaurant a chef knows what a guest means when they ask for a little more grill but still raw in the middle, especially that it was such a thick chunk of meat.   I guess they tired to teach me a lesson.   My husband had Alaskan cod and he said it was OK but so to speak, nothing to write home about.   The vegetables that came with cod were OK, just potatoes.  I did not get an impression that I am in one of the best sea food restaurants.   
To prove their tackiness they added a tip to our bill for two people. 
In overall it was an unpleasant experience because of the shabby service and average food.  
In the last 150 days I ate at about 210 restaurants (I travel a lot) so I do know an excellent restaurant with good properly cooked food from a shabby pretentious restaurant.
author: Julia Y.

description: The wine,scallops, chocolate cake, service and decor were amazing! It is a good place to take people if you want to wow your guest.
author: Christina K.

description:
The lounge area and JellyFish bar was whimsically magical.

Dinner was great and we seriously closed down the restaurant.
Ambiance wise, I did feel a little dated as it wasn't a young hip and trendy restaurant. Nonetheless, it was quality service without the pretentiousness. 

The service was very attentive with great wine recommendations.

Seared foie gras was my favorite. There were too many dishes to remember but the foie gras really stood out and I usually don't like it that much! I suggest the tasting menu to get a taste of everything.
author: Mia N.

description: The food was great. Bartender (Jaime R) was good at his craft and a pleasure to talk to. It was overall a quality experience.
author: Vito B.

description:
After getting married at City Hall last week, we had dinner in the Wine Hold private room at Farallon. Five stars isn't enough. Farallon exceeded our expectations in every way. Our server (I think her name was Nahide) was excellent, - professional, knowledgeable, helpful, and fun. In fact, the entire staff impressed us. And the food was delicious. We were hoping our dinner would feel as special and memorable as our wedding, and Farallon definitely delivered. 

Our original plan was to have dinner at Kokkari, but they ended up being difficult to work with so we went with Plan B, - which turned out to be Farallon. Now I'm thrilled we ended up at Farallon. - The experience couldn't have been more perfect. I know my family will remember it for years. 

Thank you, Farallon, for being a lovely part of such an important day!
author: Joyce G.

description: SUCH a fun place for dinner! The atmosphere sets it off--you feel like you're in a palace under the sea (dare I say Little Mermaidish, but in the best way?). The food was excellent--including the best oysters any of us had ever had. Our waiter was lovely. A bit pricey but worth it. We all loved this place and were raving about it all weekend.
author: Marta S.

description:
I took my family out for a special birthday dinner & it is an excellent "experience" restaurant.  The staff is excellent and went out of their way to make sure that we had a nice time.  

Unfortunately, the food itself was only average. The salmon was overcooked. In general, no one in our party of five was impressed by the food.

If I go again,  I think we will go for the oyster platter.  It looked impressive.

I also suggest asking to see the scotch book.  It is 42 pages long.

Overall, I'd give this 31/2 stars.
author: Dallas N.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant. We went here for my birthday dinner. I had no idea what to expect as it was a surprise. The hostess was super friendly and seated us right away, even though our reservation was a half hour later. We were seated in front of the kitchen which was a bit odd at first but nice to see the hustle and bustle of it all. Service was slow at times. Our waiter told us that he would be right back because he had to go say hi to someone. That was probably unnecessary. There was also a point where our dishes weren't cleared and the chef from the kitchen reached over and grabbed the dishes out of the way. Weird. 

For the appetizers we had the shellfish bisque and the grilled hearts of romaine. Both were fantastic. For the entree we had the seared halibut and the char. The baked char was AMAZING. It came with diced vegetables and clams which were a great addition to the fish. 

We did not have desserts because the choices didn't sound appealing. The server did bring us a scoop of their malt ice cream. It tasted like a ice cream whopper. Yum. 

The fish here is delicious. Service could have been better but not terribly bad. Ambiance was nice. Out of towners and business types. Would definitely come back again for a nice meal out. They know how to serve seafood here!
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
** They add a 4% surcharge to the bill, to pay for medical coverage that is required by San Francisco's Health Care Security Ordinance.

Here are some items on the "6 till 7" happy hour menu (all items $6 until 7:00):

- Dungeness crab cakes (see my photos): outstanding, with just the right crispy coating.  It has a rich crab flavor that is not masked by spices or sauces.

- truffled pommes frites: very good.  The truffle taste really comes through, and the sauce is great.  But, they are not as crispy as I would like; definitely order them "well done."  Farallon has upstaged The Clock Bar at the Westin St Francis: the truffled popcorn at The Clock Bar isn't as good.

- cornmeal fried oysters: not recommended.  It sounds great, but it just doesn't work; the oysters are too small, and the cornmeal just gets in the way of the taste.

- Farallon Jack Rose cocktail: It just didn't work.  It tasted limp and watered down.  There was also something else wrong: I think the glass was too small, and it arrived at room temperature.
author: Scott F.

description: I'm giving this 3 stars mostly because of where they sat us. We had reservations for 4 but someone lost them so we were in the front bar area instead of the actual restaurant- which was amazing looking, btw. I also thought the oysters were a little small and just okay. I had the beet salad (amazing) and sole for an entree. Sadly, the sole was only ok- I honestly expected more from what was supposed to be one of the best restaurants in the city. The wine was great and the price reflected that! We had a good time but I've had better seafood in Arkansas...
author: Megan S.

description: Awesome as always.  1st time there was probably 12+ years, and I was just as impressed with everything this visit with my wife for our 10 year wedding anniversary.  We took friends from SoCa and they too loved it.  Great service and very accommodating (as we were flying in from LA and thought we'd be late, we were), great table, great apps and drinks, food was awesome, dessert was great!  We'll be back.
author: T R.

description:
I have been coming for years. Last night we thought we would pop in for appetizers and a drink. In stating our intention and asking for room at the bar....I received the roll of the eyes, the turn of the head, no eye contact and the clear statement..."there is no room at the inn"
   What happened to: let me put your name on list, perhaps a seat will open soon, maybe you might want to join us for dinner instead.
    In a city full of phenomenal restaurants we did not starve.
author: David H.

description:
After reading all the rave review we were underwhelmed to say the least.

Besides the inventive decor this place just doesn't measure up.  The martini ordered at the bar wasn't ice cold and the single tiny olive was pitiful.  This should have been our first clue.  A restaurant charging this much and striving to be top notch should know how to make a first rate martini!  

Service was slow and inattentive and the wine list lacking.  

The best thing on the menu was the mushroom ravioli and bread plate!  Once the main course finally arrived it was unedible -- my fish dish was overpowered by sauces and ingredients that didn't match up.   They tried to apologize for the wait but by that time it was too late.  All we wanted to do was leave the place.  

Sorry to say that this was the first YELP recommendation that didn't pan out.
author: claudia M.

description:
I was here for my going-away dinner and it was an amazing dinner experience.  The interior is expansive and I really liked the unique balance between a modern and "Fisherman's Wharf" feel.  The sashimi trio that I had was very fresh (I wish I could remember which fishes it consisted of!) and all of my friends enjoyed their seafood dishes.  

What really stood was the sommelier's wine recommendations for the evening.  We had the 2006 Hartford Zinfandel and 2005 Robert Sinsky Merlot.  The Hartford was and continues to be the best Zinfandel I've had BY FAR.  It has an intense, yet balanced fruity character that just engulfs your taste buds and lingers oh so pleasantly after each sip.  The Merlot was also very good with just the right balance of tannins.  

It was a thoroughly enjoyable meal and I'll have to come back again sometime for further wine recommendations!
author: Eric F.

description: I cannot express enough of how much my husband and I loved this restaurant. They have a good variety of oysters and their lobster is delicious. The service was outstanding and sooooo very kind! I will definitely return to this restaurant on our next trip to San Fran! It's a must!
author: Julie J.

description: We went to this restaurant expecting a fine dining experience.  It was very overpriced.  I don't mind paying for a great meal, but this fell quite short.  I ordered the lobster and sweetbreads for $65.  It was supposed to be 1 1/2 pound lobster and it was tiny.  Nothing special.  The Louisiana Prawn dish was nothing more than a shrimp cocktail with 4 medium sized shrimp for $19 bucks.  NOT WORTH IT AT ALL!  This restaurant is pretty inside and everyone is nice but it's a big PASS for the money.
author: Roger H.

description:
A+ for atmosphere and professional, attentive service.

The grades aren't so high for the meal I had, though. I ordered a Hawaiian tuna, which came out a bit too dry and too overcooked for my taste.
author: Ryan L.

description:
The ambiance was nice. We were here for happy hours on a Thursday before attending a reception. 

We ordered from the happy hours menu (everything on the menu was 6$): We ordered some oysters 6 for 6$ (creamy and fresh), The lobster bisque was nice (light and yummy) and the mini burgers were filling. 

We will be back but next time I think we'll try the regular menu just to compare ;)
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I took my parents here for dinner, it was their first time so they were stunned by the room's coastal theme, the oceanic decor, the jellyfish lamps, and kelp-lit columns. 

Food: 
For starters we ordered a variety of oysters (kumamoto, blue point, hog island, beausoliei and myagi) for $3.25 on the half shell, expensive considering that there are restaurants with the same oyster menu for a fraction of the price =/ oh well.

Second course we had the lobster butternut squash risotto rimmed with balsamic reduction. Tasty dish. the balsamic reduction was a nice way to keep the dish appetizing since it was a lil heavy on the cream.

Third Course we had the Seared Black Bass, leeks and potatoes truffled ravioli, and the Seared scallops with fennel and blood orange vinaigrette... all good but not memorable. 

All in all, the price tag is a little overpriced for the food and i wouldnt consider this restaurant in the elite category. Opt for Aqua instead.
author: Rebecca L.

description: This was our second time to dine here. Although the first time was exceptional, the second time was not quite as impressive. Fresh fish appetizer of oysters, crab lobster and shrimp was on the salty side, and tasted very fishy. Main dishes were tasty but nothing exceptional. The waiters were terrific though!
author: A L.

description: Went to this restaurant with high hopes as our party heard great things about it. We walk in to find a very outdated decor with plasticky jelly fish for chandeliers that did not appeal to any of us. Still we decided to keep an open mind and try the food. We started with a bottle of wine, their selection was pretty decent, and ordered the grand seafood platter that was recommended to us by our waiter. This is where they lost us! The platter was mediocre and small...for $125....sorry but no, and group knows good seafood. Lobster was chewy, the king crab legs lacked flavor, oysters were ok and the shrimp was probably the only thing we liked, although small. Still very hungry, we asked for the check and decided to go someplace else. Waiter did not like our move very much.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Coming out of Las Vegas which is a food desert anyway.  

The skinny: excellent seafood

The deets:  I have eaten here before.  I started with the happy hour special, sparkling wine and oysters which were excellent.  The amuse bouche was also fantastic, rabbit with mushrooms.  I also had the octopus in paprika which was good, a bit salty as others have commented.  I finished with the cod which was also excellent.

Summary: if you pay good money for good seafood, come here.  If you want to dine cheap, look to the happy hour.
author: Tom M.

description: This was our second visit.  The first was 5 star.  This one....not so much. We paid $300 to get sick.  We both feel awful.
author: Carolyn K.

description: Very small portions for unreasonably high price.  Appetizers are over 20$ that are not enough to share with your partner.  Main course took 3 minutes to "enjoy"...Spent over 500 for 4 people and left hungry.
author: Anna S.

description:
I brought my fiance here for his birthday dinner; even though we were 15 mins late, they held our table (parking is difficult in the area - although Farallon has valet for $15)!

The food is really awesome, we took fellow yelper's advice and ordered several oysters - which did not disappoint my fiance's pallet!  We also had the bass and hawaiian ono, both cooked and seasoned perfectly!  The dessert menu looked amazing - my fiance ordered the apple sundae and I had the flourless chocolate cake, which was very rich and satisfying! They even wrote Happy Birthday on the plate.

The decor and ambiance is really fun and classy.  A great place for a special occasion or romantic date!  The only negative thing I would say, is that it's very loud inside.  We were seated in the main room about half way across from the kitchen, but I could barely even hear myself.
author: Ms D.

description: Have an appointment. Came here early. I was asked to hangout at the bar. Experienced a very rude server. Was rude because I did order any drinks Really??? Seriously....I am not coming back here. And after my quest came we were made to wait 15 more minutes after our scheduled time of reservation. Hmmm...
author: M M.

description: My husband and I went here for my Bday and it was delish! The waiter was very attentive and everyone was so nice. I ordered the sterling filet beef which was delicious and hubby ordered the Mediterranean fish! Both were very tasty! Would def go again! We did order the prawns for first course which was 4 pieces of shrimp for $20... Not worth it if you ask me but nevertheless, it was still tasty! Overall, I would recommend it and visit again!
author: Sandy F.

description:
Where do I begin! Dining with a former CEO of Hard Rock Restaurant Group and a former restaurant owner can be a little critical.

This place hit on most all cylinders and I emphasize most! 

When you look at the front entrance you get no indication of the amazing restaurant inside.

Service is great but cold. We had a very nice Sancerre with dinner. Oysters were perfect. I had the Veal Cheeks a little bit of a disconnect with the food. It was OK not memorable. 

But the rest of our party was thrilled and loved it!

I would go back and try another item.
author: Rick F.

description:
Pros - Excellent food and impeccable service.
Cons - None.
I recommend it highly if you are in SFO Union Square area. My wife and I enjoyed it a lot on a Sunday evening.
author: Jay K.

description:
My uncle and aunt bought me to Farallon for my birthday and it turned out to be a fantastic dinner treat. The ambiance and fruites de mar grand platter were the highlights for me. I loved the underwater theme, I almost felt like I was in a sophisticated Little Mermaid movie. There were jellyfish lights hanging from the ceiling and booths that looked like shells and coral - though it may sound cheesy it was far from.

Because Farallon is known for its seafood we decided to start off our meal with the Fruites De Mar Grand platter (oysters, shrimp, crab legs, lobster claw) - 2 of us finished off the whole platter and could have easily eaten more it was so tasty. More legs and claws please! The seafood on ice comes in 2 size portions, the Grand which is what we got and the Royal which is meant for 4, each has a side of onion sauce and butter. 

For a nice restaurant the Farallon had pretty big portions. I got halibut with chantrelles and an arugula salad with lemon vinaigrette. My favorite part of the fish was the crispy top crust, yum, and it went great with the mushrooms that had a subtle sweet flavor. I'm a huge fan of arugula so I scarfed that down right away. My aunt and uncle got stuffed lobster (the lobster meat was removed mixed with veggies and a sauce and stuffed back in its shell) and a beef dish (my uncle was having some seafood allergies so he opted for this plate which was 1 of 2 non-seafood items on the menu) - both seemed happy with their entrees. My aunt was going into surgery the following day and was glad that Farallon would be her "last" meal till she recovered. 

I thought service was great - our waiter was attentive and our glasses were filled regularly.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I have come here twice for a birthday party. Great, Great food, decor and service. Each time we had fantastic selections on this well balanced menu. Wine list is well composed and thought through very well. 
Service is always was attentive but not overthetop overbearing. Definitely recommend this place for a special occasion.
author: Xela H.

description: The food was very good. But The service made you feel like trey were doing you a favor and they should not be bothered with mere paying customers.  Additionally i ordered one cut of meat and received another. There is a significant difference between ribeye and a tenderloin.  Dollars are probably the same but huge differences nonetheless  The waiter did not have a clue
author: John C.

description:
Amazing dinner last night with my BF. 

SERVICE = perfect

FOOD = amazing

Ambiance= mesmerizing 

All in all, the whole experience was extraordinary and I would HIGHLY recommend this place!
author: Natalie C.

description: Very nice ambience. My wife and I came in for the happy hour, found a seat right away and had excellent service. The smaller menu had just enough options and the drinks were well prepared. I definitely recommend reservations if you are trying to sit in the main dining area.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Hooray! yet another $1 oyster happy hour location.  This is where I spent my last Friday in SF.  

Addictive fries, oysters obviously a hit, delicious potato croquettes, and good strong margaritas.  They have a fair number of happy hour items on the menu, and the happy hour lasts pretty late, so that's a plus.  

The decor is underwater kitsch at its finest.  And the mounds of fresh seafood displayed where it was being shelled and dished adds to the feel.  While I don't think I'd come back here just for the oysters, I would certainly try the happy hour again for the entire range of options.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I read the reviews before deciding to come here on our short San Francisco trip.  Loved the decor.  Thanks to the yelp reviews knew they had a special happy hour menu at the bar.  They said our table was ready but I wanted to take advantage of the discounted prices at the bar as I knew we would be dropping serious coin.    Started with the crabcakes and fried oyster.  While the crabcakes had very little filler, it was overshadowed by the cornmeal crust.  Husband summed it up, "hushpuppies." That said, the fried oyster on top a spoonful of lobster was pretty tasty along with a south beach mojito that was the best mojito I have ever had.

Onto the dining experience....the sommelier was very impressive in that he had two different years for the wine we ordered and he brought out both years to ask which one we wanted.  Most would pawn off the one they thought they needed to dispose of first...so that was a nice touch.  We started with the grand seafood platter - straightforward fresh chilled seafood - the jumbo prawns were the best.  

But what really stood out was the thai snapper.  Wow!!  There were about 6 flavors going on but they were all subtle and it all worked.   Portions are pretty good size here too.  Surprisingly there were tons of beef dishes being ordered all around us even though this restaurant is known for seafood.  The only reason I knocked off a star is that the waitress got overwhelmed and we were forgotten at the end.  However, service throughout the evening was top notch.
author: Nicole F.

description: Wow this place is amazing. Sits in a 100 yr building and the restaurant is actually built right in top of an old bath house. You literally feel the ground shaking as you sit on top of it.  Tuna tar tar is delicious as is the bisque soup. Service by Ryan was stellar.
author: Reza Z.

description:
The crab au gratin was the best Crab Chowder I have ever had. $17 for a small croquette size, next time I'm getting my own!

The food was good, however the buttery/oiliness caught up with me for awhile. This place is popular and crowded, and I would definitely recommend it. Make sure to make reservations.

The decor reminds me of Vegas, was a bit bright and loud so it did not feel very romantic.
author: E T.

description:
I'm not particularly a seafood lover but looks like a good selection, specially oysters. Some other options, but it much if you're not looking for seafood.
On a general review the place is OK but not really sure that price and service are on the line with the food serving sizes (entrees are really, really small) and quality (thumb up here)
Overall, good but not great!
author: Ignacio R.

description:
I don't think I'd categorize this with fine dining or even close.  More like family dining as the decor, although original,  seemed Disney-ish, definitely impressionable to kids eyes.

The food?  There's nothing worse than overcooked and salted seafood of any kind.  Nuff said.

Service?  Not sure what was up our waiters ass but he definitely didn't deserve even the minimum tip.
author: Delilah B.

description:
I've been staring at the glass jellyfish for the past 4 years, thinking man I really want to go there just for the decor alone!

Farallon exceeded my expectations by a million.  We had a great table in the back room, which I had no idea existed from just looking in the front from time to time.

Our meal was amazing, the shrimp parfait was probably my favorite, super fresh and tons of shrimp.  I had the Ono as a main course to prepare for my trip to Hawaii, it was the most unique tasting dish I have had in a really long time.  I loved it and will have a hard time ordering anything else.

I'm definitely coming back here to try everything else on the menu.
author: jessica b.

description: The only winner of our dinner is the tasting menu paring with wine, all the other dishes are average , the inventor of the decor is obvious, yet, need some update!
author: Chi Y.

description:
Our company holiday party was here, we took over the Beluga Room. The silly sealife artwork strewn on every wall can be talked about all night. Service was top notch knowledgeable, yet casual and cool enough to make you feel VIP, like it was your own home. Kind of like Jeffrey from Fresh Prince of Bel Air, but less snarky.

Striped bass tasted like it was fresh out of the kitchen of Giada De Laurentis. Tasty, meaty, moist, and lots of skin. droooool...

Perhaps the best thing I had here though, was the riesling. Normally prefer reds, bold, but said "hey, why not". It was my first glass during cocktail hour, and I probably drank a bottle to myself that night. Mark this down:

Gysler Kabinett Weinheimer Riesling 2009
author: Ethan L.

description:
So I've been to this place before and had a good time with the high quality service and excellent decor. But my recent trip on 11/10/14 made me think twice about this place.

It was my mothers birthday and decided to make the trip to SF and enjoy a nice dinner at Farrallon. We were greeted and seated immediately. Our server was outstanding and we ordered several things. 2.5 stars for service and accuracy.

The bad; I get places need to change menus around to have fresh ideas but maybe it was the time of year or I just ordered the wrong thing. The menu itself was limited and the choices did not look or sound very appealing.  The appetizers were also in the bland category as well. My father and I ordered the shellfish bisque and what a terrible bowl of flavorless soup that was.  The presentation and look was awful a brownish yellow color. It tasted pretty much like buttered crab and shrimp shells, I do not recommend it, the worst part about it was the gas it gave afterward, yikes!! My girlfriend order beef carpaccio and had to stop eating it because it didn't taste right to her (she's a big carpaccio fan). I ended up ordering the spearfish because nothing else looked appealing, other items were tuna, lobster, fried pork, cod and one other item I can't think of. The spearfish did not taste very good, it was more tough than I anticipated and can not recommend to anyone. I had my sights set on something simple like salmon and was let down that they didn't offer it, but sure enough they had cod and was shocked they didn't have catfish (sarcasm).

Now since I work in the food and beverage industry I normally won't bitch to the waiter about how bad something is and rarely send stuff back, I take my punches and avoid going back. But since I dropped over $500 for this meal I felt I had to write about it here and show my huge disappointment for his place.  Half star for the food.
author: Jason C.

description:
Food was good and service was great.  Reason why I'm just giving two stars is because of their portion sizes.  

Total bill was approx $300 for a five course meal for two people.  I walked out of there still feeling hungry... as if all I've had was just an appetizer.  

First two courses were tartare and scallops.  2-3 bites of tartare and a single scallop... Both were great and i figured these two to be the beginning appetizer type of courses so the fact that they were both real small wasn't a problem.  The main courses should be better right? wrong.

Third course was called "Warm Maine Lobster".  What I was expecting was a lobster tail.  What came out was a plate with two very small pieces of ravioli. On top of it was about 3 TINY TINY shreds of lobster.  It's as if they took a single lobster tail and told themselves that with that one tail they would make that dish for everybody that ordered that same dish that night at the restaurant.

Fourth course was filet mignon.  I figured since all the other courses were disappointing in size.  This main course had to be a decent size so that we wouldn't walk out hungry.  Boy was I wrong.  When my plate came out, what was on there was a 2 OZ sized piece of filet mignon. Tasted great but I finished it in about 2-3 bites.  Geez... How much more would it of costed them to give us a decent sized piece of meat??  This is a $300 dinner!!!

Fifth course was desert, which actually was a decent size.  The biggest dish out of all 5.  I normally just take a few bites out of dessert since I'd be full from dinner already.  However, I was still so hungry i finished the whole thing.

Now I'm not the type that takes a whole lot of food to fill up.  I'd say I'm about average.  A 6 oz pc of steak with a side of mash potatoes would normally suffice.  Had the portion sizes been decent I probably would have given this place 4-5 stars.  But I just find that after paying $300 for dinner for two and having to walk out of this place still hungry is unacceptable.
author: Johnny L.

description:
Beautiful restaurant. I walked in and immediately was in awe, "whoaaa, jelly fishes!!". We were seated immediately and the food came out ridiculously fast for a place like this. 

Apparently the menu changes frequently but here goes: 
2nd course: 
Stuffed calamari: we made it a game to figure out what the stuffing was. It was delicious though, the calamari was cooked perfectly and did not come out rubbery 
Truffled au gratin: Its more like mac and cheese with truffles. Great truffle taste and had lots of truffle in it. 

3rd course: 
Tai Snapper: gnocchi was tasteless, but the fish was soo good. It was fresh and the texture was amazing. The broth was also very good, order this is you don't want anything too heavy. 

Alaskan Cod: Better than the snapper. The cod was cooked just right. The ravioli was sweet and was provided a great balance. I would definitely order this if you want a fish dish.
author: Amy L.

description:
Fantastic!!
Taste really good for all we order. It was amazing. Had dinner with client from overseas and we all enjoyed food and design of restaurant. But pricy ....... ;-)
author: Atsuo F.

description: Came here with my husband for the first time.  We were impressed with the feel of the restaurant as soon as we walked in and were even more impressed when we walked into the back area where we sat next to the kitchen.  Very intimate and classy.  The chairs are nice and comfy.  The service and quality and taste of the food was excellent.  The dungeness crab was fresh and some of the best we've ever had.  The filet was great and my husband said the New Zealand venison was the best he's ever had.  Drinks/wine were great too.  It's now one of our favorite fine dining restaurants in the city and we'll definitely come back.
author: Leanne T.

description:
For the prices on the menu and bar list, I expected to have a wonderful dining experience, but several let-downs turned it into a good but not stellar meal.
HITS: ambiance/decor, excellent wait staff, good quality food, expansive wine list, great bread.  Hickory Smoked Sturgeon was excellent, tho small portions.  Same with the Seared Branzino (yummy) and Grilled Scallops (tasty, but 3 scallops for $29?)
MISSES: Baby Spinach Salad was swimming in a powerful vinaigrette that killed the dish for me--it was so bad that I should have sent it back (but didn't--doh).  The Shellfish Bisque was good but waaay too salty.  Chocolate Bites for dessert were ok, nothing special.
Overall, it was a nice meal, but given the prices it's only average for me.  I've had better meals for less money at other restaurants.
author: Rikki W.

description: Where else can you get 5 star service and and enjoy drinks/plates for $6! I've been here twice and I enjoyed my meal both times. The potato Croquettes, clams, seafood bisque and the Hemingway daiquiri are all a must try. I can't wait to come back and do a full dinner!
author: Diane M.

description:
This restaurant was wonderful in every aspect!  Incredible ambiance and beautiful, well thought out decor. (the custom chandeliers were amazing and the custom iron bar stools and railings were well designed)

A polished wait staff  delivered scrumptious food!  Every dish we ordered from appetizer to dessert was spectacular!  A total 10 and we are super particular!  

The only negative for us was the music, which seemed out of place for the style and level of the restaurant.  We seem to find  this often in restaurants, as if 20 yr. old bus boys are selecting the music...?
Something more sophisticated would have been expected.

Will definitely return and plan to bring our daughter and her husband, who is a metal craftsman.  He will appreciate the detail and effort someone has put into this place!
author: Leslie C.

description:
I went here with a friend for her birthday, because this certainly isn't a restaurant I'd be able to afford under normal circumstances! But I'm really glad to got to experience it at least once.

The inside of the restaurant is sooooo cool! There are arches and domes and cool light fixtures (some shaped like sea urchins, some like jelly fish) and ocean-themed mosaics everywhere!

Here's what we had:

FIRST COURSE: My friend ordered the "Hawaiian Hand Line Caught Ahi Tuna Tartare" (with "hickory smoked hearts of palm, roasted asian pears, [and] toasted sesame seeds"). I ordered the comparatively tame "Star Route Farms Mixed Lettuces" (with "sierra beauty apples, toasted pistachios, [and] cider-whole grain mustard vinaigrette"). We each tried a bit of the other's dish, but I'm not a big fan of raw fish and my friend's not real big on salad, so we mostly stuck to our own orders for the first course.

SECOND COURSE: My friend ordered the "Mediterranean Shellfish Bisque" (with cognac chantilly, chives, [and] extra virgin olive oil"), which she didn't really care for. She said it was sort of dull, that she couldn't taste any "edges" to the flavors, that it was sort of a mishmash of different fishes that resulted in a muddled flavor. I ordered the "Champagne Poached Nantucket Bay Scallops" (with "celery root flan, petite sierra beauty apple salad, [and] cara cara orange fondue"), and my friend and I both wondered what in the world "cara cara orange fondue" might be. To be honest, I don't even remember what it looked like or tasted like, because I was more focused on the scallops, which were delicious. The flan was just kind of bland and mushy. The apple salad, however, was terrific.

THIRD COURSE: My friend and I were both torn between the same two dishes, so we just ordered both and split each in half and shared them equally. We ordered the "Grilled Sacramento Delta Sturgeon" (with "artichoke heart puree, balsamic glazed brussel sprouts, [and] brown butter hollandaise") and the "Grilled Creekstone Farms Petite Filet of Beef" (with "olive oil crushed new potatoes, crisp parsnips, roasted cipollini onions, [and] red wine jus"). The real winner (with both of us) of this course, though, was the crushed new potatoes. They were an interesting consistency -- not quite mashed, not quite diced -- which we both really liked.

DESSERT: Again, we were both torn between the same two options, so we shared them equally. We ordered the "Gingerbread Caramel Apple Sundae" (with "vanilla bean ice cream, Aspall cider caramel sauce, gingerbread, [and] roasted Sierra Beauty apples") and the "Sticky Toffee Pudding" (with "banana-date ice cream, candied kumquats, [and] eggnog creme anglaise"). Both were wonderful, but the banana-date ice cream was a favorite for both of us, though we disagreed on the candied kumquats. My friend liked them, but I thought they were a kind of disturbing chewy texture that didn't go well with the rest of the sticky toffee pudding dessert elements. 

The presentation of every dish was truly stunning, just beautiful, which we both appreciated. And there was a tremendous attention to detail, with tiny pomegranate seeds decorating the edges of plates here and there -- stuff like that.

The setting is stunningly gorgeous (and also rather quirky, which I thought was neat); the service was some of the best I've ever gotten; the food was delicious, creative, and beautifully presented; and I just hope I get to go here again someday. It may be my favorite restaurant I've ever gone to!
author: Kimberly A.

description:
First thing you can't help but notice when you walk in is the decor, which for me was a little overdone.  Makes me feel like I'm walking into a theme park rather than a fine dining establishment.  The service was great.  They were knowledgeable about the menu, very attentive but never made us feel rushed.  

The food was not that impressive.  We started with the dungeness crab, which unless its gone bad you can't go wrong.  I liked the fact that they provided additional utensils to help extract the crab meat.  For main entrees we got the dorade and branzino, Both fish on their own were excellent and well prepared, but they were overwhelmed by the accompaniments.  The sauce de poisson served with the dorade was all you could taste, and the crab and bacon hash served with the branzino seemed pointless since all you end up tasting is bacon.

Coming from out of town this is not someplace that I would put on a list of must visit.
author: Christina K.

description: This would have been my first 5 star review if our server would have made the slightest effort.  Food was wonderful and the dining room was so cozy & unique. The support staff to our server were all friendly and attentive.  We had to make a late reservation so maybe it had been a long night for our server.  Would recommend this place to all seafood lovers !!  We will definitely be going back!
author: Carmen D.

description: Food was amazing but service was so slow and Inattentive today. Usually they are great but waiter was slow never asked how the food was asked for more cocktails desert etc. The place wasn't very busy but if I wasn't a regular I wouldn't come back
author: David B.

description: Have been here five times over the years. Normally spend 2 to 300. Also took a large group one time. Went in last night. It was not busy at all. Asked them if they could make a larger salad. They pulled together the two managers and the chef and decided they could not part with a bit more lettuce. Amazing lack of service and disdain toward their guests. Never going back.
author: J K.

description:
Bad service should not get in the way of good food.

My mother and I went here for a late night Monday dinner... the service was horrible. Here is my dirty laundry list...

1) The server took five minutes to initially hand us a menu.

2) It took another ten minutes for us to get a cocktails list.

3) It took another ten to order cocktails.

4) When the cocktails came they spilled it all over the table.

5) Finally we got to order, but our server had not been by, so we had to flag down someone else.

6) When we got our entrees, one was the wrong thing... it was strange because my mother ordered the steak, they asked how she wanted it cooked, she said medium well and bass came instead, it was a weird mix up.

7) Because of the mix up we waited even longer for our food to come.

8) While we waited they sent over soup to occupy us (the food runner was more apologetic and professional than the server ((if anyone from Farallon reads these reviews promote her!)), but they didn't ask us if we cared for mushroom bisque or if we had a food allergy to anything in it. They thought they were being classy, but their gesture could have resulted in us just having to turn it away. Another glass of the wine we were already drinking would have been a much better gesture.

9) Finally, when the bill came there were two extra desserts on the bill, totaling four desserts, for a table of two... just sayin...

10) Throughout the server was either absent, distracted and not very apologetic...

On top of it all, the food was not the great, for a meal that cost $250, my mother and I should have left dazzeled.. No such luck...

Save a $100 and go to Frascati instead on Russian Hill. The undersea atmosphere is cool, but the easy elegance of Frascati with the cable car passing by did not need to be manufactured in order to create ambiance.
author: Natalie J.

description:
I just had my first taste of the Farallon and it was divine! The service was good, even had a black napkin sent over without requesting to replace my white one so it didn't pill all over my black pants. Wine was always refilled as well as the bread and salted butter (yum!)
Now, let's get to the food! For starters, our table shared the Truffled French Fries and Oysters... OMG, sooo good! My friend and I shared the Chilled Maine Lobster Salad, again another winner. For main entree, I had the Grilled Sterling Silver Farms Petit Filet of Beef w/ Black Truffled Red Wine Vinaigrette which was ah-mazing! It came with a souffle that was very bland but the rest of the meal made up for it. 
I highly recommend this restaurant, especially if you like seafood. I had a bite of my friends black bass and that was fantastic as well.
Happy Dining!
author: Victoria H.

description: Husband took me here for a birthday dinner and had my first raw oysters - they were delicious!!!  We had a seafood feast and everything was phenomenal! I love the jelly fish lights and the energy this place has... such a great date night with great food! We stayed at the Fairmont which was really nice because it was walking distance.  Dessert was awesome and our server was super nice! Must order seafood at this place! Great place to dress up and have fun with great food!
author: Milpitas L.

description: 5 Star all the way around.  Treat as a VIP Customer to an amazing 5 course dinner on my visit 11/9/2013.  The service was impeccable and the food was absolutely delicious.  Definite must try for anyone in the area.
author: Lorie D.

description: We had family dinner here, all of us loved it! delicious food, especially sea bass and lobster! The waiter was very nice. We paid over $500 for 7 people but it is reasonable for expensive restaurant in San Francisco. If you haven't been yet, you should go!
author: Lan P.

description:
Took the Mrs. here for our 15th anniversary.  The decor was borderline over-the-top with a Disneyesque feel to it but I found it amusing.  At least it wasn't boring.  We started with the seafood platter which had crab legs, half a lobster, shrimp and oysters; delicious but pricey.  My main was a moonfish which I wanted to try for the first time.  It was a bit dry but I think this is because we took too long with our platter and they held the main dish back even though it was ready to present.  I forgot what the Mrs had but she liked it.  What was especially memorable for the Mrs. was the dessert; rhubarb cherry pie.  She found it excellent.  

Good overall experience.  The waiter understood we had theatre tickets and paced our meal accordingly.
author: J H.

description: Came here for our anniversary dinner last night at the recommendation of the concierge at our hotel. They were right to steer us there.  The decor is especially unique and gives it a warm and intimate feel.  The service was great - when we told the maître d of our special occasion he made sure we had a great booth- said it was Sharon Stone's favorite when she visits. Made my night. Food - we loved the Dungeness crab salad-very fresh, halibut main course melts in your mouth, NY strip med rare was a big portion with prawns on the side was very tender and tasty. And a small treat for the anniversary at the end of the night. Everything was prepared in a way that brought out great flavors - best I've in a while. Pricey but well worth it.
author: Craig C.

description:
I didn't make the reservation, so cannot comment on that.  I can say, however, that the ambience, food and service was very good.

The jellyfish lighting and arched ceilings were so pretty and welcoming.  We had a booth in the corner so it was cozy and quiet.

The server was very attentive and engaging.  The chef was accommodating in serving a rack of lamb as an entree even though it's only offered as part of a sampler on the menu.  

The tuna tartare was fresh though a smidge too lemony for me.  The halibut was likely the most moist and nicely seared halibut I've ever had.  The mojito was very good and not watered down, and the blueberry tea was delicious.  I only wondered why it was served in a glass with a straw when it is a smoking hot drink.  Presentation, perhaps?

The overall experience was really worthwhile and would return the next time I'm in town.
author: PJ T.

description:
beautiful, fabulous, delicious, amazing...  pretty much sums it up.  my husband arrived a little early and sat at the bar for a few drinks.  the bartender mixed up a few *amazing* cocktails.  you could tell this guy knew how to do his job very well.  our server was very informative and helpful as well.  the food was superb.  i had the shrimp parfait (i've never had it that good!), the shellfish bisque and the lobster.  everything was DELICIOUS!  not a thing to complain about!  for dessert, i had an ice cream tiramasu something-or-other and it was the perfect ending to an amazing meal.  we were celebrating our anniversary and they decorated the plate with a sweet greeting :-)  
i very much look forward to the next Farallon opportunity!
author: Anjanette M.

description: Service was off. 7pm reservation they ran out of their 5 course tasting menu which was a bit odd since it was early in evening.
author: Antonio R.

description:
SEAFOOD - GREAT

STEAK - F*IN AMAZING?!?!  how is this possible, but it is !
               No other steak on earth so far after 809 steak orders, has it come even close to this place's steak.

So weird... STEAK??.... MUST TRY.

If you happen to eat here, order more food , you'll get so damn hungry after.
author: Calvin C.

description: I took my fiance to the Farallon last Saturday to celebrate her birthday and we had the best experience. I'm typically of the belief that food service quality doesn't matter that much to me as long as the food is good but the Farallon staff was top-notch in addition to the food. They clearly explained everything to us in detail and kept checking to make sure we were happy. They cleaned our table after each serving. And the icing on the cake was that they decorated our sorbet with a candle and wrote the words, Happy Birthday, in chocolate on the plate. I was really touched by that. We went home happy. A+ for this first-time guest.
author: Richard W.

description:
What a major disappointment. $250 dinner for two got us ignored for 2.75 hours and on a birthday no less. I had called ahead to request a table in the pool room & got stuck upstairs in an alleyway banquette, staring at the back of people's heads - yeah nice "decor." thanks uglier-version-of-anna-wintour hostess. Are the menus THAT dirty that you are so compelled to wipe them down like it's a religion, while ignored patrons pile in aimlessly? No one appreciates your simpering sweet "eye" smile. Quit wiping and start greeting and seating. We got to watch the servers kiss a table of the chef's friends butts while we were ignored the entire night. Here are the major complaints:
--Drinks took 30 minutes, placing our order another 15 minutes on top of that, 
--had to ask twice for a second round of drinks, 
--no amuse bouche as we watched the "special" table of 6 get served their amuse by 4 servers, and finally
--our entrees came out 2hours and 20mins after we sat down and we only had one other course!! AND as expected on a night with such terrible service, when our food finally came out it was COLD. 

Did I mention it was supposed to be a birthday celebration? What makes it more maddening is that two tables who sat after us got their food before we did. 

Our server was a sweaty, uncomfortably awkward mess. 

The food was OK, nothing great. Duck first course was overly sweet. The spinach salad at least had some good stilton in it. The tombo tuna was cooked well and was very fresh however the supporting side dish of lentils and beets was bland. The filet mignon was also cooked well but like I said, COLD. No offer of dessert. Nothing but a nervous stare once we asked for our check - yeah dude, we ARE pissed. It's not the first time we've been here but it was our last. And I'm still fuming for ruining what could have been a great birthday experience. Leave this place to the blue-hairs and tourists who don't know any better.
author: Emily C.

description:
Was a recommendation from the concierge.  Being we found out about the place 1 1/2 hours before they opened I was not able to make reservations.  We were able to get there shortly after opening at 5:30 and secure a table without a reservation.  

Our server, Deane, was wonderful.  She asked about timeframe to be sure we wouldn't be late for a later engagement.  Made recommendations from the menu, bar, and informed us of historical aspect of the location.  

My partner started with a tuna roll and for my first course heriloom tomato salad.  My salad was tastier than the roll.  I could have had nothing but the salad for all three courses.  I wanted more of it.  Second course brought us corn stuffed tortellini and shellfish bisque.  Both very tasty dishes.  The corn stuffed tortellini was different then what we are normally used to.  For our third entree my partner had the halibut and I had the Hawaiian Ono.  The ono was cooked like Ahi tun, rare on the inside.  Both of the fish dishes had very good flavor.  The Ono not as tasty as Roy's but almost there.  

For desert my partner opted for the Baked Alaska and I went with the Strawberry Buckwheat Shortcake.  The meal started out light and surprisingly ended light as the deserts were not heavy and too sweet.  

The environment was festive.  We were able to sit in the back room and observe the chefs preparing the variety of food.  The margaritas were wonderful.  The service was great.  A great way to start our evening in San Francisco.
author: Chris S.

description:
Decor: Its weird. And cool. And kinda dated. And kinda wacky. And kinda cool. I couldn't make up my mind. I would give this 5 stars except I think the decor might put some people off. However, if you are not "too cool" and you are up for some fun - go for it. It looks like a mixture of Neptune's underwater palace meets Tuscan cathedral. It's definitely an eclectic experience. So SF.

The food: A-MAZE-ING, I think my eyes rolled into the back of my head.

Service: Great

Price: Expensive

Other: 

Normally i avoid any "touristy" places near Union Square. But for a special occasion, Its worth making an exception. They know food!!!!!

They have an amazing raw bar. Next time I want to sit there and eat! Also I would try to sit in the front room for a more casual-cool dining experience. The larger, quieter room in back is a bit more formal.

YUM!!!!!!!
author: V V.

description: Very cool place. Dinner was great & staff was really nice
author: Brian L.

description:
Wow, was this place good!  Read about it on yelp and happy to say, we were not disappointed.  Since I am a beet fanatic, we started with the beet salad.  I used to think that beets with goat cheese was the best thing, but beets and crab is even better!  For our second course, we shared the Ahi tuna and the shellfish bisque.  Would recommend both of them.  We finished our dinner with Duck and Cod.  Both outstanding dishes.  

The atmosphere was most fitting to the place;  the staff was attentive and helpful.  Our water glasses never got less than half full before being refilled.  

All in all, an excellent place, and although it is expensive, it is well-worth it!
author: Peter K.

description: The ocean threw up in here and it wasn't good. 70s kitsch and did was sub par and overpriced. Have no idea how it is so highly rated.
author: John L.

description:
Had dinner here on a Saturday night with a customer of mine. Had reservations for 8. We arrived at 7:20 and they ended up having a table for us at 7:35. :) Plus!

Sat down and the waittress checked my coat in for me. The place has a great 1920s 1930s, yet under the sea sort of feel. I loved the jellyfish lighting near the bar. Had a view of the chefs cooking, which is always neat to watch. In general the portions are not large, but if you have one item from each of the offerings, appetizer, main, dessert etc. you probably will be full.

Started off with a glass of Chardonnay.

Had the heirloom tomato bisque. Expected a tiny bowl, but was a good size starter soup. Tomatoes tasted so fresh! 

For my main course had the CAST IRON ROASTED MARYLAND STRIPED BASS: w/tiny white bean purée, roasted cipollini & fennel,
warm Dungeness crab, red wine vinaigrette. This was sooooooo good. 

For dessert: my dinner companion had a blackberry peach cobbler w/honey ice cream. WOW! The honey ice cream was done just right. The taste of honey wasn't overpowering and really complimented the cobbler I had the BITTERSWEET CHOCOLATE MALT GATEAU (vanilla bean semifreddo, milk chocolate malt crunch, espresso crème anglaise). another WOW!! 

All in all great dining experience. The only reason I did not give 5 stars is, even though our waittress was attentive, they forgot our bottled water, and we had to ask for it a few times. You just never know with tap water ;)
author: Kim T.

description: Two of my friends and I dined here, and we absolutely loved it! We each ordered one of the fish options for our entree. Every dish was sublime, and we ate every last bite. The best part was we were in and out of there within an hour. This was all thanks to the friendly and prompt service provided at Farallon. Also we went there to celebrate our friend's birthday, and she was given a hand written birthday card from the restaurant. Such a sweet gesture really perfected the evening.
author: Hugh Jass J.

description: This is one of our favorite places to eat when in the city! The fresh seafood, drinks and decor are amazing! I feel like I'm under the sea when I'm here. Makes it even more of an experience while enjoying your meal. The service is always top notch as well. We took some family members visiting from England and they enjoyed it here more than any other place while in California.
author: Amy S.

description: I have had two great experiences here at Farallon. My only input is this: they often send out emails about special event dinners, but they do not offer vegetarian options. I have given them feedback but they have just ignored it.
author: Sharon K.

description:
It'd been years since I'd been here.
Work dinner - medium to fun people.  Had heard Farallon qualitiy had slipped.
NOT true! 
Service was excellent - great guy who was absolutely full of information.  Paid great attention but didn't linger.  Managed the table of 8 flawlessly.  Great recommendations, including wine. 

Really enjoyed it and will be back fo' sho'.
author: amy b.

description:
I love Farallon!  Of course, if you eat there during the regular times, it can be pricey but I went during Dine About Town!  I had:

ARTICHOKE AND FENNEL SOUP
lemon oil

ROASTED HAWAIIAN MAHI MAHI
celeriac salad, flageolet beans, arugula pistou

PUMPKIN UPSIDE DOWN CAKE
bourbon vanilla bean caramel, vanilla chantilly

Their pumpkin cake was the best! It kind of reminded me of a pumpkin muffin. 

Decor was nice.  Looked like you were eating underwater!  Definitely go there for Dine About Town!
author: Wendy H.

description:
I love when someone else pays for dinner and they take you to a place like this. We went all out and ordered like crazy, so I'll just tell you now, everything is good. 

Fresh lobster tail, perfect oysters, crisped and flaky white fish, a butternut squash mix that was absolutely to die for, and desserts that I would kill over. The gateau was especially excellent. 

They also have a great wine list, hot waiters, and the coolest decor. I am definitely a fan.
author: Allison A.

description: By far the best seafood restaurant in SF, if you want high end, awesome seafood this is the place, it is amazing. From the time you check in at the desk, to the time you roll yourself away because you ate too much food, amazing. The wine list is impeccable, the desserts to die for, the atmosphere, and waiters are all great. I have nothing bad to say
author: Gene G.

description:
Even if you don't care for seafood everyone in San Francisco should visit Farallon for the light fixtures. Walking into the restaurant is like looking out the window of a deep see submersible. Jellyfish chandeliers made of colored glass reflect along the sea colored walls making the restaurant feel almost surreal.

The menu is exciting and even the most odd sounding of combinations look and taste delicious.

Farallon is easily one of my top five San Fransisco restaurants.
author: Cori N.

description:
Farallon is my all time favorite special occasion restaurant. I like that it is fancy but not pretentious, like some other expensive seafood joints in SF (Ame). You can get away with wearing simply a t-shirt & jeans or go all out with a suit & tie. Pretty much anything goes at Farallon. 

My hubby & I went for our anniversary on Monday night (13 years thankyouverymuch!) & also to celebrate my new job. Since I hadn't dined here in years, I was worried that maybe it wouldn't be as good as I remembered. I am happy to report that it is still an incredible dining experience. 

We went all out & ordered 5 courses. I know that's the norm in these restaurants, but really, when was the last time I had a 5 course meal? I can't even remember. We started with a dozen oysters. I like that they give you a list with the name of each oyster. I never remember them anyway, but it was a nice touch nonetheless.
