2nd course: Little gems salad. This was one of my faves of the night. A small, simple salad with sliced radishes & the most delicious smoked trout. I tried to savor every bite & vowed I would order this for dessert (can you do that?). My hubby had the Summer Melon Salad which was totally unexpected. Chopped up pieces of honeydew topped with a sorbet-like lemon ice on top. On the side were thinly sliced pieces of duck prosciutto. Fan-cy! 

3rd course: Braised octopus. I have to say this was a bit of a disappointment, only because I am an octopus fanatic & have been spoiled by the octopus they serve in Greece. This dish was slightly overcooked and of course, the portions were small. I would have liked to have seen multiple tentacles on my plate instead of just one, but I'll just have to wait until I go to Greece in a few weeks. As I said, I'm spoiled. 

4th course: Maryland striped bass & Petite filet of beef. I was thoroughly enjoying my fish when my hubby offered me a bite of his filet. O-M-G, I forgot all about my dish. That beef was amazing, and I don't even like beef. My hubby said that was the best filet he had ever had in his life. In a seafood restaurant! Maybe I should order the filet for dessert? 

5th course: OK, I went with actual dessert. Of course I had almost no room in my tummy for it but when you decide to go all out on a meal, you can't stop short at dessert. I ordered the Blackberry peach pie & coffee (decaf please, I don't want to be up all night). The coffee guy was cute & kept kidding that he was going to give me regular. Anyway the dessert was also amazing & was the perfect ending to a perfect meal.  I practically rolled out of that place. 

If I were rich, I would eat at Farallon every night of my life.
author: Erin S.

description: Taking myself out to dinner tonight on my way to SFO.  awwww yeah. This place is huge!! But also very quaint in the vibe. I love the underwater theme. It's fun but not cheesy at all. I sat at a small bar table near the door I love it :) they are into local and sustainable practices which is what I always look for in these fancy california  restaurants.
author: Vanessa V.

description:
The only thing you need to know: This is a Kuleto restaurant.  

It's pricey but it's so lovely inside and the food is sophisticated and tasteful, it's worth it.  They offer a modern seafood menu, and an extensive wine list.  I've been here quite a few times, for fun, for birthdays and the most recent, the awkward "first dinner" with both my parents and my boyfriend.  It's that kind of place, good for special occasions.


The first time came here my waiter gave me a brief history of the restaurant.  This place used to be an old bath house, the tables in the back portion of the dining room are sitting at the bottom of what used to be an olympic sized swimming pool.  I believe when Kuleto designed the restaurant he incorporated some of the original tiling which gives this place a more authentic feel.  The restaurant has a sort of Atlantis, underwater utopia theme, with glass jellyfish hanging from the ceiling and glass sea urchin lights.
author: S. F.

description:
Went to Farallon last night for dinner because I'd heard great things about their happy hour. We made it into a very happy two and a half hours. 

They have an excellent "6 before 7" menu with appetizers, cocktails and wine. From this menu two of us ordered and shared the truffled french fries, the sliders, the soup of the day (olive oil and some kind of mushroom mousse...different and delicious), and eight glasses of wine.. We also got the seared rare ahi tuna off of the main menu. They serve bread with Hawaiian sea salt on it, which was really unique. Everything was absolutely delicious. The fries were the best fries I've ever had, and the broth and noodles in the ahi dish were unbelievable.

Service was impeccable. Our waiter (Brian) was extremely knowledgeable about the menu and made us feel completely welcome. He was available but didn't linger or make us feel rushed at any time, even though we were there for so long. 

The decor is fun...like many others said it looks like you're under water, with jelly fish lamps and menus that feel like kelp. It's not cheesy at all though, it's just a really nice atmosphere. 

Only complaints are that the wine was a little watered down (but what can you expect for $6 a glass), and they canceled my reservation through Open-Table because I didn't sit in the main dining room, which I thought was a little weird since we did eat off of the dinner menu. Other than that, we had a great time and will definitely be back.
author: Cori H.

description: Great place for an upscale dinner for a special occasion.  The restaurant is gorgeous inside, the service is great, and the food was delicious.  We got the shellfish platter for an appetizer and it was delicious.  This was one of my favorite meals of our trip.
author: Michelle H.

description: It's a winner in my book. Happy hour was great. Only place I've found in America that cooks tuna better than I can at home. Truffle fries were legit.  Service was awesome and personable.  Walking distance from the hotel we stayed at which was nice.  It's on my list next time out here for another visit to do the raw bar right.
author: MJ M.

description: What is wrong with the helpers that give this place more that 3 stars? Are they all in some weird tourist brain? Ok I would give it a 3rd star for the setting but certainly not the food. The oysters were $3.50 each not $1. I ordered 3 types 1 was outstanding, 1 was mediocre and 1 I though was old and I might get sick from. I had the soft shell crab appetizer which was small and flavorless. My husband ordered the flounder and told me he had no idea what fish he was served but it wasn't flounder... For the price go somewhere else...
author: Nancy W.

description:
Date/Time: Saturday - 8:30pm
Occasion:  New Years Eve dinner
Party of:  Four
Ordered: Family style appetizers: dozen oysters (kumamoto, miyagi, and beausoleil), half cracked dungeness crab.  Courses:  foie gras, shellfish bisque, grilled dorade with house-made linguine, tuna tartare, maine lobster with sweet bread, and petit filet of beef.
Location:  Near the heart of Union Square. Beautiful interior, Parking is a headache especially on a rainy day. Valet: $12.00...darn pricey!  If you can arrive earlier and circle for parking, do it and save yourself the money and get a cocktail. ;)
Total incl gratuity: $426.00

This was certainly a good choice for New Years Eve.  The restaurant is beautiful, service is good, and food is memorable.  We came here to end 2010 with good company and good food.  It was a little pricier than we expected; it was NYE so they had special prix fixed menus.  The oysters we had were fresh - the three we chose were very good.  My favorite would still be the kumamoto.  The dungeness crab was also fresh.  The meat came right out but my only disappointment was the size - it was quite small.  I was pleased with my three course meal.  The foie gras was so delish!  It is a huge round of pate.  They give you three pieces of toasted brioche to go with it and it is not enough.  Our waitress Leila read my mind when she came by our table and saw we were brioche-less with more than half the foie gras left so she ordered some fresh ones for us.  If you like foie gras, this dish is a must order!  I enjoyed my shellfish bisque although it was a bit rich.  I think it pushed me over the edge and I was so full by the time I got to my third course, which was a shame because I felt like I couldn't fully enjoy it.  I had ordered the dorade and it was grilled to perfection.  the fish was moist and the flavor was very good..like a moist saba.  We, unfortunately, had to rush through the last half of our meal since we had to hurry over to another party.  All in all, our experience definitely got two thumbs up.  I'd love to return for more food and of course their foie gras.
author: Jess C.

description:
Great restaurant.  Food is excellent, seafood was great.  We had 3 course dinner - portions are on small side as is typical of high end places, but were excellent.

The service is great, very attentive without overdoing it.  Wine recommendation was superb.  Not a super trendy place, but very nice.  Noise level acceptable, not a hush hush type of place.  We were in town at a local hotel within walking distance of the restaurant, so parking not a problem.

We've been here twice over past 3 years during visits to the city - great both times, second time even better!
author: Lynto L.

description:
I was recently invited to this restaurant for a business dinner. When I walked in I was amazed, it was beautiful with a killer seafood / under the ocean theme. The seafood (crabs, lobsters & oysters) by the cook's station looked amazing as well. I was psyched for an killer time with a terrific meal. 

Well the first thing you should do is if you have a babysitter watching the kids, tell them you'll be an hour late. The service was super slow. A 3 course meal took 2 hours. The Atlantic Salmon Salad was nice. Not terrific, but worth a try. It kind of reminded me of a plate of lox with some special seafood spread. The meal was OK. I had the Sea Bass. The skin was too thick and a little overcooked. After I peeled it away, the meat of the fish was a little better than average. The best part was the dessert. I was really impressed with booth the Hazelnut Pear tart (see the picture of the pear on the tan tart) and the Chocolate "something". Both were delicious! 

I would give this place 4 stars if the service was better. I would give it another star if the meal was much better. Overall, the 3 stars was for theme more than anything else. 

Enjoy.
author: Andy G.

description:
Kinda like being Jacques Cousteau diving deep in the ocean or being in the movie 10,000 leagues under the sea,......with plenty of oxygen and great food. 

Have had dinner at Farallon a few times, and each time never disappointed. Dishes are beautifully prepared. Only have ordered the fish entree's, but then again......it is a seafood palace. (and of course appetizers : love the crab claws, salad : love the heirloom beets) 

Great location, Great food, Great environment, Great service. 

Weekends are definitely busy / crazy. Week nights are better. 

Will be back again and again....hopefully soon.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
I'm so confused about why people hype this place up. The restaurant is beautiful inside don't get me wrong but thats the only positive I have for them. I went a couple years ago so hopefully the service and food are better now. Our server looked like she was 12 years old and didn't do a good job but I feel bad saying that cause she looked like a baby.  Okay the food is horrible! We ordered a dish that had a huge variety of seafood and it did not taste fresh at all! :( The clams were the worst thing we had, they had sand in them and tasted old. I seriously spit it out. I truly hope they have improved but my experience was awful!
2 stars for being pretty/creative inside
author: Meredith D.

description:
Came here with my awesome gf for our anniversary dinner! did nat know it was right across the street from the westin we were staying at in union square, hell yeah!

when we got there the atmosphere was nice and low key. the attire is dressy, but its like SF dressy, so that would mean nice jeans and a button up are cool.

we got some oysters, glass of white wine, tuna poke, lobster, the fish that started with a B, i think branzino, and i got the filet mignon.

The oysters were pretty good (i prefer swan oyster depot) and the white wine our host requested went really well with it and the tuna poke.

the tuna poke was perfect and it came with these thin crispy chips that were perfect to put the tuna on.

The branzino that my gf got was aiite, i think they hyped it too much. My filet was PERFECT! I looked at it and it started to cut itself, THATS how tender it was

Id def recommend people try this place out if you looking for some fancy seafood
author: Steven C.

description: In terms of the reputation that it gets from reviewers, I expected slightly better. The oysters were fresh but my main dish, the white bass, was on the dryer side. There was a nice ambiance and the decorations were all underwater/sea creature themed. My waiter was mediocre. He did his job, but did not smile at once and make the experience memorable. Price is in $18-$30 range. A good first experience, but most likely will not go back.
author: Megan L.

description: Awesome ambiance with delicious food! Everything on the menu was seafood with the exception of a fillet. I had the lobster bisque to start with the scallop entree, very good but I expected more than 3 scallops for $30. The service and presentation was outstanding.
author: Rich S.

description:
Massive diarrhea the next day. Got your attention? It's true. 

Ok, it wasn't all bad. The service was generally spectacular except for my entree, which went MIA after I asked the waiter to box it for me.

The other great thing was my dessert, which was gingerbread, cinnamon apple and vanilla ice cream with ginger chunks. We absolutely devoured it.

I don't know why people love the foie gras. Sure, it was a nice large chunk of buttery duck liver, but after eating it, my stomach became horribly unsettled and I wasn't able to eat the rest of my meal comfortably. (Doesn't mean I didn't try eating it. I really did!) 

It's hard for me to comment on the rest of the meal, mainly because of the immense stomach pains I had following the foie gras. I generally have the stomach to handle fatty foods (especially foie gras, which I love!) but it just didn't want to take it.

For my other dinner companions, all of whom are HUGE foodies, the food was just okay. Not really worth the price. One ordered the scallops as the main dish and halfway died of starvation. One ordered the special dessert (I think it was a rum cake, kumquats and banana ice cream?) She insisted we all sample it. After a bite, someone explain "Oh honey, come and eat my good dessert instead!" Ha.

The ambiance felt... cheesy. The jellyfish chandeliers were interesting, but the place has a Cheesecake Factory feel. I'm not holding the decorations against the place. I'm holding the night of acid reflux and the hour I spent on the toilet against them.
author: Nadia S.

description:
Took my girlfriend here for her birthday. Located conveniently in Union Square ( She did some shopping beforehand ). It doesn't look like much from the outside just a glass door and the sign above it. However, once you get inside, you are in for a surprise!

The restaurant has an amazing "under the sea" theme to it, with flowing curves in the ceiling made to look like sea shells, to jellyfish hanging from the ceiling. The main dining room even has a rustic feel to it, kind of like having dinner in an old galleon. This place definitely nails it for ambiance, stunning and romantic.

The service was top notch, as expected from a very fine dining restaurant, with what seemed like teams of waiters.

The food was amazing! We ordered the lobster and the branzini. Both were extremely flavorful and were complimented by delicious sides and sauces that really brought out the flavors. I mentioned the birthday celebration when making the reservation, and when dessert came out, there were candles and everything. Really made for a wonderful moment. I really recommend this place for a romantic dinner or special occasion. A treat for the taste buds AND the senses!
author: Alex B.

description: I ended up here since i was staying around the corner in The City and saw a UYE advertised.  Well, I didn't see any Yelpers, but decided to stay anyways (Noel M. came to the rescue).  I ordered the Summer Mellon salad.  It was extremely refreshing.  Shortly thereafter, a bread basket was sat in front of me.  It was a nice touch with some sea salt sprinkled on top of the butter.  The Hemingway Daiquiris were nice and strong.  The potato croquettes were tasty; nice and crunchy outside, soft & creamy inside, too bad you only get 3.  The servers were very nice and attentive.  The doormen, unfortunately, were too busy people watching to open the door.  I'd definitely want to come back and check out their dinner offerings.
author: Tanisha B.

description:
It's kind of pointless to write a review of restaurant that averages 4 stars on yelp and nearly 500 reviewers'. However, I will because I want to tell you my recent experience and why the yelpers are spot on for this locale as well. 

If you are lucky enough to dine at the Farralon you are in for a treat a real treat. You truly cannot go wrong here. Stellar cuisine and service can't be beat. If you want to impress a seafood lover - this is the place. If you want to pass the check to the corporation that employees you then this is the place! 

Soft shell crab was just divine and perfectly prepared. The combination of crunchy and soft moist crabmeat inside was wonderful. For the main course the sturgeon was a real highlight, it was the sauce (its all about the sauce that was light but decadent) topped with caviar and accompanied with little quail eggs that sent me straight to the clouds with that dish. 

Save room for dessert as it too was delicately presented just as the seafood items on the menu. I had the Leche Merengada organic strawberries, blackberries, raspberries, hibiscus syrup, 
lemon cream, noyaux-almond praline. This was light and fluffy yet full of flavor for that sweetness to end an exquisite dinning experience.
author: Kristina A.

description:
The food was excellent and the service was among the best I've ever had - every server who brought food to our table described the dishes in detail!
The apps were great, even if the portions were small.  The main courses were truly excellent (I had a scallop dish I would reorder in an instant), and the desserts were as delicious as they were inventive!
author: Jim B.

description:
How much do I love this place?  Words cannot describe.
The Crab bisque was amazing, I waited a year to go back
to this place and had it again, and it was the same as before.
I love that they have one person just passing bread, and you get 
to watch the pastry chef create all night.  Last time we had
to leave to soon, and I can't wait to go back!
author: Robyn A.

description: Accidental discovery.  Went in for a quick bite at the bar at the restaurant next to my hotel.  Found an available bar table and was treated like a King at Farallon.  I also remembered how much I enjoyed a meal here years ago.  I'm not a big fan of the Union Square area because it is touristy, crowded, over-priced and not usually the best service.  While Farallon is not inexpensive, they deliver.  Delicious seafood.  Great wine.  Great service.
author: Ben J.

description:
I am somehow beginning to believe that this could become more ritual than special occasion.

The platters and the raw bar are what make the experience here so special after all. In fact, I beseech you: don't bother with the dinner menu at all. Sit at the bar and order some wine. You'll find yourself seductively tracing hearts into the pane of glass that separates you from an ice bed laden with colorful shellfish. 

A special thanks to Jade L. for her rave reviews about this place. If I hadn't heard you go on about the wonders of Farallon on innumerable occasions, I would never have given it so many chances to impress.
author: dani d.

description: $1 oysters on a thursday till 7 PM smack in Union Square!! What a FIND!!! I will definitely be back.  Aside from the $1 oysters, this restaurant has a cool ambiance, friendly waiters, awesome happy hour menu.  My gf and I also got the croquets and sliders.  We literally gobbled everything up
author: Stephanie C.

description:
So... went to Farallon Saturday night for special occasion. Booked the reservation thru their online link to Open Table. Someone called to confirm the day before and requested a callback... then I knew they meant business!

The parking situation is tough since you're right next to Union Square but since it was the weekend and after 6pm we lucked out on street parking. They do have Valet. 

Beautiful decor and they seated us immediately. It has a very cozy feel but still upscale. I'd like to know if there's a story behind the faded tile look to the ceilings. The kitchen is out in view of most tables which I like - adds to the anticipation. 

The waitress was very knowledgeable and energetic. We had the following:

- Sweet corn and shellfish bisque - I'm a sucker for bisques esp the creamy velvety ones and this was no exception! Just delicious!
- Shared the Prince Edward Island mussels - took a bit long to come out but I think it's part of the experience as the menu is set up to enjoy 3 courses. So don't come to dine in a hurry!
- My companion had the prawn and scallop quenelles - kinda like a poached seafood dumpling without the shell if you had to equate it with a Chinese food item. Topped with fried matsutake mushrooms which added nice texture but I just didn't like the feel of the quenelle - it's a personal preference thing. 

For entrees, we both had the Pan Roasted Mediterranean Branzino which is a light flakey white fish and the skin was left on and pan roasted to crispy perfection. The celery root puree was silky smooth. I was surprised at the nice personal touch of the Chef de cuisine coming out to present the entree to you. 

They made note of the special occasion and were nice enough to remember. I do appreciate their attention to detail and the service was 5 stars. 

Will definitely come back here again - perhaps bring the folks for a treat when they're in town.
author: Kuishingal F.

description:
This place is really great.  The staff are nice and friendly.  The atmosphere is amazing.  The inside of the main area is an old pool and the roof has been preserved with all the tile work and art.  And, the lighting is really amazing.

The food was really great and I had some of the best oysters I've ever eaten.  However, I don't think it was good enough for 5 stars.  Further, it was CRAZY expensive.  I think they're charging way too much for what they ultimately deliver.
author: Jason L.

description:
4.5 Stars
The intro:
  In the Union Square district lies a wonderful seafood restaurant. It's decor is like dining in a underwater ocean floor filled with sea creatures.

The Food:
  Seafood is done creatively and tastefully well here. The fish dishes are cooked to perfection. The raw shellfish is always very fresh and always beautifully presented. I recommend ordering the tasting menu.

The Decor:
  The decor here is very interesting. It feels like you're dining in a underwater ocean floor filled with jellyfish and other deep sea life. Pretty romantic but it does get a little noisy if the restaurant fills up.

The Service:
  The service is good here. Nothing out of the ordinary compared to other fine dining establishments.

The Summary:
  One of the best fine dining seafood restaurants in the city. My wife and I always enjoy the good food here.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Delicious and absolutely satisfied my seafood cravings! I dined here with my friend while on a business trip to SF. We both enjoyed our dinners very much. I had an all seafood meal including:  a blue point raw oyster on the half shell (the best!), a half dungeness crab on ice, and diver scallops. The raw oyster was my favorite! It's unfortunate I only had one. I highly advise avoiding the crab if you don't want to get messy. This dish required a lot of work. I made a mess and had to get a fresh napkin afterwards. I also indulged in my friend's bittersweet chocolate malt gateau which was amazing! It tasted like the malt whopper candies, but much more decadent.

The service was amazing and timely. Our server was very helpful in helping me decide on which oyster to order (they have quite the selection) and was necessary when I had no idea what the difference was. The restaurant decor is also beautiful and seafood themed. I really liked the jelly fish hanging lamps near the entrance. We also sat right next to the open kitchen and got to watch the chefs in action. I'll definately indulge here in a future visit.
author: Linda T.

description: The food was okay..I can't think of a more pretentious place to eat dinner. It made me feel extremely poor. The servers and hosts all give off that vibe. "You don't belong here! you are way too poor." They just come off super fake. The service isn't as great as it should be when you're paying so much money. They forgot my dad's espresso!
author: Maria S.

description: I have hosted events here but had yet to dine here until tonight. A true gem. The bisque was amazing, the cod was beyond belief and the service was impeccable. A must dine location in such a competitive market. Highly recommend.
author: Brett H.

description:
On a  search for an elegant place with a great after-dinner drink and dessert? Lo' and behold there is Farallon!

"The Nudge": I'm SO happy I don't have to trek alllll the way to Buena Vista for a great irish coffee-esque drink anymore. This was a warm, not too sweet, coffee libation topped with delicious home-made whipped cream that totally hit the spot, and I will DEFINITELY be coming back just for this. It's perfect for a cold chilly evening.

As for our waitress -- she was simply so down-to-earth and sweet. I think one of the biggest turn-offs when you venture to a high end restaurant and sit in the bar area is that you're gonna be treated like the peanut gallery. But our waitress was so incredibly attentive and inviting, I will surely be coming back to dine in the main hall. Hopefully she's a good representation of the rest of the service!

And finally, but not least, the decor: Gorgeous under-water theme! It feels like the Bellagio, but with lots of jelly fish chandeliers and beautiful white couches resembling clam shells. Very cool.

Will definitely be back, and am excited about the rest of the menu!
author: Gail N.

description: The service was very good but the portions were small and the food was only okay.  After a forgettable salad, a buffet-quality scallop entree (just three small scallops???), and dessert, I went to Walgreen's to pick up a snack to supplement my dinner.
author: Eric M.

description:
I have to recommend this place as far as the best place to take your spouse on a anniversary dinner.  Expect a full 5 course meal, you won't be disappointed.  I love the atmosphere and under water theme.   
One thing I thought was funny, they have a crumb cleaner, she comes over and cleans up any crumbs off the table and makes sure everything is clean.
author: Derick S.

description:
The best salad mixed lettuce w/cheese, onion, and strawberries ever!  Well I don't really like salads, but this one was great.

The fish was good as well as the calamari.

I'll have to try the set menu with the wine pairings next time.
author: D N.

description: What a dining experience it was.  It was our wedding anniversary and I suprised the missus by taking her there.  The food, ambience, and service was superb in every way.  Christy was fantastic in helping us choose from all the menu choices and the reaction from my wife when we walked in was priceless.   Take your other half there for a most memorable dining experience and you won't be sorry.
author: steven r.

description: Excellent seafood; superb service; Creative nautical decor.
author: Glenn O.

description:
What happened to the food portions here?

1- tiny Scallop 
Crab Cakes - very small, like little nuggets 
Some Fish dish - minuscule - like the size of 2 small fingers

in-n out burger - at the crappy wharf - afterwards.
Food portion is too SMALL
Price is quite HIGH !!
Need Adjustment!
author: Pug P.

description:
Phenomenal. 

My friends and I decided that we wanted to try something unique to San Francisco. I'm so glad we made the choice for this restaurant. The decor was beautiful and under-the-sea themed. Like an elegant version of The Little Mermaid. It is located right near Union Square and offers valet parking for $12.

Although the menu changes quite often, according to our waiter, everything we ordered that night was amazing. I had a summer melon salad with duck prosciutto as my first course. Absolutely amazing. I forgot what I had for my second course, but it was a grilled fish with caviar and potatoes. Also amazing. Dessert here was to die for. The pricing isn't that bad, compared to most other seafood places in the area. The service is what makes the restaurant worth coming too. Our waiter, Luke, was knowledgeable on every dish in the menu, but personable and attentive at the same time. 

I know that from now on, every time I am in SF, I will be making a visit to this restaurant.
author: Al L.

description: I want those lamps! Gorgeous glass jelly fish lamps hang from the celling giving you a swanky, under the sea vibe. We had drinks and appetizers at the bar and they were delish. The house specialty cocktail was a yummy mix of chambord, champagne, and a lemon drop and the truffle fries were AMAZING. Great service at a very classy place with prices to match.
author: Kirsten A.

description:
One of my best friends from out of town was visiting with her mom, and we wanted to do a fancy-pants dinner out on the town. I planned pretty last-minute, and Farallon was available on opentable AND got pretty great reviews on Yelp, so I thought, why not?

Our first impression of the place was the decor. It's an underwater theme (seafood, get it?) - done imaginatively and very tastefully (I can imagine an underwater theme getting really tacky really quickly). 

Service was impeccable- everything I expected from a ritzy SF restaurant. We even overheard another patron complaining about his food, but our waiter handled it very gracefully. 

The food was delicious. We opted only for a two-course meal (plus dessert) - the sashimi appetizer was perfect (you could taste the freshness in the fish), and the salmon was well-complimented by its vegetable sides. The best part though was definitely desert. Farallon's carrot cake was to die for, and came with a heaping portion of cream cheese ice cream, which I didn't even know existed. And, even better, I overheard our waiter telling another table that the recipe for the cake had been published in the SF chronicle! I'll be attempting it from home.

Given the price, Farallon is definitely worth the food and dining experience.
author: Jane H.

description:
Eaten here a few times. The food is great. The service is amazing. The table arrangements suck. I dont mind the decor but its not hip. 
Out of towner's love this place. I can see why, its central, close to theatre's shopping and film. Plus its def. not the cheesecake factory. Not as local feeling and SF experience oriented as i would want if I were visiting but whatev, im not visiting. 
Eat here because the seafood is fabulous and the variety is grand.
Lots of shellfish varieties which, if you care about eating seafood responsibly, takes the anxiety out of it.
author: claire l.

description:
We had a great experience. Anyone who thinks the portions are small, I dare you to go to Quince, where the food evaporates as you reach for it.

Farallon is a beautiful, bustling, friendly place. The mosaiced dining room is built atop an old swimming pool, which is still used. The decor is tastefully over-the-top aquatic. But the focus on serving truly kick-ass food is not lost.

I ordered the salmon, which had a whole lot going on. There was impossibly tender squid on there. The fish was barely seared, with a nice crisp on it, and sashimi-like interior. There were tomatoes, some sort of saucy stuff, baby parsnips, peas, and more-and it all worked.

Pricy, and worth it.
author: Sam B.

description:
This place is worth going to just to check out the space. It's like  a whimsical trip under the sea. With all the rounded corners everything just flows so well. 

That being said, there are three areas to be sat downstairs: 1) in front of the bar by the window (seems more casual, only a few tables), 2) the big dining room in the back and 3) a limbo type area right in between the two that for some reason is just white and lacks the design that runs through the rest of the place. This is of course where we were put. The food and the service were still amazing though. But if you're going for a special occassion, defintiely ask to sit in the main dining room.
author: Stacie M.

description: Loved it!  Had the lobster and sweetbreads and I still salivate every time I think about it.  Mind you, the lobster is small, but it is cooked perfectly. The sweetbreads were amazing, as was the sauce served with it. My husband loved his salmon also.  They had calamari that night which was great, but could have had a little bit more for sharing.  Service was good.  The restaurant has very unique decor...really fun.  Just a note:  Don't let them seat you in the front.  We sat in the middle section, but if I were to return I would to have a table at the room in the very back of the restaurant.
author: Mari B.

description:
Wow, thank you Faralllon for making me feel like Ariel from the little mermaid....this restaurant takes Under the Sea Prom theme to a whole new level, which borders on cheezy, but it's so over the top that I apprecaite their commitment to the idea. Ok, moving onto the food.

Delciious, fresh, and new ways to have seafood!  We opted on the 5-course tasting menu.....SPLURGE! LIVE A LITTLE! these are the words of encouragement I said to myself as I reasoned that I should spend the money I can't afford....WE ALL NEED TO EAT, I said, with trepidation...this better be good.

And it was. The tuna tartare was a new take on the concept, with smokey hearts of palm and asian pear. The crab thighs with rouget was delicious. The sweetbreads and lobster was OK...but too many beans and I am just not a sweetbread person. Next up, the filet....and at a seafood restaurant you probably wouldn't order meat, but let me tell you, it was some of the best cooked meat I've ever had....with an amazing broth and handmade mushroom raviolis that I could of eaten 20 more of.  Amazing, the best part of the night by far. 

Our server was really cool and brought us 2 different desserts to try. By this point we were pretty stuffed but I remember liking them both. We had a great time, with great service, great wine (thanks to the somalier for picking affordable yet delicious options for us), and above all great food.  We'll be back.
author: Ela G.

description:
Dinner here with the fam on Christmas Eve Eve.  Made a reservation through OpenTable while standing out front and went to the bar.  We were seated about 20 minutes later in a round banquette in the main room.  Beautiful, beautiful place to eat.  
Took a loooong time for our server to take drink orders, etc-about 15 minutes.  That's long past my normal 'get up and find someone or walk out' limit, but the atmosphere was nice and it was pissing down rain outside.
Drinks finally came and orders were taken.  Two of us went with a Mediterranean Shellfish Bisque and a cast-iron baked Alaskan Bass for our entrees.  G had a beet salad and the bass, and JJ had the Alaskan True Cod.  Hers was probably the best, but it was close.  Really, every bit of the food was delicious, even the halfshell oysters at $3.50 a pop.  
The only downer was service-our server, while knowledgeable about the menu, etc., was scatterbrained, bringing the wrong foods, forgetting parts of the order, and generally making excuses to us, as well as his other tables.  The busser had some kind of creepy thing after my 16-year old daughter and would hover and then disappear for several minutes.  At one point, he stood behind me and refilled my iced tea every time I took a sip...
So, 90 minutes and $375 later, I was happy with the flavor and presentation of the food, but somewhat less than impressed with the service.  
If you go, don't sit in the section served by the guy who looks like an older David Carradine and you'll be fine.  You'll know him when you see him.
author: Jeffrey D.

description: Ok, here is the whole truth about this place.   It comes up on every top ten list, and we got several personal referrals for it so we made a  Reservation.    We  are foodies, and wine lovers, we know good from bad, this was nothing but a an overrated cheesecake looking  over priced snotty restaurant.   We sat on time and things went sideways right away, we ordered a bottle of zin ,from a incredibly overpriced list, I am in the biz,  it was ok it great, the SOMMELIER cam by but offered no input just an order taker   The service was just annoying, unfriendly and a bit rude, food was small potions and nothing great.    I would skip it, nothing special, the reviews way overrated.     Truth vs fluff
author: Melinda W.

description:
I've eaten here more than a dozen times. Most recent visit was very disappointing. The menu has been recently restructured so that they want you to order at least three courses to get a meal and that's not counting dessert. This is less than 90 days old. 

For my first course, I had a shrimp parfait that was very tasty. My second course was scallops. Ooops. I mean it was a single (non-giant) scallop. Good, but not really enough. My third course was a striped bass. The piece of fish was about half the size of my cellphone. Tasty, but not really enough. After three courses, I was still hungry and ordered the three cheese plate for dessert. That was delicious and filled me up. My point, however, is that after three courses, I was still hungry. At this price point, I don't buy it. 

My dining companion had a worse experience. At least mine was all good. His first course, a few slices of paper-thin sashimi, was overly smokey. His second course, gnocchi, was rubbery. His main of coconut curry shrimp was excellent. And the mini-sundae he had for dessert was good as well. 

Service was professional as it always has been before.

Ambiance depends heavily on which part of the restaurant you are seated in. We did fine this time.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: I had seafood that was cooked perfectly. White fish is hard to cook right. Don't be afraid of it here. Moist and tender on the inside and a hint of crust outside. Seasoned just right without smoothering seems to be the rule. Chefs observed to be working very hard to impress on presentation, texture and taste. Very impressive. Service immaculate! Well trained staff not too intrusive but never leaves you hanging. Wish I lived closer.
author: Richard H.

description:
Anytime I'm in San Francisco I like to come here for dinner. It's such a funky place (love the decor) and the food, service and drinks here are excellent.

Oysters of course are great  - make sure to get recommendations from the server - they will always lead you the right way. Entrees are great as well. I've done the tastings before too - pricey, but it's worth it. If you want to stop by at the last minute - you can often get a seat at the bar, or in the little lounge area near the bar.
author: Meredith K.

description: Fabulous dinner here while in town for a conference. I decide to spurge and have a full seafood dinner.
author: Peter H.

description:
Celebrated our anniversary here last night. They were attentive and had a great table saved for us. Nathan, our server, was excellent as well. I started with the prawns which were more like (4) 25/30 shrimp, which is small for those who don't buy shrimp. Unfortunately, a little bland and not worth $19. My wife started with the Buratta and heirloom tomatoes, which she loved. 

My second course was much better than the first (sweet corn risotto). My wife had the scallop with polenta (I insisted we share as hers was as good as mine). 

Main course: she went light with the chilled half Dungeness crab while I had the pan-seared sole. I was so glad that I took Nathan's suggestion on the Sole. It was seared well with a nice crisp served over corn purée and a tomato vinaigrette which added a nice acidic hit to the dish. Bacon kept the sweetness from the corn in check. It was a fabulously balanced dish, which I highly recommend. 

We finished off with the blueberry pie and the triple-chocolate budino. I loved the cocoa nib ice cream. You must eat this first as it lost flavor after eating the budino & chocolate creme (bittersweet and delicious), so heads up. 

While the meal started rather weak with the "prawns", I quickly forgot about it with each course. A very satisfying meal for us both.
author: Thad B.

description: Fantastic vibe & the food was amazing.  The lobster melted in my mouth, wine was delicious and the service was extremely attentive.
author: BreAnna K.

description:
Nicky the Barber (you can find him at Bay City Barber Salon in the financial district!),  my new beau, that I just met Friday, and have been seriously spoiled all weekend by, brought me to this bikini bottom beautiful seafood restaurant. 
My guy knew the General Manager and called that evening and got us in that same night on Sunday. Amazingly, he got us the most romantic seats in the house...booths in the middle back of the restaurant...plenty of space to spread out or cozy up....which we chose to do...talk about trying to compose ourselves in public...nearly impossible! 

Upon being seated, the waitstaff was impeccable with their service. From offering either sparkling or still water, to the bread with salted butter, there was nothing left out.  Love the attention to detail....

I started with the beet salad, in its simplest terms....it was amazing....along with chilled fresh beets was a slice of flavorful goat cheese and field greens. The presentation was magnificent, but i could of course eaten more!  My new beau, Nicky the Barber (look him up peeps!)   enjoyed the stuffed halibut and the potato leek soup....and I also had the smoked salmon as a main course instead of a second. 

The meal was delightful, my company was even better! I'd love to return here again and hopefully will....maybe as an anniversary!
author: Karen C.

description:
My love for Farallon started many years ago.  Our recent visit continued to prove worthy of my first impressions.  

There simply is not a more lovely atmosphere in which to dine on fine seafood than this room.  It feels as though one were transported onto Jules Verne's Nautilus deep in the sea.  I find it peaceful and very inviting which is always a nice way to start a good meal. 

I've never had a bad thing to eat here period.  So I won't go into a lot of detail about the menu specifics.  The food is very good, very fresh and always well presented.  No disappointments ever. 

I will comment on their service.  This is one area in which they have always excelled.  Several years ago a date and I spent a lazy three hour lunch here.  The kitchen sent us an uneven number of oysters.  Only 17 not the 18 we had requested.  My date exclaimed to the waiter it would simply ruin our "marriage" if we were to become uneven.  He chuckled, winked and said he would be right back.  Next thing we know the chef himself is at the table, 7 oysters on a plate with a personal apology and his best wishes for our continued love.  Yes it was tongue in cheek, but a lovely and gracious gesture I have never forgotten.  It's a rare to thing to say that on many subsequent experiences I've found the same spirit of service to be present each time.  Always relaxed, efficient, well spoken and polite.  It's such a rare thing these days.  

Yes, it's a Union Square, tourist, expense account restaurant; and yet still quite unique, welcoming and delicious.  It's absolutely worth a visit if for no other reason than to say you've dined 20,000 leagues under the sea beneath glowing jellyfish.
author: Russell D.

description:
This place was phenomenal. I loved every bit of food. From my first terrine, to a wonder of a short-rib with polenta, I loved it. My prawn & green curry main course was an interesting combination and a successful one. 

To nitpick, my food wasn't as hot as I like and the decor was a bit gaudy for my tastes. However, the food more than made up for it.
author: Kaanon M.

description:
I loved their selection of oysters, my favorite was the Marin Miyagi. I thought the menu set up is a bit pretentious as it 's organized as 1st, 2nd, and 3rd course, this tells me they serve in small portions, which is exactly what happened. I didn't think there was any distinct difference between 2nd and 3rd course, so I'm going to suspect that's a marketing scheme, albeit they all taste pretty good. 

One thing I also didn't really dig was the halibut, it had fried seaweed slices on top for seasoning, which did not come out to be nice and crispy in my mouth, thank god the chef didn't over do it. The fish its self was nicely cooked and that saved the dish.

Small things like that along with the cheesy "under the sea" decor eventually took away the 5th star. I'm a fan mainly because of their oysters, plus, most importantly, I don't have to battle 50 tourists at some other union square area restaurants like the Scarla.
author: Bo D.

description: One of the best seafood meals I've had in my life. I love it so much, the fish is the absolute freshest and service is outstanding. The grotto vibe is pretty nice too.
author: Julia E.

description: Farallon is all about ambiance, panache and atmosphere. The presentation of this place is like an under water oasis. Think "The Little Mermaid". Ariel would feel right at home here. If only she could accept the slaughter of her beloved sea pals. The Under Sea theme of interior design is edgy and very whimsical. It's a place for a great night out with your woman. Whether it be an engagement or reconciliation, Farallon is a place she will not forget. It's a seafood restaurant and it is expensive. I thought it was very much worth the price, patronage and service. The waiters, Sommelier's and Hosts are friendly and very knowledgeable about the cuisine.  But, that $170 bill was hard to look at. Attention to detail and presentation of service, food, business acumen is very high here. The setting is just perfect for a relaxing, intimate night. It's a personal place.
author: Erik R.

description: Love the funky decor!  Food was ok, service was careless, dessert was incredible!  The pastry chef here saves the day!
author: Mara S.

description:
First of all, the restaurant was not even full and they only sat us (7 people) at the bar.
Secondly, the waitress was rushing us to order and take out all unfinished food, etc.
Thirdly, the $30 fish entree was raw when it finally arrived.
Not only did the food take a long time to be served but it was raw.
Seriously?? for a high-end, over-priced restaurant in Union square, you would think they'd be better...but it was a total disappointment.
The only consolation was the busboy who kept refilling our bread basket and iced tea every time we asked...lol! :)
This is not my first time here...this is my third time in fact but the first time was about 10 yrs ago and the second time was about 8 years ago...and i don't recall being this bad.
I guess a lot of things changed since then....too bad and just sad really.... :(
It's such a perfect location and great ambiance but service and food quality has gone way down..
author: Jill T.

description:
Overall:  No question you're gonna drop coin here so expectations should be high but don't look for a life changing experience.

Food:  Don't come here if you don't like seafood.  I was impressed with the salmon in spite of really disliking salmon. The wine list is exceptional. 

Service: Efficient and detailed. 

Atmosphere: Couples and people with expense accounts.

Value: Decent portion size 

Decor: Probably one of the most beautifully designed interiors in SF.

Returnability: Definitely, even though I've already been here twice.
author: Roger H.

description:
The restaurant overall seemed a bit old, dark and stuffy to me..

The unique jellyfish lighting, however, complements the restaurant's theme.
The food was wonderful too. I ordered the "Salt Baked Canadian Artic Char" and it was perfectly cooked. The staff were friendly and attentive. No other complaints.
author: Linda T.

description:
Must love seafood.
Local oysters were perfect.
Atmosphere is an old san francisco bath house/swimming pool.
I had the sturgeon...it was amazing.

I will go back...
author: Tamara G.

description:
I went here last night for my anniversary. It was the perfect place for the occasion. As soon as we got there the ambiance and decor of the place really gave us that "special occasion" feel.  The service was first rate from start to finish. We were originally sat to close to the kitchen, but at our first request we were quickly moved to a much better table. Not to be out done was the food. We both had 3 courses and although the price was significant, the reward was definitely  worth it. Each plate was great and 3 courses was more than enough. Plus, the wine list was extensive with both affordable and impressive bottles to choose from. 

The only reason I am not ready to give Farallon 5 stars after my first dining experience there is because the portions could have been a bit bigger.  To be fair however, this is a fine dining establishment and if you want enough food to really fill you up, you should splurge and get 3 courses.

Beyond saying I would recommend this place to anyone, I can't wait for future occasion to return.
author: Damon M.

description: Feb., 2013.  Service was OK, not great, it was not busy.  Food and drinks were only OK - not Great.  Whiskey's were way over priced for the quality. Prices were very high, and the portions were super small.  The entrée was a bite size piece of seafood for $30.  I do not like to over eat, and I dislike large portions big enough for two people.  ...but the portions at this restaurant were the smallest I have ever seen, at any of the many restaurants I have eaten at in 15 countries.  I felt like it was a tourist trap, 2nd only to a tourist trap I recall in Barcelona.
author: Bob B.

description:
We loved it!
Wonderful atmosphere - the ceiling is a mosaic which once covered the Elk's Club swimming pool (which is apparently still is use below the restaurant.)
The service was EXCELLENT. Our waiter was so nice and personable. He was very helpful in answering questions and made several great recommendations. 
The food was delicious.
author: M.E. T.

description: It's a nice venue if you want to impress someone. However the food isn't worth the price.
author: Amy F.

description:
This is solely based on the happy hour - and it was amazing. We ordered just about everything off of it (minus the salad and the duck) and each thing was better than the next. I wasn't too thrilled with the oysters but the mussels with chorizo more than made up for it. The truffle fries were TDF and the sliders were pretty good too.

drinks were delish and it was a really nice way to start a long weekend.
author: laura f.

description:
Hooray for seafood!!!  This place was amazing.  Started off with the Mediterranean Shellfish Bisque....and I think the name says it all.  Amazing flavor, and the added truffle oil made for an extremely decadent first course.

Next came the seared squid with white beans....not a fan.  I usually love squid but the only thing I could taste was the beans.  In a restaurant that specializes in seafood you'd think they'd create a dish that allowed for the delicate flavor of the squid to come through.  This dish left something to be desired.

For the third course I had seared halibut with ravioli.  Another amazing dish and one that I would highly recommend.  My dining partner had the Salmon with bacon, a combination that I hadn't tried before but actually tasted pretty good.  

All in all this is a great place to eat if you are a seafood lover.  if your partner doesn't like fish....then make em get the fillet.  As long as you get your seafood "fix" everyone is happy, right?

Open kitchen is a cool plus as well!!
author: Clay G.

description: We were very happy with this restaurant. The gazpacho was tasty, and the decor was amazing!  The waiters delivered the food to the larger tables choreographed to arrive all at once.  And considering how busy they were, this was no mean feat. We'd go again!
author: Kathryn A.

description:
I believe Farallon is one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  I put this place just below my favorite restaurant, Gary Danko if that says anything.  I have been to Farallon about 6-10 times.  Every time I go it is the same quality of food just a different menu.    The menu is broken out into three courses.  I usually get one in each section. Last night I had the beat salad (which was perfect), Butternut squash Ravioli (very delightful), and the Sea Bass (so much flavor that i know it had to be a calorie bomb but worth it).  I also always start off with their fresh oysters.  They are amazing!!!  The desserts are also worth the calories...I had the Chocolate Napoleon with a cup of their fantastic coffee.  Now you would think I was a huge, fat slob for ordering that much food but the portions are just perfect so I left pleasantly full.  I am only 175 and I don't eat a lot I promise. 

My Tips:

1. Reservations are a must!  Quality = People.  It is also located in Union Square so the tourists seem to make their way here too. 
2. Use the valet.  They only charge $12.  It is a long meal so no matter where you park you will spend more at that lot then here.  Although the lot by Macy's may be cheaper.
3. You will spend money.  Average tab is $120 per person with wine.  Be prepared but know that it is worth it...you are worth it damn it.
4. Ask for Luke the sommelier.  He is awesome and knows his wine!
5.  It is a long paced out meal.  Relax and enjoy.  However that does mean you should like the people you are with.  First Dates...mother-in-laws that you don't get along with, etc. should be avoided.
6.  Ask for the corner booth in the back if it is available.  The restaurant can get loud so if you really like the company you are with this is the best table to be able to chat with them at.  However being in the main part of the restaurant comes with some advantages too because the room is so beautiful.
author: Brandon M.

description:
I was amazed by how beautiful the Farallon is. Each room has an underwater theme. My favorite is the chandelier of jellyfish. I have never been in a more beautiful restaurant. 

The service was formal and good. We were all happy with our meals. It is overpriced for the meal, but I really think that is because it is so well-known.
author: Missy B.

description: Amazing experience.   First rate service, food and atmosphere.   Will definitely come back.
author: Josh S.

description:
Very disappointed. 
Room - 5
Service - 1
Food - 1
I am sure this was a good place at one time, but like many places it looses it's touch and becomes a tourist place. The food was cold and the scallop was sour.
author: David B.

description:
Love this place. Seafood is amazing and chef compliments are delicious. This restaurant is actually good for small groups of people. Crab meat is love! Design is interesting. I tried 5
Course menu and could not imagine that I actually would be able to eat everything. By the way they have a really nice wine list and champagne. Chardonnay from France is good as it is and always works with the fish. Tuna is MUST in this place! Overall this place is good for a small company or if you feel like romantic - just go for it :)
author: Demetre R.

description:
I haven't been there in a long while, but the impression they left was outstanding. Everything was tasty. My next visit to San Fran will include a stop at the Farallon. 
Beautiful place too!
author: dahlia d.

description:
I went here on 7/1/06 just for desserts.  We just walked-in and talked to the host and she said there was a table at the bar.

Service was slow probably due to lots of people in the restaurant.  I should have ordered the dark chocolate pudding ($12), or the sweet endings sample ($14).  Instead I got the boysenberry cobbler w/ Meyer lemon ice-cream ($10).  The ice-cream was good, but tiny scoop of it, and the cobbler part was just average.  I think the desserts change often you probably can't get what I did and that would be a good thing.  B. got the 3 course of cheese $14, American cheeses-why I don't know.  It comes w/ a good size chunk of each cheese, some bread, some jelly, and some almonds.  Just ok for me.

I did like the jellyfish decorations-1 star.  Free Matchbox at the host's desk-1 star.
author: Ann L.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday after seeing IMAX Avatar 3D. We still had visions of 3D blue people and weird creatures, so walking into the restaurant with it's jellyfish lamps, etc. was appropriately trippy.
Service is great; attentive, informative but not snobby or overbearing. I liked the sommelier a lot - he gave an excellent recommendation within the range of wines we were interested in.
The food was very good - he had the ahi tuna and I had striped bass - I forget the sides but remember clearing my plate. Weird to comment - but great bread with butter that had a sprinkling of sea salt on top which was like crack. Desserts were great - much better than I had anticipated. It's a definitely a special occasion spot - pricey yes, but I feel the food and the experience were worth it.
author: Barbara K.

description:
Over-priced and over-hyped. They ruined a very good scallops dish by serving it with beef tongue. WTF? Another grilled fish dish had veal "sweetbreads" in it. Organ meat from baby cows. WTF?? If I wanted strange body parts mixed in with my seafood I would go to a steak house. 

Extremely small portions - my grilled salmon was about the size of a large piece of sushi. For the price, there are much better seafood places in the city. Overall the service was very good, so no complaints there.
author: D M.

description: One of the most wonderful restaurants I've been to in the Bayarea.  A beautiful setting ...Service was great...Food was marvelously displayed, fresh & delicious. The price is pretty high, but it's worth it.  This is a must experience restaurant.  Put it on your list for the next special occassion.
author: K. S.

description: Good food and really cool decor
author: Arash E.

description:
We went there for our 10th anniversary dinner.  The staff was courteous and well trained.  As someone with several years of restaurant experience (in both the back and front of the house) I'm a stickler for service (and willing to tip extra for good service).

I had the chef's tasting menu with the wine pairing.  My wife chose from the rest of the menu.  I've tried to remember everything, but sometimes it was difficult to hear and/or remember everything exactly.

We were brought an amuse-bouche which was a spoon of a "soup" of some sort made from snap-peas.  It was perfect size for an amuse-bouche and was delicious.

For the first course, I was served lobster atop a pea risotto garnished with some edible flower petals.  My wife had 3 of the fresh oysters on the half shell.  My course was served with a glass of Taittinger champagne.  My course was very good, although I wasn't happy with the champagne (can't blame them for that, I don't like champagne to begin with.  My wife finished it and reported that it was wonderful).  The oysters were very fresh and tasty.

The second course was black cod.  I can't remember the exact preparation except that it had bacon and was delicious.  It was served with a "french chardonnay" (I'm presuming Burgundy, but he didn't say that) that went nicely with the fish.  (My wife had nothing with my second course)

The third course was artic char.  It was charbroiled and served over a bed of black legumes.  The char was served with a Pinot Noir described as from "the Sonoma Valley".  I didn't recognize it (I grew up in the valley) and had to look it up.  It was actually a Skewis Pinot from the North Coast.  Nevertheless, it was delicious.  I was **extremely** satisfied with this course, being that arctic char is one of my favorite fish and the wine was so wonderful.  My wife had the cornmeal fried squid (which was served on the same risotto as my lobster.  The squid was perfectly cooked and very tasty.

The fourth course was a filet of beef served with a Corison Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley).  Somehow, I thought the server told me it was 4 ounces, but there's no way the small serving (delicious, BTW) was 4 ounces.  My wife had the halibut, which was sizable (ordered off menu) and perfectly cooked.  She was so happy with it, it was the one thing I didn't taste!

Then came the cheese course, which was a Wisconsin cheese called "Marisa" (not sure, that's what I think I heard).  It was served with a piece of walnut bread and a candied green tomato.  The cheese was described as similar to pecorino, but I found that it was a little softer and creamier, with a great level of saltiness that totally complimented the green tomato and walnut bread!

We then ordered dessert.  My chef's menu dessert was a creme brulee with a sweet wine whose name I didn't catch (sounded like "taiko").  My wife ordered the tiramisu sundae. The sundae was amazing.  We're not tiramisu fans (big ice cream fans though), but this was GREAT.  I have to say I was a little disappointed in the Creme Brulee.  After several very good courses, this one fell short.  I was expecting the chef's menu to close with a big bang, but it fizzled short.  If the tiramisu sundae was the dessert, I would have given 5 stars for sure, but it's probably the single thing I was disappointed in that evening.  Other than that, our dinner was great.
author: Daniel I.

description: Food was good and super fresh. The wine list was awesome. $$$$. So Fancy
author: Eddy S.

description: A top notch seafood place with decor that you've just got to see.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I've been here twice.  Once with my cousin a few years back, and more recently... about a month and a half ago.  This review is for my most recent visit.  

I came here with an old friend of mine, to catch up on life and shoot the shit.  We were pleasantly seated in a small booth for two.  Okay, my friend is about 6'3''.  Poor guy could barely fit in the booth.  Anywhoo, he made the best of the situation and we began to dine.  

We started off with our salad and entree, accompanied with a delicious bottle of red wine.  I got the ahi tuna and though it was tasty, my friend got something with leeks...and that was SUPER YUMMY.  Ever since then, i've been wanting leeks.  I'm sure they were doused with yummy butter, but they were tasty.  

We didn't do dessert, but we did do a cheese plate.  It was amazing.  I love cheese.  Cheese is the one thing that makes me struggle with being a full on vegan.  The cheeses were creamy and to die for.  

Would totally go here again, especially if i wanted some seafood.... and cheese!!
author: Brenda H.

description:
I don't know if this was an off day, but I had higher expectations. 
We had oysters on the half shell, which you can't mess up. It just needs to be fresh! but it didn't seem like that was the case.
Had the grilled Maine Diver Scallops and the Baked Icelandic Char...Again, the foodflavoring  needed some adjustments. Don't get me wrong it wasn't horrible, but not what you would expect at a restaurant of this "quality". 
the ambiance is very cool though. I felt like I was under the sea. Vibrant colors and dark plush red chairs. 
May have to give it a second try down the road.....
author: Jo M.

description: What a beautiful spot. When we walked in, I thought we were in the ocean with friendly non-stinging jellyfish! We sat in the pool room which was built over the old Elks Lodge pool. Because it's an old indoor pool, the ceiling is intricatly painted with scrolls, etc. We ordered the seafood platter with caviar. Caviar was a first for me and I loved it. The presentation was fab. For the main course, I ordered the warm Maine lobster with fava bean crepes. It was so good that I wanted to lick the plate.
author: CHRISTY M.

description: i love this place, amazing seafood. One of my favorite things is the happy hour. Prices are a little pricey but its worth it. I definitely recommend this place.
author: Ana A.

description:
This review is only for the bar/happy hour since I don't have $200 to spend on shellfish. Luckily, they have a great happy hour menu where everything is $6!

Drinks were not that great and there aren't that many choices. Moscow mule is ok  but a bit too strong for me. Oysters are $6/half-dozen, which is pretty cheap considering how expensive the dinner menu is. However, the oysters are so tiny I can barely pick them up! The champagne mignonette that it comes with is realllyyy good though so that makes up for it. I also LOVE the truffle fries here, although it can be a bit salty sometimes...but still, love love love. The beef sliders you can skip, they're not that great. Clams were delicious and came with little toasted bread slices so you can dip it into the amazing sauce.

Overall, cheap and good happy hour place, conveniently located right next to Union Square. I think they have happy hour every day of the week too from 4-7pm, which is also a plus!
author: Kate Y.

description:
Came here for happy hour, and ordered off of their "Six to Seven" menu. A fun array of choices all of seven bucks. The sliders were cooked to perfection (medium, even with a small, thin patty - tough to do well!) and came with garlicky fries. I also had the mussels that were swimming in a butter sauce that I had to stop myself from sopping it all up with the complimentary rolls. 

The bartender was quite kind to give me a taste of a few of the great wines from their selection so that I could choose something that I liked best.  

Totally amazing decor that the staff will tell you all about without prompting. Very cool place. Highly recommended.
author: Jim K.

description: Sadly disappointed.  Very excited about this place from reviews and pictures on yelp. Called ahead asking if they were serving soft shell crab. Was told yes. Arrived for dinner and had to wait 15 minutes after our reservation to be seated. After initial drink arrived (slowly) we had to request bread from another server and flag down the waitress for more drinks. We discussed with waitress about our excitement to have soft shell crab as we heard it just came in season this week. It was not a conversation had in passing, rather a length. Between 4 of us we ordered 3 sides of crab. After about an hour waiting (we did have appetizers in the meantime that were wonderful... Oysters for some and bone marrow with sea urchin) the dinner arrived. No soft shell crab, just shredded crab that tasted like it came out of a can. The one in our party who didnt have crab had a pasta dish that arrived somewhere between cold and room temperature. Explained to manager and he did take off the cold pasta, the oysters, and anything related to the crab. The part of the meal we expected was good but the test was a failure. Service was poor but management was great.
author: Evan A.

description: I have only been here for happy hour.  The decor is opulent, but a little stuffy for my tastes when I'm coming to a place to unwind for happy hour.  The $6 for 1/2 a dozen oysters were fresh but pretty small.  Maybe I've been spoiled by other places that provided much more substantial sized shellfish, but I was a bit disappointed in the size.  The happy hour food options are pretty good, but the drinks options were limited.   I might try this place again for fine dining, but I think I'll take myself elsewhere for happy hour.
author: Pam S.

description:
I actually came here with my family maybe a good 8 years ago. My dad have been wanting to come back for the longest time, so I decided to bring him here for his birthday. 

So, it was a party of six, and we got seated immediately. I ordered the crab cakes and the short ribs. I was expecting a bit bigger portion because of the price, and I really didn't see anything that interested me in the third course. I was actually quite full but would be even better if I have two pieces of short ribs instead of one dinky one. The crab cake was just so-so. I also had the chance to try a bit of the dungeness crab salad - so-so once again. I also try a bit of the soft shell crab and it was just whatever. 

Don't think we will come back again, the first time we had it was wayyyy better from what my whole family remember.
author: Willa L.

description:
Farallon dining is always a pleasure. My last visit on 2/20/2010 was no exception. 
The Butter Lettuce Salad w/ Dungeness crab and smoked palm hearts, was AH-mazing. The flavors were incredible and surprisingly distinct. 
Two items that were off-key: 1) the beef filet wasn't piping hot ;and
2) the bathrooms need more attention, they just don't jive with the beautiful bar and exquisite dining room!
author: Stephanie T.

description: We ran down to the Farallon after seeing play next door and sat by the bar, wanting a simple drink and maybe some oysters. The server we got was incredibly disinterested in anything that had to do with us. We got our drinks pretty fast--my boyfriend ordered wine, which was poured from a great distance and with very little care, so it splashed on my skirt and his shirt. No apologies were offered, if anything, our waiter was annoyed with us. We'd ordered oysters and 20 minutes later, i finally asked another server, a very friendly guy named Jeff, if the oysters were ever coming. He checked, and our waiter hadn't ordered them. Again, NO APOLOGIES were offered. Jeff, in the meantime, took great care of us--bring us water and candied nuts, while we were waiting. The check came to a $100 and all we had was 2 drinks and a dozen oysters. We were having a good time and didnt pay attention until the next morning, when i looked at our bill. Oh, the guy who brought us oysters was fantastic too, so he and Jeff get the one star. But overall, the place is cold and unfriendly. I used to bring clients there for drinks, but after this experience, i don't think i will ever be back.
author: JogaKat A.

description: nice place. Expensive but worth it for occasions. Wine list extensive menu but also pricey. Food is 4/5. Place is a elegant but needs a little modernization.
author: Eric S.

description: My boyfriend and I had dinner here last night. The food was great! This restaurant is beautiful inside and very different. We will be back for sure!!!
author: Fallon W.

description:
Two Star, the redemption came from the water boy and the Sommelier who both were great!  However: For our NYE 2011 dinner for 4, they got one of the entrés--thats 25% incorrect---. completely wrong order. My two scallops were way- over cooked and the flavors were not very distinct. 
Ambiance interestingly gauche!
The only thing truly enjoyable was the 2000 Veuve Cliquot which required two bottles, to make the food palatable!
 VERY PRICEY NOT Nicey!
author: Tina Jo O.

description: best seafood presentation i have seen in many years. Great food and great service. However, not really a place for a large dinner party.
author: Dwayne D.

description:
One of the best Seafood restaurants in SF! 
Been coming here for many many years and always enjoy their dishes.
Good for business meetings as well.
author: Arya M.

description: Very impressed with this place. Their Happy Hour is one of the best I've seen in town - especially the $1 very fresh oysters! Others have raved about the bisque but I found it a bit too salty. I suppose it balances out though with the warm bread that comes out. The only thing that was as memorable as the oysters was the service. The bartender was the best I've seen in terms of taking care of drinks and taking Happy Hour orders. Super chill, attentive, and non-intrusive. Drinks were great and she knew when to ask my wife and I if we wanted another plate of oysters, another drink, etc. At the end of it, I had to leave her a 30%+ tip - she certainly earned it!
author: Parag G.

description:
Although they brought me 2 wrong dishes, can't complain too much abt the overall experience!! The service, food, complete vibe, THE FOOD THE FOOD  THE FOOD is an explosion of yumminess!!! 

Con: the menu changes frequently which is cool, but when u wanna try a dish someone had recommended few months ago-- they may not have it :(
author: Stel D.

description: My wife and I attended a celebration at Farallon.  Unfortunately, the celebrants and their other friends behaved as if they were the Clampetts.  Not only was our waiter, Brian S., patient and gracious he went out of his way to be accomodating.  The food, especially the seared salmon, and service were exceptional.  The entire wait staff was attentive and friendly.  We even had the good fortune of having the head chef visit our table, converse, and take pictures with us.
author: Ron S.

description: We had a great experience.  Food was inventive, portioned right and beautiful.  Service was near perfect too.  I did feel the age of the restaurant a bit.  It's a little dated now, but if they just edited down - took away some of the over-the-top embellishments, there would still be a grand restaurant there and it would feel more modern.
author: Denise B.

description: $65 for 2 drinks and 2 apps. For that price, you don't expect crying kids and cartoons... The parents at the table next to me kept trying to placate their toddlers with cartoons via their cell phones, so I had to listen to kids crying or loud cartoons throughout my time at Farallon... I told the bartender I was bothered by the cartoons/kids (i was eating at the bar) and she just smiled and shrugged, so it's not like I didn't give them a chance to talk to these people or knock a drink off my (overpriced) bill.  I hope it was worth it for Farallon to avoid an awkward convo w this obnoxious family of tourists to lose an SF customer forever...There are so many places for us natives to choose from - why bother with a place that charges top prices and caters to the Cheesecake factory crowd????
author: Liz C.

description: Food is #1 with me and this was okay- I am used to GREAT food, at home and away. taste has three elements for me, smell, taste and view. Looked great, smelled and tasted okay. Service was great, some of the best I have experienced sans the private dining rooms in Italy I frequent where basically the table is off the kitchen. If I was an American without those experiences this would be a 5 star experience, but 3 stars in my book is very good, needs some improvement. My personal kitchen only rates a 2 or 3 star so there you go.
author: Abe N.

description:
------Review for happy hour only-----

Came here for happy hour after spending a day wandering around SF with the boy. It's right next to Union Square. 

The decor is nice; it's the only place that can hang jelly fish from the ceiling and make it look classy and not tacky. There was a seafood bar that was filled with oysters and crabs and although I didn't end up ordering anything from there, it looks promising.

Other than that, the rest of my experience was blah. 

We ordered the fries, crab cakes and ceviche. All were good but none really stood out to me. 

The service was terribly slow. I don't understand how there was one waitress for happy hour yet three hostesses that stood around chatting with each other. Really now? What the hell. We were there for over 1.5 hrs because at least 40 min was spent waiting to have our order taken, waiting for the food, waiting to get the check, etc. 

I don't know about you but if you're aiming to be a classy high-end restaurant, bring your service up to par. I didn't even have any expectations going in and I was still disappointed. Big no no
author: Diana Y.

description:
I'm rating Farallon 4 stars because of the beautiful decor, wonderful service, and overall good food.   However, I was a tad disappointed because the sea bass I ordered was a little overcooked and a little bit on the salty side.  I ordered the seared scallops as part of my first course though, and LOVED it.  It was garnished with cold soba noodles and daikon radish, which provided a perfect fusion of texture and temperature!  

I'm also a big dessert lover and was hesitant because Farallon doesn't seem like a place that would emphasize this (I mean, I've been to places with SUPER FRESH seafood but not so fresh pie).  BUT, I am happy to report that the dessert I ordered - carrot cake with cream cheese ice cream - was SOOOO good.  If the place wasn't so darn fancy, I would have licked the plate :)
author: Jessica C.

description:
I feel like I haven't went out to a good restaurant in a while after going to this place.  I have, but there's just little things that they do which seem to make their service stand out.  For example, some guy comes around with some butter knife like instrument and quickly "sweeps off" any crumbs or what have you on the table.  Just really classy looking.  The service is rather top notch with great ancillary help.  You can even notice the upright posture of the people as they serve and greet you.  

The food is very good.  I would like to see the portions a little bigger. 
I started with lobster, then had crab, tomato bisque soup, followed by the duck, and then the bitter sweet chocolate dessert.  That with 2 beers came to a buck 16.  So, you'll definitely spend some cash, but I think I'd go back.  

Oh, the crab was so soft that you could, and people do eat the shell.  It's sort of odd at first, but it's quite tasty.  

I'm gonna ding them though on proportions.
author: Chris F.

description:
Best cod I've ever had in my life!!!
We went for my dad's b-day and me and my sister got the cod. We had the best dish on the table. AMAZING. The staff was great. The atmosphere was beautiful and whimsical, we had a great time. Give it a go if you have the chance and the money.
P.S. My dad's dinner was a bit too salty and he sent it back- the 5th star comes from the wonderful service he was given after that- they brought him back his plate with a silver dome, the chef came over, we were given wine... Oh, if I could be there right now. Wonderful!
author: Kira H.

description: Unique and fancy.  All 6 were happy their dishes and drinks.  Good times.  Highly recommend.
author: Ashley C.

description: One of the places I always go in San Francisco.  This is a nice upscale place that has very good food.  It can be a bit loud depending on your seating but they have an extensive wine list and lovely seafood dishes.  I have never had anything here I did not like.  You need reservations but can usually get them.  The service is typically spot on and they will be happy to advise you on wines or pairings of foods.  The portions are reasonable for this type of restaurant but most people can have three courses and not be overwhelmed.  I recommend Farallon.  There is valet parking but not much else around.  We usually walk from nearby.
author: Doug W.

description: I love that a destination this fabulous stays accessible by offering a happy hour selection.  You can get a series of options for $6.00 each and it is well worth it just to see the interior decor.  I was here less than 2 weeks ago with a friend.  We had a dozen oysters from the raw bar, charcuterie and sliders all for a song.  A great place to snack and eat dinner if you can afford it.
