It is just fun to sit at the raw bar and watch them compile the huge platters of seafood.
author: Amy B.

description:
I've been here many many many MANY times now. I decided to write a review because they, unlike other restaurants actually changes their menu often. They have excellent service and an awesome wine list. 

Dishes i enjoyed: 

Lemon jello crab salad with freshly made potato chips -  I actually copied this recipe and made it at home once. LOVE it. 

Caviar - it comes with capers, egg white, yolk, finely chopped red onion and other stuffs. I copied this recipe too and made it a few times as well. Buy the caviar at Bevmo and make it yourself! A lot cheaper and you get a larger amount of caviar! 

Oysters - they are always small and fresh
Cherry Stone Clams - had it once here and it was a bit fishy to me....maybe caught them on a bad day. =(

Summer Melon Salad - Very refreshing and a unique flavor 

I had many many other entries which was all good but i can't think of the names anymore. Been here too many times and i love most of their dishes. 

Love the atmosphere...i feel like a mermaid dining under the sea.
author: Amy L.

description:
I love the restaurant now! It's the best in the city! 
Love the 1927 tiled Roof and fancy orange lights!
Open kitchen give us energy and not too quiet and not too loud.

I ate 2 oysters and fixed dinner.
The appetizer, crab cake was very light. I expected like regular crab cake is kind of packed and heavy but theirs were puffy and light. Perfectly deep fried with bread crumbs. Nice.
Sea Bass was divine! The best fish ever! Loved the crisp skin, again perfect! Also they used maitake (don't know in English) mushroom. Love Love Love...
Desert the mushy (forgot the name) chocolate cake was perfect size. not too big... not too small and it was delicious.
We drank California Sauvignon Blanc, "Six Sigma, Rooster Vineyard, Lake County 2008 ($40) was light yet fruity and levels of flavor comes after... very good. very gooood. Then at last, I drunk Spanish coffee... nice and warm and delicious.

I sure want to go back again! I will recommend for anniversary, perfect date, with girlfriends... any occasion! even with parents!
author: Green Mango Y.

description: Not my first time here, but first time in the upper seating area. I have to admit I preferred the quiet and intimate feeling.
author: Brian E.

description: Well, I waited a month to write a review so I could be objective and not write emotionally.  Short version.  This place is over-priced, assembly-line food disguised as a  gourmet experience.  We went for a family event celebration.  Sequence of dishes was out of order; waiter was clearly distracted. and not once, not twice but three times the wait staff appeared in grand style to lay out our dishes - which were the wrong ones!  But the real frustration was that they then added a gratuity, I guess because we were a party of six, depriving us of the ability to deny a reward because of  poor service.  They ruined our evening. The oysters were good.  The entrees were good also, until you consider the price.  Price for value received is too high.  Decor is unusual and the kids enjoyed that.  Never Again!!
author: Phil C.

description:
I needed a place to take Melly Mel for her birthday.  She loves jellyfish.  Perfect!  Farallon would be the place!  Not simply because they had jellyfish chandeliers hung from their ceiling, but I have heard it's a restaurant with good food and ambiance.

We showed up 10 minutes late for our reservation (8 pm, on a Sat) and waited briefly (no more than 5 min) for a table.  She was in love with the jellyfish chandeliers!  Score one for me!  We sat down and looked over the menu.  

Here's what we ordered:
1/2 doz oysters (2 Beausoleil, 2 Drakes Bay, and 2 Chefs Creek)
Ahi Tuna & Atlantic Scallop Carpaccio
White Wine Brasied Mediterranean Octopus
Seared Hudson Valley Cage Free Foie Gras
Pan Roasted Mediterranean Dorade
Cast Iron Roasted California White Bass

The oysters were awesome!  They were the server's suggestions - trying different oysters from different areas.  The Carpaccio was delicious as well!  Ahi Tuna is Ahi Tuna, nothing special, but the scallops were smooth, and fresh!  The Octopus was cooked perfection!  It wasn't too chewy or too raw.  The Foie Gras was amazing!  You really can't go wrong with ordering it!  The Dorade was good and so was the Bass, but I kind of expected a bit more because this is a seafood restaurant.  To me it wasn't anything special.

All in all, we had a good time.  Why 3 stars then?  Well, we spent 2.5 hours there.  At one point, 45 min passed before our next items came out.  And when we asked about it to our server, she said there was a mix-up in the kitchen, and it'll be out shortly.  I give her credit for being nice and helpful, but c'mon man!  45 min??  Other than that, they gave Mel a free small dessert with "Happy Birthday!" written on the plate in chocolate!  Bonus points for me!  Total bill was about $175...not bad.

Would I come back?  Probably not.  Would I suggest this place to friends?  Possibly.  Especially if their significant others love jellyfish chandeliers!
author: Daniel M.

description: Very mediocre. I had high expectations as it was highly recommended. My friends portion was cold and she got sick from it. Our waitress was ok but not super friendly. I think the place had it's glory a while back. I will not be returning there are too many great restaurants in SF.
author: max g.

description:
This place is way past it's prime. I think the tourists must be keeping this place in business. The decor is kitchy Carnival cruise ship or a Mexican All-Inclusive, we couldn't decide which. It embarrassed me. The menu selection was not much to look at, nothing sounded good. The fish dishes were average, they were somewhat tasty but not enough for the price. Nothing stood out. We all left there disappointed. Pick another restaurant.
(the service was good however)
author: San X.

description:
The decor, food, and service all gel to create a truly memorable dining experience.  I have visited three times and each time the food was outstanding.  The service on the other hand, not so consistent.  If the wait staff could loosen up a bit and have some fun, the customers would have a way better time dining in such a visually stimulating and yet comforting environment.  
The restaurant is known for its seafood.  However, as I am not a huge fan of maritime bounty, I always order something more substantial like a steak and it is always amazing.  The desserts are second to none as well.  Nothing fancy or avant garde about the bar program but they serve up the classics with the freshest ingredients and perfect proportion.  All in all - a great place for a special night out like after the opera.
author: Randy C.

description: OK, so it's been a few months since we ate here...so I cant remember the names of what we ordered...but I know it was good. The ambiance is great and the server really took care of us. Check out the pics I added and that's what we ate. There were crab legs and tuna, fillet mignon and more tuna. It was tasty.
author: Charlie K.

description:
I took my parents here for their 50th Wedding Anniversary (that's right... 50th) and it was an excellent choice for such a grandiose occasion!  The food was amazing:  from the delicious fresh bread we got when we were first seated to the dessert cheese platter that completely put me over the edge.  To make me extra happy, they were having a special on wild, local chanterelle  mushrooms this week.  The service was all around superb!  The decor was actually pretty awesome (albeit a tad on the old fashioned side, but I was quite fond of it, fake "ancient" mosaics and all).  Jellyfish lights!!!  

This is definitely not a place that I would go just for the heck of it, but for a memorable dining experience - it did not disappoint!
author: Athos K.

description: Save your money and go elsewhere. We live in Half Moon Bay and eat fresh seafood all year long. Our meal at Farallon was a huge disappointment. The waiter forgot our appetizer and when it was reminded and delivered the oysters were tiny and spoiled. The pasta with lobster sauce was soaked and oily. The portions are tiny and the food (bisque) salty. The room is visually stunning however. Farallon has become the classic tourist trap.
author: Michael A.

description:
Though this review may only be for the lounge/bar area at Farallon, it gives it five stars all the way for quality, service and atmosphere! It has been exactly two months this weekend since I visited San Francisco and I was shocked when I was looking through pictures this afternoon and realized that I had not reviewed this fantastic location. Since Farallon was connected to my hotel and naught but a door stood between us and a happy hour menu, my friend and I decided to stop in for a quick visit at the bar before heading out to find a good Japanese or Chinese restaurant to walk to for dinner. Well, not only did we get a killer recommendation on a nearby sushi joint, but we got to peruse the Farallon bar bible (actually, their full liquor/cordial menu) and even made a pact to return after dinner to further explore all that they had to offer. The happy hour special is definitely worth checking out as an inexpensive way to enjoy the feel of Farallon, but if you are going and can spend awhile I would recommend nothing short of putting yourself at the mercy of the bar, letting them know what you like and simply trusting them to make your visit memorable.

Since we were counting on having to wait for seats at the sushi restaurant and were anticipating a fairly tame dinner, we were obliged to indulge in a tasting flight of three different selections of Glenmorangie and a small pour each of Hibiki (a Japanese single-malt that I had been lusting after) and of Ardbeg Uigeadail (a peat-tastic Islay under the influence of former-sherry casks). Let me reiterate... Farallon has great happy hour deals, but this is NOT what the bar at Farallon is really all about. Let them show you what they can do and it will be well worth the price!

After filling ourselves past bursting with various types of roe and raw fish, edamame, restrained amounts of rice and even a little soft-shell crab, we changed into some stretchier pants (at least, I did) and headed back downstairs to Farallon to work on further celebrating my graduation day. As promised, Mark was still manning the bar and was quick to resume his position as our bar manager/bartender/mixologist/spirits expert extraordinaire. In a relatively short amount of time I had discovered my favorite gin (and I often claim not to like this juniper-centric distillation) and had totally fallen for a no-less-than-angellic, well-aged Armagnac. Now, I am a beer geek and I work in the the wine (as well as beer) industry, but I could be happy for a night without beer OR Champagne if these libations were invited to the party. My fellow graduate and drinking partner, Robin, was overjoyed with Mark's  top-shelf take on my ginger liqueur-spiked Dark & Stormy and I learned about the smoothest, most flavorful, best-balanced orange liqueur (specifically a blood orange liqueur from Sicily) that I have ever encountered.

I cannot wait to go back to San Francisco to enjoy the City by the Bay, but I really cannot wait to get back to the bar at Farallon to enjoy the lounge under the sea. From the oceanic decor to the beyond-phenomenal staff to the fantastic spirits program, this is the best bar that I visited while on the west coast! Thanks, Farallon team!!!
author: Abby M.

description:
Very neat atmosphere, somewhere at the intersection of classy and ridiculous. The wine list is very, very well prepared.

The food is acceptable, but in my opinion not what one would expect when walking into this curiously stuffy spot, especially for the price.
author: Philly D.

description: Want a real epicurean experience where your food is absolutely delicious, exquisitely presented, and cooked to order? Then the Farallon is the restaurant for you. It's one of the pricy upscale restaurants on Post Street where one should expect quality in food and service, and receive it. But, in our opinion, the Farallon  stands out as the best. The owner, executive chef, and general manager are yo be commended. Our server, Eva, was on top of her game. Her service was equal to and added to our phenomenal dining experience. She assisted us in ordering and recommending the best method of preparation, pairings, and she was on point with her recommendations for everything--appetizers, entrees, and desserts. She was attentive and professional. Her assistant servers brought our meals out on time, and our food was served at the right temperature. From appetizers to desserts, our dining experience at Farallon was enjoyable. I mean, the food is absolutely delicious. We have dined at Farallon since it opened--more than 20 years. It is one of the few high-end restaurants, not only on Post Street, but in the entire City, that has consistently delivered quality in food and service. Honestly, whatever you order you won't go wrong. It's not a cheap restaurant, however. But, for that special occasion, it's the place to go.
author: Ernest J.

description: Ugh! We were hoping for a great seafood dinner and we were very disappointed.  My fish was so salty I could not eat it.  The décor is pink velvet that is old, dirty, and stained.  The floor and floorboards are hideously dirty.  We didn't even finish our food.
author: Lori H.

description:
We had a our holiday dinner here for a party of 12. The private dining rooms are on the fourth floor and are just beautiful.  Spacious and cozy at the same time. We were seated at the biggest dining table I've ever seen.  Great service from staff. 

The grilled shrimp appetizers were good but the mushrooms in pastry were truly awesome.     Smoked salmon plate is recommended. The seabass was very good and the filet was even better and was so tender.

They know how to do desserts here. We had the airy Meyer lemon cake and the sticky toffee cake.  Both were delicious.  

Valet parking is $12.
author: H T.

description:
The decor at this place is very tastefully done. I loved the jelly fish lighting by the oyster bar. The place is beautiful from the inside. Gives you a very romantic, up scale, under water type feel. 

The service was really good! No complaints there at all. However, i thought the food was ok. I like my seafood with a bit of spice or flavor, so i thought my halibut was quite bland. I found myself putting a lot of hot sauce and black pepper. When i was there, they had a beet salad on the menu that was yummy but aside from that maybe i didn't experiment enough but the food was quite mediocre in my opinion. I'd come back here more for the ambiance and decor more than anything else. My dad loves oysters so i'd bring him at the oyster bar for a few drinks along with some bar food for myself. 

A definite experience though!
author: Ms C C.

description:
Interesting decor, reminds me a bit of Gaudi meets The Little Mermaid - right by Union square.

The seafood is solid, shrimp cocktails, red snapper and scallops.

Pricey, so beware but a great night can be had.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Seafood is heavenly. 
Seafood in an upscale SF restaurant, with an interesting atmosphere, extremely helpful servers, amazingly fresh food, potent bottles of wine, and added plates because they felt like it? Perfect. 
Luckily the two times I've come here I didn't have to pay, because if I had I would probably break the bank. I'm not sure if that made it even better, or if it was really that great in the first place. Either way, I love this restaurant. Last time my date (at the time) ordered tons of different dishes and bottles b/c he knew the manager. I really don't know what I consumed, except that it was delicious. This time however, we ordered two bottles of Drake Pinot Noir, half lobster with dipping sauces, squid dish, Halibut, and Red Snapper. They also gave us little spoonfuls of something that tasted like a mixture of pea soup, honey and fish. Sound gross? Definitely not, more like amazing! We also got dessert, which was delicious as well...but can you really go wrong with dessert? I think not. 
Each time I've been here, I can only think about how great it was. It's definitely the kind of place I would love to come back to again and again!
author: Sonya D.

description: I just spent 5 days in SF for our company national convention.  I ate at many restaurants and Farallon was by far the best meal I had, hands down.  The food and service was impeccable.  Thank you Farallon for making this dining experience my new go to when family and friends come to visit.
author: Kathy C.

description: Service was great and food innovative. Servings were on the small side and it was all very expensive. $772 with tax and tip for four people.  There is a lot of good food in SF for $400 to $500, don't you think? So, we have tried it now, but will not go back
author: William B.

description:
I weight service very heavily and do not usually forgive bad service, but, in this case, I am going to completely ignore the 1-star service provided by the hostess and give Farallon an enthusiastic 5-stars for its mouth watering food and for the stellar service provided by the rest of the staff.  

First though, a word to the hostess on duty July 25 at 7:15-- Honey, I used to do your job back in the day, at a restaurant that was busier than yours.  It isn't a tough gig.  All you need to do is smile, seat people at the correct table, and pay attention to their requests.  You didn't do any of the above.  if you were working for me, you would be fired.

First, do not rush the customer. Our table was not going anywhere.  You did not need to make it crystal clear that you were annoyed with our party for taking the time to great each other at the door (and for one person, a senior citizen, to use the loo).  Sweetie, three of the guests flew in from Europe the previous evening.  We hadn't seen each other in years.  So quit your toe tapping and buy yourself a sense of humor because, in another year, not even botox is going to be able to erase those frown lines.

Second, when a party of six indicates that a table near the staging station isn't what they had in mind, you accommodate their request to wait for another table -- no ifs ands or buts about it. (There was an empty table for six within my sight line, so your claim that you "had no other tables" was clearly BS).

If I had been in charge of this party we would have made a hasty retreat based on the hostess's attitude.  Thankfully, however, I was out-voted because the remainder of our experience was top notch. 

Our waiter was perfect.  He knew the dishes and the wines like the back of his hand, was able to make appropriate suggestions, put together an off-menu vegetarian meal for me (which included sweat corn ravioli with an onion au jus and pureed sweet peas) that was easily the best meal I have had all year (and one of the very bests I have had in several years), drummed up a crab cocktail for one of our guests even though it was not on the menu (poor crabs), and provided excellent service that was attentive without being intrusive.  The wine he suggested (a 2008 Ancian carneros chard) caught me off guard because I do not like chards and did not expect to enjoy this one.  Boy was I wrong.  It was bold, juicy, complex and refreshing -- not words I normally use to describe a chardonnay.   (My main word is usually "yuck").  Thankfully I saved room for desert because the chocolate malt creation I selected left my taste buds doing a happy dance in my mouth.  

Farallon is expensive and the portions are small, so be prepared to spend some money if you want to leave feeling satisfied (and full).  It is, however, money very well spent.  I can't wait to return.
author: Caisa S.

description: Amazing food!  We got the stuffed squid appetizer with mushrooms.  I loved the squid and the sauce, didn't love the stuffing. The Dungeness crab was so sweet you hardly needed the butter!  And I'm an East Coast lobster snob!  The Hawaiian tuna was perfect in a curry sauce. Yelp, you were right again!
author: Kit K.

description:
We came here for Valentine's day and had a really nice time. We were seated immediately at a table upstairs and from the start, the service from our waiter was excellent. He was so knowledgeable about both the food and the wine, plus he was really personable. The only end of the service that wasn't great was the busboy - at least twice did he come to take my plate before I was done eating, and he took my husbands away while I was still eating both times. I would expect better at a restaurant of this quality.

Food-wise, I really enjoyed my dinner. We didn't get the prix fixe but just chose ourselves. We got the seafood platter to share, the small size and it was plenty of food. Kind of messy to eat, but what do you expect. We each got fish for dinner and I remember it being good, but besides that, was not memorable.

Overall, it was a good choice for seafood.
author: Lauren M.

description: We had an amazing time at Farallon. We came for the prix fixe and tried things I never would have chosen, but loved. Rabbit wrapped in bacon (that tasted like hotdog, but in a really good way), a number of shell fish dishes, and a peanut butter and popcorn desert. This is the kind of place where you can rest assured when putting your food choices in the chef's hands. Everything was fantastic and I will definitely go back.
author: Emma L.

description: I ate bisque and cod, and both of them were fantastic!  Bisque was really rich taste.  Wine list was also great.
author: Minako K.

description: I know I said it was great Harris' hasn't change but the same can't be said about Farallon.  The food was good but nothing special the service is still bad.  At least it's consistent.
author: Suz L.

description:
My amazing boyfriend took me here for my birthday, and it was such a special evening! A lot of the other parties were business meetings, but the place definitely has some very romantic tables. The decor is eclectic and breath-taking, from the glass jelly fish, to the old-school-swimming-pool ceiling in the dining room, to the seriously cool bathroom tiles.

Everything we ate was delicious, but my personal favorites were the ravioli stuffed with foie gras and topped with lobster, and the scallops main course. The calamari were good, but unremarkable. The desert menu is huuuge and everything sounds delicious... the chocolate souffle tart was great! The wine selection is amazing, with some rare wines and our waiter was a riot.
author: Mira S.

description: I love this place.  It is my birthday dream place.  Went there and had a wonderful time.  Excellent food and loved the decor.
author: Daniel P.

description:
My dining partner and I had just enjoyed a couple of cocktails before we sauntered over to Farallon.  We had reservations so we were seated immediately.  We were the youngest diners (think 50+)...and the mood was kinda somber.  I didn't really like the decor--a little cheesy.  But I love seafood so I was looking forward to dinner.  

We started with some wine.  Then had a squab dish and a butter lettuce salad as starters.  And my dining partner had halibut...monkfish?  Can't remember.  I had scallops.

I love scallops...but not these.  There were several served on a long narrow plate.  They were not uniform in size, some being half the size of others.  I've watched Top Chef and Hell's Kitchen.  That's not supposed to happen.  I think it could have been forgiven had they tasted good.  They were way  too salty for my taste.  I didn't like them...but it wasn't bad enough to complain...and I was in good spirits from the two Manhattans I drank earlier.   But, yeah, will not be going back anytime soon.

Three stars for decent starters, service..and the fact they let us have a  leisurely dinner that started at 6pm and ended at 11pm (oops!)....Anyways, for the money, I would definitely go somewhere else.
author: happy t.

description:
Farallon offers very good seafood at a new, somewhat reduced price structure.  That's good news.  Even better is that the food is well-composed, complex, fresh, and innovative.  

A chevre and leek tart with grilled peach purée and black truffle coulis was everything promised by its description.  Good pastry, ample, even over ample cheese, a taste of truffle, a taste of peach.  Nice.

Warm smoked salmon with english peas over fava bean pesto was the star of my meal.  The  salmon was crisped just a bit on the surface and was tender smokey raw within.  Taste, temperature, texture.  Perfect. 

Roasted pike was done just so.  It came with a mushroom flan, and morels.  While the taste of mushroom in the flan was ephemeral and while there may have been a dash too much salt on the morels, overall this was very well done.  

With competitive pricing, good service, and well done seafood, Farallon is a destination in the Union Square area.
author: David D.

description:
I came here to pass time and get something to eat before a concert with a friend. I was really under dressed, but I was hungry and figured they would not pass up my business, even if I was in a track jackets, Spider-Man t-shirt, jeans, and dirty checkered Vans.

Anyway, this restaurants offers fantastic food, ambiance, and service. Unfortunately, the prices are not so fantastic, so the "Fantastic Four" does not apply to this upscale joint.

The food is really good. Farallon features a seafood bar, which is really rad. If you want some oysters on the half shell, well, they have them. And they have all kinds of different types from different oceans or whatever, so it's a great place to try the different variety of oysters that are "incredible."

Their cuisine has a strong French influence. It's all very tasty, but I cannot remember the names of the menu items as I am not fluent in French. But whatever, the food was delicious. I also want to add that the steak has a very a nice smoky taste to it. I thought that was a nice touch. 

The ambiance has a dimly light, "under the sea" type theme. It really transports you to another world. Aquaman would be proud.

The service is stellar. Seriously, they get the job done with grace. No complaints here. It truly is "super."

The prices are very high for everything on the menu. But you really get what you pay for. But for my money, I'd rather hit up Morton's or Alexander's. I guess price is always the "X-Factor."

But I liked this place so much, I put myself on their mailing list.

If you want a pricey; yet, fabulously delicious meal, head over to Farallon. I recommend it.

I will be back. Well, when I put my comic books down, of course.
author: Archie G.

description: I have been coming here since basically since it was built.  I have seem many ups and downs but my most recent trip was spot on in every way.  The service and food were excellent. The space hasn't changed much over the years but why mess with success, as other reviews note it is very interesting and unique.  Small bar but it can be fun as well if you just want to pop in and grab something quick.  Yes it isn't cheap so I usually reserve this restaurant for a special occasion.  With the holidays coming on Farallon is a great place to stop after a long day of holiday shopping at Union Square.  I have done this several times over the years, a good way to wind down after that kind of day.
author: Damon S.

description: Great entrees, rich with small portions. Wine pours by the glass were laughably small and quite expensive.
author: Wayne G.

description: I went here for my bday and was really impressed!  The ambiance and dining area was really upscale and nice (a bit too loud tho).  The food was awesome.  I had the striped bass for dinner and the apple pie sundae (it had a different name) for dessert..both really tasty.  The mussels as an appetizer were really good too.  The half-lobster as an appetizer was extremely skimpy though, so stay away from that.  Topped everything off with a nice bottle of champagne and the bday was a success!  I definitely suggest coming here and giving it a try.
author: Jeff M.

description:
My evening at Farallon began normally enough. My friend called my office from Union Square and invited me for a drink before he had to meet up with his divorce lawyer. We met at the bar. Word has it they've got the best gin ever. I'm not a gin person, but I thoroughly enjoyed their citron vodka - it was some kind of organic brand which is rather cute. It cost $11. That's what I call priorities.

It was fun having a looksee. I haven't been to Farallon in years. I noticed they've removed a lot of tables from the front and added an oyster bar, which was very slow. I was intrigued by the changes. The first time I dined here was under the original Pat Kuleto design when the business and restaurant were flourishing. I often recall the appetizer I had that day - three kinds of smoked fish each with a pile of their roe atop, accompanied by a glass of champagne. Barbaric, delicious, divine! 

Aside from the oyster bar, they've sort of "beigewashed" a large part of the front and middle of the restaurant. This decorating decision, I feel, was a mistake. Because as we sat on the banquette surrounded by the beigeness blending into the light mosaic floor, I just couldn't shake the feeling we were sitting in the bottom of an empty swimming pool. They need to go with a darker color to offset the beautiful floor and fixtures. I'm no designer, but it was obvious to me. 

My confidence wasn't bolstered by the presentation of the menu. Two short pages of not very imaginitive seafood offerings including "idaho trout, " which just screams "farmed" to me. And something very bottom-of-the-barrel sounding called "Wreckfish," so-named because it likes to swim around the wreckage of ships. The waitress told us this factoid as part of the menu schpiel. Swim around the wreckage of ships? The first thing I thought of was Robert Shaw's bloated face bobbing inside the submerged hull of his boat in the movie Jaws. Or maybe that was a different underwater dead guy, but you know who I mean. His eyes might have been nibbled out by Wreck Fish.

These were the grim thoughts that were going through my head at Farallon before I ordered. But we forged on with guts of steel and decided on four kinds of oysters for three of us, the artichoke/panko stuffed calamari with white bean, and three entrees which we hogged to ourseves. 

There's nothing like juicy oysters over an even juicier conversation.  The oysters were great - we asked for recommendations of small ones, and the four kinds we ordered were all perfect in size, and uniquely textured and flavored, and presented beautifully. Heaven. All of the food was delicious. The dayboat scallops, the seared ahi, the asparagus with the tiniest pommes frites and rich, melty duck egg. My initial cynicism dissolved. 

Maybe this place is on some kind of pedestal in my memory. That, combined with the fact that parts of its interior were changed in such a heavy-handed way started me off badly. Maybe there's an old-worldness about it which I'm not used to with these particular friends. There were mostly tourists in the place, which as a San Franciscan I'm appreciative of, but my snob button got pushed or something. I'm trying to say I was wrong! 

After dinner we strolled around the closed dining room with our apertifs - what kind and patient waitstaff! - genuinely interested in looking around but also making fun of some of the paintings - can I sound like a bigger asshole here? Looking at a rather pedestrian one, of people emptying fish on a pier, my friend said "That one's from the Nebraska school of the landlocked."

Hopefully they'll have us back someday. Glad to see things are still going well. This is a still interesting bastion of better days (mine or theirs?).
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Fabulous decor.  Each course was absolutely delicious and plated so nicely.   Menu changes depending on what they have fresh.

Definitely a spot to take your wife, girlfriend, or anyone you would like to impress :-)
author: Karen Y.

description:
Decor: Somewhere between Disney and Spongebob Squarepants.

Service: Glaciers are melting faster than the service at this place. Literally.

Portions: Microscopic--even by developing nation standards

Quality: Red Lobster does better, for a LOT less.

Prices: I paid $60 for a small salad, a few shrimp with cocktail sauce, a soda, a coffee, and one drink.

I have no problem paying for exceptional quality. This experience offered none of the above.
author: Anthony H.

description: Interesting decor dominates the experience while high priced food and service takes a backseat. Servers were too eager to push the food in front of us without paying attention to appetizers versus main courses. My meal of several appetizers was complete before my wife's dinner arrived.  A soft comment to the manager was met with a very defensive almost superior response. San Francisco has too many great restaurants to waste time here.
author: Jack N.

description: Probably the best meal I've ever had.  I started with the pan-seared Maine diver sea scallop with heirloom tomatoes, oxtail ragout, and red wine jus.  Next, I had the grilled Double R Ranch petite filet of beef with creamed spinach, fondant potato, cippollini onions, and red wine reduction.  Both were absolutely fantastic.  Drinks were excellent a well; I had a flight of Islay whiskies (the standout was the Ardbeg Uigeadail, which I'd had before, but I'm certainly not complaining) and a Neal Family Cabernet to pair with the steak.  I can't remember our server's name for the life of me, but she was probably the best I've had as well.  Absolutely outstanding place.
author: Alex O.

description: The food was nicely served to table of seven all at once.  Wonderful.  Food was flavorful and interesting but too salty for most at our table.  Too salty to be healthful perhaps. $$$$$
author: Tom A.

description: Years back, this was the place to be for a trendy ambiance and tasty seafood.  My last experience here, the soup was a bit salty for me taste and seafood wasn't on par as before.  Maybe it was an off Saturday night.  The ambiance and decor was real nice & felt like you're @ an under water sea experience.  Even though the decor was unique, I felt like it's a bit dated.  Every now and then, revamp and you'd keep the thing fresh.  Just my opinion.
author: Johnny T.

description: Visited Farallon again with my wife in August 2014 and had a great Happy Hour time!  Ordered the burgers, oysters and a few drinks each and didn't break the bank.  Service was great!  Can't wait to see you again!
author: Jason N.

description:
If you've ever wanted to walk into a story book, this one takes place in the deep blue.

The first thing you'll notice are the majestic jellies, brilliantly lighting the way into the dining hall. Elegant glass tenticles lure you into a world less seen, while the aromatics prepare you for a special dining experience.

The design of this restaurant is enchanting. Seated, you feel as if you are in an under water cave, carved out just for you.

Do make reservations.

The scallops here are wonderful and so is the petrale sole. If there was ever a restaurant that highlighted the city by the bay, it's Farallon.

Waterbar is also on par, and both being Pat Kuleto restaurants, hit the mark perfectly.

The high point of the night was definitely dessert. A playful rendition of smores; we were given warm cookies and a decadent mint chocolate marshmallow dip.

It can get pretty messy, but the joy is in the construction.

Farallon is a fantastic place for a dinner out. Beautiful decor, fun dishes, with a genuine friendly overtone, that wraps up the dining experience perfectly.

I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Mike K.

description:
Went to celebrate a milestone birthday (major fraction of a century) with a small group of friends and everyone was well pleased. Everything was grand, but the high point was the halibut. As the saying goes, that piece of halibut was good enough for jehovah. Really, once of the best servings of fish I've had in quite a while. Service was first rate (informed, attentive, but never annoying) and the wine list is impressive.

The crab cakes were also a delight, but the GUINNESS MILK CHOCOLATE ICE CREAM SUNDAE was to die for (all caps courtesy of the Farallon website).

It is of course a pricey place, but very memorable for special occasions.

Most highly recommended
author: Richard P.

description:
Had the pleasure of being taken out to Farallon for a birthday dinner, and I must say that immediately upon entering I knew I was going to love this please. The decor is gorgeous-you feel like you are in a lush underwater cave. Sea anemone/jelly fish glass chandeliers,  fresh seafood sprawled across huge crystal bowls of ice, beautiful wall decor, and the best part was our booth. We had the best seat in the house-an almost completely private banquet that opened up over the whole dining room-fab.

the bread they generously passed out upon arrival was ok-def not worth breaking a low carb diet for-but the sea salted butter was delish.

Our server was very good intentioned, but a little odd. They have a specialty drink menu, and when i didnt find anything on there I wanted and asked him to recommend a vodka cocktail done martini style that was not too sweet, it was like I was asking him to explain the meaning of life. He went on this whole diatribe about what a martini is, what it is not, why my request made it difficult to suggest something, etc etc. He finally asked the bartender and brought me some lemoney charmbordy thing that was ok. The Duck Farm chard we followed it up with was great though.

I started with ono, char, and tuna sashimi trio-very fresh, but a little too much oil on the char (I like my sashimi with just an accent of added flavor to not overpower the fish, but it was good) 

Next came the main of branzino, in a lobster broth with artichoke hearts and wax beans. Lots of fresh perfectly cooked veggies, and they filleted it beautifully. Branzino skin was perfectly crunchy.

Finished with an amazing dessert that had all of my fave things: warm chocolate cake with caramel and vanilla cream in the middle, topped with dulce de leche sauce, salted peanuts, banana sorbet (out of this world) and fresh vanilla bean whipped cream. 

My only reason for not giving 5 starts is the service-they guy spent waaaaay too much time talking and really didnt seem to know what he was talking about (which created some funny moments for my dinner date and i, but was a little annoying none the less). However, the food runner  was unbelievably cute-wished he was our server.

Was a great CA dining experience-I come out here craving delicious fresh fish in a beautiful setting, and thats what I got!
author: Meredith M.

description: Do not eat here. The restaurant was full on a Monday evening. Our group filled three separate tables. We all arrived at 6:15. The service was so slow that we didn't get our entrees until 9:15. Other guests who arrived later were served first. We didn't leave the restaurant until 10:15. If you like to eat bread and drink wine for two to three hours, this is the place for you. The manager did give us a 15% discount. However, I believe that's only because three of our guests complained. Several people in our group were drunk from drinking wine without getting served their food in a timely fashion.
author: Allison J.

description: One word--Corpse reviver. Great drink that you won't forget. Having had the frutti di mare appetizer, I realized I needed to follow-up with an even better entree. Ordered a freshwater fish that apparently traverses into saltwater sometime during it's life--not sure how that happened, but ask about it! Also, be careful where you sit because certain seats echo to the other side of the room...real cool effect, not cool if you're having private conversations. Overall, service was great. Food was impeccable.
author: Ryan A.

description: What can I say? Unfortunately, nothing good. The quality of the seafood was alright but definitely nothing to write home about. I ordered the Seared Mediterranean Branzino and it was mediocre. Maybe the chef's were having a bad night? Or I don't know, maybe my taste buds aren't refined enough to appreciate this place. I've definitely had my fair share of great seafood and I expected this place to deliver just that. I mean, 4 stars, right? Sadly, I was greatly disappointed. The service was great but that is as far as it goes. It's all hype, don't waste your money.
author: AJ D.

description: Eh.  Captain Nemo meets Flashdance.  I'm sure this place was da bomb in the day.  The atmosphere is in serious need of refurbishment and the food was so-so.  Don't get me wrong.  I'm not a snob. But, if I'm gonna drop $100 apiece for dinner and wine, I expect something that is better than I got.  Not thrilled at all.  Had the seafood trio - lobster, crab and shrimp.   Food from the sidewalk stands at the wharf was better. Save your money and go eat down on the wharf.  You'll have much better food.
author: Brian F.

description: Absolutely amazing good. Very few restaurant in US offer this kind of service. It was totally worth having dinner. It is probably on of the sea food restaurant in Sam Francisco. My wife and I enjoyed very much. I would rate 10 of 10.
author: asif k.

description:
For the price we paid, we certainly expected more and better food.  We liked the decor and the atmosphere, but I'm not sure if I want to return.
  
I ordered a seared duck breast first course.  It was a good start.  The waiter recommended a white wine (the most expensive white by the glass on their wine list).  The disappointing part was:  the wine was not at all chilled.  When I told the waiter, he said that's the temperature they always serve their white wine.  (If that's true, they're in trouble)  I also had the grilled tuna - and it was a bit over-done.  So farewell Farallon - I won't be seeing your jellyfish for a long time.
author: nardo m.

description:
Dreamy atmosphere and excellent service. Nice cocktails. Man, nothing beats gin and bitters! 

Tried wreckfish for the first time. Never heard of it, but it's like halibut, only not as tough. Came with gnocchi and a creamy mushroom fondue. Yummy. The ceviche of the day was I think branzino served with a lot of cilantro and a bit of red bell pepper. That was great, too. 

Right now there's a 4 course prix fixe menu for $65 (and $35 wine pairings) which was quite good. Smoked salmon, sturgeon and buckwheat blini appetizer drenched in butter; melon, serrano ham and figs; soft shell crab, roasted tomatoes and lentils for entree; and brownie cake and malted milk ice cream for dessert. The wines worked very well, but my favorite was the Meyer Family zinfandel port. There were two amuse bouche as well, a pea soup and iced citrus. 

Too bad they're not open for lunch anymore!
author: brewgirl b.

description: I enjoy the decor of the place very sea life like.  Been coming here for quite sometime.  I always have a craving for there lobster roll, probably one of the best around.  Dinner is fairly descent's can't go wrong with seafood too much unless is prepare poorly.  But I have yet to have a bad experience there.
author: Gsk A.

description: I hate to give this place only 2 stars but if it weren't for the decor and ambiance, I'd give it a one star. The service was absolutely dreadful. Our server rarely came around and also got our order wrong. The portions are incredibly small and over-priced. The food, though, was very good, not excellent. In sum, this place looks really cool inside, but that's all it has going for it. If you want really good service and good seafood, this is not the place to go. I will never return and I highly recommend that you don't go either; very very disappointing.
author: Matthew P.

description:
The bad news is that going to this restaurant gave me a lobster craving for a entire month... The good news is : It was delicious !!!

There's a theme to the restaurant ( "Unda da sea" as the little mermaid's Sebastian would put it), but contrarily to a Disney Restaurant, this one has classe and authenticity. 

A little overpriced in my opinion though, go for a special occasion (Grandma's b-day is perfect)
author: Clara T.

description: Went here with my girlfriend to celebrate her birthday. When we arrived there was a hand-written birthday card waiting for her at the table. What a touch of class. The service was impeccable. I wish I could remember our server's name.. he was great. He even went outside to hail a taxi for us because my girlfriend was cold and he insisted so we would not have to go outside. Very cool. The food speaks for itself.. so good. The experience was worth every penny. They even customized a desert for her birthday with her name on it. Thank you, Farallon for being the only establishment we visited that actually acknowledged the fact that it was her birthday. Even the 4-star hotel in which we were staying couldn't get that right. We will be back..
author: Martin H.

description: great. expensive but really good sea food.
author: John B.

description: Best cooked piece of halibut I ever had and the accompanying sauce was fantastic. Definitely 5 stars for that. What brings down the rating for me was the mixed green salad which was less than inspired and the chocolate brownie and vanilla bean cream dessert which just didn't feel very satisfying (i think i would have much preferred a nice scoop of ice cream to the barely there fluffy vanilla mousse. But either way, the fish rocked!
author: Katie D.

description: Very interesting atmosphere and good (but not amazing) service.   Food was really pretty average and portions where small, especially for the price.  Our server said the signature dish was salmon.  It was good, but not anything special.
author: Earl B.

description:
My husband and I went here on our last night in San Fran.  The decor was beautiful.  We sat near the kitchen area, which we loved because we got to see the cooks making the food and their interactions. :)

The husband absolutely loved his tuna dish, saying it was one of the best seafood dishes he has had in years.  I ordered the salmon, which was good.  I just wish they would have cooked the salmon a little bit longer, ( But I do know  that I do like my fish cooked longer than most recommend!!)  If you're like me- just tell them how you'd like it cooked.  

The service was wonderful and I would recommend making a stop here if you enjoy seafood.
author: Kelly S.

description: Some of the best scallops I've ever had. This place is great for a fine night in the city. Be prepared to spend a good amount on dinner, but worth the food and atmosphere.
author: Holly C.

description: Superb!  I was surprised by my boyfriend who brought me here during a weekend in San Francisco.  The place has a wonderful under the sea atmosphere and the seafood is excellent!  I had my first oyster that wasn't sandy and sour.  I had the lobster bisque which was creamy but had bits of lobster!  I would definitely recommend this place for the lover of seafood and outstanding service!
author: Camille B.

description: Fresh food, wonderfully prepared, attentive staff. Whimsical, fun decor!!!
author: Kaye F.

description: Five stars for freshly shucked oysters!!! One star for the Barbie size martini glasses... Five stars for ambiance. Incredibly overpriced...but freshly shucked oysters is where they get all the stars!!!
author: Jen K.

description: I recently dined here for the first time. Wow! This place is beautiful. It has so much history and character to it. The staff are super attentive and the service is excellent. I made a reservation for a birthday dinner for 2 and requested a booth on a weekend night and they were kind enough to follow through. I wasn't too thrilled with my dish, otherwise I would give them 5 stars. I will definitely be back and see what the more popular dishes are before ordering.
author: Michael D.

description:
The atmosphere of this restaurant is still great even 'tho we've not been back in a few years.  After checking in 15 mins late because Downtown was full of cars and people for the holidays, we followed the maitre d' into the Pool Room with huge sea urchin light fixtures, so very aquatic.  There's a 3 course prix fixe menu for $50 daily before 6:30 PM.

We sat midway facing the kitchen and could watch the action. I commented to our  friends that the wait staff is well -trained,  waiting and watching patiently for the pick-up while the open kitchen chefs prepared their customers' dishes. 

It's a fairly extensive menu with appetizers and entrees in one menu book, another for the wine and a 3rd for the oyster bar specialities.  I started with a vodka oyster shooter.  It was OK, the heat from the Worcheshire sauce and something spicy really gave my nostrils a hit.  Like innocently shoving a lump of wasabi into your mouth thinking it was guacamole.  Wow,  I can breathe again!

The bread consisted of a slice of crunchy French bread with soft interiors and a crispy piece of bagette and butter sprinkled with chunks of pink sea salt.  We received a complementary taste of chilled carrot garlic vichyssoise in the tiniest of cup and saucer.  It was very tasty with a tang of ginger. 

My appetizer, the Delta smoked sturgeon served on top of a crispy potato cake and finished with Paddlefish caviar was delicious.  There were 4 decent-sized squares, really enough to share.  I could've have eaten several of this order all night long for dinner.  There are several choices for the oysters on a half shell.
Hubby had the Hudson Valley foie gras which was sweet and pate'-like.  It was such a huge serving, simliar to a small round of brie cheese and was served over paper-thin slices of persimmon with plenty of toasted brioche.  Just wonderful.  

My entree, a deliciously pan-fried and finished in the oven pike was even better.  I'd never tried pike before and the white meat was sweet and tender, reminded me of a smooth black cod.  It was served over a deliously crisped polenta with a wonderful sauce. Everyone at the table said that dish was good.  A big bite of the osso bucco was dry and bland, I could not taste any of the red wine it was cooked in. The rack of lamb was very tender.  The seared ahi tuna slices was not memorable and could be had at any other restaurant.  It was served over tiny green lentils which was good.

We had a bottle of French Merlot for $48.  The sommelier offered us the 2001 bottle for the same price which was smoother.   I passed on dessert because I could eat no more but had bites of everyone else's.  The honey roasted pear was quite good. Even better was the pecan ice cream which was served with the petite apple turnovers which tasted just like apple turnovers.  The early autumn fruit with Pippin apples, persimmon, dates and Satsuma mandarin oranges were good but pricey for $11.  It came with a container of natural honey dripping off a square of honeycomb full of honey!  Absolutely divine!

The restroom is 2 stalls, with a large wheelchair access and tiny tiles on the floor similar to the ceiling in the Pool room. The restaurant is housed in the historic building where the ElK Club lived.  My friend told me the pool is below the level of the restaurant and the ceiling of the restaurant is probably the original pool ceiling with miniscule tiles.  Our waitress was nice, attentive but not as attentive as the service at Gary Danko's at the same cost. 
The bill included 4% health surcharge for the staff.  You can pick up a wallet version of the Monterey Bay Aquarium's Seafood Watch sustainable seafood guide at the check in area on your way out for dining and shopping information.  Would recommend only the seafood here.
author: Ry T.

description:
This place is awesome!!!!!   Let me count the ways.

1)  They have valet parking, enough said.
2)  The host staff are friendly and extremely attentive.
3)  Wait staff are very educated about the menu and the specific items on it.  Just like up front, they are prompt, friendly and detail oriented.
4)  The food is absolutely incredible.  Ryan one of the Chef's there, is amazing.

I would give this place 10 stars if I could.  I've been here a few times and recommend this place for great seafood.
author: Brian V.

description:
Nice ambience and a very up to par/attentive staff. Not to mention the professionalism from the moment you walk in. From the hello greeting by the hostess to your server.

The food is delish and beautifully presented... not to mention the head chef came to our table to say hello. We received a complimentary dessert and to top it off the couple next to us sent us a bottle of champagne. This place is oozing class. My experience at Farralon was very pleasant and would definitely pay a visit again. It made a very memorable moment for my friend who celebrated their 7th year anniversary and a surprise marriage proposal that made everyone in the restaurant teary eyed.

Romantic! I'm a fan

I love valet service!
author: Jules V.

description: Absolutely the best sea food reataurant that I have eaten at.  The atmosphere and service was also top notch.
author: Daryl C.

description:
I dined here with my wife for a special occasion. We went all out basically just splurged on the menu. I can say I wasn't disappointed. The wine selection was slightly sub par, but the quality of what they did offer was excellent. The food and the service are excellent. This isn't a place I would eat everyday, but for the occasion it was excellent. Total bill ended up being a tad over $250 with tip for the two of us so definately expensive. However the food was freash and very well prepared we had the lobster and the bass for the main entress, the shrimp and scallops for the 2nd course and octopus and shrimp cocktails for the starter with a few oysters to get the night going.

Bottom line:

Food 10/10 - Very hard to beat
service 9/10 - they were kind of slow... 
price 5/10 - I'm cheap what can I say?

Overall 9/10 - Price hurts, but I understand that you get what you pay for.
author: Brian L.

description: I have always had an amazing time here. First off, it is gorgeous, I love the jellyfish and feeling like I am in a fishbowl. Everything I have had here was just divine but I love the shellfish platter that comes on ice. The lobster claws are to die for. The crab cakes are also super tasty. Once I had a dessert here I will never forget: Flour-less chocolate cake that was liquid center and served with Mango sorbet. Amazing.
author: Sarah J.

description: My boyfriend and I came here on our first night in San Francisco, moments after landing from a long flight. Our first mission was some west coast oysters, and Farallon did not disappoint. They had a selection of around six or seven different oysters, that were all extremely fresh and cold! I love an iced cold oyster. We loved the drink selection as well. The bar manager Mark was extremely welcoming, helpful, and really great at his job. He made us feel right at home in San Francisco and offered excellent service. I would highly recommend this place to any seafood or oyster lover, but expect to drop some $$$ quickly!
author: Rachel K.

description:
I was reaching across the bar at Americano during Happy Hour, stealing handfuls of Spanish olives and hungrily stuffing them into my mouth, when I officially became an embarrassment.   Hmph.

Seeking to sober me up (or salvage his reputation), my co-worker politely told me to re-adjust the kleenex in my top and dragged my drunk-as-a-skunk self into Farallon. 

Sans reservations, we were seated at the oyster bar and enjoyed oodles of beluga caviar and boodles of Sapphire martinis.  Certainly not the most nutritious dinner choice on an empty stomach, but decidedly delicious.

What a romantic restaurant, situated just off Union Square, with an "under the sea" feel.  I can't wait to come back here with a hawt date and to expense our dinner 'cause this joint is fancy.

I vaguely remember my co-worker paying $12 to get his vehicle, which costs more than I do, out of the valet.  

And then we left.  Or, we MUST have, since I woke up in my bed the next morning.  I don't recall getting home, but am relieved that I didn't burn any bridges by passing out in the restroom at Farallon.  

Although, it IS a nice restroom and Lord knows I've slept in worse places.
author: Janney B.

description:
I think I might have come with higher expectations then that which I was met with.  I must say the decor and service is exemplary.  

The three dishes I had were on the mediocre side though.  The butter lettuce salad with crab was drenched in a lemon dressing that was overpowering.  I felt as though I could hardly taste the crab or the lettuce which I love so much.  

I ordered the turbot which seemed to be overcooked to me.  It was a bit tough and rubbery.  It was my first time trying  so this could be due to the expected texture of the fish.    

The filet mignon my husband ordered was cooked nicely but the taste again was just mediocre.  It was good just not great.  

I will most likely come again to try other parts of the seafood but it's not on my immediate list to rush back to.
author: kathi k.

description:
I hadn't been to Farallon in years, well at least pre-Yelp, so was curious to check out their new oyster bar that replaced a few tables in the front. For those who haven't been, Farallon remains one of the city's classic restaurants, specializing in coastal cuisine, and it's sea fantasy-like interior (think jellyfish chandeliers and and illuminated caviar staircase) is still fresh.

The addition of an oyster bar is especially exciting to me, because it means that I might be able to enjoy Farallon at a more reasonable price (relatively speaking), and thus more frequently.

So, my friend and I arrived around six pm, figuring some oysters would be a fun way to start out the evening (we ended up going to Morton's down the street for dinner). We sat right at the bar, with full-on view of all sorts of raw crustaceans: lobster claw, crabs, clams, oysters, shrimp, all gorgeously displayed.

You can order off the bar menu, or ask your knowledgeable server for some ideas. I don't know my oysters that well, for example, but our waitress suggested a few that all proved to be delicious in their own way. I also tried the jumbo shrimp cocktail, which defines all three of the words in its name quite well. Since I knew we were having dinner later, I opted to sadly pass on what is surely a treat - the Maine Lobster roll - knowing that Farallon would most definitely will do right by this New England comfort food. Next time, ah next time.

Some items I know I'll try on that next time will surely include their grey goose oyster shooters, and if my appetite prevails, their 1/2 cracked dungeness crab with drawn butter. Oh, I might wash it down with their black peppercorn infused vodka Mariner cocktail, a nice compliment to any raw dish.

By all means, go to Farallon for the full experience if you can. But being able to sit at a bar like this makes for a somewhat more social, impromptu and casual experience, and I don't think the lobster will know the difference.
author: Nish N.

description:
There are some dates who bring out the best in you.  When you are with them everything else fades; every neuron and pulse tingles: RAPT.

There are some dates who bring out the worst in you.  They bring up every knotted frustration and hopeless disappointment you've experienced.  Ever.  And you curse yourself for even entertaining the notion .... 

Farallon falls into A Good, F*ck, GREAT date place.

Something about the w-i-n-d-i-n-g, curvilinear nautiluses.  The plush, furry seats.  The warm pink and red tones.  And of course gooey, viscous giant jellyfish surrounding you.

It is the Fresh and Salty fragrance. Impeccable and non-intrusive service.  Expertly made cocktails.  Fresh Fruits de Mer on ice (notably, the Dungeness Crab).  Lovely Chocolate Gateau with Chocolate Mousse and  Warm Pear Butterscotch Bread Pudding.  And even the Creamy Butter sprinkled with Coarse Sea Salt.

It is, most of all, natasha s.'s Best.  Second.  Date.  Ever.  

The End.
author: Natasha S.

description:
We came here the other day for a company dinner.  Here's a little recap...

- Open bar = bad news.
- 2 Ketel One and Crans.
- Oysters, oysters, oysters.
- Beluga caviar, mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm...
- A glass of cab.
- Spicy coppa crustini.
- Filet Mignon topped with foie gras, holla!
- 3 glasses of Jacky D.

The end result was the most expensive vomit that I have ever manifested.
author: Ed C.

description:
Hit this place upon a recommendation from a friend and he was spot on. I had the best gourmet prepared seafood dish I have ever had in my life. It was a tai snapper prepared in a coconut-curry broth with leeks and chili oil. It had an amazing balance of sweetness, spiciness and texture. The snapper was cooked to perfection with crispy skin left on and it was so tender.

The decor in the bar area is pretty nice with hanging jelly fish glass ornaments and other sea-themed touches but it was the dining room that was spectacular.

The ceilings are adorned with mosaics dating back to 1924 when the building was an Elk's Lounge. The chambers on the ceiling divide the dining room into various sections which make the huge dining room look cozier and warmer. 

All of a sudden you feel like you're in a different era or even in a different world. I think it would not be fair just to rate the food at Farallon. The dining experience as a whole should be rated. And for me, it was top notch.
author: Volkan S.

description:
We finally decided to toss aside our favorite eateries and try Farallon after hearing raves from friends.  OK - we were a bit skeptical.  Too much hype.

The bottom line is that it lived up to a pretty high mark.  We arrived ahead of our reservation time at their busiest.  The hostess didn't blink but seated us right away - not at the bar but at a choice table in the main dining area.  Agog at the decor, we felt like tourists.  Fantastic job.  The wait staff was completely on top of it, bring us water, bread and our drinks in short order.  They never rushed us yet seemed to be there when we wanted.

The food was excellent, starting with the shellfish bisque.  Rich but not overwhelming, good to the last spoonful.  The taste of fresh mussels was obvious and enjoyed.  We both had the sole for the main entree.  Pedestrian?  No way!  Sweet, melt in your mouth with a light sear that caramelized the fish.  The potatoes and mushrooms that accompanied were fantastic.  The servings didn't seem large but we were too full for dessert.  The espresso provided the perfect end.

Yes, we will go again.  It's pricey but well worth it.
author: Jim S.

description:
Review #100!

My 3rd visit here, and haven't Yelped it!  On our most recent visit, we came on a Sunday night after an afternoon performance of Beach Blanket Babylon.

As previous reviewers stated, this Pat Kuleto-designed restaurant has a nautical theme.  Some find it over-the-top.  For me, I love the details of the restaurant's decor.  It doesn't have the kitchy fish-net-and-floats with starfish and fish for decorations.  Interesting lights made in the shapes of jellyfish and sea urchins.  There's lots of curves and not many right angles to be found in the restaurant, evoking a wave or ocean-like feeling.

For dinner, my wife had the $50 prix fixe menu consisting of dungeness crab cakes, seared halibut, and creme caramel for dessert.  The crab cakes were 3 2-inch diameter, very moist, with large chunks of crab.  Seared halibut was also prepared well, not dry.  Creme caramel had the right amount of sweetness, and was a good ending for the prix fixe.

I started with the cornmeal-crusted squid, on top of squid ink risotto.  The squid was nice and crispy, yet still soft on the inside.  The squid risotto with the pesto sauce was creamy, yet a little tart from the sauce.  Next, I had the English Channel turbot pillows, which was turbot chunks with a lobster and scallop mousse wrapped around with lettuce then poached.  This was finished with  chopped vegetables and a foie gras sauce.  The turbot were indeed soft and light like pillows, and moist, and the foie gras sauce was very light as well, and did not overpower the fish.  For dessert, I had a German chocolate sundae.  Perfect for me, vanilla ice cream, pecans, caramel, coconut, topped with a vanilla bean cream...gooey, yum.

Service was efficient and unobtrusive.  As with previous visits, we had a nice dining experience, and would probably visit again in the future.
author: Steve L.

description:
Today, I will take you on a voyage 20,000 leagues below the SEA!!!!!! Actually, we will essentially being staying at sea level. Not even near the water but at a restaurant in Union Square. And while it is a nautical themed restaurant I didn't get to see anyone wearing a self contained underwater breathing apparatus, but the guy sitting next to me at the raw bar was wearing shorts. Shorts. That's a rarity in the city even more so at an upscale restaurant on a Saturday night.

Speaking of raw bars, I know they are haute cuisine and the "cool" thing right now but I just don't get it. I am going to assume my palate isn't developed enough to understand the big deal with ordering oysters, which we did. It was cool, just seemed kinda pointless. Grab oyster, slurp, and swallow. No chewing involved...

We were a few minutes early and seated at said raw bar which was great because it did give us some time to explore oyster cuisine and to try The Mariner, a drink made here specifically to accompany oysters. The Mariner is made with sherry and peppercorn infused vodka, this being the highlight of my oyster pit stop. 

At the exact moment when our reservations were supposed to be the hostess arrived, grabbed our drinks, and escorted us to our table. You can't really tell from the outside, but the restaurant is huge. There is the Raw Bar, the Jelly Bar, the Nautilus Room, and finally the Pool Room where we were seated. Each having a different design. The Pool Room is gorgeous and the ceilings have an aged European tile look about them. Hanging from the ceilings thoughout are light fixtures replicated to look like sea life. What I thought were sponge lights in our room were actually sea urchins. I thought sponges were a weird choice because it made me think of IUDs. Then I thought it was weird that I was thinking of IUDs at a nice restaurant. Then I wondered if a sex themed restaurant would go over well in the city. Thankfully our waiter appeared soon after. 

The service was top notch. I can't believe how many different people visited our table throughout the night either taking orders, busing, or delivering food. It was a well oiled machine. And the food... Easily one of the best seafood meals I've had. California Sturgeon over warm potato salad. Absolutely phenomenal. We ended dinner with a warm chocolate pudding cake and salted peanut ice cream. Mouth watering good, so good that it almost makes you want to fight your date for the last bite. Almost.

We picked Farallon for a celebratory dinner and couldn't have been happier with our choice.
author: Bucky K.

description: I have been coming here for years. A few years ago it seemed like the trend was downhill - same old customers getting older every year, small portions and high prices.  Things have turned around this year. A whole new group of people have discovered Farallon. Service has improved, tourists are attracted again and the vibe is on the upswing. Halibut and lobster were both very good, and soups were also very good. Portions are still small, and the menu is more limited than what you would expect, but what they have is very good.
author: Dave H.

description:
Extremely accomodating to 4 drunken fools who obviously were under 30 (okay, we all looked like we were in high school) and who rolled in 1 minute before they were officially closed and were like "WE WANT DESSERT NOW!". 

The apple fritters & blood orange cake were delightful but honestly, I thought most of the cheese plate was too stinky and hard, but then again, I'd probably had about a bucket of vodka in my system and ultimately, I can not be trusted (ultimately, I can't be trusted ever. with anything.)  The lighting in the bathroom made me look extremely jaundiced (see: bucket of vodka in my system. goodbye hepatic function!) , so I will not be going in there again. I was very dissapointed that there were no products or bathroom attendant - I thought this place was supposed to be classy???? Decor in the restaurant was so incredibly strange and the rest of the clientele was clearly dudes in suits and their Bimbo of The Month.
author: Maria D.

description:
The decor could give Stevie Wonder a headache, but the food was excellent.  We started with oysters, a generous portion of hamachi sashimi, and a peach salad that was just excellent.  The mains of halibut and sole were perfectly cooked.  I'd heard Farallon has among the best seafood in SF and, while I'm always skeptical of claims like that, I walked away believing the hype.  Not to mention the desserts were fantastic.

But it was the service that was exquisite.  First off, our waiter whisked away my companion's water glass without explanation.  He returned with a new one, explaining that he thought he saw a crack in the first glass.  Plates were delivered and cleared at the same time -- sadly, a bygone tradition.  

Also, our waiter was incredibly knowledgeable about the menu and, when confronted with a question about the oysters, he didn't hesitate to go ask the chef instead of making something up.  When I asked which of the two bottles of Vouvray he'd recommend, he sent over the sommelier.  Too often, waiters opine and make recommendations instead of asking the experts in the field.  Indeed, I asked the sommelier to surprise me with a selection and he picked a perfect bottle that matched his description perfectly.

So it's pricey and the Under The Sea ambience is a bit strange, but this really is a great restaurant.
author: Geoff K.

description:
Beautiful rooms and great staff. For those alone, perhaps 4 and a half stars. Food, while fresh and sustainable ingredients, lackluster in taste but beautiful in presentation. The cod I had was cooked well but it was missing that wow element. That thing that you put in your mouth and you can close your eyes and taste what is spectacular. 

I think for the price, decor simply cannot cut it. I had the same oyster and the same fish for half of what was paid.
author: Thia T.

description: Although Farallon is an upscale/fine-dining restaurant, it reminded me of a brasserie in Marseilles in the best sense. The food is fresh and beautifully prepared; the wine list hits the right note with the food. The wait staff was knowledgeable and helpful. The place is decorated with the underwater theme (see photos) but not "too much," which I found lovely. There is a valet parking (for an extra cost), which is convenient. I really enjoyed my experience here.
author: hk k.

description: Food was balanced and well put together.  I also enjoyed the wonderful single malt scotch selection.
author: Jessica R.

description:
We bought a travelzoo coupon for $85 which should have been for $150 value.  The restaurant must be experiencing some financial difficulties as they ripped us off and ruined our anniversary evening
1.  we were charged 18% as two people only as a "service charge"  We have never had this experience using a coupon
2. we were charged tax on the value of the coupon $150 which I am sure management pocketed the difference between $85 and the value of the coupon $150.  We have never had this experience using a coupon
3. we were charged the San Francisco health insurance contribution based on entire value of our coupon.   We have never had this experience using a coupon
4. We had the coupon showing on our cell phone.  Our waiter read our cell phone message from our phone which was just lying on the table and said "is that the travelzoo coupon on your phone."  Since when did waiters start reading the cell phone of customers lying on the table interrupting our conversation in the middle of dinner.   We have never had this experience using a coupon
5.  With all the extra charges our bill was twice the value of the coupon $95 plus $85 coupon.   We have never had this experience using a coupon
This was the sleaziest experience in what should have been an elegant evening on our anniversary.
author: magnolia p.

description:
My BF and I decided to go grab a bite in Union Square...we decided to hop over to  Farallon and visit my Friend and manager Corey;)
We sat at the bar...it was great catching up with both friends while sipping on white star....my friend and I decided to do it "tapas style" and Corey treated us to "Jumbo California Asparagus" shaved Serrano ham, hard cooked quail egg, & meyer lemon vinaigrette.  We also had "seared rare hand line caught ahi tuna" tree oyster mushrooms, miso broth, and avocado relish.  Lastly,  we shared "A Prawn & Scallop Shu Mai" ....tarragon roasted cauliflower, golden enoki mushrooms, w/ a hoisin vinaigrette.  
I like Farallon for the bar, however the dining room is beautiful and perfect for a special occasion....On a M-Fri after work you just may find me posted at the oyster bar....easy, simple, delicious!

Thank you Corey. Mvah!!!
author: Michele K.

description: Excellent food, fabulous service. We had a special anniversary meal there, and felt pampered all night. Not hurried, very relaxed. Food was spectacular. Wine excellent too.
author: John D.

description:
My all-time favorite place to go for an upscale seafood dining experience under the sea.  Obviously, it's not under the sea, but the visually stunning decor when you first walk in certainly gives you that dreamy undersea feeling.

Farallon is the exact polar opposite of a horrible tourist trap seafood restaurant at the wharf which actually does offer true dining under the sea...Forbes Island.  I'm chuckling right now since a former coworker of mine just called to tell me about dry heaves and severe cramping after dining there.  Normally, I wouldn't find it funny, but this is the same cocky guy who read my review and told me he was going anyway.  (Sorry Jim, but you need to stop lurking and start reviewing)  The last time I was there, I didn't get sick, but I was so disappointed that I was glancing around for Swanson TV dinner boxes to see if they were defrosting the pre-made tasting dinners at Forbes Island.

Anyway, sorry to get sidetracked...back to Farallon:
The amazing undersea decor has been gorgeous since day one, but even more impressive is that it has stood the test of time and aged beautifully. 

I dined here twice the first week it opened back in '97 and have been coming here ever since.  Despite all the changes over the years, this place still makes me happy.  I just took my GF here for her birthday and was happy to see that the food and atmospshere here is still going strong.

Although this is a seafood restaurant, for those of you that prefer something else (I admit it, I love steak), their filet of beef is tender and a surprisingly decent alternative.  The striped bass I had this time was succulent and perfectly cooked, as was the halibut.  

Service was extremely professional as everyone was obviously very well-trained.  Unobtrusive, yet always very much aware and attentive.

The quality of the food and artistic presentation combined with first-rate service made for a most memorable, almost surreal dining experience.

Although we didn't have it this time, the three course fixed prixe menu at $50/person is a bargain, so we'll definitely be going back there soon.  Ordinarily, that would be impossible since it's only until 6:30PM, but now that I've taken some time off to enjoy life, it's perfect!

If you're looking to impress a date or just show someone special some love, you could do a lot worse than this place. 

Interesting trivia - I hear there used to be a swimming pool in this historic building before it became a restaurant, somewhere in the main dining area.
author: Roy N.

description:
A good place for business guests and expense account dinners. 
I don't mean to say out of town guests don't have discerning tastes, but it's reliable, fancy feeling, and "easy".  There may be better restaurants in SF, but this is convenient. 
The decor is very Little Mermaid, but adults of all types seem to love it.  
I remember their bread very well. There was lots of it.  
The service was a little awkward, I don't think the waitress could gauge our party.  The sommelier was very professional.  It seemed like a good wine list, but I had to be on my game. 
The fish entree I ordered was sad, frankly.  I think it was overcooked, and the greens on the side resembled something my Polish grandmother might have had a hand in steaming to death. (sorry, Nana). 
As others have said, the tiered dessert tray was very fun and sweet.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Someone stole my review.

Seriously.

I was so going to do a version of "Under The Sea" from Little Mermaid but obviously it was less than original.

Hrmph.

But seriously folks, that song would NOT leave my head when I was in this restaurant!  I know it's supposed to be "high class", but to be honest, I felt like I was at Disneyland (minus 1 star).  The service was fairly good - they were quite attentive and we had a few waiters constantly around.  They did have one small snafu and brought a friend the wrong meal - and the correct meal took about 15 minutes to arrive.  So minus another star. (Poor Ariel and Sebastian...they'd be so disappointed...must get King Triton involved!!!)

The best thing about this place was the dessert.  I had a delicious bananas foster with creamy vanilla ice cream.  My tablemates were quite jealous that they had not ordered it (but being a good friend, I shared).

Overall, the food was about a 7/10.  It was good, but it wasn't the most memorable (except the dessert).

Service 6/10 - waiters were attentive, but the mix up of meals and delay and receiving new meal get major negative points with me.

Decor/Crowd - 5/10 - again, I just felt the decor was a bit corny - also looked a bit out dated.  The crowd was also a bit dull....a lot of Japanese business men and women as well as +65 crowd.

I don't think I'd choose to go back but if someone were paying, I'd not protest!
author: Melanie N.

description: A bit disappointing. Loud guests, dated decor, pushy wait staff but tasty but over priced food.
author: Kristy J.

description:
Must have been asleep at the wheel - took me ages to check this place out.  In all honesty, I've been here now.  Done it.  Tasted it.  Time to move on.  I'm good.  Kinda like some past relationships, eh ... ;)  You're more likely to find me regularly at Waterbar (turns out owned by the same superstar) for some delectable seafood dishes - but I'm glad I checked out Farallon.

I'll keep this review simple ... cause let's face it, sometimes that's all we need ...

BUTTER ROASTED HALF MAINE LOBSTER
: English pea ravioli, shaved fennel, orange fondue
: The ravioli was absolutely delicious.  The best part of this dish.
