: Price tag - steep $22.  Corporate account.  Don't even care about the price tag.  ;)

SEARED ATLANTIC DIVER SCALLOPS
: Black eyed peas, Fred's chorizo, Sweet 100 tomatoes 
: Delicious.  The scallops were cooked to perfection - crisp on the outside and tender on the inside.
: Hearty portion for even a large appetite.

LEMON BALM MERINGUE TART
: Brown sugar meringue, lavendar syrup
: Ok, I am IN LOVE with this dessert!!!  Tart. Tart. Tart.  With a side of tangy.  Just a touch of sweet.  Perfection!!
: I would have been perfectly content with just this dessert and a glass of Muscato.  

BECKS AE POSTER
: Umm, what better way to end the evening than checking out Becks' pecks on the side of Macy's ... Sorry sue me ... He's hot!
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description: Love the decor! We went for valentines day and our server did a great job making sure we got the (slightly off the menu) orders we wanted. He was attentive and the food was delicious!
author: Megan B.

description:
+ Great service. My cup was never empty. 
- They were either blasting the AC or they didn't have double-paned windows because it was FREEZING! 
+ Oysters with beluga caviar! The Blue Point oysters were especially delicious.
- We sat in a private dining area on the fourth floor, away from the jellyfish lights. Boo!
+ The spicy coppa crostinis were awesome 
- I ordered my filet medium rare, but it was still a little tough to cut through. 
+ It was still delicious.  
- I wasn't fond of the strawberry shortcake for pre-dessert.
+ The fudgy chocolate cake for real dessert was bomb. 

I really don't have anything to complain about because I ate like a queen on someone else's dime. I'd gladly freeze in a jellyfishlight-less area if I could eat foie gras and caviar again without having to deal with the bill! Thanks, Ed C.'s boss!
author: Amy H.

description: The Oyster Bar was excellent and the history about the establishment was very entertaining, I also enjoyed how when each dish was served the waiter(s) were completely knowledgeable about what they were putting in front of you. I give this restaurant 5 stars for excellent service and food!!!!
author: Michael R.

description: Farallon is a beautiful restaurant, and I am a huge seafood lover, but this place is a little overrated. the only reason i am giving it 4 stars is because of the decor. the portions are so tiny, and not that great, imo. the one thing i remember that was great about this place was the cute old man next to me eating by himself at his table. i had the best conversation with him about his fine dining experiences (weekly, lucky guy) and he shared his cheese plate with me ;) i really think there are MUCH better seafood restaurants in SF
author: Sheeva G.

description:
Due to meeting sales goal for 2006 the company president told us that we could eat anywhere we chose for a congratulatory team dinner. Thinking and praying French Laundry I found out that dinner would be at Farallon.  Here's the order...

Started off with an amazing fruit de mer platter with oysters and dungeness crab which was complimented by a Bilecart Salmon Rose.  Then moved on to foie gras which is a personal favorite of mine but was not too impressed with whatever sauce that was accompanied.  Then had appetizer of stuffed calamari and a spoonful of mushroom tartare (amuse bouche?)  The appetizers were complimented with a German Riesling with light fruity flavor and honeysuckle nose which usually always goes well with both foie gras and seafood.  Move on to the plat of diver scallops (one of the best examples of scallops I have had) perfectly seared and crusty on one side which was paired with both a white and red burgundy.  Finished with a cheese plate and shared an assortment desert called "Happy Endings".  Of course, ended it all with an espresso as I would have in Paris.  "Simplement tres maqnifique!"

Considering that we rented out a private room that had a beautiful aquarium in it we were treated very well.  The wine director, chef, and owner stopped by to greet us!
author: Connie P.

description:
I've been to this restaurant many times over the years and I've always enjoyed it. It's primarily a seafood establishment, and having just gone to Michael Mina, I especially appreciate how they stick to traditional ways of preparing food and do it well. 

The oyster bar stocks about 8 types at a time and are always fresh. Service is attentive, but not pretentious. The dining room displays the tiles that used to be part of a pool, along with beautiful glass art of jellyfish....definitely nice ambiance suitable for dates and non-romantic dinners. Nice bar and lounge area to boot. 

I would say this is definitely a mainstay of the Union Square area dining establishments.
author: Virg Y.

description:
This has to be on my top 10 list of favorite SF restaurants -- from the over-the-top Under-the Sea decor to the incredible fish and seafood -- and ending of course with the fabulous desserts.  

Farallon's decor is interesting in that is was originally the mezzanine level of the hotel's swimming pool (the actual pool is still there, beneath the restaurant, and yes, you can swim there!)  (If you're staying at the hotel -- or pretend you are and sneak in with those who are...).  As you look around the main dining room with the evocative arches, the mosaic tile work, the aquatic light fixtures, you start to realize that yes, this really does feel like being in a pool...

Here is a website that describes the background of the original space as well as Pat Kuleto's design choices -- I vote this restaurant as his masterpiece.  http://www.kuleto.com/PhotosandRestaurantGraphics/Farallon.htm

The fish, produce, oysters, everything is absolutely the freshest.  And, you come here for the fish and seafood -- if you want chicken or beef, go down the street -- there are plenty of places that specialize in other foods.  Be adventurous, let your waiter steer your ordering, and you'll fall in love.  With Farallon.
author: Bevy M.

description:
You can't beat the ambiance with the deep sea fantasy especially if you're entertaining out of towners.   Farallon is probably the most selected  'trade show' business dinner spot by most concierges so perhaps that explains the just ok experience I had this week.  Granted it was an all male group with one not a friend of the Sea so obvious choice was the one beef entree - did not partake in the oysters, lobster bisque just the steak which came about an hour after were seated.   His first bite of the steak was all it took for him.  He told the waiter it tasted strange and 'off'...maybe the seafood surroundings gave him the 'heebie jeebies' plus his left arm was feeling numb from a pinched nerve....I think the vicadin was messing with the taste buds.  

Our server did fine...offered to remake, order something else and bought the table a round of after dinner port for the (mishap).

Bottom line for me, Farallon is fine for those who have not been before, but there are other good choices potentially fantastic dining experiences around.
author: Randall F.

description: The ambiance, service and food were excellent.  Started off with some local oysters, which were delicious.  Then had the hamachi tartar, also very good.  Then the duck cassoulet.  Ohh, soooo goood!!!
author: Tracy W.

description:
This masterpiece interior is eloquently situated as if you are under the sea. With jelly fish dangling as lights and the arched ceilings give you a cave like wonderland. It is a magical walk through. The downside is the entrance is too narrow for this large restaurant. There is a small bar area to wait for your seating.

Our semi private Wine Room was warm and inviting with wooden panel ceiling and a view of the wine storage where they provide tastings. 

The staff is plenty and treat you as royalty. Our main waiter scared us a few times on his science lesson he gave us on the oyster choices. Our question was simple and the response was too much information. You wonder what too much information could be, right...? Question: Which Oysters do you recommend out of the 10 choices, are all oysters from cold waters? Reply: Well, I like these and those, bla bla... Oysters are only good from under a certain temperature, because the species are A-sexual, they turn male when in the warmer waters. It turns them into a gooey mush. But they are female in the colder waters. And in order to reproduce.... on and on...! I normally dont chose to listen to the discovery channel when I am eating my a-sexual - female oysters... Eeks!

The dinner turned out to be delicious. There is nothing I would change about my dish. We enjoyed a Pinot Noir which was very smooth and complimented the rest of my dinner.

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description: Great reviews,  but it was a bummer for me.  I ordered  the sliders,  which were great,  but the fries were cold.  They brought out new fries and they were hot, but dry and burnt. Over cooked or cooked twice? Then the the group next to me complained that they were missing a drink and the server comped them a whole round of drinks. :(
author: Mike _.

description: This review is just for the happy hour. One of the best happy hours in the City, for sure. All of the happy hour appetizers are delicious, but the oysters are what I come for. It gets very crowded and that has only a slight impact on service, but it's well worth it.
author: Susan S.

description:
We had an amazing experience at Farallon! From the salads to the entrees to the desserts...everything fresh, delicious, and artistic! They combine such wonderful ingredients to make very unique dishes and tastes. We also had a bottle of the Gloria Ferrer 1998 Carneros Cuvee with dinner, and it was fabulous and went really well with the Halibut!!

The service was also great, and the ambiance was very romantic. Farallon is located in the heart of Union Square, walking distance to many hotels and bars. I definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for fine dining, artistic plates, and unique seafood dishes.

Bravo!
author: Jessie L.

description: Beautiful Interior but very expensive for interesting but ultimately ordinary seafood.
author: M S.

description: uhh.. this place is overrated! The decor is super cute with an underwater world theme and the staff is friendly but the food... I definitely had better elsewhere. We ordered the seared petrale sole and grilled angus steak and it was both okay, nothing special. Super touristy, also a good place for business dinners but not a place I'd visit again.
author: Anne T.

description: The food was marginal and overpriced. I'm a foodie so I don't mind spending on exceptional food but paying big pucks for an average dinner is a big disappointment. I'm guessing most of the five star reviews come from tourist. Sadly we won't be coming back.
author: Yelp T.

description: Came here for Valentine's day...it's a seafood restaurant but I decided to go with the duck breast and I was definitely not disappointed.  It was cooked perfectly and absolutely one of the best duck breasts I've ever had.  The seared ahi tuna that came on a block of Himalayan salt was also delicious.  4 stars because I tried my gf's sea bass that she ordered and it was slightly overcooked and very bland.  Too bad for her...my meal was excellent and I don't like to share
author: Julian H.

description:
I expected bettter...

The food was good, i had a mushroom flan, it was not appealing and felt nasty in my mouth.
the cherry rhubarb pie was delish! and the place looked wonderful!
but the service wasnt very good here, and i always pay attention to service...:(
author: Dae M.

description: The atmosphere and decor was awesome. The food was good, but the bread with the Hawaiian salt was fantastic!!!!. Missed the happy hour, but will try again. Husband loved all the variety of oysters. The service was great. Definitely a repeat.
author: Veronica B.

description:
If you're low on salt intake, then I recommend Farallon for you!  

Be sure to order the line caught tuna carpaccio w/ curried egg salad and potato chips.  If that doesn't satisfy your sodium intake, then I recommend the crispy soft shell crab surrounded by yukon potato puree, sweet tomatoes and roasted chili butter.

Who knew sodium chloride could be so expensive?
author: Jenny S.

description: I totally forgot about this restaurant, but I know i've been here at least twice but I cannot remember anything special about this restaurant besides the decor. I won't recommend this place for good food maybe just for special occasions.
author: Sandy L.

description:
The decor here is very little mermaid and has the feeling of an older, kind of cheesy Vegas hotel.  We had some interesting cocktails at the bar and then sat in a booth in the back.  My ahi tuna dish was probably the most forgettable thing I've ever eaten in such a nice restaurant - overcooked, bland, and surrounded by mushy vegetables.  The more raw apps were much better.  Dessert was heavenly - I had the chocolate malt gateau.  

Our waiter was VERY detailed in his descriptions of each and every item on the menu, which was a little much, but I guess was helpful.
author: Sarah S.

description:
My friend Aine asked me if Farallon was my favorite restaurant in the city and I said no. I said my favorite was Grand Cafe, but that was before I went on a theater night (craziness) and found a hair in my house salad (mm... tastes like Salon Selectives). Now we're back to Farallon being my #1 most beloved. It never disappoints. Never.

The staff is outstanding. It's rare that I rank the service above the food, but these folks know how to treat you right. I've gone about 6 times in the last few years, and this last trip was equally exceptional. The wait staff are professionals... they're not disgruntled artists/writers/slackers that just couldn't find anything better. They take pride in what they do and it really shows. 

When you make a reservation - and DO make a reservation - make sure to request seating in the back room. You can even put this in the comments section on OpenTable.com. The upstairs is pretty (and the bathrooms are up there) because you're eye-level to the jellyfish lamps, but it doesn't compare to the underwater decor in back.

There's no valet for lunch which is a bit of a PITA, but that's a very small complaint for such a memorable dining experience. Perfect for a romantic date, a client lunch/dinner, any type of celebratory event or just to eat deliciously fresh fish fare and feel fancy.
author: Bernadette D.

description: I decided to check this place out on my b-day, and glad that I did. The staff was very courteous and professional. We ordered Chief's tasting menu which included (in this particular order): Ahi Tuna salad, angel hair pasta with crab meat, salmon, steak fillet with potatoes, cheese, and of course a b-day cake/candle dessert which was amazing. We also decided to order variety of oysters on half shell - which tasted very fresh as well. In fact, everything tasted excellent, especially the steak which was beyond perfect. I definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone looking to try a high quality seafood culinary creations!
author: Serge U.

description:
six to seven review... 

been three four years since I last propped my butt on to a stool and sat and did cocktails and oysters here... I remember back when this first opened and how the pat kulleto gazillion dollar some call it whimsy some call it WTF but I like to think that after all these years it somehow is just a stoned moment at the drawing board and we are all the better for it.

nothing new here... nothing..it is what it has always been...and will always be...solid...

ok the happy hour menu is a great deal...that is plain and simple ... no need to go over the whole thing but you can dine here like an early bird and walk away fed and happy ... why did I stop coming here? time to start a revisit of all the grand houses of san francisco proustian recollection of restaurants past....and why are all my reviews of years ago seem to be gone...? yelp is funny that way some times...
author: Ricote F.

description:
I had the opportunity to eat at Farallon lat night for the first time.  I've toyed with the idea of going before, but honestly it's a bit too pricey for me and guests always want to try places I've eaten already.

I had the Crusted California White Sea Bass with fingerling potato hash, asparagus, orange, Dungeness Crab, & bone marrow.  The sauce was basically clarified butter with a whisper of orange.  The potato hash was heaven.  The fish was good, although a little rare in the middle, which is I think not the norm for sea bass (but I am not sure...).  Very rich meal.  The chef certainly likes his butter.  The sweet corn soup starter was lovely and lighter than the entrees and was presented excellently.  Not your everyday corn chowder.  Everyone liked their meal, but only the lone duck eater was truly blown away.

The desserts were decadent.  We had the boysenberry cobbler: not too tart and tasted like it had been homemade for us--the cobbler topping was really a warm, buttery, cakey biscuit atop a mound of stewed boysenberries and garnished with lemon buttermilk ice cream (not too great on its own, but amazing with everything in one spoonful).

We also had the German Chocolate Cake with coconut ice cream.  The was tasty and rich but the milk chocolate and caramel sauces that garnished the plate didn't match well with the coconut and dark chocolate goodness of the layer cake (at least for my palate).  Don't get me wrong, the cake itself was to die for!

While I am giving Farallon four stars, I probably won't be going back.  The decor is nice, but this restaurant is too loud, too pricey, and too buttery (maybe a plus for some people?).  There are better options in the Bay Area I'm sure, but I'm glad to have been there at least once.
author: Sarah L.

description: Only went for cocktails and appetizers. Happy hour is awesome. 6$ Margaritas and select appetizers. The atmosphere is oceanic and there are jelly fish lamps hanging from the ceiling. Looking forward to a return for dinner next time we are in the City!
author: Sean B.

description: Always great!  I have dined here several times and have never been disappointed.  I can not say that about any other restaurant.
author: ginger t.

description:
This is like the Disneyland of French restaurants. For a nice tidy snapshot of how Americans like their France, come on down.

Our Bavarian-esque waitress knew a great deal about oysters, however. I asked whether she had to sit and taste each one, to get a sense of the "delicacy" or the "brininess" of this or that, but she just stared at me like I was Martian and excused herself.
author: Angela N.

description:
151 reviews, what more can be added?  Not much, except for my opinion.  Which probably doesn't count for much.

Imagine, if you will, that Disney opened a dark ride that was a restaurant.  That's what this place is like.  Dark, but friendly at the same time.

We were here with friends and had a blast.  We were a little loud but I don't think people minded since they were loud too.  So that would be a downside about the restaurant, it gets loud.   To counter that point, their wine selection was very diverse and the desserts were delectable.  (Did I just say delectable? Who says that?).

I recommend that you start with the oysters, they were very fresh (as one would hope) and finish with the flourless (sp?) chocolate cake.  What you get in the middle is your call.  I went with the halibut and loved every moment of it.  I don't think anyone didn't like their food.
author: David W.

description:
Yum. One word "Gnocci". Un-fuckin'-believable.
Here are a few more words. "Jelly-Fish Chandeliers", "Shot-Out-Sexy Wine Steward", "Pastry Selection" and "$45 Prix Fixe". Make the splurge, save you Open Table Checks, whatever, just go; its lovely

**Disclaimer- Although I work in a hotel which shares the same building with Farallon, I DO NOT work for Farallon (in fact, I've yet to get even a discount from the restaurant). This review holds no bias.
author: Daniel W.

description:
My husband and I got hitched in the ballrooms of Farallon. Cheaper then most SF weddings, it was so well-handled and over the top elegant. The chef works with the menu, taking your favorite items (for example, i said truffles, and voila, truffles on the menu) and creating the perfect dinner. It was magical.

I have dined here plenty before. Maybe I have gotten lucky, but the food has always been wonderful and worth the splurge. Yea, it's a splurge, but if you love seafood and would like to not get sick at a place like PJs or something, then Farallon (or Aqua) is the place for you.

And: the sommelier has always been great with recommendations. In fact, I think we like the same weird wines. Barberas instead of Pinots.
author: Olivia W.

description:
Holy crap, this place is sh*tty! Farallon would never survive in a city like NYC...Let me break it down for you:

1) Decor -- it's like walking onto the set of "The Little Mermaid." Must a seafood restaurant have jelly fish hanging from the ceiling? Must the booths be shaped like clam shells? I'm surprised they didn't have "Under the sea" playing in the background.

2) Menu -- for a "seafood" restaurant, Farallon's menu offers very little seafood options. The few fish they did list didn't seem to appetizing so I opted for the ribeye.

3) Food -- holy crap. I swear, I am not at all exaggerating when I say that my hand started cramping when I tried to cut into my ribeye. At first sight, I was impressed by the size of the steak they brought over, but on closer inspection, I noticed that there was a huge circumference of fat all around the thing. And to top it off, my "rare" order of ribeye was so tough, I could barely pierce it with my fork, and it was exhausting trying to cut and chew through the thing.

4) Service -- crappy much? When your menu's entrees are $36+, you shouldn't come around to the table every 5 minutes while people are still actively eating and ask if they're done or if they'd "like to box that!!" I couldn't believe how unprofessional the service was here. Not only were they trying to kick us out while I still had about a 3x4in piece of the ribeye still left (of course I didn't end up finishing it, because my jaw was in pain enough), but the waiter always had this, "Huh?" sort of look on his face anytime we asked him for his opinion on things like wine pairing and meal choices.
author: Joyce S.

description: Yeah this place does just about everything right.  Get the room in the back where the ambiance is better.  I made a few reservations for our trip to San Fran: Slanted Door, Gitane, and Farallon.  All were very good but Farallon was the most special experience.  This place really treats you right and it's hard trying to be budget minded here.  Our bill was over $400 for two of us at the end of it all.  That hurts a bit but felt well worth it during our time there.  Definitely a restaurant for a special occasion or just a really fantastic experience.
author: Brian D.

description:
Farallon knows what is up. My one complaint is the service- once we were at our table it was great, but while waiting in the bar area the hostess and bar waitresses were not very helpful or on it. We sat in the bar a good 20 minutes waiting for our table and couldn't get a drink. 

The food and wine made up for that in no time. From the fresh bread brought around by a woman with a basket to the wine selection- everything was great. My fish was cooked to perfection and NOTHING was lacking in the flavor department, which I loved. I do not like bland food.

The ambiance was cute with an under-the-sea type decor. Very fish market meets chic dining. Funky, but it worked. And, the best part is that most of the tables are located in plain view of the kitchen, which makes for a fun experience. I would definitely recommend and look forward to returning in the future.
author: Danielle H.

description:
So this is where all the suits go with their corporate credit cards... I felt like I was in a business convention center cafeteria. Mood killer.

The service was wonderful but the food was average at best. My meal was way overpriced for the quality and taste. Sweetbreads shouldn't taste like chicken mc-nuggets. The presentation was nice though. Umm, whatever.

The bathroom trash bin was overflowing with dirty hand towels to the point that I took a photo to show my wife. 

I waited eight years to finally go to Farallon, bummer. I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Alex H.

description: Nice decor. Service was slow, yet friendly. Food was just alright. I expected more for the money.
author: Tim D.

description:
Every time I come here, I feel like Sebastian from "The Little Mermaid" and ready to break out in the "Under the Sea" song.  My mouth is delighted and ready to party when I see and taste their ever-changing menu.  The chef's are very creative and are able to exploit the full flavor of the different types of seafood.  For non-seafood fans, they also serve land animal food as well.  Beyond a great menu, they also have a very good wine list with a superior white wine section - which is a perfect match for nearly any fish dish.  The decor is also pretty neat as well.  From the moment you walk in, you'll notice the jelly fish lighting hanging from the ceiling, iridescent colors, and comfortable, natural wood tones.  

The reason why I'm knocking this one star is because for the same price, I do like the food at Aqua much better.  The decor is much funner at Farallon, but the food at Aqua is superior (which is not a testament to bad food at Farallon, its just that Aqua has some amazing chefs).  Nevertheless, check this place out.  For sure, if there was ever an underwater civilization, and a Merman was going to take out his Mermaid, Farallon would probably be an exact replica of that spot.
author: Herman N.

description:
Seafood Lovers, plan a date with Farallon!

The decor definitely fits the underlying theme, Seafood, Seafood, and more Seafood!  The dining rooms are very intimate and set a romantic mood.  This will remain one of my favorite fine dining establishments for years to come.

The food here is outstanding.  Not once have I had my fish cooked wrong; White fish are perfectly prepared and not overdone, the salmon is perfectly cooked rare or medium when requested and the selection from the oyster bar is just superb.

The wait staff is friendly and attentive, wine list is HUGE.

This is a great venue for a date or special occasion.
author: Curt L.

description:
If nothing else, the ambiance of this place gives it 5 stars in my book. After a tedious week, nothing makes me better than treating myself to a couple martini's, some great food, company, and atmosphere. 

Whenever I go to Farallon I like to make it a relaxing event. I find the interior soothing and comforting, even on the dreariest of San Francisco eve's. Once seated, I always go for a Tanqueray Martini, up with olives -- goes perfect with a selection of their always fresh and tasty oysters. 

I usually go here with 3 or 4 people, so we'll generally share a dozen oysters, and one or two other appetizers. This accompanied with a solo entree leaves just enough room for dessert :-). 

One of my favorite dishes which I've had at Farallon is their Halibut over Crab Hash... (droooooooooool). SO GOOD. They have an extensive wine list to accompany any item on their menu and then some. 

Sure sure, let's be realistic. It IS expensive, but I think it's worth it. From the exemplary service when you step in the door, to the moment you step out and they help you get into your coat/jacket (if you can still fit in it after eating!) Farallon is truly an experience to be enjoyed by all. 

Definitely will need to go here one last time before LA!
author: C. M.

description:
Amazing steak here. I really love this place for a special occasion. The decor is really cool and detailed. I thought the ambiance of the restaurant really added to the experience. Everyone I went with loved the food.

I reccomend the butter lettuce salad. It has an amazing dressing.
author: Nina Q.

description: We enjoyed a nice dinner here several years ago.  I remember the restaurant was dim, and it had these amazing jellyfish light fixtures.  We sat in the back near the kitchen and were able to watch the chefs prepare the food.  Farallon specializes in seafood, so of course my hubby and I had seafood entrees and followed by dessert of course.  The food was very good.  We'll probably go back again soon, so we can experience the food again and our daughter can see the cool jellyfish light fixtures.
author: Racquel E.

description: Five stars for the decor (I don't know any better anywhere). Four stars for the service which is friendly but sometimes a bit slow. Three for the valet parking at $12. Two for the food, which should be the main act, but is disappointing. Perhaps if we'd stuck with the simple seafood platter it would have been fine. But we decided to try some of the other items off the menu, which required some real cooking, and we were very disappointed.
author: Victoria B.

description:
The decor is really fun if a bit over the top.  We went for New Years Eve and did the tasting menu.  They allowed my fiance (a pescetarian) to switch out the meat portion of the meal with another option.  The chef also prepared some caviar for us (neither of us had ever tried it before).

I don't remember too much about the food except that they did a fantastic job searing a piece of fish for me.  The skin was crispy but the fish still flaky and moist.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Ugh. I took my husband here for his birthday, as we are both big seafood fans. I should have known better. The food is average. The decor is slightly tacky. It's a "Union Square" restaurant that should be left to the tourists. Way better food in the city for the price.

The highlight of the night was when the husband leaned over the table and said "You've made better meals that this." 

An extra star for the service, which really was wonderful. And the wine.
author: Erin H.

description: Sorry but I wasn't impressed.  I thought the decor was totally  overdone and obnoxious plus our server that night was flippant, condescending and not very attentive.   I wanted to smack him.  The food wasn't even close to good enough for me to forgive that kind of thing... so I won't be back.
author: Shanna K.

description:
The last time i went out for a "fancy" dinner, i was blown away. In trying to be more sophisticated and also sort of celebrating a new job, I decided to go try out Farallon. I heard good things, and also I had a gift certificate that I embarrassingly never gave to my friend for her wedding present (TWO years ago! - note to reader, don't invite me to your wedding). anyway, I thought it would be good to try it out and get rid of this gift certificate that's just been sitting around.

It's not that farallon is bad, in fact, it would be pretty good... had we paid about one-third of what the total tab came out to. The appetizers were just so-so. I tried the seared scallops with a mango sauce. the scallops were decent, but the mango sauce just didn't belong. Also, we tried the foie gras on a grilled pineapple. Again, the foie gras was okay - i've had better - but the pineapple was completely out of place. For whatever reason, they were really feelin' the tropical fruit, but unfortunately they were the reasons I didn't enjoy the appetizers... the $20!! appetizers.

My lady-friend ordered the pike, and I ordered the barramundi. the pike was meh, served with a crab fondue which sort of went well with it. The barramundi, which I'd never had before, was veritably delicious. It was served on top of corn ravioli which were just okay, but I liked the idea. Both entrees were peculiarly devoid of tropical fruit.

We also gave in and tried their mixed berry bread pudding. Also, just okay - a bit too syrupy.

In the end, the service was good, though it had a bit of a cult-like feel. sometimes it's just a bit uncomfortable when people check in with you every 5 minutes... however, never ONCE asking how the food was (did they KNOW something?). I was not a fan of the decor nor the crowd, but I sort of knew about both going in, so I can't really fault them for that. In the end, it was an okay meal, but it was just not even CLOSE to being worth what I paid for. Sadly, I'm gonna tell you pass on Farallon if you were thinking about it. They do, however, carry a really nice wine called "Conundrum", but I think I'm just gonna look for it at BevMo.

I'm actually giving farallon a 3-minus - maybe like a 2.873.
author: Bernie L.

description:
Went here with a date and was seated promptly by the professional staff.  
Parking can be tricky so leaving the car with the valet is suggested. We had a bottle of Riesling, foie gras appetizer, grilled snapper, halibut fillet and mixed fruit for desert. We were given 2 amuse-bouches, one after the appetizer and the second before the dessert compliments of the chef. Niice! Great food and friendly staff.
author: Jeemster C.

description: Wow just a fantastic meal tonight.  Except for the oysters, which were average at best, everything was as good as it gets.   The charcuterie appetizer was fabulous as was the tuna sashimi with hearts of palm.  But the best were the cod entre and the crab salad - not to be missed.    Excellent cocktails also.   Head man Mark Franz is continuing the tradition of excellence he created with Jeremiah Tower at Stars.   Just great...
author: Mark S.

description: I am a big fan of seafood & Farallon blew my socks off with its great food & amazing service!  I had a dish with Branzino & the person I went with had Tuna & we both were very satisfied.  The waitress was very attentive & helpful.  They were accommodating to my food allergy, though they tried to bring us bread even when we asked them not to.  The ambiance is great & very relevant for a seafood restaurant.  I highly recommend dining at Farallon if you enjoy good seafood!
author: Mary L.

description: Impecable experience! The food, the atmosphere, the staff = fantastic!!
author: J. R.

description:
Incredible all around: 
Food, decor, service, crowd, value. 

Can't say anything bad about this place. 

Been here almost a half dozen times and have had everything from the filet, salmon, ono, and halibut. No matter your choice, you cannot go wrong. 

The seasonal desert of the apple pie may easily be my favorite of all time. Simply delicious. 

BEST SEAFOOD PLACE IN SAN FRANCISCO. FIVE STARS. FAST.
author: Cam K.

description: We went for a special dinner with the family while visiting San Francisco.  Everything was perfect from the beginning.  The waiter came to explain the menu and made some wine recommendations.  He was great.  We went with his recommendation and ordered a white Burgundy that went perfectly with our seafood.  We started the evening with the Royal Platter.  It was wonderful and fresh.  We all ordered different seafood entries.  We couldn't have been more satisfied.  The evening finished with several desserts that we shared and a dessert wine that paired very well together, all recommending by the waiter.  It was a wonderful experience from start to finish.  I would recommend this restaurant highly.
author: Piero S.

description:
My husband and I ate dinner here one Saturday night a few weeks ago when we spent the weekend in the City. 

We couldn't make up our minds about where we wanted to eat dinner and at the last minute made a reservation on opentable.com and came in to eat dinner about 15 minutes later. 

We walked in and could tell that this is a upscale restaurant, the lighting set the tone for a romantic dinner and the decor was reminiscent of various items you would find in the sea. I must really say that decor matched the name of the restaurant. 

We were a few minutes early and sat at the bar because there is absolutely no room to wait so don't get there during happy hour. 

My husband ordered a drink while we were at the bar but the hostess came to seat us before the drink was made and of course it was delivered to our table within seconds. 

After being seated we were immediately given bread and a glass of water. 

Our waitress promptly came over and introduced herself. I don't remember her name but she was very knowledgeable about all things on the menu (or not). 

I ordered the lobster salad ($22) which was small but wonderful and perfect for me. My husband ordered the grand platter ($65) which had a variety of chilled seafood (shrimp, lobster, crab, oysters and I think mussels and/or clams). 

Before our meal we were served a complimentary one bite of tuna tar tare which we were told would waken the pallet. It was delicious and got us off to a good start. 

We were served dinner less than 5 minutes after our one bite. my salad was great and my husband thought his food was great until.... 
He offered me a shrimp and I gladly accepted and broke the news to him that the shrimp was on the verge of being bad because the texture was a little on the soft side. He looked disappointed and tasted the shrimp and agreed they were very fresh but he did really enjoy the other items. 

At the end of our meal we were given a complimentary mini dessert. I am not sure of what it was called but it was sort of like a parfait with layers of chocolate, peanut butter, cream and a hint of coffee. It was surprisingly very good. Even the hubby enjoyed it and doesn't really like sweets (except for me). 

Our experience at this restaurant was positive even though the shrimp was not the freshest. The servers were very attentive without being intrusive. We would be willing to give this place another try some time in the future. 

P'S. Hubby said the Hennessey side car he ordered was good too.
author: Nikki W.

description: My husband and I came here a few nights ago after reading many great reviews. We arrived a minute or two early for our reservation and were curtly told to "make ourselves comfortable" as they were "making their way down the list." After seeing no one else seated other than a walk in, and witnessing other reservations offered a seat at the bar, we were finally seated in a section with many other available tables. Our waiter was rarely present - we waited 15 minutes for water to appear, he did not check in on our courses, he handed us the dessert menu without a word and did not reappear for another 15 minutes. His and the other table staff's interactions were dismissive, seemed judgmental, and bordered on rude. While the food was prepared well, the service certainly left much to be desired. We felt ignored enough to wonder if we needed to be carrying keys to a Lamborghini in order to get served. I would not go back.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Looks fantastic.  You walk in and the staff is overwhelmingly friendly.  Almost cultishly nice.  They promptly found our reso and led us swiftly to a comfortable, cozy little table. Oh this seems like it's gonna rock.

The waiter approached, mentioned some things we brought up in our reso and he set about hooking us up with drinks and apps.  While waiting a member of the staff dropped off some bread.  Fresh? Hmmm. Unlike some other places the bread wasn't piping hot, or even warm.  Adequate but not mindblowing.

Our app arrived and again, this worked. It was a simple shrimp parfait with a nice cocktail sauce and a crunchy relish.  Good stuff when mixed with the generous chunks of avocado. It was all going so great...

And then our entrees arrived.  Flat. Just nothing to them. Adimittedly, I've got a pretty adventurous palate but sea bass and halibut both seemed to be concocted with nothing approaching the zest and verve promised in the menu.

The place looks nice and the staff is so wonderfully nice but in the end we left wondering why we'd drop this kind of money on something so banal.
author: Karl F.

description:
Actually, let's give this a 3.5 star review.

This has been a San Francisco institution since its inception in 1997.  In fact, when I first came to this city in 1999, people around me spoke of Farallon with grave seriousness and reverent tones.  I was an innocent chap in those care-free times with nary a penny in my pocket.  I remember saying to myself, "when I make it big in this town, I'm goin' to Farallon!!"  

Silly me...

Nowadays, I am fortunate enough to enjoy some of the comforts that life has to offer and I've become a jaded and cynical food snob.  I am an embarassment to all that San Francisco represents:

- I can be accurately labeled as a "Yuppie" (although I believe this term has fallen out of favor).
- I drive an SUV.
- I point my pinkie out when I hold my coffee cup.

In short, every fiber of my being should love Farallon.

But I don't.

Perhaps it's the jellyfish light fixtures that creep me out.
Maybe it's the stifling undersea theme.
How about the lackluster and overpriced dinner menu which averages nearly forty bucks per entree?  Yeah, that's it...

Whatever the case, my experiences at Farallon have triggered an acute case of self-introspection.  Why am I here?  What is the meaning of life?  Where can I get a decent goddamned burrito in this town?

From now on, I promise to be a man of the people... as long as those people don't scratch the paint on my car.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: I have dined here a few times and enjoyed it more when it first opened years ago.  Now, the food seems to be less appealing both in taste and portion size, given the price.  The space is still attractive but since the substance has declined, I feel less and less inclined to patronize this spot.
author: V B.

description:
I very much appreciate good food and unfortunately Farallon is nothing special. I did a lot of research as I wanted to pick a great place for my boyfriend's birthday. The decor is fun & we got a nice booth.

We ordered the 1/2 lb lobster for an app, really it was only 2 good bites. I ordered the Ono and he the lemon fish.  Both were average, not bad, but nothing special. For dessert we had the Sunday Brunch Apple Spice Sunday and Bittersweet Chocolate Malt, again nothing special. The waiter also forgot my boyfriend's b-day even though I was very clear about it on the reservation. For a pricy SF restaurant, they could do way,way better. If you're a foodie, definitely not your place. While I would never pay for a meal again here, I would go to the bar. Their happy hour bar bites are fun and tasty.
author: Liz M.

description:
On Tuesday, December 23, 2008, my 22 year old daughter and I went to Farallon for her first real dinner in San Francisco, she is a southern girl and came to visit for Christmas.  I had let the staff know ahead of time that this would be her first visit and they certainly made it a remarkable evening for both of us.

Due to the holiday traffic we left early and arrived about 45 minutes before our reservation and found the bar area packed, we waited a few minutes and gained two seats at the bar.   We soon began talking to the bar manager Craig and found that he was very knowledgeable of the liquor and recommended the Octopus Confit as and appetizer as we sipped on our drinks.  I can not remember when I last enjoyed an appetizer so much, it was tender, tasteful and just a delight to the palate. 

We were soon called for dinner and had a table overlooking most of the dinning area, Our server soon appeared, discussed possibilities and removed himself quietly as we perused the menu.  I selected the sturgeon and she selected the seabass, both were presented well and extremely well prepared.  We shared the the chocolate dessert and enjoyed coffee at the end of the meal.

I should mention that my daughter is a bartender in a high end restaurant and is super critical of service, food preparation and ambiance.  She agreed with me that all were superb, she got an extra kick out of the jelly fish chandeliers.

I would highly recommend dinning at Farallon.
author: Kenneth G.

description:
For this bi-weekly "restaurant hopping", my husband's choice was Farallon! (To refresh your memory, my husband and I, and a friend of ours try out one restaurant every two weeks.  The rule - it should be a restaurant that the three of us haven't dined at before).  
The moment we entered Farallon, I felt as if I was inside a cruise ship.  The décor will give you this "under the sea" feeling.   You may also feel a little claustrophobic with the restaurant not having any windows in the dining area.  Thank goodness the food made it all worth it.

Our dinner started off with the chef's compliment - cauliflower soup with caviar.  I'm with two people who are not too fond of veggies but they liked this one.  We ordered 3 appetizers - Octopus Carpaccio, Soft Shell Crab, and Assortment of Oysters.  The octopus carpaccio was just okay.  It has this jelly-like taste and unfortunately the flavor didn't sift in.  If it wasn't for the sunflower seeds, I would've given this 1 star rating.  Loved the oysters - fresh and flavorful.  The soft shell crab was the best - crispy, well-balanced flavor.

Now the main dishes... FRESH! FRESH! FRESH!

I had the English Channel Turbot Pillow Foie Gras - this dish was very filling!  Fish was fresh, and the foie gras sauce gave it a lot of flavor, just yummy! If there's one downside with this dish it was the carrots.  I think it would've been better without it.

My hubby had the Halibut with Pancetta - another nice dish.  The danger with ordering a halibut dish is it could turn out dry and bland.  This dish was not dry at all.  The fish was fresh and the pancetta just balanced the flavor.

Our friend had the Pike with Gnocchi - he gave this dish a 4 star rating.  He liked the crispiness of the fish and the gnocchi was superb!

As for desserts - well first, to clean our palate, they gave us this Meyer Lemon Lavender - it was a nice touch.  We ordered the pound cake - awesome! , cheese plate - just okay, and the small landings - nothing special here.

The service was great!  Our server was very friendly, knowledgeable, helpful, and just really took the time to explain the menu.  Of course, we left her a pretty hefty tip! 

Overall, this restaurant was a good pick!  I only have two minor complaints - bread was not warm and I wish the chefs in the kitchen (we were seated facing them) wore caps/hairnets.  I hate to see hair strands in my food!  

But hey, Method hand soap in the bathroom - not bad at all!
author: Elaine C.

description: füN pLaCe . .. gr8 service . .. mM .
author: Y I L I W.

description:
I had read the reviews for Farallon and all agreed the food was great, but pricey and petite.
The decor is a bit on the whimsical side but not over the top (as some reviewers claimed) and adds a little fun to the ambience with a nod to underwater life.
Service was wonderful, knowledgeable and friendly. Our waiter explained that the 1st and 2nd courses were portioned like a tasting menu and third courses, like small entrees. This was accurate.
We started with the chilled Dungeness crab legs, w/ lemon aioli, drawn butter and cocktail sauce.  Delicious, six small legs, like a tasting course.
My husband had a salad - good. I chose the American paddlefish caviar on buckwheat blinis, with a dab of creme fraiche and chives sitting on a pool of melted butter... divine, though a tad less melted butter would not overwhelm the other more delicate flavors of the dish....but it seems petty to complain as it was heavenly. 
DH had the seared scallop (large scallop) on a generous bed of truffled polenta, kale and crisp pancetta - I am not a scallop fan, but he was thrilled with it.
Third course for him - Hawaiian Tombo tuna with trumpet mushrooms, baby book Choy in a red miso broth. Also wonderful, and more "entree" sized.
My third course: seared sole with truffled sweet potato raviolis, sautéed crispy baby artichokes and brown butter. Truly lovely and more than enough for me. 
All in all, a wonderful experience. Check came in at just under $200 (without tip) for three cocktails, crab app, salad, caviar and blini app, scallop, and the two entrees. 
We would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Marcia G.

description: One of my favorite places to go for appetizers and a glass of wine. It is lovely and the staff are very knowledgeable and helpful. They have a great selection of oysters as well as other seafood choices.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Farallon done right by me y'all!  I had some time before a downtown meeting last night and I grooved on into Farallon cause I love me some seafood and had heard that despite the bizarro Disneyland decorations, the food here is quite good.  I plopped myself down at the bar with the Wall Street Journal as my date and perused the menu.  

I must admit, that at first I was like, holy shit balls this stuff is expensive, but then once my eyes became acustomed to the large numbers it all seemed much more reasonable (assisted my rather scrummy viognier).  Anywho, I got the Lobster "Roll" which isn't really a roll but rather a pile of succulent goodness on top of some fantastic brioche with a little pitcher of butter.  I poured that crap onto of the "Roll" and went directly to heaven.  Do not pass go, seriously, catapulted straight outta the cannon into heaven.  This is the best starter I've had in at least a year....

I then progressed to a lovely sea bass on a bed of sweet corn ravioli and was again impressed.  This time I remained on my seat, but it was still phenominal.  

The staff was wonderful and accomodating, stopping to chat so I wouldn't have to resort to the painfully boring MarketPlace selection of Wednesday's WSJ.  They also managed to smile and seem pleased to serve the horde of overweight tourists who arrived just as I left, screaming about cab fares and hills.  They all sweated over to the bar seats and managed to pull themselves into upright positions while fanning with napkins, apparently the walk from the St. Francis is really aggressive, or so I was told. 

Gotta give this place a super shout out for making me feel so welcome on a lonely Wednesday night after work, and rocking my tastebuds' world. I am still thinking about that damn Lobster Roll...unnghghghghhgh.
author: Claire C.

description: Ate here for New Year's Eve dinner with my fiance and was extremely disappointed. We had booked this restaurant due to it's good reviews, but sadly to say, it was a waste of time. We arrived on time for our reservations, were seated, and ordered our selections. After an hour and 15 mins. we had finally received our first course- a salad and oysters. After another 30 mins. of waiting, we grabbed our server's attention to ask why so long? He apologized immediately and also talked to the manager. Our second and third courses eventually came out of the kitchen. In all, the dinner took a total of 2 hours and 15 mins for three courses. To top it off, we just heard a whole bunch of apologies and no action done by management.
author: Xtine B.

description:
My boyfriend's birthday was on Saturday so we made our annual pilgrimage to Farallon, as we have for his last three birthdays.  But, why?  Because Farallon meets all of our requirements for an exceptional dining experience: wine pairings we have never tried, ingredients you can't buy in stores, exotic preparations we have never seen or read about, and a great staff of people (we have had the same two Sommeliers for the last three years and Luke our waiter on Saturday was VERY knowledgeable about both the menu and the winehe had tried most of them, so he deserves a special thanks for making the meal memorable).

I would save your pennies and go to Farallon if you are prepared to go all out so that you can do a nice selection of wine parings.  I recommend doing a glass of Champagne with the raw bar and two half bottles, one white, one red.  The list has a wonderful selection of half bottles, and because a lot of the appetizers are fairly delicate but the entrees can stand on their own, you can pair the appetizers with a nice white and the entrees with a good Pinot without over powering any of the dishes.  PS, I like chardonnay just as much as the next guy, but they really over power a lot of the dishes so ask the sommelier for an alternative, such as a Grner Veltliner (the latest craze to come out of Austria--and you heard it first on Yelp.com ;). 

Other recommendations if you plan on going this season include: the tasting of marinated fish (some of the best credo ever, especially the one with the quail egg mixed with caviar), the lobster salad (it comes with a vat of butter, you pour over the lobster and brioche awesome with Champagne), and the Roasted Hawaiian deep water "Lehi" snapper with ros Champagne poached manilla clams, buttered leeks, potatoes, chervil.
author: Rosie F.

description:
Let me first start off by saying this is a beautiful restaurant. The service is also amazing. When you walk in you feel like it's a little "enchantment under the sea" with fake jellyfish hanging from the ceiling and other amazing decor.

Now for the bad news, the food is....well.....not good. My boyfriend ordered the lobster bisque (absolutely no flavor, a can of campbell's soup would outshine this by far) and the beef fillet (mediocre, not worth the price). I ordered the artichoke salad as an appetizer (please just take this off the menu, it tasted absolutely horrible, dry with no flavor....and I LOVE artichokes) and the california yellowtail for the main dish (couldn't even finish it, the flavor was just all sorts of wrong). 

The only food that actually tasted good from this place was a side order of fries that had to come from the bar area because it is not on their regular menu...they topped it with parmesan cheese that made it very tasty. So perhaps the bar food is the way to go when visiting Farallon?

Anyway, if you don't want to be out almost $200 for a lack luster meal for two, don't waste your time. BUT, for the atmosphere, perhaps a stop at the bar and an order of their parmesan fries (I can't remember exactly what they called them) with a cocktail might be worth it. Other than that, don't order from the main menu.... your wallet and taste buds will not be happy with you.
author: Natalia H.

description: We ate in their private wine room on the 4th floor. It was very nice. The food was excellent. The halibut was excellent, served on a creamed corn ravioli which gave it a hint of sweet. The citrus bread pudding was ok. Great texture but I prefer sweet bread pudding. The lamb was also very nicely done.
author: Sven G.

description: We had a great experience: after a disappointing start with trouble getting the attention of the waiter, Farallon recovered magnificently and provided a superb experience. The food was wonderful, but the sommelier did an event better job. We generally drink Pinot Noir and were considering either a Pinot Noir or a white burgundy, but Luke Kenning, the Wine Director, convinced us to have an Austrian reisling (Nikolaihof Wachau). It was splendid. We had a wonderful dinner, leaving after 3 hours.  I strongly recommend Farallon
author: Mark R.

description: good drinks, great staff, good food, great ambiance and i cant forget the funky cool jelly-fish chandaliers! two thumbs up for farallon!
author: Shari S.

description:
I have to agree that this place is all hype.  The decor is awesome but the food and service only so-so.  We went for dinner here the day before New Years Eve.  We ordered the Bass, Sole, Duck and Trout.  The Bass was too heavily salted and oiled up.  My boyfriend ordered the Sole which did not arrive with the rest of the entrees.  Our server was not honest with us what had happened to the fish and just said there was an accident in the kitchen.  We later asked who I believe was the manager of the restaurant what kind of "accident" it was and he said that when they drop food on the floor they don't put it back on someones plate...mmm! I guess after knowing that his Sole did not seem as appetizing.  
The dessert was probably the best dish...all of us shared the Small Endings (handmade confections).  I don't think I'll be going back here anytime soon.
author: Jaki B.

description:
Foodie recommendations are usually quite good and this one was spot on and worth the visit.

First, the decor. Simply put, really interesting bordering on wacky. Our party of three was seated on the balcony and we had a fantastic view of the entire place. The low ceiling height coupled with soft fabrics and moody lighting made the whole dining experience "cozy" -- in our case, perfect for serious conversation. The wacky part were things like the jellyfish light fixtures and the cast metal railings. Cool, but different.

Service was fantastic. Our server paired a perfect pinot noir with our heirloom tomato salad that later worked well with all entrees. She was very attentive and quite helpful, answering any and all questions we had. 

In terms of the food, it was great. The tomato salad was spectacular. I had an entree of rabbit prepared two ways -- sausage and wrapped in bacon. Both were quite good, but not as striking as the salad. Dessert was, well, pretty darn good given the choices. I'm not a big fan of making odd concoctions of traditional desserts with grapes and berries, so for me the menu really reduced down to one option -- a chocolate dessert with honeycomb. Simply awesome.

So, would I go back? Absolutely. Farallon was a great recommendation, great experience, and a great find.
author: Chad K.

description: Had a wonderful dining experience here. This is mainly a seafood restaurant. I am not a seafood fan but, was able to find excellent alternatives. My husband of course loved the seafood. By the way, I did try his food and I must say it is the first time that I have tried octopus and it was not chewy. The place was beautiful and very romantic. Our server, Curtis, was the best server I have ever had. He recommended the most delightful girly martini, catered to our every need and even managed to make an annoying arguing couple next to us happy. The food was delightful. I especially loved my salad and steak. Oh, and the chocolate dessert was so decadent. Next time I am in San Francisco I will be going to Farallon again and requesting Curtis.
author: Ellie S.

description:
I love it when restaurants offer a different menu everyday. You know the food's really fresh.

Service here was top notch. 

Food was excellent, unique, and ofcourse pricey. But hey....it's good food!

Will dine here again.

One of the BEST seafood restaurants in SF.  And certainly one of the most unique spaces.  Ask to be seated in the back, in the cozy and colorful sea-like dining room.  

The menu changes nightly, but you can always enjoy fresh seafood from the raw bar (including generously sized lobster tails).

The service is impeccable.  I tried to time how long it would take to replenish my wine.  Before I finished my sentence, the waiter was filling my glass.  An enthusiastic five stars!
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
I can't comment on the food, but the bar is tremendous.

We stopped by to check out the decor and sat down for a quick drink at the bar.  We had a great experience with the very friendly and helpful bartender and learned a great deal about some different drinks.

I look forward to going back to enjoy a full experience of the restaurant.
author: Brendon F.

description: I can't say our experience was bad but it wasn't that great for what you pay. We had travel zoo vouchers and even with that we paid over 240 out of pockets. Drinks are expensive and small food portions are small the soft shell crap was hard to eat. The shell was not tasty.  The sole was done nicely with a great sauce. The halibut came with lentils that were tasteless.  The blueberry pie was very good. Avoid the chocolate bites.   Our waiter was totally lacking of personality. I guess when you add the tip automatically no need to be friendly.
author: Sarita d.

description: I've been to Farallon twice now, both for industry dinners. I just love it. Each time I have had a three course dinner and each course was just stellar. Though they are all about seafood they also have fantastic steak and duck options. I would definitely recommend it for private dining and events.
author: Jessica H.

description: Prefect for a special occasion, food is out of this world. If you're lucky enough to go when foie gras is on the menu it's a must have. They have the best foie gras anywhere hands down!!! Service is great, atmosphere is great and the food.... Only problem is, it's in downtown SF so find a parking garage or valet because finding parking is almost impossible. The food is pricey but you get what you pay for, also they serve a "real man's drink" there so be careful if you're driving because they pour a little heavy, which is fine with me.
author: Luke B.

description: PRETTY FOOD AND WAY, WAY, WAY too expensive for what you get. It appears this place is more focused on making the food look pretty as oppsed to making it taste good. Save your money and go to Blondie's.
author: D S.

description: I took my wife here for our anniversary, the decor is beautiful but I too think the restaurant is bit overrated. Small portions and expensive. I gave it a four because of it's decor and that we wanted to visit here for a longtime.
author: DJ G.

description:
Well decorated, the feeling of dining at the premier restaurant of a cruise ship while at sea. The ambiance is supurb and one would be hard-pressed to top it for an underweater themed seafood restaurant. The tiled floor, the jellyfish lamps, the paintings and murals, the clam-styled seating - all very nice and well done. This decor gives Farallon most of its stars in the ratings, the food was so-so, the cost was astronomical. 

I had the Hawaiian ono, my wife had the prix fixe- neither were all that impressive. It was good, but nothing popped or stood out from other seafood restaurants. With the price, you'd expect it to compete with the tastes of other perennial seafood places in SF and other coastal cities (Boston, Miami, Seattle), but it really didn't. I was trying to convince myslef that it was really good, but I hate lying to myself, and my wife told me to stop. The dessert was actually really good, so Farallon saved itself from complete mediocrity.

The service was very good. Coat check, reservation in tact, superb wine list with helpful advice, though I wish they hadn't advised me on an unlisted 11 oz. bottle of beer that ended up being $13 per. They were very personalble and a good wait staff though, makes SF looks good.

And really, that is what Farallon is. It is located off Union Square and attracts a lot of out-of-towners. It's decor and service helps tremendously meet the image of San Francisco others may have, and for that we are lucky to have Farallon. And just like the coffee in Paris tastes that much better to we Americans, Farollon in San Francisco may taste that much better to those travelling from, say, St. Louis. But to me, it impressed a lot of my senses, taste just wasn't one of them.
author: Dave C.

description:
A group of us went here after seeing "Ratatouille."  We wanted to have  anice fancy dinner after the movie, and this place was chosen.

While we waited for our table, was sat in the lounge area and had cocktails.  I had the specialty house Manhattan, which was pretty good.  After a short wait our table was ready.  As we walked through the restaurant, I noticed there was an ocean motif in the decor.

We started off with some selections from the oyster bar, which were very good ... very fresh.  We had 6 different varieties of oysters.

Next, we all had an appetizer, and sampled off each others' plates.  The grilled scallop and the foie gras with grilled pineapple were good, but the seafood pyramid was only mediocre.

For entrees, we all got something different.  I had the ono, which was a bit lackluster.  Actually, I found all the entrees to be a little ... lacking.  Food was beautifully presented, the service was impeccable, the wine list was decent, but the food just did not move me.  For those prices, I'd like to leave feeling like I had a great meal, but Farallon failed to deliver that to me.
author: Asteridae A.

description: Found this place by accident while searching for a quick bite after attending a conference. What I found was one of the best meals I think I have ever eaten. I was unfamiliar with some of the items on the menu, but was feeling adventurous, and I'm glad I was. Every course from salad to dessert was phenonmenal. The restaurant decor is beautiful, if not a bit gaudy. The wait staff is knowledgable and fun. All in all, a great dining experience, and I WILL return.
author: Michael O.

description:
Beautiful ambience.  Average food (especially when factoring in the price).  My biggest knock on this place is the portions.  I realize that people do not go to expensive restaurants to stuff themselves, but the portion size was borderline ridiculous.  If I am going to spend $60+ for a meal, I shouldn't be looking for the nearest burger joint the moment I step out of this place.

For the 1st course, I had a mixed green salad ($10) that consisted of 1 strawberry (cut into four pieces) + about 2 ounces of mixed greens.  The vinaigrette dressing was subpar.  
For the 2nd course, I had the scallops ($15?) or should I say scallop.  Good, but nothing special.
For my main meal, I had the prawns with rice ($25-28, can't remember exactly) which consisted of 4 average sized prawns on a bed of rice that was roughly equivalent to the size of a small ice cream scoop.

If the strawberry, the scallop, the prawns were the best I ever tasted, then maybe, but they weren't.  They were merely decent, not noticeably better than chain restaurants I have eaten at. 
For people like me: you go here ONCE for the ambience or on that special occasion with the wife.
author: Chris K.

description:
Most gorgeous restaurant in SF.

For a truly elegant meal, you must try Farallon. Excellent food, service and an all-around beautiful dining experience.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Find Nemo in Extravagant Seafood Dining off Union Square


Farallon, just off Union Square, is as known for its exquisite seafood as well as its over-the-top oceanic dcor.  Mark Franz, who opened the once-famous restaurant Stars with Jeremiah Tower, is the Executive chef.  Mr. Franz opened the restaurant with restaurateur Pat Kuleto, who created the outrageous "Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea" dcor, with  hand-blown jellyfish lamps, kelp bedlike backlit columns, glass clamshells, sea-urchin light fixtures, a sea-life mosaic floor, and a tentacle-encircled Jellyfish Bar.

I started off with a "Original Mai-Tai" on a velour couch in the bar area.  It was an odd rum martini that lacked sufficient sweetener, but the whimsical dcor and friendly service made up for the disappointment.  We were seated upstairs in a comfortable intimate booth.  Service was both friendly and hyper-knowledgeable (responding at length with a blow-by-blow of how crab are caught and hauled in after a concern about the oil spill).  

We ordered the Fruits De Mer Royal Platter as both an appetizer and main entre for two.  This iced  tower consisted of one whole lobster, one crab, two kinds of ceviche (citrusy ono and a sesame salmon), raw scallops, clams and oysters, several crawfish and jumbo shrimp.  It was a delight.  It came with cocktail sauce and a delicate champagne mignonette.  However, I had to request drawn butter.

Next we tried the seared Maine diver scallops, which were plump and fresh.  They came with seared bacon braised Swiss chard and short rib tortellini.  Farallon also offers meat and game items, such as pheasant, lamb and steak.  Our dinner was thoughtfully paired with an Oregon Argyle "Nuthouse" Chardonnay.   The wine list was its own book, offering more than 400 by the bottle and 30 by the glass.  There was also a whole book of cocktails.  

For dessert we could not resist trying the Cocoa Nib Beignets, which are Southern fried donut holes sprinkled with sugar.  These came filled with melted bittersweet chocolate, and two sauces: vanilla bean and cocoa nib anglaise.  We also tried the gourmet cheese plate, which was fabulous.

The high price tag make it a good place for special occasions or a cocktail-and-appetizer or lunch stop.
author: Jen H.

description:
It's a dining experience that you must have if you're in SF.  The decor was second to none.  Their chandaliersare crazy - I wouldn't even know where togo to buy one.  Their flower arrangements are huge.  There's definately a wow factor when you enter and are seated.

The food was very good as was the service.   Found the menu as creative as the decor.  I like it when a chef takes risks.  when you come toa place like this you're hoping they aren't playing it safe in the kitchen.  Some plates were fantastastic others were good.  None were bad.

The last wow factor was the bill.  But I suppose someone has to pay for the decor.

Great location.
Great bar.
Original food.
Good service.
author: El Guapo G.

description:
I think the environment and decor is warm, creative and fit for any occasion. The food was mixed. We had sardine, shrimp and scallops quenelle, lobster lamb crepe as starters. The crepe had a wonderful texture; it was light as air and tasty. The sardine and the quenelle were both disappointing imo.

The entrees were both awesome: branzino (brazillian bass) and trout with green curry. The bass is crispy and tops some delicious grilled vegetables. The trout was tender and the curry was surprising, since the only curried fish I've had are really salty and spicy ones in Indian restaurants. I thought it was good.

We didn't have any shellfish or lobsters this time, but I would say the fish dishes warrant 4 stars at least. This place didn't blow me away, but I enjoyed the meal.
author: Tracy W.

description:
Normally I tend not to review the over-reviewed.  Yes, Farallon is tasty, the service is above average, and the fact that the dining room is located over a private swimming pool is at least thought-provoking (I'll bet not everyone knows that one - ask your server about it next time you're there).  

But each time I go back to San Francisco, I am reminded of the time I was sitting at the bar, waiting for my colleagues to arrive, and the woman next to me ordered a virgin Cosmopolitan.  I almost choked on my glass of champagne, but the bartender, being a true professional, didn't crack a smile.  He ended up talking her into a virgin margarita instead, which I'm sure was delicious, as he took the time to make it with fresh citrus juices.  

I saw that same bartender the next evening, working at another neighborhood bar, and I couldn't resist ordering a virgin martini for myself and a virgin Manhattan for my companion.  He came over to our table and told me that no one that he worked with believed his story, and our (real) drinks were on the house.  

I try and revisit Farallon whenever I'm back in San Francisco, if only for the next hilarious story!
author: K J.

description:
I went to farallon recently, with a gift certificate that my husband won, after not having been there for at least 6 years.  I had very good memories of my meals here, so I was pretty disappointed...  While I'm sure the ingredients are of the best quality (the beausoleil and kumamoto oysters we had were the best I've ever eaten), and our waiter was very helpful and gracious, the lobster bisque was kind of soul less, as was my main dish.  I ordered the branzino because I'd recently had it at kokkari and decided it was my favorite fish ever, and this one had none of the butteriness and complexity of flavors of the one I'd had before. If I could do it over again, I would probably just get one of the crazy seafood plateaus they have. We saw one pass by and it looked amazing, and as I said, the oysters were pretty good.

We also ordered a $150 bottle of burgundy, just because we could (it wasn't our money), and I have to say, it was totally meh.  I've had better 30 dollar bottles of california pinot.  I don't know if that has something to say about french vs california wine (I've had some pretty amazing french wines) or about the wines they pick at farallon, or about me not knowing what the hell I'm talking about (very possible), but there you have it.
author: cecilia g.

description:
I visited Farallon almost two years ago.  But after a recent trip to "#1" Gary Danko, I think Farallon deserves some praise.  Let's see what I remember...

My boyfriend surprised me with a birthday dinner here.  From the get go, I was floored by the beautiful decor.  The ceiling is purple colored with giant glowing jelly fish as lamps!  

We were taken upstairs, where it was extremely private.  Our waiter was amazing.  We were mere 19-year-olds in a fancy restaurant then, but he treated us with the utmost respect, as he would an older couple who knew what they were doing.  

We started with a soft shell crab that has yet to be beat.  Not overly fried, just the right amount of crunch. 

I can't remember my fish dish, but it came out on a rainbow of vegetables (literally a perfect color spectrum) that I still dream about.  My boy ordered the salmon which I remember being very good. 

We ended the warm summer evening with the perfect dessert of yogurt (creme fraiche), fresh berries and granola.  Oh!  So delicious and light.  

The bill was also much lighter than GD's, even with a hefty tip.  

Though the menus have undoubtedly changed, I hope to have another excuse to come back here soon.  Of all my fancy restaurant experiences (not that there have been many), Farallon is my most memorable.
author: Erin G.

description:
Fantastic!

The service was great and the food was excellent. Some of the best oysters I've had anywhere. The decor makes for a really unique experience. Put on your nice shoes and escape to Farallon for some fine dining!
author: Lars J.

description: I haven't eaten here in a couple years but it's one of my favorite restaurants in the world. Farallon is an upscale seafood eatery with unique decor and excellent dishes. Whenever I'm in San Francisco I make a point to eat here. The service is top notch, the food is EXCELLENT, the atmosphere is very cool. Do yourself a favor, dine at Farallon, you deserve it!
author: Karl F.

description:
Oh Farallon you are so dependable. I still remember our first encounter. It was my 17th birthday, circa 1998 and my aunt took me for a ladies' dinner. I think that was the first time I got drunk on wine too, but I digress...

I absolutely love the interior of Farallon. Gorgeous jellyfish shaped chandeliers hang from the ceiling and you really feel like you're underwater. I know that sounds cheesy, but its true! The service is great and the food (particularly the seafood, duh!) is excellent. I love the scallops, but I think the menu changes pretty frequently.
author: Jen L.

description: this is as good as it gets, the food was awesome, service  top notch and if your there for happy hour, the prices are really good, for what you get we will be back there real soon!!!
author: george k.

description:
My dish, the Hawaiian Walu tasted great, as did the Hama Hama oysters. This was not the case on the way back out... 

I received the worst case of food poisoning in my life. After passing out on my bathroom floor twice, shivering from cold yet sweating simultaneously, and barfing from both ends... I decided I wouldn't revisit Farallon...
author: sandra m.

description:
It didn't live up to the hype. It seemed like a good Cheesecake Factory for seafood. Good wine list. Sommelier was okay - he didn't seem confident. 

I'm used to small portions, but we left feeling unsatisfied. We did a prix fixe, with some additional appetizers. We didn't think the value was there, compared to other restaurants in this "supposed class".

The wait staff were a bit strange. Inexperienced, perhaps?

I would go back if I had to, but I'd rather go somewhere else.
author: El Huron I.

description:
I went to Farallon one Friday night while in San Francisco because that day I had gone to the wine country on a tour and the tour guide was shocked that the Farallon Islands were visible from the Golden Gate Bridge.  He said that in his whole 12 years of doing tours in San Francisco that was the very first time he had been able to see the islands.  Dang, all that fog must be for real!

I went to Farallon (the restaurant, not the islands) with  my husband and a friend.  The atmosphere was very interesting.  Blown glass that looked like sea creatures--it is beautiful.  The ceilings are high and the blown glass looks like it sort of floats above the tables--I will say it again, beautiful.

I thought the food was good, but not impressive- it was a little on the exotic side (think bone marrow as a dish) and my husband and our friend did not appreciate that at all.  The fish dishes and the steaks are great, but go with an open mind--this is not your typical seafood and steak place.

We went on a busy night, but the service was still very good.  The prices are high, but hey like I always say--you get what you pay for.
author: Jen M.

description:
Farallon is overpriced, and hence disappointing.  Much better food can be found at Aqua for the same price.

The decor is interesting and fun, and I think most ladies would enjoy the setting.  I think it was a bath house before, so that's peculiar.

The wait staff was friendly, but relatively inexperienced compared to similar priced restaurants such as La Folie, Aqua, and Gary Danko's.  Instead of an experienced waiter who has memorized the menu, you will probably get someone in their 20's who's only been working there for under a year.  Just a subtle difference.

Everything has a price.  At $125/person, Farallon is a disappointment.  Prices need to be half that to match it's overall appeal.  Go to Aqua instead.
author: Jacob J.

description:
WoW, was the first thing that came to my mind when I stepped in this restaurant. I liked the unique underwater theme. Service was good and friendly.
Dont know what it was exactly called, but had one sea prawn that laid on a bed of mixed greens as a starter. It was so sweet and yummy, but  only one? oke two if you considered that they cut it in half. I mean i expect skimp food from these fancy restaurants, but dang. For my main courseI had the filet mignon, and was it delicious..it just absolutely melted in your mouth. My wife and I wanted to get this seafood tray, where it came with crab, lobster, oyster and mussel on a giant tray with ice. Being that it was our first time there, didnt' want to feel all arkward there. Maybe i'll try the next time i go.
author: Charlie N.

description: Food and embiance was good...service and portion size was poor
author: Sal P.

description:
Unusual decor in the dining room.  OK if you want to impress an out-ot-town tourist who has never eaten in a decent restaurant in a big city.

Food: quality is very inconsistent.  Can range from 1 star to 4 stars.  For the price they charge, one would expect much more consistency.

Service at tableside: professional and courteous

I strongly suspect there is some racial discrmination in the seating by the hostess.  I ususally get pretty decent tables.  But when I go there with Afro-American friends, we would always get the worst tables, even when the rest of the restaurant is almost empty.
author: Eric T.

description:
