We ate here foe dinner on our one night in the city - big mistake! With all the great restaurants in San Fran we ended up spending way too much money for bad food and horrible service.

Our oysters to start were ok but our salmon and cod entrees were dry and crusty on the edges. Our waiter had some nasty comments because we asked if their sparkling water had sodium in it. All in all a poor choice!
author: Andrea K.

description:
I went here with my husband and my best friend for a fun evening out. The lighting is great and the atmosphere low key but classy. I loved it. But the food - really outstanding. We started with a selection of oysters which were all fresh and delicious. Then on to the main courses. I had the the trout wrapped in pancetta, and my friend ordered the scallops. I LOVED my fish, but I loved her scallops more. I didn't know scallops could be cooked that perfectly. 

The bill packs a punch but Farallon really makes for a wonderful evening out. 

The reason the restaurant isn't getting 5 stars is a rather disappointing work dinner I had there. We had one the private rooms and a menu with only two options - maybe that was the problem? But that meal was really sub par, particularly now that I know what they can do!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I've been trying to write this review for about 10 days now. I think it has taken so long since I used to love this place. Granted, it has been about six years since I was last here, but I must admit I was excited to return. My brother and his wife were visiting from New Mexico and craving seafood, so I was also excited to show them, what I thought, was one of the best of the best. 

I must first comment on the service. Impeccable. Never once were we without and never once did we feel like we were being intruded upon. Very silent service, the way it's intended to be. Although I did like the bread that was generously passed out, there was a point where enough was enough. If this was a review about the service, I would rate it a 5. 

But...

The food. I really hope the flavorless, over cooked, BORING dishes was just a one-off encounter. We were a party of four and were all VERY disappointed. The Ahi was sent back since it was delivered well done.  Hmmmm? The other three dishes were dry and boring. For $40 a dish, my taste buds should have been in absolute orgasm. Not here.  Although we were disappointed in the main meal, my brother's wife, who used to live in France, wanted to have the cheese plate for dessert, since again, she lives in the middle of nowhere New Mexico and can't get good cheese. Let's just say another big disappointment. Even the smelliest cheese on the plate was flavorless. How on earth do they do it? 

We all felt as if we had been robbed with the bill came. 

I feel that we have another San Francisco restaurant that is living on its name and could probably serve dirt and still get high ratings. Sad.

Never again.
author: Shane A.

description:
Perhaps a good place for a fancy first date if you like fancy decor and you and your date are planning to get something to eat after having dinner here.

Based on our visit for dinner,  the food is okay, but nothing really special.  Quantities are ridiculously  tiny.  The crabcakes would be better described as crab nuggets.  Service was a bit on the slow side, but not terrible.  

If you have an unlimited budget and don't mind ordering two courses of appetizers for each person --  and aren't very hungry -- this is a good choice.  

I think that some of these reviews had to have been written by Farallon management.   No way would I give this place even four stars.
author: Secret A.

description: Lovely physical plant, good waiter Brian, sommelier Luke suggested an interesting white wine to open the tasting menu.  But the food just wasn't there.  The salmon was fine, but no better than dozens of other restaurants.  None of the food took my breath away.  My partner's sole was very good.  If it were a little less pricey, I would rate it 4 stars.  We spent about $300.
author: steve M.

description: Had dinner at Farallon last night for the first time in a while.   Won't be going back.  From the chilly reception by the hostess through the end of the meal, there is nothing positive I can say.   We were seated in an area where we could observe the backlog of servers waiting for their customers' meals.   The kitchen was backed up to the point of waiting over an hour for our main course (which arrived at 10:45 pm).  The salad was uninspired - few pieces of lettuce and slices of apples which somehow managed to be warm.   After a long wait, the filet mignon arrived as two tiny slices of beef, which were undercooked.  The pasta dish with truffles was tiny, as well.   I ordered this as my main dish and would have appreciated the waiter warning me that this was not enough for a main dish.    There were ample truffles, but a tiny amount of pasta.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Super disappointed. I went here a decade ago and vowed never to return because of the ridiculous acoustics which make it a) impossible to hear conversations at your own table and b) impossible to avoid hearing everyone else's conversations. This time I went at the invitation of a family member. Waiter couldn't wait to get us to order the Royal Platter...undercooked lobster (it was disgusting and gooby), a couple of crab legs, 6 oysters, a couple of clams, 2 pieces of tuna sashimi that tasted like tuna jerky, and a couple of tablespoons of meh ceviche...all for the bargain price of $125. That plus entrees (oddly, the beef entree was the best tasting), 5 glasses of wine, 3 shared desserts and the bill was almost $600. Service was not that hot...asked twice for the waiter to remember to bring me the teaspoon of espresso they served. Waited forever between courses. Didn't refill the regular coffees either. The only decent service was from the water server. The bus boy loaded up the plates on his arms like he worked in a greasy spoon - it was awful. There are SO many better restaurants in SF - on the same street for that matter. If you're going to Farallon go at happy hour and go somewhere else for dinner.
author: Shannon H.

description:
Fruit De Mer!!!! WOW!  Generously large and sweet lobster claws, tender crab claws, four freshly shucked oysters and four large delectable (and de-veined!) prawns... $55 yes it's a lot, but this feast is worth every penny. We weren't even in need of the turbot "pillows" which were very interesting and tasty:  pounded thin turbot fillets wrapped around a little lobster and stuffed in a cabbage wrapping over finely chopped carrots and celery with a rich  foie gras sauce. The sauce was a tad salty, but foie can be sometimes, and it was an excellent complement to the mellow turbot. 

Service was outstanding. Very attentive and kind, though we were a relatively small tab (no dessert, shared entree, one drink a piece) and seated quite late at night.  "The Mariner" martini was excellent and served straight up with a freshly sliced cucumber. My date's martini was well-mixed too. 

Yes, the decor is a little like Disney's submarine ride of yore, but I appreciate the playfulness of the proprietors to play out the theme to an almost absurd extent. Bravo, Farralon!
author: Jenni D.

description:
Several years ago when I still lived in Florida, I was watching the Travel Channel and San Francisco was the topic. There was a very long feature about the Farallon, and the restaurant's spectacular decor. I watched the entire segment in amazement and a day later promptly forgot all about it. 

Five years pass, and now I'm on Yelp in search of fancy seafood restaurants for my one year anniversary, and I stumble upon the Farallon. I recognized the jellyfish lights hanging from the ceiling in a heartbeat and a flood of memories came rushing back (sitting in my mothers living room, woohoo)! 

I decided this was the place for us to go and promptly made reservations. When we arrived the place was a little empty, but we were early and were sat right away. I requested the Pool Room, which I suggest you do as well. The octopus domes, European mosaics and fisherman fresco really tied this room together. Our table was a bit small for my liking, but the quaint atmosphere really set the mood and made the entire evening very romantic. 

The staff was extremely well trained and each person that greeted our table had a specific agenda for the night. The "wine guy" was very knowledgeable, our waiter knew about seafood and the restaurant from head to toe, and everything was just great! Thanks Farallon for making our night really special.

-M
author: Melody H.

description: Great food, great service. Nice ambiance. On the pricier side, but worth it for a special meal.
author: Altaira T.

description:
The only great part of dinner was my glass of Sancerre Wine and my oysters. I had higher expectations of their seafood as I was here years ago. The food was ok, but the service actually made up for the average food. The location being in Union Square is a great place to go to before heading to the theatre!

Their new oyster bar is great!
author: Suzie Y.

description: Overall not a bad experience. Wait staff was excellent, attentive and professional. Ambiance is unique and visually interesting. Sound level quite reasonable. We sat opposite the kitchen, entertaining. That said, given the prices, the food was merely fair. Not bad, but in no way remarkable for SF. In other words, way overpriced. Our first and last visit. There are far better ways to invest ~$150 for dinner for two.
author: Matthew L.

description: Wonderful Service. High quality food. Nice interior. The fresh cold seafood is a must.
author: Q J.

description: We sat in an incredible booth. Excellent seafood and the atmosphere was enchanting.
author: Sarah A.

description:
I am a serial entrepreneur and have traveled international borders from London to dining at Chef Charlie Trotter's in Chicago and every other five star restaurant along the way; some restaurants are a minimum of $400/plate where your credit card is still charged if you don't make an appearance for your reservation.

Now I consider myself to be a purveyor of only the finest restaurants, oft-times enjoying, though sometimes not, these expensive emprises that my curiosity takes me to and I can tell all of you without hesitation who have eaten here or are thinking of it, Chef Mark Franz and Pat Kuleto have created San Francisco's, no, the west coast's finest dining experience. The food literally creates a "dance of the taste buds" in your mouth that makes you wanting far more than what your stomach can possibly allow. From the Ceviche to the shrimp hors devors, and the filet of beef to the bass, even the short ribs, I've tried them all, and every single bite makes it seem like you've tasted for the very first time.

The wine aficionado Alex, who helped us select the best bottle of Riesling from Germany, to our waiter, the manager Peter, all deserve approbation for making our dining experience truly unparalleled to none.

So Chef Franz, Mr. Kuleto, as well as the rest of your team, job well done, we will surely return. The warm greetings of smiles and welcoming every step of the way from the door to our table was much appreciated in a time where that is rarely found, even at the most expensive price tags.
author: Alissa K.

description: Boyfriend and I went here last night to celebrate our anniversary. Truly amazing: wonderful food and service. We started with a few oysters, the warm dungeness crab, and the shellfish bisque. All three starters were incredible. We also had the salmon and lobster. Both amazing as well. Skipped out on dessert because we were short on time. Overall an amazing restaurant.
author: Stacey B.

description: Always have enjoyed eating here when stuck in Union Square hotel ghetto. But I got in a little late the other night and dashed over to eat at the bar and at 9:25 PM I was told the kitchen had closed!  I guess I had forgotten what a small town SF really is, but 9:25 on week night in the hotel district is just ridiculous.
author: S P.

description: Nice interior, but very loud, over priced, typical down town restaurant, unfortunately. The food was ok, but nothing outstanding. I remember their coffee was sooooo good though. That's all I remember.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Mmmm, excellent seafood spot in San Francisco.  

The decor and ambiance are perfectly in tune at this unique restaurant space sitting on top of an old Elk's Lodge swimming pool with an authentically antiquated looking Roman/Greek tile mosaic ceiling that used to be the ceiling for an Olympic sized swimming pool still in existence below the restaurant (all this useless info gained from friendly banter with co-workers during appetizers).

The seafood is on par with what's found on Pier 39, fresh crabs, lobsters, ceviche, oysters, raw scallops (not a fan) - all piled on high on the Royal Platter appetizer - enough to satisfy 7 of us!

Some of the most amazing desserts - definitely try the apple turnover, I ordered the lemon custard tart because everyone else got the apple turnover but I still hear about this darn turnover to this day so I figure it was really good!  

Anyhoo, I won't waste anymore breathe on this review - Farallon is an SF establishment for fine seafood, but it is quite pricey ($1000 for 7 of us!).
author: Ricky S.

description:
Great ambience and ok service. This places gives you a sense of calm and relaxing feeling. We were seated upstairs which was less busy and more quiet, and is much better for conversations. Server was very nice and courteous. Food wise, we had mackerel as appetizer and Ono as main course, which were both so so-- I expected the fish to be a lot juicier. It also appeared to have been prepared but was forgotten to be brought to us so it was only warm and not hot. Also, my glass of wine was less than the usual glass, which I found to be a bit rip off. However, the angel cake dessert was good but not impressive.

The two stars are for the atmosphere and nice deco.
author: T L.

description:
A Pat Kuleto restaurant, Farallon oozes with maritme decadence, bejeweled in jellyfish lamps, shell-shaped booths, and bread baked to look like seaweed.  The dining room is an elegant play on whimsy and perfect for any special occasion or business meeting.

I've enjoyed most of my fish dishes here and though the cuisine is progressive for seafood, I wouldn't go as far to call it inventive.  

For me, the stars are really the desserts.  Don't let the menu descriptions fool you--the concoctions are more intricate and sublime than they let on.

They offer a reasonable three-course lunch menu, but my experience is that lunch compromises the restaurant's reputation.  In a word, salty.
author: Monica T.

description:
Somewhere btw 3.5-4 stars...  I wasn't sure which so I rounded down...  

Went to Farallon w the bf on date-night.  Inside is super cool - really pretty blown glass jellyfish all over the ceiling... beautifully laid out raw bar...  Decor is really pretty, and just toes the line of tacky (but doesn't manage to cross it).  Dress when I went was pretty business-dressy (def not trendy-dressy), but u do see some ppl wearing polos and khakis in there too (u expect some tourist crowd b/c of Farallon's closeness to Union Square). 

This is one of those restaurants that I crave every once in a while, but I hate going to b/c I'm young.  Dammit, I'm young, and I look it - so I don't get as good service as those old men with fatter wallets...  Water takes a while to refill, waiter is a little snooty...  *sigh*  Maybe in 20yrs this will change. :(

Food was really good, but not awe-inspiring, taste-bud tingling...  Menu options were pretty standard fare, nothing super-creative; but entrees were well-done.  But maybe that's b/c my visit was a few months ago and I've forgotten how great it was?  Prices are up there, but nothing astronomical for seafood in SF.  I would def love to go back and sample more of the raw bar.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
From the time you enter Farallon, you enter another world.  The decor is amazing and, while it is a large restaurant, it is nicely divided into separate rooms, each with their own character.

The staff were experienced, especially our eccentric waiter, the knowledgeable sommaliers, and the dedicated chefs toiling away in the open kitchen.

I was here with my parents who were visiting SF for the first time.  They were raving about it for days -- it definitely made a great impression.
author: Adam W.

description:
This is my favorite place to go for a fancy seafood dinner. The oysters are great. The wait staff is very knowledgeable about wine pairings.
For anyone who is just dipping their toes into eating fish, and hasn't managed to get past the salmon or tuna steak, Farallon is a great place to branch out and try something new.

I also like that the menu is chosen responsibly (they will even give you one of those little cards with good fish choices on it!)

The Dale Chihuly interiors are not to be missed. It is simply one of the only dining rooms in San Francisco that can get away with having no outside view.
author: Dena D.

description:
I'm feeling a little ambivalent about this place.  The food was in very small portions but was mostly excellent -- subtle flavours, well presented.  We loved the soft-shell crab with fried green tomatoes, the walleye pike with mushrooms, the branzino with snap peas, and the chocolate malt gateau (AMAZING).  We were not so impressed by the shellfish bisque (boring) and the baked alaska (decent, but nowhere near as good as the chocolate malt gateau).  The amuse bouche was oversalted, as was the butter.  Our service was polite and attentive.  My main sticking point is the price -- we had a $100 dinner credit from my date's work, but without that, the bill would have come to over $150, even without wine.  I've been to restaurants that might be worth that price -- Farallon is not.

Sidenote: My date thought the decor was cool.  I thought it went over the edge into tacky.  Either way, it was certainly different.
author: Sarah B.

description:
That's some nice big restaurant! Oh my!

Had dinner there with Lillian R. and the hubbies before Jersey Boys. I really enjoyed the food which was in season (i.e: I got my sweetbread fix for the 3rd time in a week). The portions were generous.

What can I say? It's perfect coupled with the theater. And if you drink enough you will feel like a fish in the ocean, quite literally thanks to the floating jellyfish and urchins.
author: Elsa T.

description:
This review is only for the bar.
The restaurant overall has a nice decor. Craig, the bartender, was awesome. He was very friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable about wines and spirits. My friend and I had couple glasses of Taittinger (very yummie), beausoleil and St. Simon oysters and SEARED ATLANTIC DIVER SCALLOP with roasted foie gras, pain perdu, nectarine coulis--appetizer. They were all very delicious. The service, atmosphere, and food were all very good. The price? well.... 4 glasses of champagne, 4 oysters, and 1 scallop app.... $120...exxxxpensive!
author: Jina K.

description: We had such a wonderful dining experience at Farallon! A delightful ambiance, excellent and friendly service, and delicious food!!! If you love wine, you'll especially love their list to choose from. The restaurant has this underwater flair that gives it so much character--from the painted mosaic dome to the jellyfish and urchin chandeliers, I found myself pleasantly gazing in the tiny details even when my food arrived. Make sure to save room for dessert!
author: Mindy L.

description: A friend and I went on Tuesday night afer 7pm, it was very empty. We must have just missed the happy hour. I ordered a cocktail, the Stockholm. It was very delicious! Food was good but small portions. Thought the design of the place was kind of funny... Reminded me of Disney! I would come back here again just for the drinks, regardless of the price. They were that good!
author: Stephanie U.

description:
Farallon's interior is as highly praised as its food and service, so you can imagine my utter disappoint when I discovered that this self-described "beautiful underwater fantasy" is a gaudy, overrated water park. 

Don't get me wrong, I found the overall experience enjoyable - I was all dolled up and I had delightful company. The service was quite good, although my server had the unappealing habit of spitting profusely when he talked. But everything else about the restaurant - from the gaudy octopus and squid chandeliers down to the food - impels me to recommend so many other SF restaurants above this one. 

The meal got off to a promising start with the dungeness crab gratin served on bone marrow with black truffles and toast. This was a stunning piece of work - such a triumph in mixing together unlikely ingredients. The seared scallops with white bean ravioli, on the other hand, were what had me thinking that perhaps things weren't going to go my way. The scallops were either not fresh or not properly cooked. Either scenario is unacceptable for a restaurant that purportedly specializes in seafood. 

The whole roasted tai snapper with clams and heirloom tomatoes was good although far from delectable. Finally, the grand finale failure was the grilled ono piquillo pepper sauce and sweet corn. I could've eaten something comparable at Chili's. 

The grape pie with creme fraiche ice cream and orange caramel sauce was thankfully palatable and worth the splurge to the waistline, but good dessert does not make a restaurant exceptional.
author: Baochi N.

description:
Farallon is a loud, fun and uniquely designed restaurant in the heart of Union Square.  A perenial favorite -- it specializes in creatively prepared seafood dishes that other traditional Western seafood restaurants would never attempt.

Great service, celebrity's and the who's who (last night we ate next to David Brenner), and professional operations have this large restaurant humming on a busy Wednesday night.  Still if there are any negatives it would be that the food did not reach the height of my bill reached.

Don't get me wrong.....the food is fresh and there are plenty of creative dishes including my roated bone marrow appetizer, but nothing wowed.....

Farallon is so close to the 4 star an I wish we had a 1/2 star option.  It is the same rating as La Folie, but I would come here over La Folie any day.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Very pricey, but well worth meal.  The ambiance is great.  It's not an everyday restaurant that you go to.  It's a place where you are celebrating.  It's better if it's a 2 person place.  The upstairs is very cozy and romantic.  You can sit in these comfortable booths and talk.  Very romantic.  The filet mignon and the fish was awesome.  The beef was cooked exactly medium rare as I requested and the fish was very tasty.  Just with the right amount of juice and freshness.  
We also ordered the cherry stone clams and I did not like how i found some shells in mine.  They did not clean it well enough.  That was the minus one star.  The ambiance was better than the food.  It's really a romantic place to have dinner.  Come here w/ a bf or gf to celebrate, but don't come here w/ a huge group or just to try it.  The experience is highly different.
author: AhLin C.

description:
If God started a seafood restaurant, this would be it. And given the cost of the dishes, He'd be raking in the bucks, too. 

Take your appetite, your best duds, and be sure you've got room on your plastic. Always a great experience and absurdly good food.
author: Gregg G.

description:
This restaurant belongs in Disney Land.  It's that over-the-top.

Unfortunately I wasn't feeling the greatest the day we came here.  I was a little sick to my stomach (there was a stomach flu going around the office that week) and the thought of seafood made me turn green.  We had the scallops (not cooked very well) and short ribs (incredibly fatty meat) and neither were above average.  The service was good, however.  It should be, for the prices you pay here.

I think I'd like to come back and try again, but I'd get fish next time.  Or maybe not, because there's such amazing food in SF for less $$$.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I found a WORM in my salad.  I pointed it out to the waitress and she was horrified.  She said she would comp the salad.  That's it.  It probably soured me on the whole meal, but I thought my halibut and pound cake were both dry and nothing special.  I tried a bite of some brownie sundae which was pretty tasty.  

I don't know if the salad was on the check since I was someone's guest, but I do not think that would be enough to make up for a WORM in my salad at a place like this!
author: Amy D.

description: Disappointed in the food. Atmosphere and service were great. Food flavor and temperature lacking. Bread was good. Had snapper, just ok. Forgot the rest. Not worth the price. Weak for what it's supposed to be.
author: The Mouse G.

description: good food, but the service was slow, and our server kept forgetting our drinks.  Has been better.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Solid example of fine dining.

Food -- The Mushroom Bisque was average in my opinion, but perhaps it's because I've had amazing mushroom bisque before and this definitely was not it. The Foie Gras was good (great texture, simply presented, well paired/flavored), but not the best I've had either. Both of the above are geared toward more earthy, subdued flavors, and I prefer a shot of excitement when eating (intense flavors with great complexity). I switched it up this time and went for the Tai Snapper with Gnocchi. The gnocchi was perfectly done, as was the snapper. Perfect texture for both, excellent flavors, but small portions. My lady had the scallops which, again, had an earthy, subdued taste, but still very good. For dessert we had the honey roasted pear, which was a new one for me but a delightful surprise. The mascarpone went perfectly with the butter cake and roasted pear, and it was a very clean, simple, tasty way to end the meal.

Service -- Excellent! The staff were very professional, helpful, and attentive without being cumbersome or annoying.

Setting -- The setting is unique, and there are several tastefully themed rooms. Albeit a tad loud due to conversation, it was an inviting, pleasant setting. The chairs, however, had very little cushion in the seat and wore down my hind end as the meal went on. If you're assless like me, consider yourself warned.

Verdict -- Great location (right next to our hotel; next to union square; lots of shopping and food nearby); above average food (especially if you prefer more calm, earthy flavors); excellent service; great setting; small portions, so don't come too hungry. Definitely recommend, but not my favorite.
author: Damian S.

description: Old classic restaurant.  Food was delicious.  Pettrale was off the chart wonderful.  Service wa good but not great.
author: Nick L.

description:
Came here with friends, a while back, for a post-shopping meal, and was presently surprised. Usually the over done theme is not my cup of tea, but I had a great meal, so I can't be too harsh on the jellyfish lighting.

Service was attentive, decor is over the top, but in a charming way I guess, but the squid ink risotto was total perfection! Delicately seasoned, nice bite and lots of squid throughout. 

I, personally, don't see myself coming here again, but would say it's worth trying once for the experience.
author: Antoi C.

description:
Decent food despite what people have said to the contrary. It is a bit pricey.  Stick with the appetizers such as the crab salad or the mini-lamb burgers from the bar menu. Service was good but not great. The wine list left a bit to be desired but there were some decent picks for less than the usual 200% markup. Overall, I would pick it as a place to take friends from out of town way before I would pick other restaurants in the area.

Food 3 stars
Service 3 stars
Decor 3 stars [a bit over the top for me]
author: Allan H.

description:
Had read many not so good reviews on another site.  Also, our neighbors warned us that Farallon is not all that--after we told them we had booked reservations there for a birthday.

That said, we had a truly wonderful experience from start to finish.  We were shown a quiet table on the second floor.  The service was wonderful, our server was attentive but not obsessive.  Because I had indicated that we were celebrating a birthday, my partner was presented with a nice birthday dessert---which was a pleasant surprise.

The decoration was lovely, though the restaurant was much smaller than I had imagined.  The location is great--just up the street from Border's in Union Square.

We had no complaints, everything was quite nice.  It's a fun place to bring out of town guests and also to celebrate special occasions.
author: Penny P.

description:
Ah, Farallon.  Memories, thats all I can say.

First off, I hate driving in the city.  I know how to get to a handful of places but other than that I get lost like a little kid in a store.  So, after getting turned around the one way streets and calling in for directions, we finally made it to Farallon.  Wait a minute, that looks like Union Square across the street.  Weren't we just there a few hours ago...dammit, it *IS* Union Square.  

OK, so we arrived about 30 minutes late for our reservation but the staff was very accommodating.  Walking in, I noticed the underwater theme and thought it was a nice touch.  I mean jellyfish lamps, how can you not like jellyfish lamps?!   All that was missing was some ambient sea sounds.  Anyways, we were seated upstairs in a nice booth and were taken care of promptly.  Our waiter was nice and was a perfect blend of hands off but still attentive.  

I had the fillet of beef which was very good while my girlfriend had the striped bass.  The wine was fine but the best part of the evening was dessert.  I had let them know ahead of time that we were celebrating our anniversary so they brought us a special dessert, a chocolate pecan tart.  

Overall, we left satisfied with our evening and got a good laugh that we drove around like idiots.  I wouldn't hesitate to dine at Farallon again.
author: Ninja C.

description:
Exquisite!  My hubby took me here for my birthday and to this day, I haven't tasted a piece of fish better prepared than the one I had at Farallon. Ironically, I don't even like sole, but I was absolutely thrilled I ordered it.  

The dcor is beautiful, and the food is just as delish...
author: Lauren S.

description:
There's not much to say about this place.. except how I LAA-UUHHV it!

I came here a month ago to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday.  I called on the day of the dinner (a little last minute, but let's keep that between us.. shh!), and although they were packed, they squeezed us in for a 7:30 reservation.  Nice. 

The service itself was great.  We were 15 minutes late for our reservation (stupid downtown SF traffic!), but they didn't fuss over it or make us wait around.  We were immediately seated in the pool room (hint: it's uber quiet, dim, and romantic!)

Our waitress was great.  He was very knowledgeable about the extensive wine/champagne list, as well as wine/food pairings.  I can't really say much about the menu or give any recommendations because I don't think it'll help much (the entree part of the menu changes everyday).  But when we went, I had the seafood appetizer platter, halibut and lobster (entrees), and some sort of lemon meringue tart for dessert.  Everything was so good!!! 

All in all, the food, service, and ambiance was A++.  This place is just fantastic, and it was a great experience.  WIll definitely come again.

btw, if you're a huge oyster fan like me.. you MUST try their oysters. i think they have about 12 different kinds.  SO YUMMY.
author: S L.

description:
I am not much of a seafood person, but I must admit.  Each visit to this establishment has not disappoint.

The decor is great, food is terrific and the price is reasonable for a place like this.

I would give it 5 stars if they catered more to non-seafood diners like myself.

But hey 4 stars from a steak n potato guy....speaks tons.
author: Thomas P.

description: Food, service and ambience in the back room - simply beautiful
author: carole p.

description: omg. wow. This was an AMAZING meal. The head chef was so detail oriented, the menu changes regularly and the fish is so incredibly fresh. I love it. Had my anniversary dinner there & I really will never be able to enjoy a meal as much as I did this one. Get a wine pairing, their sommelier is a genius and the wine selection is quite large. Also, if they still have the carrot cake - ORDER it. I hate carrot cake, but somehow this is the most amazing dessert I've ever had.
author: linda t.

description:
Tried here for my bf's b-day. Atmosphere was pretty fun the jelly fish light fixtures were fantastic feature that makes you feel in the restaurant serves sea food.. That was pretty cool design. Luckly we had frienndly nice waiter serves us that night but place like this much price like here ($30 average on main course) don't serve higher service..and food was average not memorable..

Different experience but not coming back again.
author: Beautee K.

description: From the moment you walk through the door into this gorgeous fantastical space, you will be transported. You will be greeted with a friendly smile and no matter where you are seated, you won't be disappointed. But the best is yet to come. The food is out of this world. I have a soft spot for any place that offers an amuse bouche-you will get an amazing one here, along with a tiny sweet sendoff after dinner. Service is impeccable-friendly, efficient and no one is overbearing. And you won't be knocked over by the cost-you will think it is worth every dime. Can't wait to go back!
author: Cathy N.

description: Waiter was phoning in his performance; not very helpful or committed to us having a great dining experience. Menu was filled with many terrific choices. We enjoyed them very much. Decor made created a magical atmosphere. This would have rated at least four stars had the waiter not been so blah.
author: JT. F.

description: Honestly, for the price of the food, this should have been far better.  The fish was undercooked and tasteless and the wine list, though expansive, was ridiculously overpriced.  The portions are teeny-tiny.  Not to mention the undersea decor makes this place look like a blown glass factory.  Lets just say that when the next big earthquake hits this place is going to be ground zero.
author: Drew W.

description: The most delicious restaurant in the universe! Worth every penny (all 4 billion of them....)
author: Bailey H.

description:
The decor is quirky, but the stoned Jules Verne look kind of grows on you.

The menu is fish.  Yeah, there's other stuff, but go there for the fish.

The wait staff is erratic.  Lots of reports of bad service, and count me among them.  Good someliers, though, with a nice albeit slightly overpriced wine list.

Desserts are heavenly--thank you Emily Luchetti.

So, if you're willing to gamble with $100 plus wine, you could get lucky here.
author: Shawn U.

description:
I'd like to do 2.5 stars, but I guess I'll go with 3. 

Our reservations were at 8:15, we show up 10 minutes early and weren't seated until 30-40 minutes later.  Kind of lame, but I had a lovely sidecar that helped tide me over. The hostess originally tried to put us at the random booth right next to the oyster bar and across from the restrooms that didn't even seem like it was part of any dining area. My dining companion was not happy with that so we requested a different table. They sent us back to the bar to wait and promptly shuffled us off into the low ceilinged area that's before the back dining room. Also, the hostess didn't offer to take my coat, which kind of struck me as odd in a place that's considered fine dining.

Our server was excellent and attentive, the food was okay. Nothing terribly wrong with it, but nothing fantastic. The decor was unoffensively cheesy. It seems like a good place for business dinners and tourists (judging from the other patrons there that's mostly the kind of business they get). For a nice night on the town however, I'd recommend going somewhere else.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Great food, great service, great atmosphere. One thing you have to try though is the dessert. It's the perfect finish to the delicious meal. Come on, one of the world's top pastry chef works there!

Let me tell you this, you'll definitely want to come back for more!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Luv this place!

Best decor in town.  Great oysters, wide variety of seafood menu, best of all.... most awesome dessert.  Staff is always professional, good martini's and wine selections... what else can u ask for!  Oh yeah.. it's a bit steep on the wallet...
author: Addison C.

description:
Admittedly, I probably only eat here once a year, but I feel like the food and service have been pretty consistent. I may be biased by the fact that my favorite dessert chef, Emily Luchetti, work here.

Just the ambiance and unique decor of Farallon deserves mention. Where else can you sit on octopus bar stools and enjoy you dinner in a clam shell. The jellyfish chandeliers are fabulous. I just love knowing that they converted a former indoor swimming pool to an "underwater grotto." It's a great visual.

The food is solid and always done well. It's nothing fancy or offbeat like some other nouveau restaurants, but I think they do well with their courses. And, of course, I love trying the desserts. If you have enough people and they offer a sampler platter, try it, it's really fun.
author: Px C.

description:
You should go at least once to "sea" for yourself.

Decor:  Whimsical, under-the-sea theme, including hanging jellyfish lights, rolling wave patterned booth backs and assorted shell lamps...very unexpected in an upscale establishment and it's either ridiculous, a la Disneyland, or exciting and fresh, depending on your taste.  

Food:  On the whole, nothing spectacular, but the butter is insanely good (extra salty, creamy and fatty).  The melon salad is worth trying, unlike the lobster bisque, which is too salty and not that flavorful.  The amuse bouche was delicious and creamy, but I have no idea what I ate!

Price:  Not bad for this type of restaurant and the quality of service, which was excellent, albeit a little slow:  $15ish for an appetizer, $30ish for an entree, $12ish for dessert and wines by the glass start around $10).
author: X E.

description:
I feel like ever since Chef Park left the food has been a bit lackluster. I ate there recently and granted I was not feeling well at the time, but could still tell that something was up. 

Visually the dishes just weren't there and taste-wise they were so-so. Foie gras torchons with biter citrus marmalades was a bit strange and the amuse bouche was less than amusing... just random bits of other dishes recognizable from the menu. One particular amuse we were served -- the lobster with caviar and fondant potato was a bit off. The potato was way too big, and combined with the caviar had a bitter finish. 

I'd go back but only in a few months when the kitchen is back to normal.
author: Jeff K.

description:
I can't imagine anyone saying that the food here is not amazing. I freqently have to have businesses dinners and this place is at the top of my list of choices. Last night I had the Alaskan Halibut and it melted in my mouth. I am always shocked how good food really can be when I eat at Faralon.

Also I love the underwater details. I especially love sitting in the pool area...you know there is still a working pool under the dining room? The tile details are beautiful and you get a bit of history to boot!
author: Denise L.

description:
It's been over 8 months since I ate here for my X-mas work lunch, so my memory will be a bit cloudy. We had a private room (Beluga Room) at this restaurant. The room was decent size with six tables for a party of about 60. The decor in this room was weird and interesting. Wall paintings of sea creatures, skeletons, and even a baby underwater in weird poses. The artist must have been high on something.  Service was average, what you expect from a fine dining restaurant. 

We had the prix fixe 3 course menu (menu might have changed since then), but the main dining room you can order from their regular non-fixed menu. I started with the Lobster Bisque, which was average and nothing spectacular. The entree I had the Filet Mignon, which was very good and juicy but of course like all restaurant the filet was small. Finally for dessert, I believe it was some sort of chocolate cake on top of some vanilla bean ice cream.  Also, to mentioned that this was my second time at this restaurant. The first time I remember it being much more spectacular probably because I haven't sampled much fine dining before, but the recent time was "EEHHH....."  This place is definitely a notch below the likes of Gary Dankos, but nevertheless it is A-OK to me.
author: Peter L.

description:
My parents were in town visiting and we are the first family to walk in the nearest hole in the wall for (usually) the best food in town. We decided to join the elite one night, however, and went fancy for Farallon.

It was almost closing time on a weekday so they were empty and we sat up at the bar. The bartender was extremely nice. We ordered our ... pricey ... (reason for 4 stars instead of 5) food according to his recommendations. Every single thing we got was incredible. Definitely one of the best meals I remember having. A fresh bean salad doesn't sound like it could be anything extraordinary - but just wait. We got a few fish dishes, no idea which, but all I know is it was good. The decor is awesome too! If you're feeling high class (and rich) one night - this is a great place for splurging on a date. Or getting you parents to take you...
author: Ali W.

description: I can't believe how over-hyped this place is. Food was average at best and exetremely expensive for what you get. We were sat at a small table by the cash register. Over and over waiters and waitresses were complaining about things and nobody had a clue which table they were taking care of. We waited forever for our watered down drinks and warm beer. That was the first problem. Everyone around started getting irritated too because their service was subpar. Manager came out and started apologizing to everyone and even gave the table behind us a free dessert. Now, we all had crappy service in that area. Not sure why that table received special treatment but I digress. Anyway, wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. Very disappointed in the service, ambiance, and definitely the food.
author: Mike A.

description: I was so disappointed in our recent dinner. This is one of my sentimental favorites in SF. The atmosphere and decor are just beautiful.  Unfortunately, the food, service and value were just not there. It took way too long, more than 15 minutes to get a martini and when it arrived, it was not very cold. The diver scallops were really good, cooked perfectly but there were only 2 scallops and one 1/2 scallop. The service was friendly enough but not attentive at all. We were never asked if we wanted another drink or dessert. He just brought the check. I will go back but just to have a drink at the lovely bar. There are just way too many other good restaurants in SF.
author: Mary R.

description:
After years in Union Square, Farallon still delivers. The decor is gorgeous and thematic without being overly precious. Still a stunner after all these years. 

Great friendly service from the valet to the hostess to the waiters, it's obvious a lot of training goes into this destination restaurant. 

OK, the food: the bear started with seared ahi tuna and I had the butternut squash lasagna. Great tastes with the only detriment being that the pasta was a little too soft for my taste. 

For main courses, the bear had half dungenesse crab served with butter and a lemon aioli while I ordered the perfectly grilled fillet of beef with Stilton cheese, spinach puree and twice baked potatoes. I guess I could take the time to pull up the menu and go for the complete description but just go to the Farallon site, take in the sights, and read the menu completely...that gives you the options of what is served there. 

As my dinner companion says, you don't end a meal like this without a decadent dessert and Farallon again delivered: he had the chocolate blackout cream cake with salted peanuts and I had my standby carrot cake with kumquat marmalade. Yummy! 

A fantastic setting, great food, excellent service...go grab a date and head over!
author: TJ T.

description: Haven't been here in a few years. Food was just excellent. Service to match. The butternut squash ravioli & fingerling potato dish was one of the best meals I've had in years.
author: Fred C.

description: The seafood is as fresh as it gets in a restaurant! Four in our party. We all opted for a separate appetizer..I had a wonderful Mediterranean dungness crab dish with a wonderful white sauce. Two had the Lobster bisque, and one had a scallop dish. All were very happy. We all then shared the royal iced platter of seafood. Was pricey ( $125), but all of the seafood was wonderful. It included 6 oysters on half shell, a whole lobster, dungness crab legs, 3 clams, ceviche, scallop dish. All were served cold with a choice of mignonette or cocktail sauce. Cocktail sauce was full woth horseradish.  It was plenty of food for our party of four. We all had desert as well. I can't remember what the others had, but I had a sticky toffee pudding that was wonderful as well. I don't have a bad thing to say about this place. We were treated very well!
author: Kathy G.

description:
I was there with my customers last week.
Jelly fish light is good and have expensive wines.

I orders halibut from the menu.
A few minutes later, water come back to me and said halibut is out and how about wild yellow tail. Yellow tail is my favorite fish and I expect filet of a yellow tail with delicious meat.

But what I got minutes later is a hard meat with no taste. I feel I was eating a rubber.  I was sure it was a part of meat just next to the tail fin. I could not believe they use most bad part of the fish for a customer.

They do not know the very basic of a fish at all. Better to chage the chef.
author: Ted S.

description: This place is very over-priced, and the food was pretty average.  You're much better off spending your money elsewhere.
author: Jack S.

description: came here for happy hour! amazing fresh oysters but albeit pricey for the happy hour special..nevertheless a great time with 7$ drinks including two yummy house picked cabs and chardonnay are on the drink list..bread is offered with olive oil and the usual balsamic.  ordered the crab bisque on the menu and the flavours were pretty amazing..a great accompaniment with the bread bowl....coming back to try dinner sometime. overall great experience :)
author: Dustin G.

description:
Was pleasantly surprised with an early birthday dinner here.  I've always wanted to try this place out and I was fairly please with the results.

Some people would say the decor is gaudy or overly done, but I thought it was nicely laid out.  I love how there are so many SF places that look small from the outside and entryway then open up into a large open space.  The lighting was perfect and the seats comfortable.

The appetizers were great.  I didn't really think much of the salad at first since it looked like they just quartered a head of iceberg lettuce, however the dressing along with a light goat cheese and figs made it absolutely wonderful.  Very refreshing and tasty.  The Smoked salmon was perfectly cooked with a very heavy smokey taste along with a hint of orange citrus.

The main dishes were equally as tasty.  The stuffed sole was fairly light, but the lobster stuffing was very flavorful, albeit probably due to a generous amount of butter.  The Hawaiian Opah was seasoned and grilled to perfections.  It was described as a fillet, but the tenderness was done like a steak.  The thinly sliced fried onions made it even more delectable.

Dessert was a chocolate mouse cake topped off with a butterscotch/toffee ice cream.  Very sweet, and both flavors complimented each other very well.

The service was absolutely wonderful.  Our waiter was very cordial and attentive.  i was very impressed with how prompt everything was, the patience with explaining the dishes, and the friendly smile.  I really didn't feel we had to ask for anything as he seemed to just know when we might be needing his something.

I'd definitely go back since I fell into the eying everyone else's dish mode.  The fillet looked incredibly good, the tomato bisque is something I crave for, the grilled salmon and halibut looked equally as appetizing as well.

I wish I lived closer to this place, as I'm sure it'd be a great after work place to meet for a drink or some after work oyster shooters.
author: Yehoy L.

description: Dessert ''GATEAU ROYALE'' is ooooh SOOOo YUMMY!!!!!!!!!!!!!One of the best desserts I've ever had....HIGHLY recommended~~^__~
author: Creamie S.

description:
I've dined here three times, twice some time ago and once recently.
The first couple of times I LOVED it, everything was delicious and the service superb.
This last time, well, pretty much the opposite.
It was a couple of months ago at this point (I'm trying to catch up on my reviews) so I don't remember the apps., but I recall they were good.  While my boyfriend's entree was served rather speedily, mine took forever, something like 30 minutes.  No joke.  And what was taking so long to prepare?  Seared tuna!
There was a rather curt apology from the waiter on the delay.
I felt rather badly as I had really built up the restaurant.  
It's still beautiful.  Such creative decor.  I guess at some point I'll give it another try, but not anytime too soon.
I just thought I'd mention this as I would have given it five stars before, but it was such an off night, you should be aware it can happen.
author: Kara H.

description: The restaurant seems overrated. Decor is classy and fairly unique - nice and plush seats, jellyfish hanging from the ceiling, romantic atmosphere. Table service was good - timely water refills, polite and warm waiters (albeit food took forever). Seems like it was tough to get a reservation here too - we got a 9pm dinner seating on a Saturday night. The food however, was a far cry from the review we read. We came here because it was recommended by a renown travel book as one of the top 10 places to eat in San Fran. We had a table of five so I would say we ordered enough food to be objective in terms of variety. Salmon was overcooked and I didn't like the fact that bacon bits was served with it. I did not feel the combination was complementary and adding bacon to any kind of food seems like a cop out. Hawaiian ono was served with black bean sauce which I found a little overwhelming in taste. Black bean sauce was overpowering and the fish lacked texture. Seared ahi tuna appy was served with ginger slices - unexciting, to say the least. Entrees took more than a hour to arrive and at 10pm, I can assure you the restaurant was not busy. I am unsure what took them so long but we finally finished dinner at midnight and I didn't even asked for a dessert menu. Overall, quite unimpressed. I will not return - expensive fine dining but rather disappointing in terms of taste.
author: Amelia Y.

description: I love the decor! You feel like you are "under the sea" with the jellyfish chandeliers and the seashell chair backs, sea urchin light fixtures, kelp columns, you name it! It creates a fun but still elegant feel inside! I've been here a few times now and they regularly update their menu. I can say that the menu is hit or miss on occassion but still overall great food! Definitely a restaurant worth checking out!
author: Jennalyn M.

description: Had a marvelous Valentines Day dinner with good friends. Food was excellent as was service. Ambiance is romantic, historic, and filled with good energy.
author: Barbara K.

description: Farallon has gone through several changes of staff over the last several years.  We don't recommend it anymore; the decor is still fabulous but the food isn't.  It's still good, but no longer matches the prices.
author: Josh B.

description: Absolutely yum sea food.. Herb Crusted Rare Ahi Tuna is a must have!
author: Ruchika I.

description:
So here is a review for a seafood restuarant from a person that DOES NOT EAT SEAFOOD (except clam chowder). I'm sure I'm not alone and I'm sure I won't be the last of my kind that goes here because a close friend or spouse loves the place or celebrates a special occasion.
If I remember correctly, and I do, besides salad there are three items on the menu I had to choose from. Two items were steaks, the other was lamb. Yes, that's it, no chicken, no soup of a non fishy nature, nothing else. One of the steaks was sold very well by our waitress. It was the american kobe beef steak (I forget which cut) with lobster layed on top. I mean she made this piece of meat sound like it was made of gold and since I know kobe, I ordered it. There were only a couple of tiny pieces of lobster on top and if I was a lobster lover I would have been pissed, but yay for me less lobster to choke down... The meat itself was just ok, I've had better american kobe than this so I think it may boil down to you don't go to a seafood restuarant and expect great steak, the cooks just don't prepare enough of it.
Overall the service was good, especially the seperate bread guy. I asked for an end of the french bread and for the rest of the night he was sneaking ends on my bread plate. That was very cool. The place is also pleasant to be in, nice decor, strange acoustics though as I could hear several conversations from tables in places I wouldn't think to hear anything from. I also thought the little seafood bar up front across from the alcohol bar was cool and different. Only if I liked seafood...
author: Chris M.

description: This restaurant was absolutely spectacular; the ambiance isn't even the beginning with this place. The staff seemed like a well oiled machine, one that really worked like clockwork and coming from the F&B industry I really appreciated that. Although having to wait 15 extra minutes wasn't a great first highlight, it was understandable since the place was packed and it was a Friday night. Once seated I had already gone through the bar menu while waiting for the table was getting pretty stoked (not like I didn't research the heck outta the restaurant before hand). So sat down, and was immediately greeted by the server and had to get another mojito cause I'll say god damn! Haha...every dish that we had was excellent, and honestly don't feel like going into all the fine, delectable details of some of the best seafood dishes that i have EVER had! Def check it out...well worth the price!
author: Andrew M.

description:
After eating at Boulevard on a trip a couple of years ago and having a great meal, when we found out that Farallon was also Pat Kuleto's restaurant, we were pretty excited to try it. I made reservations about 3 weeks in advance and asked for a table in the "Pool Room" and wrote in the comments section that my wife and I were celebrating our 19th anniversary. A a couple of days before the trip, Farallon's reservationist called to confirm our reservation and told me that they had reserved us a booth in the "Pool Room". We arrived a little early for Happy Hour, and I ordered a margarita and my wife ordered their Hemingway Daiquiri. Mine came out in a glass, hers in a beat up copper and tin cup. I though Hemingway was a pretty rugged guy, so maybe that is their homage to him. Mine was fine, hers was awful. It tasted just like the pickled ginger you get with sushi. Don't get me wrong, with sushi it's a great taste, but I don't think you want to drink a whole cup of it! Come to find out later in the evening after looking at their cocktail list, that the bartender had given her a Moscow Mule. 

We were seated in a booth upstairs overlooking the bar and my wife commented that it looked different in the pictures. After looking around at the cheesy pictures, the slightly dirty resin sea stars stuck on the columns, and the really dirty window covered by fishing nets, I came to the conclusion that this restaurant is really just an upscale Rainforest Cafe. They must not do their cleaning during the day because there were dust bunnies covering the sloped ceiling behind us and covering the air grate right above us. The whole effect is kind of dingy and outdated. 

We were trying to decide what we wanted for wine, and my wife wasn't sure what she wanted for dinner. When I asked our waiter,( who was about 6'4" and had an annoying habit of standing as close to the table as possible so we had to strain our necks to look up at him), about a particular glass of wine pairing with the black cod. Of course the $8.50 glass I asked about wouldn't pair well with it, but the two most expensive glasses at $18.50 and $24 respectively would go nicely! I decided on a $42 bottle of A to Z Pinot from Oregon and It paired nicely with our selections. 

For dinner we received an amuse of smoked sturgeon mousse with a fried caper and citrus sauce. It was okay, but a little too salty. We split a beet salad with was a little odd. The cheese on it was like cheddar shaved with a vegetable peeler, and then there were quartered beets and a beet "duxelles" which was slightly gritty, like the beets weren't washed correctly. 

For entrees, my wife had the black cod and I had the dorade. Both were prepared nicely, but the portion size was 4-5 ounces for both. 

For dessert we had a poached pear which came out kind of shriveled and dry, with a brown butter cake that was also slightly dry. It did have Happy 19th anniversary written in chocolate on the plate though, which was nice. 

All during dinner, service was technically good, but very robotic. There was no warmth, no personality, no effort to make the experience a memorable one. 

When paying the tab, I put out my credit card and my Passport card. Now, in the interest of fairness, I own a restaurant, and I take Passport. It was my decision to take Passport because I felt it was in the best interest of my restaurant. The owners of Farallon take Passport because, I assume, that it is in the best interest of their restaurant. When our card was picked up,( by a manager I might add), 
she kind of gave us a weird look, and then was gone for about 10 minutes. When the check came back, I went to total the payment, and the gratuity had already been added. HMMM...what if I didn't feel the service deserved 18% gratuity. There was a section to add additional gratuity, but no place to comment or explain why you felt service didn't deserve an automatic gratuity. I have always tipped at least 20% in the past, but that really stuck in my craw. If the house thinks that their restaurant is so good that they will automatically add the gratuity then so be it. 

As we were leaving we walked through the rest of the restaurant , we saw the room we thought we would be seated in. I asked a server what the room was called. "Oh", she said, "this is the Pool Room". 

Kind of figures, doesn't it?
author: S. C.

description: Very good seafood. Wine expertise was okay, the general dining room is loud
author: Nick F.

description: Who knew that a restaurant near Union Square with jellyfish on the ceiling could be so top-notch in every way?! I had a lovely work dinner here, where every item we ordered was perfectly prepared and full of unique flavors. My usual qualm with ordering cooked seafood/fish is that it is too bland, or uses spices/sauces that I could easily make at home. Not here! My spearfish had a very tasty garlickly coconut sauce accompanied with mussels, and my ceviche trio contained just the right amount of citrus, salt, and accompanying vegetables. We also received outstanding service. Granted, we were a group of almost 20, and we had reserved the semi-private balcony (which I recommend for a group!), but our waiter was very attentive and very knowledgeable about the menu and appropriate wine parings. Our group has some new favorite wines, based on his suggestions. The only downside is that your bill will add up quickly here if you want to get a full taste of all Farallon has to offer, so keep this place in mind for your next work event or special occasion. Can't wait to return!
author: Alison S.

description: Been to Farallon a couple times and had a great time. Good food. Nice setting. Like it. Overall a good spot for cocktails and pretty good food. A little pricey. Enjoy!
author: Love B.

description: We went to celebrate my husband's BD, but we didn't feel we had a very special/memorable dinner.  They put together a BD card and a presented the dessert we ordered with a candle and a BD message.  I was actually expecting tha tthey could have at least given us a complementary dessert like other high-end restaurants.   The food was ok, but salty.  It's unlikely we'll return with so many other great one's to try.
author: Sandy S.

description: My girlfriend and I were VERY excited to splurge on a 5 star restaurant in downtown SF.  Upon arrival we were unpleasantly surprised that the highly rated decor seemed little old fashioned and a bit tacky... time to upgrade.  Long stroy short - The service was really really slow (until we waived a manager over).  The portions were smaller than expected... the $16 shrimp appetizer came w just 3 shrimp (really?).  The Filet and Scallops were delicious but for $200 we expected ALOT more.
author: Robert A.

description:
Ive been here twice.  the ambiance is unparalleled.  The service is fantastic.   The food is really good but could be better.   

I say go and try for your self--everyone should eat here at least once.  It is worth the trip.
author: Johnny C.

description:
This was the second time I have been to this restaurant and it seems like it has gotten better.  The food was excellent and the service was great too.

I would go back again in a heart beat.
author: Chris L.

description:
This place has an amazing decor and great desserts.  Sit in the bar and get an after dinner drink and dessert and you can experience the best of Farallon at a fraction of the price of dinner.

This is a great place to take folks from out of town (especially if they are not from a big city) as the atmosphere never fails to impress.  

The bathrooms are great, too.
author: Bay G.

description: Beautiful Decoration and great service, but I think the food doesn't justify the prices.  I suppose you're paying for the decoration.
author: Dave S.

description:
Let's start with the good.  Scallops were great, Ranger Cookie Sundae was tasty (yes fergie there is no "e" in tasty), and the decor was mildly impressive.

Now for the bad.  The $37 Sole that was bland and average, the seats next to waiter lobby/computers, the waiter still forgetting to bring my lovely date a second glass of wine, and me referencing Fergie.
author: Sean S.

description:
Get the scallops (delicous), not the Sole (awful).

The staff was running around trying to cater to a group of high rollers (annoying) and the decor is kindy creepy -  an Under the Sea theme with octopus-like lights that hang from the ceiling. 

Unless you are dining on a gift certificate (like we were), I wouldn't visit this place.  Not worth it.
author: Julie P.

description:
Great food! Its been a while since my last visit so I cant remember what I had exactly but I did remember that everything from the appetizers to mains to dessert and wine were fabulous.

Its nice if you have a party of eight or so and get seated in the private room. You get a great view of the entire restaurant through its glass windows, yet have enough privacy from the rest of the tables.

Definitely will be going back soon!
author: Gobbledygook C.

description: Great place for dinner. Been here a handful of times and always had great food. Always considered it a touristy restaurant but in reality it is hands down one of the better seafood places I've been to. I also love the fact that they have my favorite champagne ( Laurent perrier rose) and the food is quite reasonably priced for what you get. The decor is probably the most memorable to me, it's got to be one of the nicest decorated restaurants i seem to remember.  They have these chandeliers that resemble sea creatures and the service here was top notch. Definitely would go back for some reasonably priced seafood.
author: Cesar H.

description:
The crabs legs were SOOO worth the extra effort of snapping, cracking, and multiple hand wiping.  A messy, but necessary part of your meal.  The seared Alaskan cod was absolutely amazing!  Who knew fennel ravioli could taste so damn good!?
The service was excellent and the room was spacious so you couldn't hear your neighbors' conversations.
author: Colleen B.

description: Honestly one of the best oyster bars in San Francisco. I went for holiday drinks with friends. We had their crab salad, sardines plate, ceviche of the day and their amazing pomme fritz. Everything was fresh and delicious. The drinks were strong and served me as a nice insulation to the night's coldness. The place is real cute, an under the sea theme. The only reason I didn't give it a 5 star rating was because our waiter would leave for long periods and we would have to flag another waiter to get service.  But that didn't take away from a good meal and some nice drinks. Can't wait to go back.
author: Eli R.

description: It was a while ago since I dined there, but I was not impressed with the food. I had sea bass with the crunchy skin in the broth. It did not taste that good. It does not  seem like a dish that requires a skilled chef to prepare. I do like the underwater theme and the jelly fish. No need to go there again.
author: N G.

description: Breath taking decor... Excellent fish... Surprisingly kid friendly
author: Jeff B.

description:
Over Rated is what comes to mind.   NOt to bash or anything, as the meal was fine and all, but for the price the experience should match. 
   I'll Explain. The Decore is really cool. They definatly put alot into it and it shows. For me, I give it a B+( I prefer Refined elegence) it kinda reminded me of a muesem. Anyhow, On the the Service.......It was my birthday and My G.F. told the waiter while I was parking the car unbenounced to me. He was a Robot. NO charm no personality and took forever. He seriously told us to take our time every time he came to the table. We saw the table next to us get sat 3 times during the course of our meal...ridicoulus. Enought about that, I think I made my point. He was a C- at best.
      The Food was a B+. It was fresh and high quality, but it felt to me that they were trying to hard to be cool. I had Ono with a veggie spring Roll and a Chard-Mango Coulis. The Spring roll was a dissapointment. I get better at the local Vietnamiese place for 2 Bucks. The Ono was done perfectly thank goodness. My Girlfriend hnd the Halibut. She only took  a couple of bites. The Ahi App we had was great.
     to top off the night, as we were looking over the desert menu, the food runner came out with a birthday desert and a candle in it..how sweet. Funny though, he took it to the tale next to us nad when they said it wasn't theirs, he went to the next table over to drop it off, but they still had menus in their hands!! What a Moron!. He then took off embarrased and never came back. My Girlfriend was so upset by this it ruined her night cause she wanted to suprise me. Bummer
author: chris c.

description: The ambiance and decor are nice, the service is good; but the food is not that special. You could do better for less.
author: Chris S.

description:
Don't get me wrong. The food was quite good, but nothing special given the big name and price. The atmosphere was fun (though it seemed a little dated). 

The problem with this place is that it seems that you're paying a premium for the name. The decor was neat, but the whole restaurant seemed to be a little dated... past its prime. 

The food was well presented and the service was attentive and polite.  They had a good variety of oysters and fish (both run of the mill and more exotic). Oysters on the half shell were quite good and they had a nice variety. However the taste/quality of the food itself was not anything to write home about.  My halibut certainly spent a little too long underneath a heat lamp. 

It's a fairly large establishment and I think that's one of the problems. I didn't feel as if  our food got the attention it would get at a smaller but similarly priced restaurant. 

It's worth checking out once if you have the money to burn because it is a nice place. But one can do much better if the quality of food is top on your list.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
We went a few times for dinner once by choice and company functions where we had little choice.  I like the ambiance and the location close to Union square.  The food was ok but certainly not up to the standard of a top restaurant.  
I think this place is good for large groups and for after dinner drinks/dessert in a sophisticated setting.
author: John P.

description:
I've been here several times.  The dishes are always great.  Service is rapidly going downhill which is unacceptable for this $$$ place.  I usually take visitors and business partners, and its just plain embarrassing when the waiter starts to take orders and keeps disappearing.  Then wine glasses get snatched as we are ordering wine, etc.  Lots of other issues with timing and interest in helping newbies.

Suffice it to say, the food remains consistent, but the experience would have been the same if we sat at the bar at Aqua - maybe even better....next time.
author: DaPlayer A.

description: Ah, Farallon! Went for the amazing Happy Hour but too crowded so got a table and ordered the superb Grand Platter of FRESH, cold Seafood. Lobster, Dungeness crab, shrimp, oysters, etc. Add a bottle of cold Prosecco. Endless fresh Acme bread and salted soft butter. We were in heaven. Came back second night for HH. Server (J) was attentive and friendly. $6 appetizers and good cocktails. Third night came back after canceling another restaurant's reservation and ate off bar menu. Everything first rate, including house manager, Parker, and winning woman server, (L), one of the finest we've ever had including those at French Laundry and Les Bernadine in NYC. Such wonderful dining experiences, three nights in a row. Can't imagine better seafood or service; these were the stars of the show. Didn't really focus on the room's ambiance. Price kept reasonable for us. We don't order course after course. If you do, expect a hefty tab.  For us: HH: under $50 (including drinks) bar menu: $75+ (including HH drinks); Grand Platter and bottle of Prosecco: $100 ( not including tax/tip). You like seafood? Go.
author: Robert H.

description:
3.5 stars

Good food, great atmosphere, sloow mediocre service. Insanely obnoxious couple behind us that were very loudly gushing over their waitress and tipping the kitchen, the sommelier, the manager, the coatcheck girl..... but that's not really Farallon's problem. Overall, a very nice seafood dinner with the boy.
author: Alex L.

description: We had never been here but sort of went by accident.  We were in the city to see a play, two doors away from Farallon and we luckily stopped in to get a quick bite before curtain time.  We were seated at the fresh seafood bar, so we watched the preparation of some GREAT seafood.  Lead chef Robert was working this prep area and was very willing to chat with us as he worked and supervised.  Each of the small dishes that we ordered from the happy hour menu were fantastic.  Six small oysters on the half-shell, for example:  $6.  Nice!  The woman who waited on us was very attentive and informative about the dishes.  This was a VERY wonderful experience.  We have relatives coming to visit, both of whom are foodies and we want to introduce them to this charming 'find'.  BTW, the play (at The Playhouse) was exceptional, as well!  After the play, we walked around Union Square, watched outside ice-skating on the outside rink....and felt like tourists, though we just live across The Bay.   What an evening.  Thank you Farallon.  Thank you, San Francisco.
author: Robert E.

description: I am a huge fan of their interior design and Coral Reef Chairs. The light fixtures remind me of jelly fish, and I love the bar. As for the Menu, a great deal is the Prixe Fixe menu. Have a drink during happy hour at the bar and have dinner in the dining room. Perfect for an early night out during the week.
author: Aimee G.

description:
I went there with my wife for our anniversary and here is my story :)
Atmosphere:
We had a reservation at 7:00pm for dinner, but they set us a bit earlier. Waitress was very nice, not too "in-our-face" neither "where-the-hell-are-you". It got a bit loud at some point but common, give a brake to businessman after half a bottle of wine :) Restaurant became full in a blink of an eye. By 8 I did not see open tables. 
We set in front of the kitchen where minimum six chefs at any given time were running around and creating their magic. See food bar had quite a selection of ocean creatures: lobsters, oysters, muscles and that is at least in few varieties of each. Platters that they make are to dye for... look wise:) amount of seafood wise - hm.... - lets just say that they looked Supper nice  What else would you expect from a very nice restaurant. He he  
Menu:
Menu, at the first glance, seemed to me too small and too expansive as well as the wine list seemed too long and even more expansive :) BUT: after few minutes looking around I got more comfortable with the atmosphere and accepted the fact that it is not a fast food restaurant. 

Food: 
Back to our table: my wife got their prefixed menu (3 courses) and I went with "KONA BLUE KAMPACHI TATAKI" for salad + "SEARED NEW ZEALAND TAI SNAPPER" main dish (recommendation of our waitress) 
Kampachi: that was my first time trying the dish - Loved it!!! Somen noodle salad was excellent with the fish.  Nice, clean, fresh taste of all ingredients. Nothing was blending or overpowering. Yum!!!
Snapper:  supper tender, excellently accompanied with coconut curry, without any fishy taste and with one hell of a crust!!! Bravo and compliments to the chef!!!
I have tried the halibut that my wife got: it had more of a home-cooking-like taste, which I would not like in such restaurant. It was okay when it was hot, but when it cooled down - fish got dry .... 
We also shared her dessert "BITTERSWEET CHOCOLATE CUSTARD CAKE Gianduja sauce, vanilla bean chantilly, hazelnut crunch" - yeah - too many words: it was very tasty. It was not too sweet but chocolaty enough to make a finishing point at it's highest.   
To finish all up:
At first it looked a bit small amount of food but I got out of table full, satisfied, happy and feeling glad that I chose this place.
Definitely would come back and definitely would recommend the place.
author: Alex S.

description:
I have been to hundreds of restaurants in the city over all the years. I had a business client come out, never tied it here so.. why not. Well, do not go. The portions were child size, price adult size. All our dishes were luke warm at best,, food bland,  and the waiter was not to be seen.
I will never return .I have been to rest homes with better food.
author: Jon m.

description: Farallon has truly unique, wonderful seafood dishes. It is a favorite of mine to share with family and friends when they come to visit in San Francisco. The decor is incredible and the presentation and taste of the dishes live up to their surroundings. If you are looking for a true San Francisco dining experience, Farallon is the place. Pricy, but worth every penny.
author: Christopher S.

description:
let me be simple about farallon
decor 5 stars
food 5 stars
sevice 5 stars
Constantly i keep thinking about farallon, and last sunday
was the 4th time that I was there in 2 years. We eat, drink and had fun 
and was memorable. I felt a little ackward in order filet in a seafood restaurant....I was wrong, I ate one of the best filet of my life. Couldnt finished cause was so big.. delicious delicious delicious The sound it is an underwater music very exotic, make you feel under the water.  Yes I ll comeback.
author: Alex M.

description: This is a simply outstanding place.  I've had the happy hour treats, which are great, but the dinner and dessert was outstanding.  This is my second time at Farallon, and I would go back every time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Anne P.

description: kinda like an E&O trading co type of place.  easy for business dinners.  separate private dining rooms in the attached hotel.  had spinach salad with the usual fruit, nut, cheese garnish, and a seabass with mushroom and peas, plus apple cake dessert.  one scale in the fish skin.  minus a star right there.  plus something gritty in the side mushrooms.  nice fresh ginger snap cookies.  just another kuleto restaurant, nothing special.
author: Rob C.

description: A pretty cool atmosphere, I recommend going in at least once.  Good service and good seafood menu.  I personally found it overpriced and the food took too long, would probably spend my money elsewhere unless taking out-of-towners or a first date.
author: Loralyn S.

description:
Wow, this IS as good as it gets!  Started with the Oysters on the half shell, with a perfect cocktail that went spectacularly with the brininess of the Oysters, this was at the bar, then promptly got seated upstairs where our waitress and the rest of the staff treated us like royalty.  The prefixe menu was absolutely magificent, it started with a trio of fish, the salmon melted on our tongues, the ceviche was absolutely perfect and the ono, which we had never had before was absolutely one of the best fishes we've ever had.  The second, a warm crab cake on top of a roasted heirloom tomato was just delicious, but the star of that course was the duck fat fried crouton, we could have eated a dozen of those!  The third, a perfectly cooked piece of seabass, nothing exotic, but miraculously, the cooks pulled off an outstanding dish and made the seabass the absolute star of that course.  The fourth, a med rare piece of steak, perfectly done, then before dessert, we were treated to a cheese course with a wonderful cheddar, a walnut bread, with baby grapes and almonds, then of course, dessert...wow..., a beautiful buttermilk strawberry shortcake, with an "over the top" chantilly cream.  All of the wine PERFECTLY matched each course, these guys really  know their food.   What can we say about the staff?  Friendly yet very professional, knowledgeable and unpretentious.  Answered all of our questions, stupid of not, without looking "down" on us for not knowing about wine regions in France.   We have found a new restaurant that we will frequent every time we go to San Francisco for a 
visit, maybe even bring our company christmas party to San Fran!  We will see you soon, Farallon, for SURE!
author: Steve J.

description:
