Splurge restaurant - very spendy but gorgeous restaurant, delightful menu and attentive service.

Decide on an event to celebrate and come to Farallon for a great experience.
author: Lm C.

description:
The first time I came here (pre-yelp) I was mesmerized by the scenery.  I was so distracted I dont think I paid any attention to the food.  All I remember was waking up the next day and feeling like crap.  So I of course blamed Farallon (not the 2 bottles of wine). Cest la vie I had thought, and all the better for my wallet.

Well, I went back this past weekend and now that I've lived in SF for 7 years, the scenery is barely noticable.  Jellyfish lamps you say?  There's crazy stuff in every restaurant!  But the food was TERRIFIC!  I truly enjoyed every morsel I ate.  The halibut in particular was soo buttery and perfectly prepared with a wonderful sauce and great little cherry tomatoes and some juicy garlicy spinach.  Yum!  It was so great after having such a bad experience at Aqua recently that I would gladly point anyone here rather than Aqua.

NOTE: Wine corkage: $25 BUT! If you bring your own bottle AND order another from them, they will drop the corkage fee! Hooray! Drink up!
author: Carol D.

description:
I've eaten at Farallon 4 or 5 times in the past year and am now morally obligated to now write a review and spread the culinary love.

Farallon pretty much has it all for those who enjoy fare of the oceanic (and fresh-water, I suppose) variety. I'm not going into a lengthy description of some of the dishes I've had the joy of sampling, but their menu changes perpetually - and they always update their website with the latest, so you'll never be disappointed due to a stifled expectation.  I've never had anything cooked to a point other than perfection and the chosen flavors force me to close my eyes with each bite.

The service is impeccable - all the waiters/waitresses seem to be completely proficient sommeliers as well - which is fortuitous since their winelist is the size of a small novel.

My only warning would be that this isn't exactly a "romantic" location - the atmosphere is entertaining and alive - but it's a bit noisy and full of movement - more like a power-lunch atmosphere than a cozy dine-in.
author: Don N.

description:
Very nice and unique decor.  

Good seafood.  The accompanying sauces and little sides stood out as much as the fish itself.  

Will not be an inexpensive dinner to take your time and enjoy yourself.
author: Elaine K.

description:
I used to live in the mid-west and I remember hearing about Farallon several years ago from my best friend, who had just had a wonderful trip to San Francisco with his new partner of the time.  He went on and on about this incredible restaurant and how it had been the highlight of their romantic evening.  I was envious and dreamed of a day I would be able to eat at great restaurants like that.
Fast forward several years and lo and behold, I ended up moving to the bay area.  I never forgot about Farallon and when the opportunity came for a special occasion dinner, I didn't hesitate to pick this place.  The time had come and I had waited years for this...YEARS I tell you!
Well, it was a magical evening, all around.  From the first moment I entered and took in all the wonderful under-sea decor, to the exemplary service, to every mouth-watering bite of each course, it had all been worth the wait and worth every penny (and yes, this place does cost a pretty penny).  No, this isn't a place I can come to every weekend, although I wish I could.  It's a special place for a special occasion, at least for most of us who still have to work for a living. But it fulfilled everything I consider important in a high-end restaurant; ambiance, food, service, location, cocktails, etc.  I have had the pleasure of eating here twice now and if I have my way, that number will continue to grow.
author: Paris B.

description: A solid 4 stars for the food, ambiance and service... Must love seafood. Great if you're eating clean.
author: David X.

description: My fiance and I were celebrating our anniversary in San Fran and our hotel was less than a block away from Farallon so we decided to give it a try (only after we read some other great reviews about it on Yelp ). All of the staff were really nice and welcoming. The restaurant has an underwater theme, with jellyfish hanging from the ceiling (but not in a tacky way). Our waiter was Javier who was awesome!!!! The portions are on the small side. The lobster and corn bisque was a must!!!! Fantastic!!!! Javier even brought us a small dessert (even though we said we didn't want any) for our anniversary.  We will definitely go back the next time we are in SF!
author: M S.

description: The food was not remarkable.  The place is stunningly gorgeous..in a very weird way.
author: Bleep S.

description: The Chocolate Malt Gateau is to die for! Probably the best dessert I've ever eaten. They're scallop parfait is also amazing and the butter takes the whole "bread and butter" concept to a whole new level. Waiters were extremely knowledgeable about the preparation of all the dishes and the atmosphere was great as well. I had the pike for my entree and although I thought the fish was great I wasn't a fan of the mushroom flan. Oysters were also great I wish I had gotten one of every kind! Overall, a great experience I just wish I had ordered a different entree.
author: Ashelen V.

description: The most unusual ceiling lights you can imagine. They look like Jellyfish lights but it works because thats San Francisco. I had the scallops on a seafood entree, very creative elegant presentation. Nice wine selection and everyone seemed to like everything. Expensive but a very nice dining experience.
author: Harold L.

description:
Love the room. Service was great. But only some of the food was as good as it should be for this price and with this reputation.

There were four of us so got to taste a lot of dishes. To my surprise, the star of the evening was the soft shell crab, something I don't think I'd ever order but one of my tablemates did. Presentation was great. Served on a coaster-sized duck crouton, stacked with a slice of broiled tomato, it was so perfectly crisped on the outside and delicately flavored on in the inside, it was a revelation. Too often, soft shell crab just tastes fried. This had great depth.

Little gems salad with smoked trout was very good but a really paltry portion (Waitress warns up front that portions are "petite," but c'mon, we're talking mostly lettuce here). My octopus appetizer was very nicely cooked, very tender and toasted pine nuts were a nice complement. Summer melon salad was just OK.

Main courses were a bit of a letdown. Halibut was in a pretty unexciting sauce. Both the accompanying shelling beans and squash were very bland. Fish was well cooked, but overall dish was a bore. Salmon was also ehh. The sweet corn ravioli on the side was richly flavored, but the apple smoked bacon just didn't go with the salmon. Maybe pancetta would have worked better, but those two tastes together just didn't work for me (even though bacon usually improves everything!). Friend's sturgeon kept up the trend. Nicely cooked fish in an environment that didn't take the dish to another level.

Seeming to find a lot of places these days where the appetizers outshine the entrees. Kitchen offered no specials on this night, which was disappointing. A seafood restaurant should always be finding something amazingly fresh every day to offer as a special. At these prices, I don't know how many times I'll be back to try again.
author: Michael M.

description: Nice atmosphere. Service was stellar. Food was ok, but nothing spectacular. I got the crab chowder which had an overabundance of green onions in it which made it not as awesome as the waiter was describing it. The meal was okay. I ordered some kind of fish in a light black bean sauce. It was definitely way too light of a sauce and watered down. I love the asian dish clams with black bean sauce, so the sauce here for the fish dish did not compare!
author: Helen V.

description: Farallon is a special place, a top notch experience from start to finish.  The décor is charming, the service was great, the food was excellent.  It's interesting to be in a restaurant with such unique décor and history.  Our waiter was professional and helpful.  He explained dishes, described wines, and was mindful that we were on our way to the theater.  Several servers brought our food in a timely manner, everyone in our party was served at the same time.  Classy.  The shellfish bisque was delicious, tasting of fresh briny seafood.  I ordered my steak medium, and it was perfectly cooked, moist pinkness on the inside and crispy crust on the outside, and it was melt-in-the-mouth tender.  Our dessert was chocolate tart with sassafras ice cream, a lovely melding of flavors and a real treat.  Although part of the kitchen is visible to the dining area, it is quiet and unobtrusive.  The chefs are focused on their work.  I believe that is the sign of a good restaurant, and the food quality reflected their dedication.  It is not an inexpensive restaurant but I think it's worth the splurge.
author: Cece W.

description: AMAZING ambiance. You are really paying for the scenery. It's beautiful. You'll spend about $200 on food and still be hungry though. Great staff, great servce, good food, but not plentiful. My ex took me here for Valentines and we had a great time, but we had to go to Jack in the Box after cause we were still hungry . Hahaha!
author: Lucky N.

description: We ate dinner at Farallon the night we arrived in San Fransisco and liked it so much we returned for dinner on the last night of our trip. We started with the assortment of heirloom tomatoes. They were fresh and sweet. The dressing was delicious. For entrees, we had the sole, which was absolutely devine, the ono which also was excellent and the stripped bass which was fantastic too. The baked alaska, berry pudding, and the bittersweet chocolate malt gateau were incredible! The atmosphere was lovely and it was not too noisy. The kitchen is visible and you can watch the staff preparing the food. The service was attentive.
author: Wendy J.

description: the best part of the whole farallon experience is the restaurant's website. It lulls you into a tranquil ocean-themed haze. Then you show up and they try to serve you baby cow and have only one vegetarian option. and that option is disgusting. and you go to work hungry. and then you're depressed. and then you turn to drugs. and 45 years later, you are homeless and are turning tricks to support your $100 a day coke habit (and that is a lot of tricks!) all because your mom took you here one time. I don't even know anymore.
author: mark s.

description: Thank you for introducing me to skate wing. I had no idea it could be so darn good! Like the worlds biggest scallop served perfectly seared. I went here with my 90 yo grandmother and the service was outstanding. She hates it when all of the waitstaff talk to me and ignore her as if I am her relay tower. At Farallon they always spoke directly with her and had the up most patience when she was having a hard time hearing. The decor is delightful and if you go there for the first time, take you time and look around. Some artist must have had a blast working on all of the installations
author: Cy W.

description: I've only eaten here a few times, partly because of prices but also because they do business with little regard for customer preference or request.  It's a real Jules Verne type place with great Pat Kuleto design touches which surely add to the sky high prices.  Quality is outstanding, service is good and atmosphere is beautiful and exciting, but somehow it just doesn't all come together for me.  My last visit was a party of four and after dinner, we all went to The Grubstake for something to fill the empty hole that the small portions left.  Maybe we ordered wrong, or appeared to be country bumpkins from a place the sun don't shine, but we left hungry and upset that we didn't want to give it five stars.
author: Stu S.

description: Three of us had dinner on a weeknight.  The service was good - no complaints there.  The food was okay but not spectacular.  I had had higher hopes.  The quality of the ingredients was excellent but the preparation and presentation were lacking...at least for the price.  Dessert was the best part of the meal.
author: Miranda K.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this place. I admit I wasn't expecting much because in general I'm not a big fan of their specialty (seafood). But, I had an amazingly tasty dinner there and the staff were just wonderful: attentive, personable, knowledgeable, and accommodating. The decor was pretty weird but it grew on me - big jelly fish chandeliers were the focus of the decor which I at first thought were a little cheesy but then the overall atmosphere grew on me and by the time I left I thought they were pretty cool (hopefully that wasn't just the wine speaking!). They also have a nice little bar which apparently has some good happy hour specials...I just might have to go check that out.
author: Amber P.

description: In my opinion, this is the best restaurant in the city. Maybe even my favorite restaurant. Spectacluar Food and service that is perfection. Wonderful drinks, oysters, appetizers, entrees, dessert. Everything here is just wonderful. I also love that every time I go here the menu is totally different, I am a creature of habit and when I go somewhere and find something I like, I keep ordering it, I love that Farallon keeps me branching out and trying new things. I have never been disappointed here, in fact, I have never not been amazed here. Also, THEY HAVE GREAT AGED RUM!!! That is fantastic. I go at least 4 or 5 times a year, I'm going at the end of this month for my birthday and we have the wine hold which is a private room. I can't wait!
author: Benjamin K.

description: If you're into great food & service, classy atmosphere and beautiful architecture, this is the place for you.  I love the soft-shell crab and their desserts have never disappointed.  It's a must try!
author: C M.

description: I was so excited to try this place considering the menu looked outstanding. We got there on time for our reservation and were seated immediately. Everything was downhill from there. Our waiter didn't really seem to know what he was doing, and he was so so so slow. Everything was slow. We ordered some caviar to try which was fine. Nothing mind blowing. Then we waited for 45 minutes for our first course which was 3 little shrimp. Three. Shrimp. Then after an hour and 45 mintues we hadn't received any more food and asked the waiter politely when we would receive our food. Now we sat right by the kitchen and saw lots happening, but no real food going out. It was a mess. You could even tell the wait staff was frustrated. We left. We put some money on the table to cover what we had eaten and we walked out. Nobody said a word to us either. I explained to the hostess what happened and she kind of shrugged it off. I was very upset and customers deserve so much more. I would have appreciated a phone call or a follow up email perhaps with an apology at least, but nothing. Needless to say we won't be returning and discourage people from trying it!!
author: Erin M.

description:
My mother and I came here on her first night in town visiting and it was really fantastic. We walked in and were immediately seated at the seafood bar, had prompt service and great recommendations from our server, Mike, and the food came out quickly and was absolutely deliciously. We ate the organic gems salad, sweet and succulent and for dinner I had the striped bass and my mom had the dorade. Both were great fish dishes, but I would highly recommend the striped bass.
We finished dinner with by sharing the chocolate gateau. It is to die for, but I would highly recommend sharing this dish because it is extremely  rich. I was also able to sample the pear sorbet which is creamy and you could really taste the natural pear flavor.
Superb dinner!
author: Erin S.

description: Super fresh seafood, great decor (picture Little Mermaid) and outstanding service.  The oysters are fantastic as is the dungeness crab.  Pricey but great for a special night out.  Fun to eat at the bar too.  I have never had a bad meal here although I always stick to the oysters and crab.
author: Jan C.

description:
The bf took me here for my fancy birthday dinner.  It's an interesting mix of people that were all dressy hoochied up like me, and people who are just going to have a casual expensive dinner.

According to our waiter that evening, the menu changes frequently, with a focus on what is fresh and seasonal.  We had the lobster "roll" for an appetizer, which was probably my favorite course of the evening - lobster on a brioche round with a ridiculous amount of melted clarified butter on the side.  I dream about that lobster brioche with a little saliva pooling at the corner of my mouth as I write this.  The squash apple soup was quite good, as was my filet and the bf's very fresh Thai snapper.  The side dishes and flavor pairings with the entrees are interesting and tasty, the Thai snapper coming with chorizo and creme fraiche, and my steak served with a delicious potato gratin (thinly mandolined potatoes meant lots of creamy layers) and foie gras, which I avoided completely but my boyfriend happily gobbled up.  Service is a little slow, but it's nice to have a relaxing dinner in a large booth without being continuously pestered, too.

Special note must be made of Farallon's exceptional bathroom lighting.  Forget the jellyfish lighting fixtures.   You go into that bathroom and you will never look better in your entire life.  Remember that video where Vanessa Williams was saving the best for last and you watched it and were like, damn, that bitch has some fantastic lighting?!  Preternatural beauty that she is aside, I wanted those little reflective light-y things in the pupils of my eyes, too.  The bathroom gives you those elusive pupil circle things as well as a soft golden glow.  Go in and you will find it hard to return to the harsh lighting of reality.  Only the lure of the remainder of the lobster roll was able to drag me away from my reflection.
author: Tanya N.

description: One star for decor that caught my attention for the first few minutes.  The food was BORING and so unmemorable.
author: Amber L.

description:
This is not a seafood restaurant. Its a restaurant that serves some seafood. Three entrees to be exact on the night I went. All fish. Could not order off the menu b/c per the server: "most of our shellfish is pre-cooked".

My wife wasn't interested in any of the three seafood entrees, so she ordered a crab cake appetizer, and a side. Easily one of the worst crab cakes I've ever had. I guess I'm spoiled by DC and MD crab cakes.

I convinced myself that I would enjoy the wreckfish and I did. Very well cooked. Not too dry and had the little bit of flavor you'd expect from an American seafood restaurant. Pretty ordinary as someone else said about their halibut. Except for how moist it was though seared on the outside.

Service was very good. Decor is fantastic, just wish they knew how to cook more than a couple seafood dishes. Even their oyster selection is limited though they did have the standards. Kumamoto, etc.

Before going, I'd check their menu (which they say changes frequently) and make sure there's something on there you'll like. If you're dropping $150 plus tip for two (including shellfish platter), you want to make sure its something you'll really like.
author: Akil C.

description:
This was a miserable experience from beginning to end.  I know this place received some very good reviews from other Yelpers, but my experience with Farallon was miserable.  The food was OK at best, but the service was horrible.  If I was at a fast food restaurant, this would be expected, but at an expensive restaurant where we dropped $200+ for dinner, you'd expect a little more.

To start, we ordered some oysters which were mediocre.  The presentation was nice.  Then the waitress, who was clearly miserable at her job, knocked over a full glass of very cold ice water right on my croch!...yes, my croch.  Needless to say, the sensation was a bit uncomfortable and I was completely soaked in a very uncomfortable area.  I got a couple "oops and sorry 'bout that" but that is all.  I had to ask for more napkins several times.  They didn't even offer to cover a round of drinks or maybe throw in coffee or anything.  They pretended like nothing happened.  Than, we ordered a wine tasting coarse where they poured 5 different wines and gave you a taste of each.  The glasses had so much lint on them it was disgusting.  You could choke on that much lint.  I'm not just saying a few pieces of lint, it was covered in lint that you had to shake it off.  We had to ask them to send them back and get us some glasses with less dust on them.  Overall this place was pretty bad and very expensive which is a deadly combination.  OK food, horrendous service, rude and inconsiderate wait staff, high prices....but other than that it was fantastic!!
author: V C.

description: The seafood was perfect.  Everything was.  I can't tell you what I ate because it was gone before I could memorize what it was.  I inhaled dinner and even went for their delicious desserts afterwards.  It was worth the five mile run I had to do to make up for the calories the next day.
author: Angelina J.

description:
this is a super foo foo restaurant.  went here on my birthday last month with the bf.  it was pretty snazzy inside.  the crowd seemed to be mostly those finance district suits...  yuppie style.  

it was a little too formal for my tastes.  I ordered the lobster.  the presentation was nice.  the lobster was DELICIOUS.  i could've ate 3 of them no problem.  it was served with a side of brocolli leaves?  they tasted bitter - awful.  

the decor was interesting - all oceanic and ish.  it was SUPER EXPENSIVE.  i don't think it was worth the price tho.  the service was good.  they even gave us some kind of drink on the house.  nice.

if i was a rich yuppie who worked downtown, i would probably like this place more.  hee hee.  but i'm just a simple girl... i'd rather go to Osha Thai.  that's fancy enough for me!
author: Hello.kitty.kat S.

description: The food was decent to pretty good, I thought it was a bit on the salty side.  The decor was beautiful.  It's not a 4 or 5 star because it's damn expensive and I can't justify coming here again.
author: CalBear H.

description: The food was excellent. Great oyster bar, perfect cod, great service. I tempered my stars b/c the interior looks like a psychedelic Disney ride. It's really gaudy for such a fine restaurant.
author: Lyly D.

description:
Farallon, named after the islands off the coast of San Francisco, is a premier, albeit expensive, dining destination for seafood lovers.  I parked south of Market Street and walked down Powell Street to get to the restaurant.  I immediately remembered why I generally avoid this street.  It is saturated with tourists, which attracts the freakshows.  I nearly got accosted by this scary-looking girl walking in the opposite direction.  Her mangled face was covered in piercings and chains, accompanied by a Fiona Apple "this world is bullsh*t" expression.  She sorta reminded me of that freak that appeared on the first episode of this season's American Idol (the one with glitter all over her face who shared a studio with her mom).  I merely glanced in her direction - she took immediate notice, stopped in her tracks and glared back at me, as if ready to start a fight.  I just pretended I was looking at something else and kept walking....faster.  As if I weren't already edgy enough, I had to keep dodging bums left and right, including one that yelled "BEEP BEEP!!!" as I crossed the street in front of him.  

Food:  4 stars.   Don't bother coming here for the $45 prix fixe menu, which is available before 6:30pm.  You don't get a choice and what they offer seemed unappealing (port poached red d'anjou pear, wild rice stuffed sonoma quail, and sticky toffee pudding) compared to the rest of the menu.  Be prepared, however, to pay through the roof for an a la carte meal (entrees are priced in the $30's).  For starters, we had the seared kona blue kampachi (very nice and hearty dish, accompanied by a tasty truffle potato raviolo, lambs lettuce and caramelized onion jus) and paprika braised octopus (nice texture and blended well with the garlic vinaigrette).   For main courses, my friend had the tasty seared hawaiian butterfish, cooked to perfection and garnished with Maine lobster relish and Meyer lemon brown butter (she had an upset stomach afterwards, but it was worth it - more on that later).  The fondant potato that accompanied it reminded me of eating a baked potato (skin and all), only slightly crunchier. I had the hearty roasted maryland striped bass, which had a subtle taste but combined well with the flavors from the butternut squash galette, wilted escarole and pinot noir gastrique.  For dessert, I was blown away by the warm pear butterscotch bread pudding with vanilla bean ice cream, almond butter crunch, and Maraska maraschino cherry syrup.  I couldn't get enough of the little bits of almond butter crunch.  My friend had the gateau royale (flourless chocolate cake, chocolate crisp, and milk chocolate mousse), which was a little too rich for my taste.

Service:  3 stars.   Service was a bit disappointing given the restaurant's caliber.  My friend arrived first and was already seated by the time I arrived.  When I checked in, the hostess told me that someone would be here shortly to take me to my table.  I waited 5-10 minutes, which seems like an eternity when you're hungry.  This is generally not an issue if the restaurant was busy, but the hostess could have gotten one of the idle servers to take me or she could have done it herself.  When we asked our server for recommendations, he made it a point to suggest not ordering the butterfish because it doesn't sit well with some people digestively (then why is it on the menu?).  When we told him that we've had butterfish before (at Roy's) and never had problems, he asked us if the restaurant actually called it butterfish because some people get it mixed up with walu (which we've also had before at Aqua).  At the time, I felt a little insulted because we mentioned to him that we had tried butterfish and felt like that message was falling on deaf ears.  Now I understand that he was trying to watch out for us because he's done some heavy research on the fish.  I guess it would have been better if he just gave us a minor disclaimer about the fish and let my friend order it without having serious reservations about it....  Plus it planted the seed in her head, which is why she probably felt sick later.  Additionally, the timing of the service was off.  Our first course was served before we even finished our amuse bouche, while there was a long lag between the appetizers and entrees.  The sommelier was kinda funny and endearing at least,  even mentioning at one point that he would hop on one foot for us if we asked him to.  

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  The grand decor, accented by the jellyfish chandeliers, kelp columns, and caviar-embossed stairways, epitomizes the seafood experience.  Given the high-priced menu and older look of the restaurant, I expected the clientele to be older.  I was not disappointed.

Hits:  Paprika braised octopus, seared hawaiian butterfish, warm pear butterscotch bread pudding.

Misses:  Gateau royale, inconsistent service.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Aqua, Nick's Cove
author: Keith C.

description:
The decor of the restaurant is what attracted me here in the first place, cuz the jellyfish lights and conch lamps were soooo cute! I want some of those fixtures in my house!

Service is good. I can only comment on happy hour in terms of the food. The truffled french fries are soooooooo goood! The crab cakes were just ok and really small. We also got the scallops that's supposed to come with the prix fixe but the chef allowed us to order it a la carte. It comes with a risotto. The scallops were really good but the risotto rice was undercooked and hard. The waiter claimed it was al dente but I know the difference between that and raw rice. Fortunately they took it off the bill, so overall, we were happy.

For such a beautiful 4 star restaurant though, I was hoping the food would be a bit better. Maybe regular dinner dining might be better?
author: Ellie Y.

description: On our first trip there ever, Farallon lived up to its reputation.  Thanks to another reviewer,  we sat in the pool room.  Incredible decor!  Some might think it's cheesy, hence the comments in the reviews.  We started with the Crab Gnochhi, then moved on to the Branzino and the Spearfish.  Everything was creative, fish was cooked perfectly, and our waiter was helpful and a little playful!  Just do it.... Beware of the $45 valet, though!
author: Mike M.

description: I ordered the braised beef and wasn't impressed.  I tried the steak and striped bass which were both better, but not as good as I'd expect from a restaurant of this caliber.  The atmosphere of the restaurant is magnificent, but not enough to come back for.
author: Lindsey M.

description: The food was great here although the waiter was kind of strange. He was kind but seems to be shouting all the time. I didn't like the raw oysters but my fish in light broth was DELICIOUS! I really enjoyed the presentation and the decor was very pretty. The chairs looked like sea snails and the ceiling lights are sea urchins.
author: Tiff W.

description: Ooh, glass jellyfish fixtures.  Ahh, cute waitstaff and cooks.  Eeh, delicious seafood.  Ohh, excellent service.  Mmhmm, I'm coming back.
author: M A N I K.

description: Farallon is a pretty cool place to go to dinner. Not the best meal in the city, but still a fun place. Decor is pretty cool and unique. Service could be better, but the place was packed. They have a pretty impressive wine list and the prices are pretty fair. This would be a good place to take an out of town guest. Very different feel then a lot of places in the city.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Five stars for ambiance - go here for the fantastic architecture, sculpture, and lighting. While the food is above average, this former Elk Lodge is an amazing, almost surreal underwater scene. Akin to an upscale fantastylike "Little Mermaid" backdrop - the jellyfish blown glass fixtures and Neptune shell shaped booths provide an out of the ordinary dining experience. 
The service was exceptional and the raw bar items were impeccably fresh. I enjoyed the fruits of the sea plate and the heart of romaine salad, but was disappointed with my main entree of pan seared striped bass. The fish was a bit over cooked and was under seasoned, but the hand cut paperdelle that accompanied the dish was delicious. The night was capped with a 12 yr aged tawny port, small endings cookie platter, and the cheese plate. All great. 
The wine list is extensive, so my only complaint was that there weren't enough middle of the road wines in terms of pricing.
author: Stacy T.

description: The only memorable thing about my meal was the check.   There are just too many great places to eat sea food in San Francisco for me to spend as much as I did.  Funny but no matter how much money I make, I guess I will never truly leave the 'class' that I was born in and love.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Tried this place on a whim while walking around Union Square & was tickled pink by the quirky but beautiful decor, service & fresh food. We tried some amazing cocktails to start with then some very reasonably priced & delicious California caviar, then moved onto a delicious butter lettuce salad, then had some yummy softshell crab & grilled octopus which was so delicious! The only part I wasn't crazy about was my main dish; branzino with a bacon hash, which sounded amazing but for my taste, was way too "bacon-ey"; I just thought it made the fish, which was simply seared & would have been great, but then the bacon hash made it too greasy for my palate. My husband loved it though so it was all good. The wine was amazing! My waitor recommended a delicious pinot noir to go with the fish & it was perfect. The dessert was probably the best part, I had panna cotta with what seemed like candied mango, so delish! Our friend tried this amazing Japanese style cheesecake, which was so light & airy it was unlike any cheesecake I've tried, so yummy! I'd definitely go back here, it seems like a great place to take parents or for special occasions. Great service too, everyone looked actually happy to be working there :)
author: Sara F.

description: This restaurant still be one of my 10 best choice for fine dining over the years since I started experiencing great ambience and food...food will always be creative ( so it really depends on ones perspective how you will appreciate creativity though food can be entaintaining) and be appreciated) but I  go for comfortable,friendly service, loungy setting for the top price they offer but to top it all it really depends on the the company you are with!!!
author: cecille p.

description: I just love BEING in this place, I don't know how they pulled it off to make you feel like you are somehow in the ocean. And, to have amazing food on top of it. Perfection. Truly. We got the Chef's tasting menu, I know that it was a specific number but we lost count and placement of where we were at because they kept bringing out more surprises. The seafood is amazing with such perfect combinations, lobster, crab, fish, caviar, oysters (I don't even eat oysters, I had two!). What else would you have if you lived in the ocean? We left here so full and blown away also with dessert that we could not possibly finish. They even popped in more surprises in the take away. The staff is attentive and so friendly from start to finish. I do wish they kept more Carneros Cuvee in house, we got the last bottle of the evening and that was the only hiccup. Not that I would take a star away for that, just sayin' I like good bubbles. I can't wait to go back, well worth it.
author: William R.

description: I'd give it five stars for my first visit, but my second drops it down to four.  The food is amazing, but I was disappointed in the service.  When I was with my parents, the service was excellent.  During the second visit (minus the parents, with the boyfriend at the time), they forgot the amuse bouche and service was slow.  However, the sommelier did pick out a nice glass of wine to go with the meal.  It's a fun place to go, but next time I'll have lower expectations.
author: Kate S.

description: Decor was probably the best thing about this place...lots of blown glass, great "under the sea" theme.  Shrimp cocktail app was nothing special, nor was the tuna dinner, it was pretty bland.  Apple crisp for dessert was average.  Another great thing about this place is the wine list.
author: Rita M.

description: Again, I do not "do a review" unless I've been at a restaurant at least 2 times. I think it's only fair that way.  Well, I've eaten at Farallon 8 times in 6 years, so this place never fails to deliver fresh, fantastic food (specifically seafood), beverage and service. The atmosphere and setting could not get much better...it's a perfect place for a romantic dinner, date and to wine and dine clients.
author: Al G.

description: My man and I wanted to enjoy delicious seafood one weekend. He made reservations at this restaurant and luckily we were staying at the Sir Francis Drake a block away, so it was a short walk. The wait staff was pleasant given the circumstances....they were packed in the front! Our hostess led us to the back of the restaurant, where it was quiet and decorated with old ceiling murals and oceanic lamps and fixtures. The whole place smelled so wonderful, not fishy, and I couldn't wait to eat some oysters. I can hardly remember what we ate because it was several months ago. I remember we uncorked some Dom Perignon that we brought with us and had the best seafood I've had in years. The service was wonderful. I'll be going back soon! You will absolutely enjoy!
author: Alyssa E.

description:
First of all, I have no idea what I was doing eating dinner at Farallon below the age of 50. The place seems to appeal to those who have rejected assisted living in favor of St. Regis condos. 

The decor is pure Vegas extravagance, from the stacks of crabs on ice displayed near the entrance to the sweeping upholstered booths and gigantic glass lamps shaped like sea urchin shells. Apparently the Romanesque sea-themed tile mosaic and arches in the rear dining room date back to the space's former use as the Elk's Club pool room. 

The food was good...perfectly cooked and fussily stacked. But service for our table of eight AMAZing. Our appetizers and entrees all arrived at the exact same moment, give or take .2 seconds. My wine was refilled after I took two sips. Our server was accessible and helpful but unobtrusive. I'm trying to remember the last time I was that impressed. It's been a while.
author: Debbie K.

description:
This was by far the worst place I have ever been to in my whole entire life. This place was even worst the hole in the walls in Chinatown. 

I came here yesterday for valentine's day. I had made reservations for 8:15 and did not get seated until 9:05. (What is the point to make rsvps if you are going to be seated almost an hour later) The great thing was that we were seated upstairs where is was a bit less noisy.

We had ordered the raw royal platter where the oysters were horrible, almost made me want to yhack. We also ordered the foie gras which was so so....maybe as good as boulevard.

We ordered the 5 course prix menu which was awful and took forever to eat. We had to wait a good 30-40 mins inbetween each course. Each course tasted like I poored a full salt shaker in my mouth. The best plate me had was the tuna tartare, but Aqua's is still 10 times better. 

Service was just horrible, we did not get our water refilled, or wine refilled. The table was left uncleaned throughout the night and our bread was never refilled. The waiters were really new to the place because they did not explain each course and did not know what they were doing. 

We did not leave the resturant until 1:15 or so. It took us 4 hours because the service was so slow to each 5 courses. At the Ritz Carlton I ate 13 courses and it only took us 3 1/2 - 4 hours. 

This is by far the worst place I have ever been to, and I will never come back. But I give it 1 star for the decor.
author: Gin L.

description: Went here for V Day dinner and it was great! Staff was, as expected, both knowledgeable and attentive. The king crab app was perfect as were both our meals. I thoroughly enjoyed my hand line caught ahi tuna with fresh gormet mushroom blend. The ambience/decor as made for a great meal. The back room (with view of the kitchen line) used to be an indoor pool which they built over!
author: Matty H.

description:
I really enjoyed the decor.  The jellyfish lamps and the mosiac ceiling in the dining room.  The building used to be the elk's club and has the pool underneath the dining room floor still.  I find the history of this space to be very cool.  

Well, on to the food.  I ate here a few years ago and I will forever remember it due to my first real upscale dining experience and my wonderful introduction to sweetbreads.  I was perusing the menu and saw a chicken dish that tickled my fancy.  The chicken was sitting on a bed of sweetbreads.  I thought to myself....hmmm, I don't know what sweetbreads are exactly, but must be some sort of bread, right?  So I get my dish and I'm happily eating the delicious chicken, when I notice the sweetbreads.  WTF???  This isn't bread.  This is some sort of strange textured brown looking poop thing.  I'm adventurous, so I try it.  Interesting texture, meaning, yuck!!!  I look around the table and ask, "what the heck are sweetbreads?"  My friends mom looks at me and says "cow brains".....again, WTF???  Why am I eating this shit?  Later, come to find out sweetbreads are either the thymus gland or pancreas gland of a baby animal.  Just writing this makes me want to try sweetbreads again, just to see if they were as disgusting as I remember or if my palette has matured enough in order to enjoy them.  I will keep you all posted.

p.s.  thank you Tamar's rich uncle for taking us here and getting us hammered off vino.  you be rad!
author: Christina S.

description:
positives:
waiters are very professional; food is delicious and the presentation is flawless; decoration is tacky but cute...overall ambience is very nice. definitely order from the oyster bar...quality is amazing.

negatives:
service was slow for me but that was kinda expected since i was there with my boyfriend (we're 19 and 20) and it's a really nice place; either park really far or give in to the valet. 

i would definitely go again. most likely on the boyfriend's dime since this place is reeeally expensive =]
author: Jessica Lei D.

description:
you walk in and you really are transported to an underwater world

[don't worry it isn't corny, it's tasteful and elegant, warm, inviting]

the food and service are top-notch as well, come here for a special occasion
author: Charles C.

description:
a little theme-y but it kinda works for them.  great seafood menu with plenty of selection.  tasty dessert menu as well.

if you're going to do a private event, consider coming here ... i checked out their private dining rooms and they're pretty impressive if you want to do something outside of a stuffy fancy dinner.  one small room is a little cheesy.  another small room is nicer but still intimate.  their largest room is pretty awesome.  total underwater theme, a little over the top, but definitely makes for great conversation.
author: spiff e.

description:
i loved it.
the waiter was awesome.
i asked what there was for a vegetarian and he just asked what i liked, any dislikes? and had the chef whip something up which was DELICIOUS. gnocchi (my fave!). cant go wrong with that in my book!

the dessert was huge (very important) and again, delicious.

i loved the decor. i thought it was really beautiful and not cheesy at all! 

then again, im not toooo tough to please: a gracious, helpful waiter, good food in generous portions and pretty surroundings with romantic mood lighting...how bad can it be? :)
author: Stephanie S.

description: Visually stunning inside, this place is worth at least one quick cocktail after work. But, really, you should stay for the food. Being this is a $$$$ restaurant, you'll need to budget accordingly. On my last visit, we had a group of about six, and what appeared to be a team of about 12 serving us, seamlessly. Somehow, someone is always at your beck and call, yet the staff is not in any way intrusive. Oh, and the monk fish was divine.
author: Anne P.

description:
This is a tough review for me to give since we were at a corporate event in a private dining room - but here goes.  The service we had was incredible, while we were not able to order off the full menu, we had a variety of selections and the waiters were great to offer their pick on both food and wine.  The crab dumplings were really great, at my table of 10 I think the majority of us ordered it and really liked it.  The halibut was pretty good too, perfectly cooked.  The fait accomplis was the bread pudding.  I must admit I was a little disappointed that despite the menu saying it would be served with vanilla ice cream (and it wasn't) - I still really enjoyed it.  Who knew a place known for its seafood could excel in a southern dessert?  
We ended up at the bar after the dinner for some cocktails so I was able to get a glimpse of the restaurant, the jellyfish lights hanging from the ceiling are really neat.  Based on other yelpers descriptions of the under the sea theme I kind of thought the decor would be a little tacky or over-the-top but surprisingly it is understated and really neat.  Thankfully I never saw the bill but heard the prices are pretty steep so this might be a business expense only kind of place or a special occasion.
author: Katie P.

description: YEARS ago, I saw this place featured on the Food Network or something like that, and thought, I HAVE to come here. Well, when I finally made it to SF, we walked by it and went inside for a late meal. I knew it would be good, but it definitely exceeded my expectations. I kept wanting more, and by the end of it all I think I dropped about $150 for the two of us. Our server was excellent, and I didn't get a pretentious feel about this place whatsoever. I'm a fan of the decor, but then again, I'm easily amused...
author: Sarah B.

description:
Imagine the song below as a restaurant, and you'll get the fantastically over-the-top and gaudy restaurant known as Farallon:

The seaweed is always greener
In somebody else's lake
You dream about going up there
But that is a big mistake
Just look at the world around you
Right here on the ocean floor
Such wonderful things surround you
What more is you lookin' for?

Under the sea
Under the sea
Darling it's better
Down where it's wetter
Take it from me
Up on the shore they work all day
Out in the sun they slave away
While we devotin'
Full time to floatin'
Under the sea

Down here all the fish is happy
As off through the waves they roll
The fish on the land ain't happy
They sad 'cause they in their bowl
But fish in the bowl is lucky
They in for a worser fate
One day when the boss get hungry
Guess who's gon' be on the plate

Under the sea
Under the sea
Nobody beat us
Fry us and eat us
In fricassee
We what the land folks loves to cook
Under the sea we off the hook
We got no troubles
Life is the bubbles
Under the sea
Under the sea
Since life is sweet here
We got the beat here
Naturally
Even the sturgeon an' the ray
They get the urge 'n' start to play
We got the spirit
You got to hear it
Under the sea

The newt play the flute
The carp play the harp
The plaice play the bass
And they soundin' sharp
The bass play the brass
The chub play the tub
The fluke is the duke of soul
(Yeah)
The ray he can play
The lings on the strings
The trout rockin' out
The blackfish she sings
The smelt and the sprat
They know where it's at
An' oh that blowfish blow

Under the sea
Under the sea
When the sardine
Begin the beguine
It's music to me
What do they got? A lot of sand
We got a hot crustacean band
Each little clam here
know how to jam here
Under the sea
Each little slug here
Cuttin' a rug here
Under the sea
Each little snail here
Know how to wail here
That's why it's hotter
Under the water
Ya we in luck here
Down in the muck here
Under the sea
author: Chanpory R.

description: I agreed with Laurel L.  We were turned off by the rude hostess.  No smile on her face and when I asked if we could move to the booth, she scowled at me and abruptly said it's not her decision.  She then came back and told us bluntly that there was only one booth, take it or leave it.  So we took that and it was our worst decision ever made.  I am only 5'8'' and I could not stretch my leg during my entire meal.  This table was ridiculously small and tight.  It's really unfortunate that the hostess turned us off that bad.  The ambiance was great; the waiter was highly knowledge and service was outstanding.  The seafood was great too but unfortunately we ordered a duck entree that was a huge disappointment.  The duck was tasteless and the combination with sausage was very odd.  We dined on March 24 so if restaurant management read this review, I hope that they will take note of this scary hostess.
author: Fong K.

description: My expectations were high for great food.  Everyone at the table ordered something different to share.  The serving plates were cold and the food was served warm.  The service was good.  I did like tasting the large range of seafood.
author: pamela m.

description: The solid reputation of this restaurant preceded itself, but did not live up to our expectations.  We were initially seated at a small table adjacent to the kitchen which got a bit noisy as much of the staff hung out around the area.  This irritated me a little at first, especially since there were many open small booths that were much more private and intimate which is what we were looking for.  Normally, I'll acquiesce to the determination of the host/hostess of where my party should be seated, but this time I requested of our attentive waiter that we be moved to one of the more intimate booths which was a good decision.  The decor and ambiance throughout the restaurant were appealing and unique with its custom jellyfish chandeliers.  It is definitely a nice date spot if the food were better.  The trouble we both had with the food throughout the entire meal, appetizers through dessert, was that the flavors were either overwhelming or did not have the right balance.  (Although, there may have already been a slight bit of bitterness in my mouth due to the fact that I was missing out on Super Bowl XLII.  J/K!)
author: Erich D.

description: I first ate at Farallon when I was dating a staff member.  I was instantaneously stunned by the undersea theme.  The restaraunt was once an underground, indoor swimming pool.  One almost feels like a sea urchin in an enchanted underwater landscape.  However, I would have liked the menu to be less complicated, contrasting the intricate decor.  Dishes seemed to have more layers than urchins have bumps.  You must go at least once, for the experience.
author: Amme P.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by Farallon.  If you've read any of my reviews before, you know I'm not a seafood fan by any means, and in fact, I'm such a carnivore--it's ridiculous!  I did, however, quite enjoy my dining experience at Farallon.  My boyfriend and I met his friend and his friend's parents for dinner at 5:45pm.  They were seated though the entire party had arrived...I like that cause I hate to keep the entire party waiting when we're late.  

The ambiance was sweet.  As you enter their jelly fish floating from the ceiling, a seafood bar with fresh crabs, clams and other shellfish, and lovely, welcoming hostesses (which by the way had my boyfriend in all a twitter...all tongue tied when he told them we had reservations).  We sit in one of the booths that appears to have a clam or oyster motif.  The seat is plush and comfy.  

I checked out the menu beforehand, and knew that between my boyfriend and I we'd get the steak and the ahi tuna.  The other fish such as the halibut seemed very interesting though.  For an appetizer by boyfriend and I split the seared Mediterranean rouget, which our waiter had the kitchen split on two plates.  The rouget fish is apparently a small red fish that gets its color and taste from all the shellfish it eats.  (Our very knowledgeable water told me this.)  I enjoyed the buttery texture of the fish fillet, the simple taste of the zucchini blossom and the zestiness of the Himalyan red rice (or did the zestiness come from the sauces that were drizzled on top of the fish?...hard to tell because I make perfect bites of the everything on my plate).  The ahi tuna I ordered as an entree was only okay as it wasn't seasoned enough and the olive topping was too strong of a flavor that I soon became to dislike. I enjoyed the baby arugula salad for its simple vinaigrette dressing was a nice addition to my palate.  The fillet of beef was nice (glad my boyfriend gave me half)--tender and well seasoned...though it came w/ a shrimp paste that I wasn't crazy about.  

By this point in the meal, I was stuffed, but we had time to kill before our movie, and who am I kidding I can't resist dessert and coffee!  I could have been fine with sharing, but no one wanted to share the summer berry pudding with me.  I was very pleasantly surprised by it as it appeared as a bread pudding, which I adore!  The drizzle of raspberry sauce, fresh berries atop, and the scoop of vanilla ice cream made it a dream--perfect combination of tastes.  With my coffee to accompany it, I nearly ate the entire thing, forgetting how stuffed I was even prior to dessert.  

Service was excellent.  Water glasses always filled, wait staff checked up on us frequently, fresh bread served twice during the meal, knowledgeable of the menu, and overall quite friendly.

I left the restaurant three pounds heavier; my pants closures almost busting!  Again, I'm not a seafood fan, but with good fish done right (and desserts and wine too), I could be...or maybe it was just Farallon.
author: Marie B.

description: Extragavant and high class seafood restaurant with an amazing Atlantis-like decor. The food is delicious. Makes for a great romantic night out or a fancy dinner with your vacationing friends.
author: Ross W.

description: Walking into Farallon I felt like I was entering an underwater kids theme restaurant and I wasn't sure what to expect next. Luckily, I was pleasantly surprised. Farallon is one of the very few restaurants that I have been to where every ingredient on the plate enhanced the dish exponentially. When sampling each part of the dish individually, each was good; but when taking a little bit of all the ingredients on my fork at once, the flavor combinations were triumphant. It was one of the most memorable dishes I've had.
author: Silly H.

description: Each December, my sisters and mother meet in SF for shopping, eating and laughing!  This time we ate at this restaurant and all of us loved it! It's right around the corner from the St. Francis Hotel at Union Square...it is the BOMB! Delicious.  The ambiance, the service, the food...it's simply one of the finest restaurants.  Will I go back...you betcha...I may even fly up just for the Seafood Platter!  Out of this world.  Try it...you'll love it!
author: gail s.

description: Take the plunge! Then do it again, and again. For a restaurant experience Farallon has almost everything... Awesome bar, wonderful seafood, meat prepared to the tops, involving design, excellent service. The wine vault off the main diningroom is a beautiful ship! The cast jellyfish and sea urchins are stunning. The three banquet rooms are jewel boxes. Praise the whole team, Franz, Kuleto, Luchetti! Bon Voyage!
author: Ian M.

description:
I love the under-the-sea disneyland-like decor!! =) 

I had the seared Australian barramundi and it was one of the best fish dishes that I've had. (The waitress warned me that the fish comes with the head and tail, haha, doesn't bother me cuz I'm Asian!) The meat is buttery (steamed? baked?) and the seared skin is crispy.. it was the perfect combination, mmMMmm. 

I'm definitely coming back here for more seafood!
author: Carrie F.

description: This place was excellent.  The ambiance was great and the service was excellent.  The valet service was great and while we arrived a half hour early for our reservation, we were seated almost immediately.  Our orders were taken as soon as we sat down and there was hardly any wait for food or drinks.  The fish we had was some of the freshest I've ever eaten, and that to me completely justifies the price on it's own.  We had the shrimp and scallop shu mai for an appetizer, and had the striped bass and halibut for the entrees.  The only thing I must say is that the bass had a little more of a smokey flavor than I prefer, however no one else at the table that sampled the dish had any complaints.  The dessert with the caramel flan and caramelized sugar/chocolate chip topping was delicious as well.  We'll definitely be going back to sample the rest of the menu.
author: Stacia M.

description: Great atmosphere and top notch service!  They do something with the butter that is just has amazing flavor.   It is definitea romantic place to dine.
author: michelle r.

description: I'm only reviewing the bar for happy hour, and one drink in particular.  If you come for anything, come during happy hour and order the Hemingway.  Nuff said.
author: Todd C.

description: Very tasty dishes for the steep prices. The service is pretty spot-on but a bit dry and lacking in personality. Nice atmosphere.
author: K F.

description: The Farallon has a beautiful atmoshpere.  My husband and I ordered a dozen oysters to start off with.  We tried a a few from each region.  Every oyster was delicious.  We then had scallops which was topped off with foie gras and this was excellent.  The scallops were cooked to perfection and the foie gras was delicious.  I ordered the hallibut which was very well seasoned and cooked very well.  My husband ordered the rabbit sausage which unfortunately was not as great as the rest of the meal; however, this restuarant is worth another trip.  The service was good and the food all in all was excellent.
author: CHERRYL H.

description: I had a great meal at this restaurant. Great service, very well priced wine list and delicious food. The scallops were not a hit but everything else was excellent. I recommend the plateau de fruits de mer to start. The chicken is actually amazing ( I know, who orders chicken in a seafood restaurant? But it was recommended and just delicious ). I am a fan and I will come back !
author: Chris A.

description: This place is all hype.  I mean, don't get me wrong here.  The food is great but not for the price and it definitely doesn't deserve the reputation it has.    The only reason I'd ever go back would be for the decor.  If I were doing ratings on decor - I'd give it a five.
author: Cyan C.

description: Boy were we ever disappointed. The WORST service. And the food? Honestly, nothing to write home about. If you're going to blow your cash somewhere, there are so many better places to do it. In a town with options like Gary Danko there's no reason to have this place on your list. And if you're looking for great seafood, you'd be happier at Yabbies. Seriously. Ugh. What a shame when you're really looking forward to a meal and spend a lot of mullah, all to have to wash away your sorrows with cocktails at Swig afterwards. blech.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Farallon delivers a truly unique dining experience; they treat you like a king, and complement their exemplary service with excellent seafood dishes and a memorable dining atmosphere.

I went to Farallon about two years ago for a birthday.  The hostess held a few gifts I had brought in beforehand, and delivered them at the right time.  This was the first of many very memorable interactions with the staff.  The food was incredible; I had the Ono and was able to steal a taste of the Halibut.  

What really stood out about our dinner was Farallon's top-rate Sommelier.  Even though this experience was years ago, our Sommelier's attention to detail and impeccable customer service is still memorable today.  I brought in a few bottles of special wine for a birthday party; we started with Krug and then went to a Havens Albarino that a friend had given me.  As we were enjoying our wine, the Sommelier brought out a few tastes of a Spanish Albarino from Rias Biaxas (where most Albarinos are from, as that is the original locale of the grape), and described how each Albarino was different, and how they would go well with our different dishes.  Now I've seen good Sommeliers before, but an on-the-fly complement to two whitefish dishes, with a unique varietal nonetheless, was remarkable.  Not an impossible task for a stellar Sommelier, but taking the time to really think about your clientele with that level of detail is the mark of a true professional.

We ordered a taste of Chateau d'Yquem to finish off the night.  Given the hefty price tag for a two ounce taste ($50...which is reasonable for a good year of d'Yquem), we decided to split it two ways.  He arrives with two generous "tastes" clearly surpassing two ounces each.  Sure it cost Farallon a few bucks to do this, but the end result of creating a story I'm still telling years later makes the small cost more than worth it, and will be "accretive" for Farallon in the long run.


P.S.  Why doesn't Yelp's spell checker have "Sommelier" in the dictionary?  Are you guys serious?
author: Nate H.

description: Went here last New Years with the GF. Ate a $120 seafood platter all by myself. Beautiful place with great decor. HIghly recommended for seafood, but be prepare to cough up some green.
author: John Z.

description:
yick.  i was planning to take the bf here for his annual birthday dinner (we always go seafood, since that's his favorite) but i am *so* glad i tested it out with a friend first before deciding!  

absolutely not worth the price AT ALL.  while i admit the decor was quite interesting, the place was pretty noisy and didn't impart that calming effect implied by the photos on the website.  my friend (a major foodie, he was visiting from manhattan) and i were not impressed with our entrees, my fish was very dry and flavorless.  service was good, but for a restaurant that tries to compare itself with aqua, the food needs to be up to snuff as well.
author: Vicki Y.

description:
Six years ago Farallon was one of the very first "nice" restaurants I ate at in the city. I really loved it and was excited to go back last Tuesday. The restaurant itself is gorgeous, I love the mosaic tile ceiling. We had a concert to go to so we only had time to get apps and desserts. We told our waiter and he was totally nice about it. Sometimes you get a little attitude when you tell staff something like that but ours was super nice about it and made some excellent recommendations to help us save time. Lou, our waiter even gave us updates on what time it was. He totally rocked! One of the best waiters I've ever had. We got two shellfish bisques and the butter roasted lobster with english pea ravioli and fennel to share. The soup was good and came with a cognac cream. The only thing I didn't like about the soup was that the cognac was really strong in the cream (that might just be me though as I tend to really be able to taste alcohol) and the soup really tasted like shellfish. Like the actual shell on the fish. I still finished it though. The butter roasted lobster was amazing. The lobster was really good and pretty tender and my favorite part of the dish was the english pea ravioli. SO good. The pasta tasted really fresh and didn't have any of that gummy taste you often find in pasta. Delicious!
I was SUPER excited to try the desserts here. We got the garnet cherry cheesecake and I was ecstatic to find that they had fried banana cream pies. I love fried bananas and I love banana cream pie, sign me up! Both desserts were really good. I particularly liked the pistachio tuile on the cheesecake. The fried banana cream pies were heavenly, with a delicious dulce de leche and an el rey chocolate sauce. The desserts were definitely the best part of the meal. Overall a really good dining experience.
author: Cathy T.

description: Go once for the blown glass. Make sure to check out the piece I made.
author: Scott B.

description: Farallon is one of the better fine dining options just off Union Square.  I've walked by it for years while in SF on business and staying in hotels nearby.  I'd stopped by for a drink, but this was my first meal there.  I'm sorry I'd waited so long.  While the decor in the bar area up front feels a little bit like the entrance to a Disney undersea ride, it opens up into a elegant dining room in the back with large, vaulted ceilings.  My salad with beets to start was very nice, though a little on the small side.  My salmon entree was excellent.  Their wine list was expansive and expensive - I hate it when nice restaurants gouge you on wine.  My boss, who was dining with us, thumbed his nose at the somalier (and shredded his local wine credibility in the process) by ordering a bottle of red from Long Island.  As in Long Island, NY.  Frankly, it wasn't very good and I'm surprised they had it on the list.  Anyway, on to dessert - my sour cherry sundae was off the charts good.  All-in-all a very good meal - the biggest points off were for the wine experience.
author: Ryan W.

description: I really wanted to like this place, especially since it's decor is so cool! But I must say I was less than impressed. My fish en tree came out overcooked and everything else was just alright. Another thing I noticed was the age demographic of the restaurant. I'm not if it was because it was a weeknight, but everyone was OLD. I would never hold that against a restaurant except for the fact that I felt like this restaurant reminded me of those tacky "nice" restaurants in Fremont like Papillion and Massimo's. I did not come all the way  to city for this!
author: Hoiling W.

description: Quite frankly nowhere else anywhere is able to cook fish as magnificently at this place.  Yes it is extremely pricey and their wine list could use some work, but this place never fails to satisfy all the senses.
author: Sarah K.

description: First off, the decor of this place is absolutely amazing.  I have to say that it is probably one of the most nicely decorated places I have gone to for a meal.  Unfortunately, the food was at most mediocre and average.  For the amount you would pay at this place, you could defintiely get better seafood somewhere else in the city.  I would defintiely say that this is a place you paying for the ambience and not the food.
author: Charles C.

description: This place is very nice, very good customer service, very very good food. If you are looking to take your partner for a nice restaurant i recommend  it. You pay for what you get, every penny we spent was worth it, it was our first time there and we are planning to come back.
author: jorge c.

description: The Farallon is alright. The food wasn't really as great as all the hype...but the decor was beautiful in here. As for being considered a "romantic" place I think not.
author: Valerie F.

description: My wife and I just got into town from NY and we made a reservation here is this was close to our hotel. What an awesome suprise. The decor is was amazing and we sat on the rail right at the kitchen to watch the well oiled machine put out beautiful dishes one after the other without a stutter step. No yelling, no rushed atmosphere. Service was excellent as well. We enjoyed the tasting menu along with the pared wine selections all done to perfection. We would highly recommend this stop and would visit again so sure.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Originally a strikingly theatrical restaurant with superb service and an innovative, stimulating menu, Farallon is aging badly.  The interior is visibly shabby and not in a chic way (the upholstery is fraying!  For those prices, I want my banquette to look better than the dog's couch at home, you know?) and the food is coasting.  I notice that other reviewers have remarked on irregular service; yet the serious problem here is the inconsistent kitchen.  Overcooked fish is a sin, especially at these prices, and dishes ordered together should be delivered together so you and your friends can eat together, which is why you're there, sharing a meal, and yet Farallon is not managing to do these things well.  The management isn't managing; the wait staff are out of their depth, and the kitchen is not under control.  You shouldn't have to pay for past glories; you're buying a meal today.  

The bar's still great though!  So start with drinks here, worship the tentacled ambience, and eat elsewhere.  Leave Farallon to the easily-impressed tourists.
author: Ego S.

description: I used to be in the restaurant business, and have worked in numerous establishments both in the U.S and abroad. I have to say I was completely blown away with my experience at Farallon. The staff were gracious, skilled and professional (and kind enough to give us the best table in the house). The food was exquisite, and the bread man was funny and fun. I've never had a dining experience quite like it, and overall, I found the prices to be quite reasonable considering the quality of the entire experience. Eating at Farallon is like experiencing a great work of art. I will definitely be going back again.
author: josie b.

description:
My husband and me used to consider Farallon one of our favorite restaraunts.  Unfortunately, we changed our minds last night.  The service was really bad for this type of restaraunt.  The waitress was either interrupting our conversations or joining them in an intrusive manner at the beginning of our meal, and by the end was ignoring us, and forgot to offer two of us dessert or coffee (which we had requested in advance).   Our plates were swept away half eaten.  The bisque soup last night was fantastic, but the other special, a stuffed lobster, was so heavy on the potatos that you couldn't find the lobster or even taste it.  All in all a disappointing evening with a bill of $500 for three folks.  Too bad.  In this economy fine dining should be on it's toes.  

There was also a wailiing baby in the restaraunt which didn't help with ambiance.
author: Ginny P.

description:
Once again, I used my parents so that I could eat at a restaurant I otherwise couldn't afford...that's not so bad is it?  
Regardless, this place lived up to its expectations.  Service, food, decor, all of it was top notch.  I'm sorry others who've reviewed feel it was less than stellar however my experience was excellent.  
The sommelier was right on point with his recommendations and considering two of us ordered fish and one person went with the duck, the wine he chose fit in very well with array of dishes.
While its a fancy place, there really is nowhere (ok, except that Danko place) where you can't get away with wearing a nicer pair of jeans.  
If possible, request to sit upstairs and be ready for a hefty check at the end of the night.
author: Mike F.

description: This is one of my absolute favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I absolutely love the decor - the beautiful blues and greens and the jellyfish  make me feel like I'm under the sea. It's expensive but worth it for a special occasion - I even sat a few tables away from George Lucas once!
author: Lindsey S.

description:
the decor is really fanciful and almost an adult version of a childlike dream.  there are different kinds of sea creatures hanging over you.

i came here for lunch - good way to try out pricey places for less.
with dinner entrees starting at $35 plus, not a bad suggestion.

i recommend the scallops and seared foie gras.  yummy but cha-ching!  expensivo.  they have a good selection of oysters and cheese.  i think i can just live on that every day.

the menu is a seafood smogasbord.  hopefully, you are there on a business account because the bill might give you heartburn.
author: Anh V.

description: Not good. A total disappointment. My crab was dry. they dont even carry Grey Goose Vodka.  The soup was very salty. The desert was a sugar donut. with jam on the side and some horrible cream. The service was fine. the table way too small. It is a tourist trap. We spent over 200 dollars and went back to the hotel and had something from the mini bar. Really. Next time i am trying Gary Dankos or Boulevard, I had heard alot about Farallon and being a Native San Franciscan i felt compelled to give it a go. Dont go. Plenty of other places that are far better!
author: Donna S.

description:
I had dinner at Farallon last night and was just not at all impressed with the food. I tried the heirloom tomato tasting menu. Now, I love a heirloom tomato and I love me some seafood, but this was not that special. The service was good. The wine selection was good. The food...not so much. One dish was under-seasoned, one was heavy on the oregano. The sauce on another dish tasted like undiluted Campbell's tomato soup. Just really uninspired. 

The restaurant was busy, but it seemed like it was mostly tourists. I wonder how long this place would stay in business if not for those tourists. There are so many better restaurants in the city - for the money, I would go elsewhere.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Decor was really cool and out there!! Food was great well worth the price, service was very good.
author: Tom S.

description: I recommended Farallon to my friend the other day.  At the time, I couldn't think of the name, even if my life depended on it.  Somehow, I was able to describe the whole under-the-sea, little mermaid theme ambiance to her.  What stood out to me about Farallon is their take on seafood.  I remember trying whole fish baked in salt.  It was so simple yet so different.  They told me it was their special and they only make 15/night.
author: Jen L.

description: completely over hyped. Terrible restaurant experience. Rude arrogant staff. Almost motivated me to write a formal complaint. Extremely over priced. You are paying for the decor and nothing more. Farallon does have nice decor, and the look of the restaurant is worth seeing. Maybe stop by for a drink, but avoid shelling out $300 for a proper dinner, go somewhere better. Asia de Cuba is also just as expensive, but at least their food is delicious.
author: Fadi M.

description: I've eaten here a couple of times in the last 5 years and it has always been good.  My recent experience wasn't so good.  Our seafood dishes were soggy and served with too much broth.  I'm afraid that the yelp reviews are overrated.
author: Jase P.

description: Great bar, romantic setting.  Almost made me feel like the little mermaid under the sea.  I was disturbed by the high prices and food that did not deliver and match up.  Disappointing for me.  I would go back for drinks and appetizers -- no more, no less.
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
me and a coupla friends treated a close girlfriend to a bday dinner at farallon ages ago. the decor of blown glass sea creatures hanging from the ceiling was stunning. we were seated in a cozy booth where we had a view of the kitchen. the food was tasty and we were comped a coupla appetizers (always nice!). we all enjoyed our entrees and desserts, including some yummy tawny port. absolutely no complaints.

i think the final tab ran about 90 bucks each (excluding bday girl of course).

i'd say the attire is on the dressier side, but all of us were dressed relatively casual after a day of traipsing about the city (no heels or other uncomfortable footwear). but i don't think there's a place in the bay area that strictly enforces a dress code, at least i haven't been there.
author: AlfiHatesFlea S.

description: I've been wanting to come here for awhile and I finally got the opportunity to do so a couple of nights ago, before seeing Clybourne Park. I am so happy to report that this place absolutely did not disappoint. When we fist arrived, were seated immediately (which I love). When we sat down, we were able to take in all the beautiful decor. The restaurant is wonderfully circular shaped, which makes for a unique and surprisingly serene experience. Our very learned and attentive waiter suggested a wonderful Rose, that complimented everything we ate, with perfection. We started off with a smoked salmon moose amuse bouche and from that first bite, everything was a glorious adventure. For our first course, we ordered the calamari and the ahi tuna. Both were amazing and left me wanting more. For the main course, we had the scallops-- were honestly the best scallops I have ever had, and the striped sea bass--which was served with purple potatoes (I love anything purple!) and left me with a big smile on my face. Usually I am not a dessert person, but because the portions are rather small, and the desert items were raved about in other posts, we decided to give one a try. As our waiter had done such a wonderful job with his previous selections for our meal, we asked him for his recommendation. He told us to go with the grapefruit and rhubarb pie with white chocolate ice cream on the side. He explained that he did not like grapefruit OR rhubarb in general, but that they all married together and went with our wine perfectly. I felt that his distaste for grapefruit alone was reason enough to trust his choice and I am SO glad we did. The dessert was phenomenal...and the white chocolate ice-cream; let's just say I will still be dreaming about that tonight!
author: Tiauna G.

description:
Two friends took me to Farallon for my birthday. What a huge disappointment.  The service was TERRIBLE, and the food was not much better.  For the very large amount of money we spent, this place should have been off the charts in every way.

We went on a weekday night, and I think we might have been the only women in the place.  The entire resaturant was filled with large tables of guys in business suits.  I felt like we were at a convention.  We barely ever saw our server the whole night.  I think we were well into our third round of small plates before we got any wine.  We had to ask three times for some Pellegrino.  The special, a steelhead ceviche, was so fishy, it was almost rank.  We had to send it back because none of us could stand to eat it.  The crab bakes were deep-fried balls that could have come from Long John Silvers.  The single scallop that you get when you order the scallop dish was cold and sitting on a pool of sauce that tasted like pure congac--it was horrible. They did manage to remember to bring us our coffee, but not until after the bill had been paid.  To top it all off, they gave my friend a hard time about getting her coat because she'd left her coat-check thing at the table.  I don't recommend this place to anyone--there are so many other seafood places in San Francisco that are SO much better.
author: erin r.

description: So far, if I had to one last meal...it would be at Farallon.  The service is as good as it gets, the food is flawless.  Yes, it is expensive; yes, it is over-the-top...and YES it is among my favorite restaurants in the world.  Drop a buck or two and see how kings eat.  FIVE STARS!
author: Josh T.

description: I was here with my husband for my birthday in Feb.  The restaurant is beautiful!  It looks like you're under the sea!  The Sommelier brought us our wine and then after some back and forth, we found out it was his birthday, too!  Same year, even!  The wine was great, the food delicious, and then the Sommelier sent over a cheese plate to end our evening on such a high note.  If we lived in the Bay Area, we would spend all our celebratory meals here.  Love this place!
author: Robin A.

description: Unique decor, great service, but the quality of the food for the price is way out of whack. My mother had one scallop (1) that cost $17 and a salad with literally 4 pieces of lettuce for $15. I had artic char that was very marginal for about $35. I'd say only go to this place if you are craving fresh oysters.
author: Mike C.

description: I don't understand what the hype is about this place. I went 2-3 years ago, one time with my boyfriend. Just to give you a taste, I am a true restaurant lover and love trying new things but this place just didn't do it. It was by far the worst experience in a fine dining restaurant to date. We were sat in a hole in the wall area near the kitchen doors. The place is dim but when I looked up into the light, I basically saw what appeared to be fruit flies flying around above our table.
